DOC.HEAD: House Approves $268 Billion Military Spending Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4th graf: ``The Senate,'' unable to finish debate. Stads for AMs
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a military spending bill Thursday that slashes President Bush's 1991 budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative but adopts the Pentagon's plan for a high-tech fighter aircraft. By voice vote, the House passed the legislation which provides $268 billion for the nation's defense in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, a cut of $19 billion from Bush's initial proposal in January. Debate and final passage of the largest bill before the Congress took a mere 11 minutes as lawmakers push to adjourn before Sunday. The legislation now goes to the Senate, which is expected to approve the measure. The Senate was unable to complete debate and put off final action until Friday. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney supports the spending bill and Bush's signature is likely. Among the provisions in the bill, which meets the targets set in a defense blueprint adopted by the House late Wednesday, is a nearly $2 billion cut in Bush's $4.7 billion request for SDI and a reduction in funds for the B-2 stealth bomber that keeps the program alive for at least one more year. ``This bill shows restraint. It's a lean bill,'' said Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense. The legislation largely tracks the military blueprint but breaks ranks with the authorization bill on several issues. The spending plan calls for a troop cut of 78,500 from the 2.1 million men and women in uniform worldwide, just over $900 million for the MILSTAR communications satellite and full-scale development of the Advanced Tactical Fighter. The administration requested $283 million for full-scale development and $763 million to complete the demonstration and validation phase of the prototype aircraft. The defense blueprint provides $964 million for the program but prohibits full-scale development in fiscal 1991. The authorization bill emphasizes the need for the Air Force to finish demonstrating several technologies, including aerodynamic performance, low observability and engine capability, before beginning full-scale development. The Pentagon plans to begin buying the aircraft, intended to replace the Air Force's F-15, in 1996. The total number of fighters to be bought is 750. The spending bill concurs with the administration's request on the fighter as well as its proposal for the SRAM-T, a stand-off tactical nuclear weapon. The Pentagon sought $118 million in fiscal 1991 to begin SRAM-T test units and F-15E adaptor hardware. The authorization bill provides $35 million while the spending bill meets the administration's total. The blueprint reduces U.S. troop levels by 100,000, but, bowing to pressure from the Pentagon, gives the defense secretary added authority to limit the troop cut to 80,000 if he believes the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf warrants such a step. The authorization bill also provides $600 million for MILSTAR, but again, responding to Pentagon demands, gives Cheney the authority to transfer money from other accounts for the program. In other action, the House approved a beefed-up version of the Defense Production Act of 1950, extending its authority for another three years. By voice vote, the House adopted the measure aimed at revitalizing the U.S. defense industry through an array of steps, including giving the president the authority to maintain the technology base. ``It will ensure that our troops in the Persian Gulf receive the equipment and supplies they need,'' said Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deadlocks and Mistrial Declared in Rape Case of Comedian's Bodyguard
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Thursday in the case of a bodyguard accused of raping comedian Sam Kinison's girlfriend. The Superior Court jury deliberated 2{ days before announcing it was deadlocked on five felony counts of rape and sexual assault against Unway Carter, 22, of Greensville, S.C. Carter was very disappointed, said his public defender, Barry Collins. The 6-foot-4, 300-pound Carter, who was hired to protect Kinison, was charged with raping Kinison's girlfriend June 21 after bringing the couple home from a party. Kinison was asleep in another part of the house during the alleged assault. Carter testified earlier this month that the 26-year-old woman consented to having sexual intercourse with him. Carter has been in custody since June in lieu of $100,000 bail. Collins said prosecutors could take a week to decide whether to seek a retrial of the case. ``After speaking to the jury, if we have to try this case again it can only get better for Mr. Carter,'' Collins said. ``There's no more evidence, nothing in this case that is going to make it harder for us next time.''

DOC.HEAD: Munitions Bound for Middle East Show Up in New Orleans
DOC.TEXT: About 84 metric tons of munitions that were supposed to have been unloaded in the Middle East showed up at the Port of New Orleans near a shopping mall, federal authorities said. ``We are certainly not happy about it and we will take any steps necessary to make sure it doesn't happen again,'' said Marge Holtz, spokeswoman for the Navy's Military Sealift Command in Washington. The munitions arrived in New Orleans aboard the ship Green Island, which pulled into port about Oct. 18, said Coast Guard Lt. Anthony Morris. The vessel, owned by Central Gulf Lines Inc., was leased to the Sealift Command. It was designed to carry barges full of cargo. Workers on Friday discovered that one barge removed from the ship was full of munitions, Morris said. Two more barges full of munitions were discovered Tuesday. The barges were towed from a dock on the Mississippi River's east bank near the Riverwalk shopping mall to a more secluded west bank dock, Morris said. Central Gulf Lines employees notified the Coast Guard immediately after the first explosives were discovered, Morris said. Holtz said the Green Island and its cargo of munitions were part of a ``pre-positioned'' force in place at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait prompted the U.S. military's Desert Shield operation. The Green Island was sent to the Persian Gulf where the munitions were apparently supposed to be unloaded, said Ms. Holtz. She said investigators from the Defense Department and the Inspector General's office were sent to New Orleans to look into the matter. Meanwhil, the Coast Guard tightened security around the ship. Coast Guard broadcasts warned other ships to steer clear of the Green Island.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Films Lawmakers Easter Trip To Barbados
DOC.TEXT: While millions of Americans were spending last Easter weekend rushing to finish their taxes, members of the main House taxation committee were on a taxpayer-paid trip to Barbados - on something like Candid Camera. There to discuss a trade bill, the lawmakers spent much of their time frolicking at the pool, being entertained by lobbyists, or golfing at taxpayers' expense - unknowingly under the watchful eyes of a television news crew. The five-day, four-night stay at the Paradise Village and Beach Club came at the end of a 12-day official committee trip by 34 people that also included stops in several South American cities. The bill: $100,000 in all; $40,000 for the Barbados portion. The eight members of the House Ways and Means Committee were met and entertained on the Caribbean island by lobbyists representing insurance and computer companies with interests before the tax-writing panel. What the lawmakers, aides, spouses and military escorts on the trip didn't know is that much of their visit was videotaped by a crew from ABC-TV's ``PrimeTime Live,'' which broadcast a report on the trip Thursday night. The Barbados stop was approved by committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., so the lawmakers could research the Caribbean Basin Initiative, a trade bill before the panel. According to ABC, the lawmakers spent less than seven hours in business meetings and most of their time relaxing; each billed the government for $1,176 in daily expenses and other expense costs, even though they received many of their meals free at official receptions or those hosted by lobbyists. On the second day of the trip, the lawmakers attended a 40-minute morning meeting on the trade legislation and another hour-long meeting later after a luncheon at the prime minister's residence, according to the network. By midafternoon the work was done and three members went golfing, billing their green's fees to the U.S. Embassy. Other lawmakers and members of the delegation relaxed at the resort pool. ``I think that this idea that the press thinks these trips are junkets is absolutely ridiculous,'' one of the three golfing lawmakers on the trip, Democratic Rep. Marty Russo of Illinois, told ABC. ``The bottom line is we work very hard on these trips.'' Also on the trip, were Rostenkowski, Democratic Reps. Fortney Stark of California, Barbara Kennelly of Connecticut, Thomas Downey of New York and George Miller of California and Republican Reps. Richard Schulze of Pennsylvania, Raymond McGrath of New York and Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan. Miller is not a member of the Ways and Means Committee but was invited on the trip by Rostenkowski. The videotape of the trip shows lawmakers swimming, snorkeling, jet skiing, sunbathing and playing football with some of the lobbyists. The lobbyists included two for mutual insurance companies that would benefit under tax legislation filed by Downey and a former top Russo aide who now works at a law firm representing Comdisco, a Chicago a computer company that would benefit from leigislation filed by Russo. Until last year, Russo was on retainer for the same law firm, Coffield, Ungaretti, Harris and Slavin. Russo's past two financial disclosure forms show he received $25,000 from the firm in 1988 and 1989. Downey, who only participated in the Barbados portion of the trip and was videotaped with one of the insurance lobbyists before the rest of the delegation arrived, told the program there was no discussion of legislation with the lobbysits. He said he suspected the lobbyists were there ``so that they can see us in an informal setting.'' Russo said he did not believe his legislation presented a conflict because of his past role at the law firm. He said his former aide's role as a lobbyist had nothing to do with his introducing the legislation. ``I introduced a bill for the computer industry because I think the computer indistry in this country is being unfairly taken advantage of,'' he said. ABC said the other lawmakers on the trip declined to be interviewed for the segment. ABC traveled to Barbados ahead of the delegation after receving a tip about the trip, and the crew videotaped the activities of the delegation using hand-held cameras.

DOC.HEAD: Army Colonel Convicted In Court-Martial
DOC.TEXT: An Army dental surgeon accused of dressing as a woman and performing in a bar frequented by homosexuals was dismissed from the service Thursday and sentenced to nine months in prison. A court-martial board announced the sentence the same day it found Col. Edward Modesto guilty of eight counts of conduct unbecoming an officer. The nine-member board acquitted Modesto of two counts of indecent exposure, stemming from allegations he exposed himself to women at several Laundromats. Modesto's attorney, Walter Gerash, said he planned to file a motion for a mistrial. Modesto was confined at Fort Carson and was scheduled to go Friday to Fort Leavenworth, where he is to serve his sentence, Fort Carson spokesman Maryl Neff said. A 17-year Army veteran, Modesto, 43, was charged in April after he allegedly engaged in homosexual acts, dressed in women's clothing and performed at a bar frequented by homosexuals. Modesto pleaded not guilty to the indecent exposure charges and twice offered to resign rather than face a court-martial for violating the Army's ban on homosexuality. Military regulations prohibit homosexuality in the ranks, saying it threatens security and morale. Modesto is the highest-ranking officer to be court-martialed under the homosexual regulations at Fort Carson in at least three years. A father of three, Modesto testified Wednesday that he made the agonizing decision to acknowledge his repressed homosexuality when he turned 40. He and his wife are estranged.

DOC.HEAD: Six Typhoid Fever Outbreaks in '90 - Matches '80-89
DOC.TEXT: Six typhoid fever outbreaks nationally this year equals the number reported in all of the 1980s, federal health officials said. One outbreak, in Washington state, was linked to a large family reunion, Centers for Disease Control researchers said Thursday. The locations of the other outbreaks weren't disclosed, but the researchers said two were reported in restaurants, one was linked to home-cooked food, one was traced to imported shellfish and the other had an unknown origin. Typhoid fever, once a dreaded disease, is most commonly linked to poor sanitation; it is spread via contaminated food and water. It's now rare in the developed world. Symptoms include fever, headache, pains and nausea. Preliminary CDC reports show 406 cases reported nationwide, with 10 weeks remaining in the year; if that rate continues, the 1990 total could reach 503, the most since 1983. The CDC received reports of only six typhoid outbreaks - or clusters of cases - from 1980 to 1989. The family reunion outbreak occurred at a gathering of 293 people from five states in Skagit County, Wash., the CDC said. At least 17 people at the reunion were dagnosed with typhoid fever; the average illness lasted 20 days. Health investigators found that three food items served at the reunion were linked to the outbreak; a person who prepared one of them tested positive as a carrier of the typhoid bacteria. Typhoid is preventable by a vaccine recommended for Americans traveling to areas with typhoid problems, such as Central and South America, Africa, India and Southeast Asia. The vaccine has been reported to cause severe side effects in some cases, including high fever, but an oral vaccine approved earlier this year promises fewer side effects.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Says - Again - `Twin Peaks' Killer Will Be Disclosed
DOC.TEXT: ABC television said it will reveal on Nov. 10 the identity of ``Bob,'' killer of teen queen Laura Palmer on the much-hyped but little-watched nighttime series ``Twin Peaks.'' Episodes this season made it very clear to viewers that ``Bob'' is responsible for the 6-month-old slaying, ABC programming chief Bob Iger told reporters Thursday at the network's West Coast headquarters. Problem is, it's unclear just who or what ``Bob'' is. A demon? A person? A distant cousin of Freddy Krueger? ``On Nov. 10, you will know who Bob is,'' Iger said. ABC has promised before to identify the murderer in its downright confusing ``Twin Peaks'' series. So far, the network hasn't made good on that promise.

DOC.HEAD: Network Says FBI Investigating Report by Nevada Inmate of 1960s Murders
DOC.TEXT: A television network said Thursday the Justice Department is looking into a convicted murderer's allegations that at least 25 blacks were abducted from the Washington area, then tortured and killed by the Ku Klux Klan in the 1960s. Fox News said some of the bodies may be buried in mass graves near Warrenton, Va., about 45 miles southwest of Washington. Authorities were told of the abductions by Edward Allen See, an inmate in a Nevada prison, Fox said. See is serving a life sentence without possibility of parole for the murders of two women. The network said See was ``having trouble identifying the specific place'' of burial, and no one had yet searched for the bodies. Justice Department spokesman Michael Robinson told The Associated Press he had no information about the report. The network said See told the FBI a number of blacks were kidnapped at random from the streets of Washington. See also has alleged the killings were done with the complicity of local law enforcement officials and politicians. See has passed one lie detector test and is scheduled for another next week, Fox said. But his mother told authorities on one occasion he was ``a liar who just wants attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Revolution Still Possible Despite Collapse of Socialism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1 Oct. 19.
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Ortega, who won international respect by accepting an election defeat, says revolution in Latin America may survive the collapse of European communism, but not if its leaders cling to dogma. Nicaragua's former president said in an interview that injustice and poverty still are problems in the region, providing the fodder of revolution. At 46, with a decade of leadership behind him as head of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, Ortega has abandoned the olive fatigues and black-and-red bandanna of his guerrilla days and years in power. President Bush once compared the outfit to a Boy Scout uniform. Ortega cultivates a youthful image, dressing in jeans and colorful shirts, and remains politically active in Nicaragua and abroad. Young admirers pursue him for autographs when he appears in public. His acceptance of the February election loss to Violeta Chamorro, Nicaragua's new president, improved his image in the world. At home, Ortega has reined in the more radical elements of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. A combination of Ortega's influence and two crippling strikes led by the Sandinistas persuaded the new government to retain many Sandinista programs, including land distribution. ``The reality of Nicaragua is that no one can govern without the FSLN'' he said, using the initials of the Sandinista Front. ``I am sure that our talks with the government and our attempts to reach a consensus have angered some people inside the government, but we think common sense is prevailing.'' Elements of Mrs. Chamorro's fractious coalition accuse her of weakness for dealing with the Sandinistas, who are by far the largest party in Nicaragua and want to be consulted on important economic decisions. The Sandinistas oppose such austerity measures as currency devaluations, reductions in the public payroll and selling nationalized industries back to private investors. Ortega works for the party and travels abroad seeking foreign aid for Nicaragua. He said being out of office allows him more time with his eight children, but that they interfere with a book he is writing on the years in government. Wealthy nations are focusing on their own concerns at the expense of Latin America and other poor regions, Ortega said. ``We will now see an industrialized North, including the former Socialist countries, that will determine the distribution of the world's technological resources,'' he predicted. ``The problems of the Third World will continue. The industrialized countries of the North have no time to consider our economies or problems in the South.'' U.S. economic assistance to Mrs. Chamorro's government has not met Nicaraguan expectations. About $65 million in cash has been provided since April and an additional $40 million is promised in credits for agricultural development. ``The collapse of the Eastern Socialist bloc gives the United States the hegemonic control that always was its objective in Latin America,'' Ortega said. ``The policies of assistance of the Socialist bloc . . . disappear and they are not compensated by the United States or other industrialized countries. ``This places Latin America at a disadvantage. It does not help our countries. The need for revolutionary change remains. ``We still have a revolutionary movement in El Salvador, and Brazil can explode, too. We have armed groups in Peru and Colombia. What happened in the East does not improve the living conditions of people in the South.'' Washington no longer can accuse all revolutionary movements of being communist, Ortega added, and ``at the same time, the revolutionary movement must rethink the kind of projects and programs they want. In the past there was a tendency to dogmatism.'' ``Our revolution was never subordinated to the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``They offered their support after the victory.'' ``The United States must show respect for Latin America if it wants a world of peace, and Latin America must increase its contacts with sectors of influence in the United States that . . . know the rich will sink if the needs of the poor are not satisfied,'' Ortega said. Of Nicaragua's future and the Sandinista role in it, he said: ``We realize this government came to power with the help of the United States. We accepted the challenge in the elections. ``But the Nicaraguan revolution's changes brought on by the Sandinista Front remain. ``Now the party must change, and adapt to the times. Neither the structure nor the programs of a party are immovable. We now need other forms, although the objectives of ending human exploitation and the principles of justice remain.'' ``We still have a lot to do to emerge from the crisis,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prince of Wales Calls for End to Destruction of Wildlife Habitat
DOC.TEXT: The Prince of Wales called for an end to the destruction of Britain's wildlife habitats, which he said were damaged by development. Nearly 700 sites of special scientific interest were lost or damaged between 1984 and 1988, the heir to the British throne said Thursday, quoting government figures. Road-building plans in southeast Britain could damage more than 370 other sites, he said. The prince, patron of the Royal Society for Nature Conservation, was speaking at the release of a society report on nature conservation in Britain. In a videotaped message played at a London news conference, the prince said there was widespread recognition of the need to consult environmental groups before going ahead with development. ``One pond drained, one new road through one small corner of an ancient woodland, might not in itself be a disaster, but the destruction of a whole network of sites, by a whole catalogue of changes, can destroy the viability of entire communities of wildlife,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Ask Maximum, One-Year Sentence for Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 2 and grafs 6-10 bgng: ``In his,'' letters to judge from Barry and his wife.
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors, saying that Marion Barry is sorry ``only that he got caught,'' urged Thursday that the city's mayor be given the maximum sentence of one year in prison and be fined $100,000 for his misdemeanor cocaine conviction. Barry, meanwhile, pleaded for mercy from the judge, saying he is sorry for his actions and already has been humiliated. The mayor's wife, Effi, also wrote to the judge, saying some of the witnesses at her husband's trial were lying and that the ordeal has left him ``publicly castrated.'' U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is scheduled to sentence Barry on Friday. In a memo, U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said Barry has shown a ``flagrant disregard for the law and seriously impugned the integrity'' of his office. ``In short, the defendant is not genuinely remorseful about his criminality,'' the document said. ``He is sorry only that he got caught.'' Barry was convicted Aug. 10 on one count of cocaine possession and acquitted of another. The jury was unable to reach a verdict on the remaining 12 counts, including three perjury charges. In his letter, Barry wrote that he is a drug addict and was ``deeply sorry'' for behavior he called ``degrading and outrageous.'' ``When I sat in your courtroom each day, hearing things about myself that I had not wanted to face, I may have appeared to be calm and unmoved, but on the inside I was suffering nearly unbearable humiliation and deepest regret,'' Barry wrote to Jackson. Mrs. Barry asked the judge to ``search your humanity.'' ``What further punishment does this man deserve?'' the mayor's wife wrote. ``For certain there can be no greater sentence than to have the whole world tune into your day in court as you are publicly castrated.'' The letters from Barry and his wife were included with numerous documents filed on his behalf with the court on Thursday, The Washington Post reported in its Friday editions. At a hearing last week, Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, objected to a finding in the probation officer's report that the mayor was not sorry for his actions. Stephens decided not to retry the 54-year-old mayor and Mundy said Barry had decided not to seek a new trial on the one conviction. In the government's sentencing memo, Stephens charged Barry had a ``brazen disregard for the law'' which ``conveyed a particularly devastating message to a number of people.'' According to the prosecutor, Barry's conduct was ``disheartening'' to law enforcement officers who were struggling to bring drug-driven crime in the district under control. Barry also undermined the nation's efforts to work with foreign countries to stop the flow of illegal drugs, Stephens maintained. ``How are we to explain to these officials that our efforts to reduce the near-insatiable demand for drugs in this country is earnest and is not empty rhetoric when an elected official who publicly urges all to `just say no' in reality was adding to the demand for illegal drugs?'' the prosecutor wrote. He also said Barry's actions had a ``devastating effect'' on efforts to convince young people that ``their future as well as ours rests with their rejection of drugs.'' The memo says that Barry, in his pre-sentencing interview with a probation officer, admitted to ``two dozen unspecified cocaine possessions.'' Barry's third, four-year term as mayor expires in January. He is an independent candidate in the November general election for one of two at-large city council positions.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Is Giant Sand Box Filled With Tools of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA2 Oct. 25.
DOC.TEXT: Picture a child playing war games in a sandbox, marching his toy soldiers here, moving toy tanks there, leveling ripples with his bulldozers and roaring his play jets overhead with sweeps of the hand. That's a miniature version of what it looks like in Saudi Arabia, except the sandbox is an endless tract of desert and the soldiers and weapons are real. The United States has deployed some 210,000 troops in Operation Desert Shield and thousands of missiles, artillery pieces, tanks, combat jets and armed helicopters to confront Saddam Hussein in occupied Kuwait. The British, French, Saudis, Egyptians, Pakistanis and other allies have sent thousands more men with their arsenals of modern weapons. This deployment, the biggest U.S. military operation overseas since Vietnam, has turned the desert, once the domicile of Bedouin and camels, into an awesome arena of military power. Less than three months ago, the only tracks in the desert were from the hooves of hardy animals. Now those tracks have been obliterated by the crazy-quilt pattern of tank treads, armored personnel carriers, trucks and the new generation of jeep. Where once the desert air was pierced by the occasional bleating of goats, jet engines whine, the dull thud of helicopter blades assaults the ears and the crack of guns is heard on practice ranges. Clouds of dust spit up by columns of vehicles on the move whirl through the air. There is something captivating and scary about all this military maneuvering. From a helicopter cockpit, the olive-drab tents of military encampments look like mushroom clusters. They contrast with the white Bedouin tents donated by the Saudis. Scout helicopters skim along the horizon like angry hornets buzzing from their nest to respond to intruders. From the road, the barrels of guns on tanks dug in among the dunes poke out from under camouflage nets toward the north, where an estimated 430,000 Iraqis are deployed in and around Kuwait. To say hello, crews flash hand signals used by surfers. Near port facilities, Patriot surface-to-air missiles, designed to take out hostile incoming missiles, point northward. Sandbag bunkers surround encampments and giant, closed warehouses that the imagination fills with endless stacks of ammunition and other supplies. Concrete barriers rise in roadways to deter truck bombs or other terrorist attacks. Everywhere, convoys are on the move. Some trucks haul soldiers on maneuvers. Others dash back to the rear for supplies. They are the tail that leads to the teeth of the military beast at the front. The front-line troops get hot meals for breakfast and dinner. These are trucked to the front. So are water for the soldiers and gasoline for thirsty vehicles. Some troops are ferried by bus back to the rear for showers and what little recreation they can find. Soldiers, like native Saudis, play football and soccer on grassless fields. New features such as a heliport being paved on top of the blistering landscape materialize almost overnight, like mirages to a disbelieving wanderer. Each morning brings a spectacular dawn, each night an equally inspiring sunset. The roar of night-time traffic pierces otherwise silent, starry nights. Out of sight, but not out of mind, is an international armada of more than 70 warships from a dozen countries bobbing in the gulf and the waters around the Arabian peninsula. Even the Saudi cities offer strange images. Concrete and glass towers rise from the arid wasteland, thanks to the petrobillions earned from the oilfields. These riches allow such luxuries as six-lane highways paved through the deserts and Baskin-Robbins shops in suburban malls. In the bazaar of Al-Khobar, just outside Dhahran, shops offer T-shirts with Desert Shield themes. One depicts a camel in a gas mask riding a flying carpet, another shows tanks idled in the sand with a few Z's printed above and the legend ``All Quiet on the Eastern Front.'' Servicemen and women are often seen shopping, mostly buying air conditioners and stereo equipment to alleviate the heat and boredom of waiting for a war that might never happen. Soldiers in airy desert camouflage fatigues hardly raise eyebrows any more when they wander through hotel lobbies or grocery stores carrying rifles and sidearms. The sandbox is accustomed to the real-life war machine.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Writer Praises Nobel Prize Winner Octavio Paz
DOC.TEXT: Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa, whose novel ``Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter'' has just become a Hollywood movie, says he's proud the Nobel Prize for Literature went to Mexican poet Octavio Paz. ``I think Octavio Paz is a great poet, one of the greatest intellectuals of our time,'' Vargas Llosa said in an interview with local television. ``So it made me very proud as a Latin American that the prize went to Octavio Paz.'' Vargas Llosa, 54, was visiting Puerto Rico for the CinemaFest film festival which opened Thursday night with the movie ``Tune in Tomorrow'' based on his ``Aunt Julia.'' Vargas Llosa made an unsuccesful bid for the presidency of Peru in June, losing in an upset to maverick candidate Alberto Fujimori. Vargas Llosa said Thursday he had no further political plans and would dedicate his life to literature. Vargas Llosa said he loved ``Tune in Tomorrow,'' starring Peter Falk and Barbara Hershey, although the film adaptation did not follow to the letter his novel about a young man who falls in love with an older woman, the sister of his uncle's wife. ``Movies are another medium of expression,'' he said. ``The novel is the written word and films are images.'' Another Vargas Llosa novel dealing with an affair between a young man and a relative, the erotic ``In Praise of the Stepmother,'' was published in English this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Fireworks Plant Injures 20
DOC.TEXT: A blast at a fireworks factory leveled buildings, tossed a car through a church wall and scattered wreckage over five miles, local television reported. Twenty people were injured. TV Globo said the blast occurred before dawn Thursday in a residential neighborhood of Campo Grande, 916 miles northwest of Rio. A short circuit in the building's electrical system was thought to have caused the explosion, which also tore the roof off a school, the network said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain to Reopen Tehran Embassy on Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Britain will reopen its embassy in Tehran this weekend with a staff of five, the Foreign Office said, and Iran will staff its reopened embassy in London with a similar number of people. The five Britons will fly to Tehran on Saturday and reopen the embassy the following day, a Foreign Office spokesman said Thursday, speaking on condition of anonymity. The two countries will not exchange ambassadors for the time being, the spokesman said. The move was agreed to at a meeting last month between Douglas Hurd, Britain's foreign secretary, and Ali Akbar Velayati, Iran's foreign minister. Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain 18 months ago over the Salman Rushdie affair. Rushdie, the Indian-born British novelist, was condemned to death in February 1989 by the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding ever since.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Waffles on Troop Deployment, Public Ratings Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Japan's proposal to deploy troops overseas is being dragged down by fierce resistance in Parliament, and if it fails Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's job could go with it, analysts say. Polls published Thursday showed Kaifu's popularity in a sharp dive, largely because of the perception that he is waffling on a decisive issue for Japan in the Persian Gulf standoff. That negative image has been magnified by televised debate in Parliament over the deployment bill, an acutely sensitive issue in this nation. Kaifu is seen repeatedly shifting position under attack from opposition members, who seem to have enough votes to defeat the bill. ``Kaifu has done it with spectacular incompetence,'' said Garrett Scalera, president of the Tokyo Institute of Policy Studies. ``I think his days are numbered.'' The newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun published a poll Thursday showing that support for Kaifu's Cabinet has fallen by 10 points since last month to 49.8 percent. Most of the drop was attributed to the prime minister's wavering statements in Parliament. Another leading newspaper, the Mainichi Shimbun, put his support at 35 percent, a drop of 6 points. The polls did not give a margin of error. In July, a Yomiuri poll had Kaifu's popularity at 62.5 percent, the highest rate for any postwar Cabinet. Those results in part reflected the 59-year-old prime minister's strong showing at the Houston economic summit and U.S. trade talks earlier in the year. The gulf crisis, however, has been a far more serious test for Kaifu. And he's responded with a series of flip-flops. After the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, Kaifu announced a financial aid package for the gulf but declared the nation's Self-Defense Forces (SDF) would not go. When Japan's senior security partner, the United States, expressed unhappiness over the decision, Kaifu did an about-face. The result was a proposal to deploy support troops under the United Nations umbrella. That opened a Pandora's box that Japan has preferred to keep shut: whether to reconsider its post-World War II constitutional ban on using force overseas. ``Kaifu himself didn't want to send the SDF from the very beginning. His indecisiveness is the reason why the bill is so unpopular,'' said Seizaburo Sato, a Tokyo University politics professor and former adviser to two prime ministers. ``If Kaifu really firmly believed it was necessary for Japan to send the Self-Defense Forces, the people would accept it.'' Faced with anti-deployment sentiment at home as well as in other Asian countries, Kaifu has been at best confusing, at worst self-contradictory under intense grilling from leading opposition members at a special session of Parliament in recent weeks. On Wednesday, for example, he was pressed to clarify what cooperation Japan could offer to Gulf forces already there. Kaifu answered he could not say at present, despite previous assertions that his Peace Cooperation Corps would be involved in transportation, medical aid and other specific non-combat activities. And he dismissed concerns that corps members might face armed conflicts overseas, despite some forecasts the gulf could soon erupt in war. Some experts say Kaifu's political weakness in Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, a factor since he was installed in August 1989, has finally come home to roost. The prime minister, elected from a small party faction as a compromise candidate, has been repeatedly embarrassed in recent weeks as powerful LDP politicians have edged him out of the headlines by making independent diplomatic initiatives in North and South Korea and elsewhere. Some analysts say those politicians, conservatives themselves who want a strong deployment bill, see Kaifu as a sacrificial lamb on the issue. Few now believe the overseas deployment bill can be passed by the time Parliament's special session ends Nov. 10. With Kaifu's credibility bound up in the proposal, the only thing that might save him from resigning if the bill fails is the lack of a consensus candidate to replace him before his term ends in November 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Mounting Frustration Breeding Violence in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Frustration over the political and economic impasse gripping Nicaragua has flared into a wave of bombings, looting, land takeovers and armed skirmishes. President Violeta Chamorro and a 14-party coalition swept to victory in February, ending more than a decade of revolutionary Sandinista rule with promises of economic recovery and peace. But the Sandinistas, by far the largest and best-organized pressure group in the country, have used negotiations and muscle to keep control of the army and police and to block the government's economic programs. In view of the government's relative impotence, some of the Sandinistas' enemies are threatening to take the situation into their own hands. The Episcopal Conference, the influential organization of Nicaragua's 11 Roman Catholic bishops, warned Thursday against the deteriorating situation. ``There is a growing frustration in broad sectors of the population regarding the use and future of the vote cast last Feb. 25 and of the implementation of measures and programs different from that for which they voted,'' the conference said in a statement. On Wednesday, about 300 demobilized Contra rebels and sympathizers surrounded the Sandinista-controled police station in the small town of Rio Blanco, demanding the removal of the police chief. The same day, a gathering of businessmen, government officials, and independent and Sandinista labor unions broke off negotiations aimed at developing an economic program, after 34 days of talks. While all sides agree that Nicaragua's economy is flattened by hyperinflation, a fiscal deficit and low production, the government is being pulled by the demands of leftist Sandinistas and rightist business groups, neither of which seem willing to compromise. The Sandinistas say government proposals to stabilize the economy will cause mass unemployment. Business groups say the plans don't go far enough. The Superior Council for Private Enterprise, Nicaragua's major business group, claims the government has diluted its plans to return property confiscated under leftist Sandinista rule. Partial strikes by Sandinista-organized government workers are frequent and disruptive. Their demands range from pay raises to the firing of officials appointed by the new government. Many of the 20,000 Contra rebels who finished demobilizing in June are unhappy with what they say are broken government promises for land. Former rebels have taken over Sandinista cooperatives in remote parts of Nicaragua, and shootouts between ex-rebels and Sandinista security forces have left more than 12 people dead and scores wounded. Last week, the government declared a state of emergency in the remote Atlantic town of Puerto Cabezas, where demobilized Indian rebels looted government warehouses, accusing the officials of stealing donations intended for them. Three people were wounded and 21 people arrested. Earlier this month, at least 200 ex-rebels took over the hamlet of Waslala in northern Nicaragua, forcing out Sandinista police and soldiers in clashes that left four dead. Around the same time, bombings temporarily silenced two Managua radio stations, one Sandinista and the other fiercely anti-Sandinista.

DOC.HEAD: Militiamen Don't Believe War Is Over Despite Disarmament Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Mash-Hoor, a bearded Druse Moslem militiaman, greased his AK-47 and wrapped it tightly in a plastic bag to bury it - just in case. Thousands of gunmen like him are doing the same. After countless bloody battles in the course of Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, the three main Moslem and Christian militias agreed Thursday to withdraw from Beirut and its environs. But it is an uneasy peace. ``This rifle is mine,'' Mash-Hoor said. ``I won it in a battle in 1984. Who knows when I or someone dear to me will need it?'' Approval of the withdrawal plan came from Samir Geagea's right-wing Chritian Lebanese Forces militia, Nabih Berri's moderate Shiite Amal militia and Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party. But Hezbollah, or Party of God, held off on promising a pullout. The Shiite group is believed be an umbrella for underground extremists holding most of 13 missing Westerners in Lebanon. Hezbollah, with some 3,500 main-force fighters, has long feuded with the more secular Amal for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's biggest sect. The groundwork was laid for the militia withdrawal when President Elias Hrawi's Syrian backers crushed a mutiny by rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun Oct. 13 in fighting that killed up to 750 people in eight hours. The ultimate objective is to be disarm the militias and absorb some of their fighters into government security forces. But hardened gunslingers like Mash-Hoor - a nom de guerre meaning ``Famous'' - don't believe it will happen. ``No one believes they'll be disbanded. It never worked before. It won't work now,'' Mash-Hoor said. There are about 20,000 fighters in the dozen or so militias. Many have their own personal arsenals of automatic weapons, grenade launchers, explosives and hand grenades. During past disarmament bids, fighters handed over some weapons, but hid most of their arms - including tanks, artillery and mortars. Many of the fighters, like Mash-Hoor, have known nothing but violence. They are school dropouts, with no skills. Serving in the militia is a meal ticket - the fighters simply take what they want at restaurants, bars and gas stations. Mash-Hoor has been a member of the Druse Progressive Socialist Party militia since he was seven years old. The civil war is all he's ever known. He was born Marwan Yahya, and grew up in Druse town of Shweifat, in the Chouf foothills. When the war broke out in 1975, he was only a child. But he quit school to join the fighters. His first job in the militia was collecting empty cartridge cases to be refilled. He was dubbed Abu Khartoush - Father of the Bullets. He attended school ``on and off'' during lulls in the fighting, but he found he no longer fit in. ``I was no longer willing to listen to teachers, do homework and be disciplined,'' he said. ``I was Abu Khartoush.'' At 12, he was renamed Abu Tabikh, or Father of Food, because ``I was driving a Land Rover and distributing food to fighters on the front lines.'' In 1983, he proved himself as a fighter, battling Christians in the Chouf Mountains, earning his fighting name. Warfare has been his trade ever since. Unlike Mash-Hoor, Haidar, a 37-year-old Amal militiaman, can now earn a living from his peacetime profession. Before he took up the gun, he was a house painter. ``There'll be lots of painting work to do in greater Beirut,'' he said, in an understated reference to the war-wrecked capital. Haidar echoes Mash-Hoor in his skepticism that the militia will truly lay down arms. He said Amal will withdraw from the south Beirut slum of Shiyah which it controls. But, he said: ``I have no orders from my superiors that the militia will be disbanded.'' Haidar said he'll stay on with his militia as a part-timer. He said on weekends, he would head south to Amal bases, where the fighters would regroup. ``I don't believe that the war's over once and for all,'' he said. ``I won't burn my bridges.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Rumors Move World Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Prophet Mohammed supposedly appears to Saddam Hussein in a dream and tells him to leave Kuwait. Or whispers emerge that Israeli troops have crossed the Jordan River and squared off against Iraq. These may be rumors with no relation to the truth, but they move financial markets thoughout the world, driving the price of oil and other commodities up or down. Either alone or coupled with the legitimate news of the day, such hearsay can result in drastic swings in which fortunes are made or lost. ``A rumor can affect the market just like real news,'' said Ian Seymour, editor of the Cyprus-based Middle East Economic Survey, a respected oil industry publication. ``Markets are so greatly volatile that any little rumor can move them and move them by considerable amounts,'' Seymor said in an interview. ``Certainly these things go way, way beyond the fundamental laws of supply and demand, particularly in times of war and uncertainty.'' The gulf crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 provides fertile grist for the Middle East's notorious rumor mill. Suddenly, world oil supplies were threatened, propelling prices skyward. Hints of diplomatic settlements bring them down, while suggestions of imminent hostilities drive them up again. A popular rumor breaking into financial markets over the past few weeks has been simple but effective: Saddam is dead - slain by top aides, or Israeli commandos or unknown assassins. Although there's a chance it could backfire, the general interpretation is that the demise of the Iraqi leader would lead to a peaceful settlement. On Monday, crude oil prices plunged more than $5 a barrel based on a combination of Middle East peace hopes and a rumor that Saddam told his associates that Mohammed told him in a dream his rockets were pointed in the wrong direction. The dream story first appeared in a Kuwaiti newspaper, now published in the gulf, that has actively tried to discredit Saddam. It was based on alleged rumors from Iraq. The peace hopes stemmed from a report on a speech by Saudi Arabia's defense minister, Prince Sultan, that led traders to believe his country was willing to make some concessions to Iraq. There were also ``unconfirmed reports'' that Iraq was withdrawing troops from parts of Kuwait. On Wednesday, markets in Tokyo were briefly affected by a report that fundamentalist Moslems in Jordan had allegedly declared war on Israel. The rumor turned into gossip that Jordan had declared war on Israel, which in turn had sent its troops across the Jordan River and was squaring off against Iraq. Seymour said there are so many rumors it's impossible to keep track of them. It's equally hard to find who starts them, even though exchanges have penalties for members who engage in rumor-mongering. ``The rumors appear and they have no parent,'' Seymour said. ``Everybody seems to plant rumors on Friday afternoon, just before closing. That way you can really make hay.'' Futures traders ``react to anything, whether it's a rumor or real,'' he said. ``Those in the ... trading sections of big oil companies tend to cover themselves by hedging.'' Rumor or real, the gulf crisis makes for an active market. ``Basically, one thinks that the theoretical framework for it is you take a price that the experts think the price would be if there's no threat of war, say about $20 to $25 a barrel,'' Seymour said. ``Anything above that would be a war premium.'' ``Obviously all this feeds on rumors,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Island Leaders, Uneasy Over Chemical Weapons, to See Bush
DOC.TEXT: Pacific island leaders meet with President Bush on Saturday, worried that their ocean is becoming a U.S. chemical weapons dump and their tiny nations are slipping down the list of U.S. aid beneficiaries. Flying in from across the Pacific to confer with Bush are the presidents or prime ministers of nine remote and economically vulnerable countries, ranging from Papua New Guinea, population 3.6 million, to Nauru, a mid-ocean dot supporting 8,000 people. Bush, who arrives Friday, scheduled the unprecedented session to coincide with a swing through Honolulu to campaign for Patricia Saiki, a Republican congresswoman vying with Democratic incumbent Daniel Akaka for a U.S. Senate seat. For months, Pacific islanders have expressed concern about plans to destroy chemical weapons from U.S. Far Eastern and European bases at a giant new incinerator on Johnston Atoll, a U.S.-held ring of islands 825 miles southwest of Hawaii. As Bush and the Pacific leaders meet in two hours of talks, followed by lunch, the latest shipment of such munitions will be nearing Johnston Atoll. Two U.S. Navy ships carrying 100,000 artillery shells packed with nerve agents, the U.S. Army's stockpile from West Germany, are expected to reach the atoll next month. The South Pacific Forum, an organization of regional governments, has complained the plan could make the region ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' The environmental group Greenpeace USA went to court to block the operation, but a federal judge last month rejected the challenge. Tests of the incinerator are to end late next year, and full-scale incineration is expected to begin in 1992. The United States and Soviet Union have agreed to destroy such weapons by 1997. Geoffrey A. Henry, Cook Islands prime minister and chairman of the Pacific Islands Conference, another regional organization, said Johnston Atoll will be on their minds when he and the other leaders meet with Bush. ``In my view, the top concern is the enviromental issue,'' Henry said in a telephone interview. A U.S. administration official said in Washington on Wednesday that islanders have been ``reassured that the destruction of these chemical weapons will be carried out in an environmentally safe manner.'' But the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Johnston Atoll and other environmental issues are expected to be a major topic at the Honolulu talks. Island leaders also want the United States to sign the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, banning use, testing, dumping and storage of nuclear weapons and nuclear waste in the region. The Soviet Union, Australia and New Zealand are among the nations that have signed the protocols. Besides the Cooks, Papua New Guinea and Nauru, the island governments represented at the summit with Bush will be Fiji, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, Tuvalu and Western Samoa. The islanders may also seek reassurances from Bush on long-term prospects for U.S. development assistance. They fear that the budget crisis in Washington might mean cuts or even the elimination of U.S. aid. ``Because they are mini-states, U.S. funds for them could get squeezed out,'' said Michael P. Hamnett, a Pacific scholar at the University of Hawaii. The aid programs, an estimated total of $16 million yearly for the islands, could be reduced because of American commitments to Eastern Europe, Central America and the Middle East, Henry said. ``We understand the rest of the world needs attention and we in the Pacific have to learn to live with that,'' he said. ``Nothing is happening in our region that requires the attention of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE SPENDING ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Gingrich Foe Says GOP Whip Neglecting His District
DOC.TEXT: Republican Newt Gingrich hasn't set foot in his congressional district all month. There are few Gingrich campaign posters in his home town of Jonesboro. Gingrich says he's been busy in Congress. All of that is fine with Democrat David Worley, who's been campaigning against the House Republican whip full time for three years. ``This district is tired of Mr. Gingrich,'' Worley says. ``He forgot the average American in this district for his Washington agenda, which does not serve the people here at home.'' House Democrats are tired of their combative nemesis, too. They've posted a sign in their Capitol cloakroom that says: ``Make the 102nd (Congress) Newt Free.'' The poster features Gingrich's photo and a caption calling him ``the most corrupt minority whip in history.'' That's a swipe at his frequent descriptions of former House Speaker Jim Wright as the ``most corrupt speaker in American history.'' Worley, a Jonesboro attorney, won 41 percent of the vote against Gingrich in 1988. This time, he's accusing Gingrich of repeatedly flip-flopping on taxes and neglecting the district. But Gingrich still retains a strong base of support in his conservative Georgia district and is a heavy favorite for re-election. Gingrich, who made his name as a fervent anti-tax crusader, last visited his district on Sept. 29. He did find time for a quick campaign trip to New Jersey this month for a GOP colleague. His spokesman, Tom Blankley, blames his absence from Georgia on the fact that Congress ``has been in session just about non-stop for weeks.'' Political analyst Michael Binford said Gingrich must perform a balancing act. ``One of the dangerous situations he's in is that if you're an ambitious politician and have a national stage and forget the folks back home, they can punish you for that,'' Binford said. ``He hasn't ignored them, but he's not back here as much as before he was made whip.'' Because Gingrich is a controversial figure, he's ``not going to breeze to victory as most incumbents do,'' said political scientist Alan Abramowitz of Emory University. ``But it's really hard to unseat an incumbent.'' Gingrich was elected to the House on his third try in 1978. He rose to the No. 2 spot in the House GOP hierarchy after instigating the ethics investigation that led to Wright's resignation in 1989. But then Gingrich himself was attacked on ethics grounds regarding the publishing deal for his 1984 book ``Window of Opportunity.'' The House ethics committee said it found no basis for a full investigation. Gingrich broke with the White House earlier this month when he led the defeat of a budget proposal backed by President Bush. Worley, who also opposed the budget deal, says it was at least the fourth time since July that Gingrich changed his tax position. In July, House Republicans approved a resolution opposing higher taxes. A day later, Gingrich supported a $25 billion tax increase and promised to use his leadership position to deliver key Republican votes for it. But in early August, he said he opposed any tax increase. He later advocated tax cuts to stimulate the economy, but his plan died. In opposing the president's budget proposal, Gingrich said the ``equation has changed'' because of the Persian Gulf crisis and increasing evidence that the country is headed for a recession. Worley, noting that Gingrich supported a $35,000 congressional pay raise, offered his own budget plan: repeal the pay raise, eliminate franked mail and increase income taxes on the wealthiest Americans. Worley says Gingrich missed his most significant opportunity to help the district when he refused to back federal intervention in the Eastern Airlines strike. The district lost 6,000 jobs as a result of the strike, according to Worley. Gingrich accuses Worley of being a ``liberal who voted for Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis'' and of becoming a full-time candidate instead of a tax-paying wage earner. Worley produced joint tax records proving he and his wife, also a lawyer, had paid income taxes. He said it is true he has not practiced law in the three years he has been campaigning against Gingrich. Worley says he's no liberal. He supports the death penalty, opposes gun control and favors a balanced budget amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Cuts Said to Delay Antimissile Decision by Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Deep cuts in Star Wars spending in 1991 will delay a White House decision on deploying an antimissile shield by at least two years, the project's director says. Henry Cooper, who took over as head of the project just last summer, has determined that because of the budget squeeze, he cannot provide the scientific basis for a deployment decision before the end of 1994 at the earliest. Shortly after he took office in 1989, Bush told the Pentagon he wanted to be able to decide what kind of Star Wars defense to build by the end of his term in 1992. Cooper's spokeswoman, Maj. Carolyn Channave, said Wednesday that Cooper had reached this conclusion on the basis of the 1991 defense bill approved on Wednesday by the House and expected to be passed by the Senate this week. Cooper was not available for comment, she said. The spending reduction of about $800 million, to a five-year low of $2.89 billion, also is likely to mean the end of development work on some of the exotic weapons that gave the Strategic Defense Initiative its Star Wars nickname. One expected casualty is the free-electron laser, once considered one of the most promising efforts to harness intense beams of light for weaponry. The powerful laser would bounce its beam off a series of orbiting mirrors to zap ballistic missiles over the Soviet Union, destroying them moments after lift-off. More than $700 million has been spent on this project over the past seven years. The budget also may sound the death knell for the X-ray laser. Powered by the detonation of a hydrogen bomb, the X-ray laser was envisioned as firing multiple beams of radiation across space to destroy Soviet missiles. Work on this weapon, which does not yet exist, has cost about $1 billion in recent years. Bush had requested $4.6 billion for SDI for the 1991 budget year that began Oct. 1. The decision by Congress to sharply reduce the spending total does not mean the project is dead, but its pulse is slowing and its shape is changing. SDI was launched by former President Reagan in March 1983 and became a cornerstone of American defense policy. Reagan promoted the project as a way of rendering nuclear weapons obsolete, but the Bush administration has abandoned the idea of erecting an impenetrable antimissile shield. Cooper disclosed earlier this month that he is restructuring SDI to attempt to win congressional support for building a limited defensive shield, one that could stop as many as a couple hundred ballistic missiles but not protect against an all-out Soviet nuclear attack - a threat most see as receding. Bush said earlier this year that strategic defense was more important than ever before, but some of SDI's most fervent supports are now wondering why the president didn't put up a bigger fight against Congress' rush to cut Star Wars spending. Daniel O. Graham, a former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency and chairman of the pro-SDI group Americans for the High Frontier, said the 1991 defense budget deals a ``devastating blow'' to the project. He urged Bush to veto it. Bush is not expected to veto the bill, in part because Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said this week he would not recommend rejection despite his misgivings on SDI spending. Equally troubling to Cooper, the SDI director, is a provision in the bill that would, for the first time, give Congress control over how the SDI money is spent. Cooper has said this will limit his ability to apply technologies developed in one area of the project - such as space-based interceptors - to other areas.

DOC.HEAD: From El Alamein To Saudi Arabia, Tank Warfare Doctrine Similar
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The confrontation of multinational forces in Saudi Arabia with Iraq in occupied Kuwait has the makings of the largest tank battle since the classic World War II struggle at Kursk on the Russian Front. Several thousand German and Russian tanks fought in that epic 1943 battle, a Russian victory that marked the German ebb on the Eastern Front. Iraq has about 430,000 troops in Kuwait, bolstered by an estimated 3,500 Soviet-designed tanks, ranging from the aging T-54 to the more advanced T-72. They face more than 300,000 troops in the U.S.-led multinational force with a tank strength expected to reach 1,800 by the end of the month. This month marks the anniversaries of two other famous tank battles that helped change the course of wars - El Alamein in the Egyptian desert in 1942 and Israel's armored thrust against the Egyptians across the Suez Canal in the 1973 Yom Kippur conflict. The British victory at El Alamein, in which several hundred tanks on both sides were deployed, turned the tide against Adolf Hitler in the Middle East. That epic battle pitted British Gen. Bernard Montgomery's Eighth Army against the vaunted Afrika Korps of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, the ``Desert Fox.'' The British 7th Armored Brigade, the successors of Montgomery's 7th Armored Division known as the ``Desert Rats,'' are now deploying in Saudi Arabia with their Challenger 1 tanks. The tanks may now be high-tech leviathans, but the tactics differ little from those used back in World War II, veterans of desert tank warfare say. October is also the anniversary of the 1973 Middle East war, in which Israeli armored columns crossed the Suez Canal and encircled the entire Egyptian 3rd Army in a classic tank operation. An estimated 1,200 Israeli and Egyptians tanks were involved. The men who fought in El Alamein and the 1973 conflict say one constant factor in desert tank warfare is the need for air power. ``When Montgomery took over, the first thing he did was to move Royal Air Force headquarters alongside his own headquarters,'' said retired British Army Col. Michael Jeffery, who fought in the Western Desert campaigns. ``If you've got air superiority, you have freedom of action, and to attack the supply lines, which is also important. At El Alamein it was complete air superiority,'' he recalled. Zev Eitan, who served in Israel's tank forces in the 1948, 1956, 1967 and 1973 Arab-Israeli wars and a veteran of the Suez tank battle, noted: ``In 1967 ... once we had mastery of the sky our air force could help and we just had to follow to exploit the success of the air force.'' Air superiority was also important in the 1973 war, ``since in the desert you don't have so much cover,'' he said. Eitan was a battalion commander in the 1973 conflict and is now a consultant at Israel's Jaffe Center for Strategic Studies. The Iraqi forces of Saddam Hussein are deployed in defensive positions behind a shield of anti-tank ditches, earthworks and minefields. The Iraqis are master military engineers, whose dig-in tactics were perfected during their 1980-88 war with neighboring Iran. For most of that war, however, Iraqi tanks were used in a static role as artillery rather than in the running battles that Western forces are trained to fight. Tanks of the multinational force include U.S.-built M60s and the top-of-the-line Abrams tank in several configurations, as well as the Desert Rats' up-to-date British Challenger tanks. The multinational force tanks are generally far more advanced than those of the Iraqis, whose T-54 is based on a 1947 Soviet model. ``Technology makes a vast difference,'' said Jeffery. ``Ours is better than Saddam's.'' Providing air cover for the the multinational force tanks are hundreds of ground-attack jets and tank-killer helicopters. Iraq also has hundreds of ground-attack jets and attack helicopters, but it is unclear how many could be used for armor support operations. Since Iraq has a two-to-one edge in tanks, another major factor - especially in an area where resupply is problematic - is retaining control of the battlefield once the running clash of steel has subsided. ``This is important in armored warfare, because not all tanks hit are a total loss,'' said Eitan. ``If you remain in control of the battlefield you can repair some of your tank casualties.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Change Tactics in New Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Two attacks on key military garrisons appear to signal the beginning of a major rebel offensive, but it might not be the sort of onslaught the guerrillas initiated out last year. Residents of the capital have been on edge since the end of the rainy season, the period starting in the fall when most guerrilla offensives have begun during the 11-year-old civil war. Last November, guerrillas mounted an assault in parts of the capital that continued for three weeks and was their biggest offensive of the war. Military and rebel sources indicate the pattern of this year's attacks might be different. Instead of entrenching themselves in densely populated neighborhoods, the guerrillas plan an escalating series of hit-and-run attacks on selected military targets, the sources say. A more sustained effort to rout the armed forces might follow the attacks, the sources say. The new rebel campaign opened with a thunderous 20-minute mortar barrage early Oct. 17 on the main air force base at Ilopango, on the city's eastern edge. Nearly two hours of combat between paratroopers and retreating rebels ensued. The firefight struck panic in residents of the eastern neighborhoods, where the fighting in last year's offensive was fiercest. But by dawn the zone had returned to relative normalcy. The attack on Ilopango left five soldiers wounded and damaged six helicopters, according to the air force. The rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front said it had damaged 24 helicopters. The capital was rattled again Tuesday afternoon by two powerful explosions - a botched guerrilla attack on the military compound in the city's southern sector that houses the Defense Ministry and the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Both homemade mortar rounds fell some 150 yards short of their target, onto a private house. The mortars killed two children and wounded three adults. Rumors of an offensive have been circulating since July. The army has been on a high state of alert for months, cancelling leaves, stepping up patrols, beefing up base security and setting up new checkpoints and roadblocks. Hours before the attack on Ilopango, the defense minister, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce said in a televised interview: ``We have good information that they (the rebels) are indeed preparing an offensive of a type different from that of last year. According to our information, it is going to be more selective and will involve more firepower.'' FMLN leaders say the offensive is aimed at spurring talks to end the war. ``It will be necessary to carry out extraordinary military operations, to increase the level of military action in order to give impetus to peace negotiations,'' said Salvador Samayoa, an FMLN leader, said last week. Representatives of the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the FMLN have held five rounds of peace talks since May. The talks, scheduled to resume Nov. 4 in Mexico, have bogged down over bitterly differing positions on the future role of the armed forces. In an effort to force both sides to the bargaining table, the U.S. Senate voted Friday to halve the $85 million aid package to El Salvador's military and promised to cut aid altogether if the government withdrew from peace talks. If the rebelsfail to demonstrate good faith in negotiations - or launch a major offensive - the slashed $42.5 million would be restored. An earlier version of the bill would have restored the aid if the rebels refused a government offer for a cease-fire, but it was rejected. The rebels say there is no point in a cease-fire until negotiations have achieved major changes in Salvadoran society. They want a drastic purge and reduction of the armed forces in exchange for their own demoblization. The government says it will not agree to measures that undermine the armed forces' integrity, and insists that the military do any housecleaning it deems necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Speculation Abounds About Dole's Replacement as Labor Secretary
With PM-Cabinet Merry-Go-Round, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Three high-ranking women in the Bush administration and a House member are among the names being mentioned as possible successors to Elizabeth Dole as secretary of labor. Mrs. Dole, 54, became the first of President Bush's Cabinet secretaries to depart when she resigned Wednesday to become president of the American Red Cross. The White House said it had not settled on a possible nominee or talked to any of the likely contenders. ``We continue to look at candidates and consider people and search for the best person,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. One person frequently mentioned is Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., should she lose her bid to oust Democratic Sen. Paul Simon in the Nov. 6 election. Asked if Martin was on the list, Fitzwater replied, ``Everybody's on the list.'' Other possible contenders that consistently come up are: Constance Newman, head of the Office of Personnel Management; Elaine Chao, who holds the No. 2 job at the Transportation Department; and Constance Horner, undersecretary of health and human services. Horner also served as OPM director under former President Reagan. Observers speculated that if Newman, who oversees the government's 2.4-million-member workforce, were to get the nod, Bush might look to Social Security Administrator Gwen King to replace her at OPM. That would allow the administration to promote two black women at the same time. A Labor Department aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said officials did not expect Bush to name a successor at least until after Election Day. That way, if a loyal Republican making a bid for higher office lost, the president could reward him or her with a Cabinet job, the aide said. In addition, officials noted there was no rush to fill the job because Mrs. Dole will remain on the job until Nov. 23. In addition, if Congress adjourns this week as scheduled, the Senate - which must confirm any Cabinet secretary - wouldn't be back until January to give its approval, anyway. At a White House news conference Wednesday, Mrs. Dole said the choice of her successor was ``up to the president ... What the president and I have discussed, I think, has to remain between the two of us.'' Mrs. Dole, who is the highest-ranking woman in the administration, said that after 25 years of government service, she was looking forward to focusing on humanitarian causes at her new job at the American Red Cross. She denied she had been frozen out by White House policymakers. Aides and union leaders have said she had little clout at Bush's Cabinet table, and many labor policy decisions were left to presidential chief of staff John Sununu. ``I can't imagine who was saying this ... Most definitely, I feel very much a part of the circle that's making the decisions here at the White House,'' Mrs. Dole said after announcing her resignation with the president at her side. Later, in an interview, Mrs. Dole testily labeled those reports ``totally erroneous.'' ``It's been a wonderful relationship,'' she said of her ties to White House aides. She said such officials as Sununu and budget director Richard Darman naturally have a close working relationship with the president. ``But my issues, obviously, I'm the one carrying the ball, I'm the one developing the strategy,' she said. Mrs. Dole, wife of Senate Republican leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., also denied that she might use the $185,000-a-year Red Cross position to lay the groundwork for long-term political goals. ``I'm on my way to the Red Cross. I have no plans to run for anything,'' she said. Rumors have been rampant that she would eventually step down to run in 1992 for the Senate seat now held by Democrat Terry Sanford of her native North Carolina. In the interview, she did not rule out some future bid for elective office, saying, ``You learn in this town never to say never.''

DOC.HEAD: NFU Says Study Shows Farm Bill Will Cut Income
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Daryll in 2nd graf correct
DOC.TEXT: A new study finds that farmers will be in for some harder times under the 1990 farm bill, the National Farmers Union says. The analysis by economist Daryll Ray of Oklahoma State University shows that a farmer with a 350-acre wheat base and a net income of $15,787 in 1990 could see income drop more than $1,000 in 1991, based on current prices and costs. By 1995, the fifth year of the new farm bill, the annual reduction in net income from current levels would be nearly $4,000, according to the study distributed Wednesday by the farm organization. The reduction in net income would result mostly from provisions in the legislation that reduce the amount of acreage eligible for government deficiency payments. Those are subsidies to make up the difference between market prices and target levels. The acreage cuts involved a ``triple base'' option so farmers can plant what they choose on that acreage. Those crops, however, are not eligible for deficiency payments. Specific cuts in the commodity programs were provided in the farm bill but were also tied to the passage of the budget-reduction measure that is aimed at cutting federal spending by $500 billion over the next five years. The Agriculture Department's share of that reduction is $13.6 billion and includes the cutbacks in commodity price support operations cited in the study circulated by the National Farmers Union. ``I don't know how anybody who purports to represent farmers - be they in Congress, in the administration or in farm and commodity organizations - could support this farm bill,'' NFU President Leland Swenson said in a statement. ``It will absolutely devastate rural America, and these numbers show the unfair share of budget cuts farmers would shoulder.'' In all, according to the NFU, deficit reduction may cost the average taxpayer as much as $100 to $300 per year. But farmers, who also are taxpayers, may end up contributing many times those amounts because of reduced income. Most farm organizations have been saying all along that the $13.6 billion reduction in USDA programs over five years will mean reductions in net farm income. The National Farmers Organization, for example, said last week that the low-price policies advocated by the Bush administration were bargaining tools in the current negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. NFO President DeVon R. Woodland said the drive by the administration to get the European Community to go along with subsidy cutbacks will fail and that Congress will have to reconsider the farm bill after the GATT talks end on Dec. 31. The National Grange has said the $13.6 billion cut ordered for USDA programs represented ``unilateral disarmament'' by the United States in the trade talks. The Grange's national master, Robert Barrow, said the costs of trimming the budget deficit should be borne more equitably. Rob Nooter of the American Farm Bureau Federation's Washington office said Wednesday that the farm bill and its tie to the $500 billion budget-reduction package is ``certainly going to have an impact on farm income.'' Some of the income lost from reduced deficiency payments will be made up by other features of the 1990 farm bill, but not all of it, he said. Federation President Dean Kleckner said last week that he wasn't happy with all of the farm bill but urged its adoption. ``Although farm program budget cuts are disproportionate, and we accept them with great reluctance, the bill will continue agricultural market orientation and give farmers greater planting flexibility,'' he said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The 1990 farm law will be a prime topic of discussion as the Agriculture Department unlimbers its annual outlook conference next month. It will be the 67th USDA meeting for economists, farm leaders, commodity experts and others to look at what may be forthcoming in the year ahead. This year's session is Nov. 27-29. The opening day will include talks by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleberger, conference officials said Wednesday. They will be followed by Sidney L. Jones, assistant secretary of the treasury for economic policy, who will present the economic outlook for 1991. USDA officials will discuss prospects for farmers, consumers and agricultural exports. Other first-day events will include a panel discussion on European and Soviet Union affairs. Commodity prospects and the outlok under new farm legislation will be highlights during the remainder of the conference, along with environmental and energy issues. Among the forecasts will be USDA's first for consumer food prices in 1991, and its predictions for exports and farm income. The impact of higher oil prices will be a major factor in the 1991 farm income forecast. Energy also will be important in looking ahead at retail food prices. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Production of farm-raised catfish dropped 9 percent last month from a year earlier to 27.6 million pounds, according to a monthly report by the Agriculture Department. However, the report said the average price paid by processors to growers in September was 78 cents per pound, up 13 cents from a year ago. On a cumulative basis, catfish farmers delivered about 277.8 million pounds of catfish to processors through September, compared with 255.3 million pounds in the same nine months of 1989. Imports of freshwater catfish, mostly from Brazil, are down from a year ago. The report said imports in August, the most recent month calculated, totaled 362,000 pounds, down 14 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 20th graf to add first reference to Hatfield, -In Oregon,
DOC.HEAD: GOP Situation Looks Tough; Bush Being Blamed
DOC.TEXT: Republicans are bracing themselves for Election Day losses and conservatives are ready to lay the blame at the feet of President Bush. With less than two weeks remaining before the polls open, polling data from a wide range of states points to growing support for Democratic candidates. ``A month ago I would have said we were going to win one or two seats in the Senate,'' said David Keene, a Republican political consultant and conservative activist. ``I think now we're going to lose two and it could be more.'' Keene also predicted Wednesday that GOP losses in the House ``would be a lot worse than anybody thought.'' And, he said, ``it's traceable to one person and that's the president of the United States.'' Lyn Nofziger, White House political director during the Reagan administration, said he thought the election was breaking for the Democrats and that one problem was that ``if I'm an independent voter, if I'm not a party erson, George Bush hasn't given me much reason to go out and support his party.'' Going into the election, Democrats control the Senate by a margin of 55-45 and the House by 258-176. Republicans had hoped to trim the Senate margin and hold their House losses to fewer than 10 seats. But the budget negotiations proved a disaster for Republicans. Conservatives rebelled against Bush's decision to drop his hard-line opposition to any tax increases and helped defeat a compromise package worked out between the White House and the congressional leadership. Then the president appeared unable to make up his mind on whether he would or would not agree to increasing the tax load on the rich.
