While all that was happening, the Democrats succeeded in reinforcing a public perception of the Republicans as the party that cared more about the wealthy than the middle class. Douglas Bailey, a Republican media consultant, called the long-running budget negotiations ``a mild form of disaster for Republicans.'' ``The president's image is awful,'' said Bailey. ``The president does not look in charge.'' ``There does seem to be a marked movement toward the Democratic Party, largely because of the fairness issue,'' said Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa. In a recent Newsweek poll, 65 percent of the people said they thought Bush was ``more concerned about wealthy Americans than he should be.'' ``In the last 10 days Republicans have taken a nosedive,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., who believed the Republicans should hold to a hard line against tax increases. ``It's not possible for the Republican Party to win the public relations battle over fairness,'' said Weber. ``People are inclined to believe that the Republican Party is the party of the rich more than the Democratic Party.'' The Minnesota congressman said that ``my advice to every Republican candidate is to get back to Republican basics.'' The White House showed some displeasure Wednesday at the growing tendency, an almost frantic scramble, by Republican candidates to put some distance between themselves and the president. ``If they can sleep with their conscience, let them try,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Poll results that have Republicans nervous include these: -In Oregon, Democrat Harry Lonsdale leads Sen. Mark Hatfield 50 to 44 percent in a survey conducted late last week. A new survey in the governor's race has Democrat Barbara Roberts taking a four-point lead over Republican Dave Frohnmayer. Bidding for a fifth Senate term, Hatfield got 67 percent of the vote six years ago. Lonsdale, a wealthy businessman, began the race as a virtually unknown long-shot. -In Minnesota, a new poll shows Democrat Paul Wellstone pulling to within 3 points of Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who began the campaign rated one of the safe Republicans. Boschwitz aides insist their internal polls say it isn't that close. -Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., who was looking like a possible victim of virulent anti-incumbent sentiment, holds a 14-point lead over Republican challenger Jim Rappaport. The race was a dead heat in polls two weeks ago. -Also in Massachusetts, a new survey puts Democrat John Silber six points ahead of Republican William Weld in the race for governor. -In Ohio, Democrat Tony Celebrezze said an internal poll shows him leading Republican George Voinovich in the race for governor. Independent polls have said Voinovich was holding a double-digit lead through most of the race. -Democrat Harvey Gantt continues to lead Republican Sen. Jesse Helms in North Carolina. The latest survey put Gantt's lead at eight points.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: What has kept Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward married for 32 years? Eternal love? Undying affection? Try sheer luck. The Newmans, breaking a policy of not talking about their marriage, told Parade magazine they don't know why they've stayed together. ``Our marriage hasn't been a bed of roses,'' Newman said in the magazine's Oct. 28 issue. ``Sometimes you get terminally irritated, and at one point I just packed up and left.'' Asked why she thought their marriage had lasted, Woodward said: ``I have no idea. Absolutely not one single idea onthe subject. Probably sheer luck.'' And what about the time Newman packed up and left? ``I was gone about 15 minutes,'' Newman said. ``And I stopped and thought to myself, `What the hell am I doing? I have no place to go!' And I turned around and came right back. Joanne's right. She said it. What we've got is sheer luck!'' --- CHICAGO (AP) - Always-on-tour comedian Jay Leno says he has become so good at his routine he can do it in his sleep. ``When I do two two-hour shows, which is fairly often, I get into the rhythm of the thing and I fall asleep on stage,'' Leno, a regular host on ``The Tonight Show,'' said in the December issue of Playboy. ``I just plain go out for about 40 minutes and then come back in again and drift in and out. My wife knows when I'm asleep. But I don't think anybody else does.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - David Cassidy still sports the long, shaggy hairdo of Keith Partridge - plus a few gray hairs - but wants to shed his old teeny-bopper image with a comeback album. The former star of television's ``The Partridge Family'' would just as soon forget such early-'70s pop hits as ``I Think I Love You.'' He said he hopes listeners will see his serious side with his new album, ``David Cassidy.'' ``I was really naive enough to think people won't assume the music I'm playing on the show and that light, fluffy sort of airhead character was really me,'' he said Wednesday. After leaving songwriting and television, Cassidy raised racehorses and worked in theater after a few solo album failures. --- ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (AP) - James Michener says he plans to keep on writing five hours a day while he spends his winters teaching and taking part in a college program for 216 retired professionals and their spouses. The author said Wednesday that he and his wife, Mari, have settled on the Academy of Senior Professionals at Eckerd College in which to pass their time from October to February. They had looked at about 40 possibilities. ``It's what people my age look for,'' said Michener, 83. ``We know a mere quiescent retirement is quite often fatal. ... I try to keep my mind active.'' The author of such novels as ``Hawaii,'' ``Chesapeake,'' ``Centennial'' and ``Texas'' announced earlier this year he had written his last big book. The Micheners plan to live from February until mid-May at the University of Texas at Austin, where he is professor emeritus. The rest of the year they will spend at Brunswick, Maine. --- MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. (AP) - Game show host Bob Barker and an animal rights group want people to boycott a film in which horses jump from a 10-foot platform into an 11-foot-deep tank of water. ``Wild Hearts Can't Be Broken,'' which is being filmed here, is about a woman who jumped into the ocean on horseback from a pier at Atlantic City, N.J., during the 1930s. Lou Phillips, production executive for the movie, said producers have gone beyond American Humane Association standards in the care of the horses, and no injuries have been reported. The jump ``may be acceptable to the producers, may be acceptable to the association, but if the horses could speak, I'd bet it would not be acceptable to them,'' Barker said Tuesday. Barker, a longtime animal rights activist, works with the Coalition to Protect Animals in Entertainment. Since forming in 1987, the coalition has called for the boycott of 10 movies, including ``Project X,'' ``The Bear,'' ``Young Guns II'' and ``Days of Thunder.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Reinstated At EPA After Disclosure Of Tobacco Lobbying
DOC.TEXT: An anti-smoking group praised the Environmental Protection Agency for reinstating a scientist who had been dismissed from an advisory panel under pressure from the tobacco industry. The EPA said Wednesday that Dr. David Burns of the University of California at San Diego had been reinstated to a panel on the health effects of others' smoke. Mark Pertschuk, executive director of Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights in Berkeley, Calif., said he was delighted with the decision. ``I think it was the only ethical thing at this point that they could do,'' he said. ``To have given in to the tobacco industry would have been a horrible statement about the impartiality of the peer review process.'' But an industry spokeswoman complained that Burns' reinstatement would endanger the panel's ability to do its work fairly. ``David Burns cannot be considered to be an objective party in this issue and that is very well documented,'' said Tobacco Institute spokeswoman Brennan Dawson. ``We have a panelist that doesn't belong.'' Burns said he was pleased by the turn of events. ``I think it reflects the EPA reconsidering the importance of the public policy decision they were making,'' he said. ``I think that the information they received from the press and the scientific community was that there was a tremendous concern about the influence of the tobacco industry on this kind of scientific panel.'' Burns has worked on the Surgeon General's reports on the dangers of smoking since the 1970s. He was editor of the 1986 report on passive smoking. He was dismissed recently from a panel chosen to review two forthcoming EPA reports on the health effects of second-hand cigarette smoke. The tobacco industry and Rep. Thomas Bliley, R-Va., a tobacco industry ally, had lobbied vigorously to remove Burns from the committee of the EPA's Scientific Advisory Board, a standing group of independent experts. Steven Bayard, manager of the EPA's project on passive smoking, said he had never such a response to industry pressure in his 12 years at the EPA. After the success of the tobacco industry's lobbying effort was disclosed last week, Donald Barnes, the Scientific Advisory Board's staff director, asked the board's executive committee to advise him on whether to reappoint Burns, according to EPA officials who spoke on condition they not be named. The executive committee voted unanimously to reinstate Burns, the officials said. Barnes did not return telephone calls to his office. Burns was originally told on Aug. 10 that he had been appointed to the panel, and had received drafts of the passive smoking reports before his ouster. The panel's job is to review the reports to assure their scientific accuracy. The Tobacco Institute wrote EPA Administrator William Reilly on Aug. 10 protesting Burns' selection. ``Frankly, we are mystified how an individual with Dr. Burns' long and intense involvement with the anti-smoking movement can be expected to contribute to a reasonable, objective examination,'' the letter said. Bliley didn't mention Burns by name in his letter to the EPA on Sept. 18 but said the panel should ``consist of qualified individuals who have not already prejudged this issue in any manner.'' EPA officials said they understood that to be an objection to Burns.

DOC.HEAD: Job Bias Battle Resuming Next Year
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights forces plan a fresh fight next year for the job discrimination bill that President Bush vetoed on grounds it would result in hiring quotas. ``Like MacArthur, we shall return ... and we expect to win,'' civil rights leader Benjamin Hooks said Wednesday after the Senate sustained the veto by a one-vote margin. Eleven Republicans joined 55 Democrats as the Senate voted 66-34 for the override. It thus fell one vote short of the two-thirds needed to enact the bill despite the president's objections. It was Bush's 16th veto in 21 months as president. He has been sustained in all 11 override attempts by Congress. Hooks, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the bill as introduced next year would be similar or identical to the 1990 version. Six Supreme Court decisions that caused a furor when they were handed down last year would be negated under the bill. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in the most extreme discrimination cases. Bush said he wanted to sign a civil rights bill and was willing to go along with a ban on harassment along with other provisions. But he would not agree to intricate features that would make it easier to win race and sex discrimination cases against employers. He said they were so stringent that employers would turn to quota hiring to provide themselves with a ready-made defense if sued for discrimination. Sponsors denied to the end that the bill would result in quotas. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., called the quota argument ``a sham.'' ``The president has taken the low road on civil rights, but that is no reason for the Senate to take it, too,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said in a last-ditch appeal for support. But Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said the bill would enable ``lawyers to reap huge profits in the name of racial justice'' and result in ``quotas, quotas, quotas and more employment quotas.'' Republican critics of the bill expressed dismay that they were not able to vote on a more moderate measure. But they said the bill vetoed by Bush would go too far. ``It swings the pendulum too far against employers and in favor of employees,'' said Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., a supporter of the bill, suggested that a vote to sustain Bush could unseat some senators up for re-election. And Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., suggested the president could persuade voters his veto was a necessity. ``If he can't convince people it is a quota bill, then I think it's a loser for him,'' Packwood said. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said it as ``a political move to try to get to conservative, Democratic, blue-collar workers. I think it's Bush listening to his political advisers, and shame on him. It was a cold political decision.'' Former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke, a Republican state legislator in Louisiana, watched the proceedings from a front-row seat in the Senate visitor's gallery. Duke, who this month lost his bid for a U.S. Senate seat, told reporters he was opposed to the bill because it would ``discriminate against qualified white Americans.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Duke's appearance ``has nothing to do with us. We disavow David Duke in every way, shape or form. Absolutely.''

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Volunteer Service Bill Despite Complaints Over Cost
DOC.TEXT: Congress is sending President Bush a bill calling for $287 million in new spending to encourage volunteerism and community service, turning aside complaints about the cost. Bush is expected to sign the legislation, its House and Senate sponsors say. The compromise National and Community Service Act passed the House on a 235-186 vote Wednesday. The Senate approved the agreement last week after it emerged from a congressional conference committee. ``This bill, at least for now, signals a change from the `Me Generation' of the 1980s to a community service ethic I hope will pervade America in the 1990s,'' said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. Republicans attacked the bill as unwarranted and wasteful spending at a time when Congress was struggling with a bill to raise taxes. Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., said Congress was wrong to authorize such new spending when budget constraints have prevented it from fully funding existing programs for children and the poor. ``Has the Congress of the United States gone bonkers?'' asked Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. ``People wonder why the American public is upset with the Congress,'' he said. ``I'll tell you why they're upset - because they don't understand this kind of drunkenness with new bureaucracy and new spending.'' Only 22 Republicans joined Democrats in supporting the bill; 41 Democrats opposed it. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., praised the bill as ``a call to action for the nation.'' John Buchanan, head of the liberal group People for the American Way, commended Bush's support for the measure and said not since John Kennedy has a president championed community service as Bush has. The bill authorizes spending $62 million in the current fiscal year, $105 million in fiscal 1992 and $120 million in fiscal 1993 for national and community service programs. A part of the measure is a $5 million authorization to begin a Thousand Points of Light Foundation to encourage volunteerism, taking its name from Bush's phrase for volunteers. Among the key elements: -A new part-time program encouraging community service by young people, established through schools and community organizations such as the YMCA or the United Way. It would encourage adults to volunteer in schools and community-based service programs. Money would go in grants to state education agencies, which would distribute it to schools and service groups. -An expansion of youth corps programs to increase fulltime service opportunities. Young people would be put in teams to work on projects cleaning the environment, helping the hungry and homeless and aiding the poor. Some 60 conservation or youth corps programs now are operating locally. -A program to encourage colleges to make community service programs available to their students. -A greatly reduced version of a civilian national service corps proposed two years ago by Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and Charles Robb, D-Va. A test program would provide $5,000 in education assistance in return for a year's full-time service at a subsistence wage. Also available would be $1,000 for education or home down payment in exchange for a year of part-time civilian service, to be matched by another $1,000 from the state.

DOC.HEAD: Architects of Korean War Memorial Say Government Ruined Design
DOC.TEXT: Four architects who won a $20,000 contest to design a Korean War veterans' memorial saw the government turn the plan into a battle scene that glorifies war, their lawyer says. ``Architects have to have some faith that when they enter a design competition and win, then that's what it's going to be,'' attorney Robert Sokolove said in an interview Wednesday. ``You can't change the rules in the middle.'' Particularly galling to the architects is that the new version depicts soldiers in battle-ready positions, Sokolove said. The original plan called for ``a dream-like'' collection of 38 soldiers moving, some unevenly, across a remote landscape toward an American flag. The architects are fighting to have the original design restored. Sokolove said he learned of the changes two months ago when they were presented by a Washington architectural firm that he thought had been retained only to implement the earlier plans. But Col. William Ryan, director of operations and finance for the American Battle Monuments Commission, said Wednesday that the new model ``is so far superior to the other design, it's unbelievable.'' The commission erects and maintains memorials honoring American soldiers. The new design retains the essential elements of the old one, adding a pool, pathways and benches and cutting back bushes - all to accommodate large numbers of visitors, Ryan said. Sokolove said the new, circular pathways ``look like an I-95 interchange.'' He represents four Pennsylvania State University architects who beat out 1,018 competitors last year to design the memorial across the Reflecting Pool from the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial. President Bush was the guest of honor as a one-eighth scale model was unveiled at the White House on June 14, 1989. The entry was declared the winner of a $20,000 prize by a jury of Korean War veterans. The soldiers were to show ``the experience of moving into and through war,'' according to the architects' original design statement. But the redesign ``no longer alludes to the struggle and sacrifice of walking a hostile landscape, but instead glorifies war'' by depicting a battle, said a statement delivered by the architects to President Bush's aides last month. The changes were ordered by the National Capital Planning Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts and the Interior Department, Ryan said. Also playing a role in the final design, he said, were Korean War veterans serving on the panel that selected the design. ``The main thing is the 38 heroic statues of ground combat personnel. They're still there,'' Ryan said. He said the final design was submitted by the Cooper-Lecky architectural firm of Washington. Sokolove said the government was still using a photograph of the original design to raise funds for the project. But Ryan said that is only because photos of the new model are not ready. Originally budgeted at $6 million, the memorial is now expected to cost $14.9 million, according to Ryan. Organizers hope to have a dedication in 1993. Some 5.7 million Americans served in Korea during the 1950-53 conflict, and more than 54,000 were killed. The controversy recalls the designing of the Vietnam War memorial. A vocal group backed by then-Interior Secretary James Watt opposed the 1982 design as unheroic. The group won a concession when a statue of three soldiers was added in 1984 near the V-shaped wall bearing the names of more than 58,000 Americans killed in the war.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Resigns; Faced Second Sexual Misconduct Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Donald E. Lukens' final days in Congress were spent out of public view, on the telephone with people urging him to resign rather than face a second sexual misconduct investigation. He didn't appear at the House on Tuesday or Wednesday. He slipped out of his congressional office Monday, before the House ethics committee announced it had reopened his case because of a new complaint that he sexually harassed a Capitol elevator operator. Lukens' last official action was a letter of resignation transmitted to Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste shortly after 11:30 a.m. Wednesday: ``Effective immediately, for the good of the Congress and the integrity of the institution, I resign my seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. Sincerely, Buz.'' A top aide said Lukens stayed away from Capitol Hill but kept in contact with supporters, staff, his attorney and party leaders via telephone. House Republican Leader Robert Michel was among those who convinced Lukens, defeated for renomination in Ohio's May primary, that he faced an expulsion vote unless he stepped down. Ethics committee spokeswoman Jan Keyes said Lukens would not have lost his retirement benefits even if he had been expelled. Lukens will qualify for a pension of more than $2,000 a month beginning in 1993. Under the federal pension system, his payment is determined by combining his congressional service with his 6{ years in the Air Force and two years on a congressional staff. Lukens resigned two days after the ethics committee revived its dormant case against him to include the new accusation that he fondled a House elevator operator earlier this month. A source who spoke with the elevator operator said she alleged that Lukens approached her more than once on the same day. After fondling her, Lukens gave the woman his business card and asked her to call him, the source said. The elevator operator reported the incident to her superiors. She was given leave with pay and assured she would not have to return to work as long as Lukens was around the Capitol, said the source, who requested anonymity. The ethics committee earlier had been examining whether Lukens had violated House rules by having sex with a 16-year-old girl - an episode that led to a misdemeanor conviction in Ohio last year. The 59-year-old congressman, who is divorced, has been free on bond while appealing to the state Supreme Court. Lukens' office operations will continue until his successor is chosen. Ohio law requires the governor to call a special election, even though only 10 weeks remain in his term. A primary must be held if more than candidate in a party files nominating petitions. The two men vying to replace Lukens both indicated they'll run in the special election. Republican nominee John Boehner is viewed as having the edge over Democrat Gregory Jolivette. If the same candidate wins both the special election and the Nov. 6 vote, he would get a leg up on the House freshman class of 1991. Office space, for instance, is determined by seniority. Thus, someone who takes office in November would be ahead of those who arrive in January. Party leaders pressed Lukens for more than a year to resign, but he ignored them. They largely reacted with relief Wednesday. ``I'm just sorry it took so long to do the right thing by the people of the 8th District,'' said Ohio GOP Chairman Robert Bennett. ``I think he was wrong to remain in office,'' said Donald Birgel, a party official from Lukens' home base, Butler County, Ohio. ``It was selfish of him.'' Lukens served in Congress from 1967 to 1970, when he made an unsuccessful attempt to gain the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Ohio. After 15 years in the state Senate, he returned to Congress in 1986. He was diagnosed as having throat cancer in 1984 and was given just weks to live, but battled back and successfully ran for Congress two years later.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Curbs Rebel Aid in Third World
DOC.TEXT: Congress is beginning a gradual winding down of U.S. support for covert conflicts in the Third World with an intelligence bill that curbs money flowing to rebels in Afghanistan, Cambodia and Angola. On a voice vote, the House on Wednesday gave its endorsement to the compromise bill, which provides roughly $30 billion for intelligence activities around the globe and institutes reforms growing out of the Iran-Contra affair. The Senate followed suit early today, sending the bill to President Bush. Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., said that while Bush does not like parts of the measure, he may ``hold his nose and let the bill become law.'' On the covert paramilitary conflicts, the bill reflected a growing congressional skepticism about such expensive and thorny involvements, and the evaporation of U.S.-Soviet tensions that was the rationale for an American role. According to sources familiar with the bill, and to limited sections made public, it: -Provides that U.S. covert weapons supplies to the UNITA rebels in Angola could be suspended if the Marxist government in Luanda agrees to free elections and a cease-fire, and the Soviet Union halts its own weapons shipments to the government. It would be up to the president to decide whether those conditions have been met. The provision was a scaled-back version of restrictions that had been adopted by the House during an unusual public debate last week on the aid program, which is technically secret. Half of the lethal aid would be put into a restricted account subject to release only on approval of the congressional intelligence committees. Weapons aid represents roughly half the $60 million annual U.S. support for the rebels. -Suspends the covert aid program to non-communist rebels fighting the Moscow-backed government of Cambodia. The program, which sources say amounts to about $13 million, will be phased out early in 1991 and converted into an open program of humanitarian aid to the rebels and to other Cambodians. Lawmakers are worried that aid to the rebels is finding its way to the infamous Khmer Rouge, who were responsible for the killings ofmmore than a million Cambodians during their rule in the late 1970s. The country's warring parties are working with the United Nations to set up a provisional government in December that would then organize national elections. -Trims aid to the mujaheddin, the rebels fighting the Soviet-backed government of Afghanistan, from Bush's request for $300 million to $250 million. That compares with $280 million last year. The aid also will be split into two six-month increments. This will give an opportunity for the United States to end the assistance at mid-year if talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze result in agreement on a mutual aid suspension. The intelligence bill also includes provisions intended to head off a recurrence of a scandal like the Iran-Contra affair, which came to public attention in 1986. The section includes a new definition of covert action: an operation undertaken by the United States in another country ``to influence political, economic or military conditions abroad'' in a way that the U.S. role is not acknowledged publicly. Under the new provisions, any covert action must be approved by the president in advance, in writing, in a document known as a ``finding.'' The finding must state that the action is necessary to support U.S. foreign policy objectives, and must be reported to congressional overseers ``in a timely fashion.'' The finding also must spell out which U.S. agencies will be involved and whether any outside party will be enlisted in the operation. The covert action may not be used to influence domestic political processes or public opinion, and may not violate the Constitution. In the Iran-Contra affair, congressional investigators found that ``a cabal of zealots'' inside the executive branch had commandeered policymaking, set up operations outside normal government controls and failed to notify Congress of efforts to trade arms for U.S. hostages in Iran and generate money to supply the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the provisions in the new bill ``really put that chapter behind us ... I'm really pleased that we now have some positive, tangible results from those long investigations that were undertaken. It is perhaps the most significant part of the bill.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Incumbents Have Huge Fund-Raising Edges
DOC.TEXT: A dozen Senate incumbents who face the voters in two weeks enjoy better than 9-to-1 fund-raising edges over opponents, according to a survey that indicates spending in a handful of Senate races has or likely will pass $10 million. In addition to the 12 senators with the whopping fund-raising advantages, another nine incumbents up for re-election had raised at least double the amounts of their challengers, Common Cause said in one of its periodic analyses of campaign finances. ``When it comes to our political system, rich incumbents are getting richer, and poor challengers are getting poorer,'' Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer said Wednesday in a statement released with the survey. In the 27 Senate races in which incumbents faced opposition, the incumbents enjoyed edges in all major fund-raising areas, Common Cause said. That includes a 4-to-1 edge in political action committee contributions. Incumbents on average were outspending challengers by more than 3-to-1, the group said. The only incumbent trailing a challenger in fund-raising was Sen. Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, a Democrat who was appointed to the seat in May. Akaka is facing his former House colleague, Republican Rep. Pat Saiki. As of Sept. 30, she had raised $883,00 to Akaka's $821,000. Common Cause, which compiled the information from the latest campaign reports to the Federal Election Commission, said four Senate incumbents with no major party opposition this fall had at least $850,000 in their campaign coffers as of Sept. 30. Common Cause is one of the major lobbying forces behind legislation designed to restrict or eliminate political action committee contributions and take other steps to cut the fund-raising advantages of incumbency. But the legislation appears dead for the year as Congress rushes to adjourn before the Nov. 6 elections. In its latest study, the organization said combined spending in several Senate races had or was heading past the $10 million mark. The costliest race so far has been the North Carolina contest between Republican Sen. Jesse Helms and Democrat Harvey Gantt. As of Sept 30, the cutoff date for the latest reports to the Federal Election Commission, Gantt and Helms had spent a combined $16.9 million. In Texas, the matchup of Democrat Hugh Parmer and heavily favored Republican Sen. Phil Gramm had cost a combined $10.9 million. Spending in the Illinois contest pitting Democratic Sen. Paul Simon against Republican Rep. Lynn Martin totaled nearly $10.7 million. The New Jersey race pitting Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley against longshot Republican Christine Todd Whitman had combined spending of $9.1 million as of Sept. 30 and spending in the Massachusetts race pitting Democratic Sen. John Kerry against GOP nominee Jim Rappaport was nearing $8 million at the filing cutoff. The dozen incumbents enjoying at least a 9-to-1 fund-raising edge heading into the final five weeks of the election cycle were: Democratic Sens. Joseph Biden of Delaware, Bradley, David Boren of Oklahoma, Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia. Also: Republican Sens. Ted Stevens of Alaska, Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota, Pete Domenici of New Mexico, Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, Gramm and Alan Simpson of Wyoming. The nine incumbents who had at least doubled the fund-raising of their challengers but not reached a 9-to-1 edge are Democrats Howard Heflin of Alabama, Simon, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Kerry, Carl Levin of Michigan and Max Baucus of Montana and Republicans Dan Coats of Indiana, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Helms. Johnston already has won his race through Louisiana's unique open primary system. Democrats Sam Nunn of Georgia and David Pryor of Arkansas and Republicans Thad Cochran of Mississippi and John Warner of Virginia face no major opposition in their re-election bids.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Trip Opens New Era in Soviet-Spanish Relations
DOC.TEXT: If Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev needs a break from economic headaches at home, he's likely to find it in the warmth of adoring Spaniards during a three-day visit that begins Friday. He also comes in search of real economic help - reciprocal agreements are ready for signing, and Madrid is offering state-guaranteed credits of up to $1 billion for the purchase of Spanish consumer and industrial goods. The first Spanish visit by a Soviet head of state aims to put relations between the two countrieson an equal footing with Moscow's ties to other major Western nations, Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez said. ``The Gorbachev visit is very important because it comes at a time of great changes in the world, especially in Europe,'' said Juan Antonio Yanez, adviser to Socialist Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. ``And it's a time when the Soviet Union finds itself at a crucial moment in its economic and political development,'' he said. Gorbachev is to be accompanied by his wife, Raisa, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevarnadze and a number of top economic, political and cultural advisers. Soviet historian Svetlana Podzarskaya, who is accompanying Gorbachev, told Spanish reporters in Moscow that both sides feel an urgency to deepen relations. ``Spain and the Soviet Union remained outside the European process of economic and political development for many years for political reasons,'' Podzarskaya said. ``Now, we both have entered. Spain did it earlier and with more success,'' she said, referring to Madrid's 1986 entry into the European Economic Community. ``We're just starting along the path.'' The Soviet leader's popularity is running particularly high in Spain in the wake of his recent Nobel Peace Prize, and opposition politicans from conservatives to traditional Communists are jockeying for photo opportunities with Gorbachev. Officials at two Madrid universities awarding him honorary degrees are battling for the right to host the joint awards ceremony. The Soviets suggested a neutral site. Gorbachev is to sign a key joint political statement underscoring the two countries' commitment to broad European unity and cooperation and strengthening of world security. ``We go to Spain in acknowledgement of Spain's creative and growing role in the development of European and non-European policy,'' Gorbachev told reporters in Moscow on Monday. ``There is a deep reserve of good feeling among Spaniards toward the Soviet Union,'' Madrid University International Relations Prof. Roberto Mesas said. ``Spaniards, particularly on the left, remember the Soviets' political and military support for the democratic 1931-39 Second Republic during the 1936-39 Civil War.'' The war was sparked by a military rebellion led by Gen. Francisco Franco and resulted in nearly 40 years of right-wing dictatorship under Franco that ended only with his death in 1975. Political parties were banned, and Communists in particular suffered from the repression. A year after Franco's death, the Communist Party was legalized. In 1977 Spain held its first democratic elections since 1936 and restored the diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union cut for four decades. ``People recall warmly the Soviet military support for the elected government during the Civil War at a time when the French and British appeared to take a non-interventionist stance that condemned Spain to dictatorship,'' Mesas said. Key accords to be signed during Gorbachev's visit include one on reciprocal investment guarantees and another on joint development of tourism, a key Spanish industry and the nation's chief foreign currency earner. Other accords will set up regular meetings between government ministers and officials, top military brass and cultural officials as well as the establishment of culture centers. Gorbachev is to meet with King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia, who made a state visit to Moscow in 1984. The Soviet leader will also meet with Gonzalez and speak before a group of parliamentarians. He also isto visit Barcelona to promote investment and view the site of the 1992 Summer Olympic Games.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir's Rejection of Bush Appeal Widens US-Israeli Rift
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Already strained U.S.-Israeli relations are under new pressures, following the Bush administration's second vote against Israel in the United Nations despite a plea for understanding from Jerusalem. Secretary of State James A. Baker III - and others in the administration who would like to see Israel negotiate with Palestinians Arabs - will try to repair the damage before it destroys any chance for getting those talks started. But Israel, which has depended on U.S. support in a world organization largely hostile to the Jewish state, is bound to feel even more anxious about risking negotiations with only the Bush administration for protection. The Security Council voted unanimously Wednesday to rebuke Israel for rejecting a U.N. mission to investigate the killings of 19 Palestinian Arabs in Jerusalem. The vote followed Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's rejection of an appeal from President Bush to allow the investigation. It was the second time the United States turned against its old friend over the Oct. 8 incident on the Temple Mount. The administration sponsored the initial Security Council resolution, adopted unanimously Oct. 12, which condemned Israel and directed U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send investigators to Jerusalem. Bush, in his letter to Shamir, urged the Israeli leader to reverse the Israeli Cabinet's decision not to cooperate in the inquiry. But Shamir and Israeli diplomats in Jerusalem and in Washington informed the administration the decision was based on two principles that could not be reversed, U.S. officials and other sources told The Associated Press on Wednesday. One was that the Security Council had already condemned Israel so the inquiry could hardly be an open-minded one. The other was that admitting the U.N. investigators could challenge the sovereignty Israel claims over all of Jerusalem as its capital. This plea for understanding was conveyed to U.S. officials in Jerusalem and in Washington. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Bush's letter expressed condolences about the violence between Israelis and Palestinians and told Shamir it was ``important to all of us to have the focus back on Iraq.'' The 19 Palestinians were slain after police used tear gas and rubber bullets in an unsuccessful attempt to stop the stoning of Jews praying at the Western Wall. The attack on the Jews was not condemned in the resolution. Israel felt it was being singled out unfairly. Its Cabinet felt that not only was the resolution one-sided, but riots at holy places in other countries with a much higher death toll are routinely ignored by the United Nations. The administration, urging Israel to cooperate with the inquiry, said it was the only way for the facts to be sorted out. The Israeli government has ordered its own investigation. A U.S. official, insisting on anonymity, said if Shamir refused to cooperate ``the mood of the council will be less solicitous than if they did.'' However, he said no resolutions apart from the renewed request had been prepared for council action. While Israelis of various political persuasions may differ on most issues, there is general unanimity that Jerusalem must remain Israel's capital. The predominantly Arab eastern sector was under Jordan's rule for 19 years until Israeli forces captured it during the 1967 Mideast war. The Cabinet's decision, and Shamir's refusal to reverse it, reflected concern that the United Nations was trying to get a foothold in the city. The United States and nearly all other nations do not recognize Israeli sovereignty over East Jerusalem. Bush has referred to it as occupied territory, and the assertion contributed to the strains between the United States and Israel. The settlement of some Soviet Jewish refugees in East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza is another sore point. The Bush administration considers settlements of Soviet refugees or any other Jews in the territories an obstacle to peace since the Arabs hope to recapture the lands they lost in the 1967 war. Like its predecessors, the administration also is committed to urging Israel to give up most if not all of the territory in exchange for Arab acceptance of the Jewish state. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid, head of the AP's State Department staff, has covered US-Israeli relations since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: The Congress That Wouldn't Die
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: One disgruntled lawmaker says he's seen the likes of the 101st Congress before. ``Think of what it would be like to watch every `Friday the 13th' movie back to back,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga. ``Freddy is hiding somewhere in the corridors.'' Like a character in a bad horror film, this Congress won't die. October 5 was the original adjournment date. Then, Oct. 12. Then the 18th. Next, well, maybe before Halloween. Congress has never pushed its session so close to an election. Credibility is nil. When word of an impending budget deal filtered through the Capitol on Wednesday, the news was greeted with a mix of skepticism and pseudo-enthusiasm. ``It's like the boy who cried wolf,'' said Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., chairman of the House Rules Committee. ``The joy will come when the speaker hits the gavel and says the final two words: sine die,'' the final adjournment, said Rep. Gary Ackerman, D-N.Y. Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., was optimistic for a weekend departure and said members were talking of little else. ``That's the number one topic - to get out of here,'' he said. Was he now overcome with enthusiasm? ``Euphoria,'' he deadpanned. ``Exhilaration. Ecstasy. Passion,'' added Rep. Charles Wilson, D-Texas. Despite frustration, lawmakers said there still was no sentiment for adjourning now and trying again to finish the year's business after the election. ``If there's a lame duck we're all dead ducks,'' said Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., adding that he was fortunate to be running for re-election unopposed this year. Not everyone was finding humor in Congress' predicament. Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., complained that lawmakers' self-flagellation wasn't helping matters. ``He that maketh himself an ass must not take it ill if men ride him,'' he reminded the Senate. And tempers were running short. When Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, was blocked early today from offering an amendment to a bill providing money to run Congress, he confronted Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla. ``This is dirty pool,'' Glenn fumed, poking his finger hard into Nickles' chest. ``You told me not to filibuster, now you filibuster.'' Glenn then stalked off the floor. Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, was a pessimist. Sitting outside the House chamber, he observed how lawmakers had nobody to blame but themselves. Less than two weeks before the election and with the public clamoring for budget action, the House had spent most of the afternoon in a turf fight between two committees on a seafood inspection bill. ``People are not just tired, they're exhausted,'' he said. ``And we spend the whole afternoon talking about fish.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Seeks Split In Western Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is offering to swap Canadian and German hostages for diplomatic visits from those countries in an effort to drive a wedge in the western alliance against Baghdad, say congressional sources. The offers were made in recent days and represent cynical attempts to use hostages as bargaining chips, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told lawmakers Wednesday in a closed-door briefing, the sources said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invited the foreign ministers of those two countries to visit his country, holding out the prospect that some of their nationals could be released if they did so, House members were told. The two Cabinet members said the overtures have failed but are signs that Saddam would like to weaken Western resolve by manipulating the hostages he holds, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the administration also described Saddam's military forces as deeply dug in along the border with Saudi Arabia, and the defensive posture belies any shift toward a genuine openness to diplomatic solutions to the standoff, said the sources. ``My view is that from time to time (Saddam) makes efforts designed purely to drive wedges between members of the coalition,'' Cheney told reporters after the briefing. ``But if you look at his deplyments, there is no indication he is preparing to withdraw.'' Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said the reported entreaties to U.S. allies ``are viewed by our guys as cynical, exploitative of the hostages, and I think Congress agrees with that assessment.'' He said Baker described the situation as like that in a political cartoon showing Saddam with bound hostages behind a sign that reads, ``The Bazaar is Open.'' The pessimism about any change in Iraq's stance was underscored by Sen. Richard Lugar, a senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who flatly predicted: ``The fact is that we're headed toward conflict.'' ``We're headed toward conflict because Saddam (Hussein) is reinforcing, as far as we can see, his forces in Kuwait, shows no sign whatsoever of giving up anything, and the United Nations is on a collision course to make sure he does give it up,'' said Lugar, R-Ind. ``I think the possibility of armed conflict depends entirely upon our ability and willingness to bring it about,'' he said. House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., also said Cheney told lawmakers there is no clear evidence that the Iraqis have learned how to operate the HAWK anti-aircraft missiles they captured in Kuwait. Aspin said Baker and Cheney had declined to discuss how they might consult with Congress, which is about to adjourn for the year, if U.S. military action is called for in the Middle East. ``If a decision is made to use military force in response to a provocation, my guess is they will do that and consult afterwards,'' Aspin told reporters. But if the international embargo does not succeed in driving Saddam from Kuwait in a reasonable time and Bush decides to issue an ultimatum to Iraq, the procedure for consulting with Congress has been left unclear, he said. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said they would reserve the right to call Congress back into session for such consultations, and announced creation of a bipartisan 18-member consultative group that would be available to consult with the president during the adjournment period.

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Aims at Chiles' Relationship With Ousted CenTrust Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez asked his Democratic opponent, former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles, to explain his relationship with ousted CenTrust chairman David Paul. Martinez's written request followed a report Tuesday in USA Today that showed Chiles on Paul's personal calendar during visits to Washington in 1987 and 1988. The Miami-based savings and loan, once the state's largest, was taken over by federal regulators in February at a loss of $1.8 billion. ``It's ridiculous innuendo in this letter,'' said Julie Fletcher, campaign spokeswoman for Chiles. ``He (Chiles) met with him once, an introductory, routine courtesy meeting,'' said Fletcher. ``They talked about CenTrust activities. A very short meeting.'' Fletcher said Chiles' records showed the 15-minute meeting sought by Paul took place Nov. 19, 1987, and was so inconsequential that Chiles initially didn't recall it.
DOC.HEAD: Hermening Wants Independent Commercials Taken Off the Air
DOC.TEXT: Republican Assembly candidate Kevin Hermening said he asked a conservative political action committee to pull about $25,000 in television commercials designed to help his campaign. But a spokeswoman for GOPAC, a political action committee for conservative U.S. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Georgia, said the ads would continue, likely right up to the Nov. 6 election. ``I've seen these ads, and they are sending the wrong message,'' said Hermening. ``I believe candidates should be able to control their own campaign messages. They should be able to do that without outside influence.'' Two Wausau television stations, WAOW and WSAW, said GOPAC purchased about $25,000 worth of advertising time for commercials for Hermening. The commercials are ``pseudo-biography spots,'' portraying Hermening's experience as a former Iranian hostage, campaign officials said. Hermening was the youngest of 52 hostages taken at the embassy in Iran in 1979 and held for 444 days. Hermening ran for Congress in 1986 and 1988 and is challenging Democratic Rep. Brad Zweck.
DOC.HEAD: Contributions Vary Greatly in Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Carroll Campbell reports he has amassed $1.85 million in campaign contributions in his re-election bid, while Democratic challenger Theo Mitchell has raised about a tenth that much. Mitchell's biggest donor is himself. A contribution list provided by the campaign shows he has given himself $24,520. Besides his own donations, Mitchell's biggest entry is from the state Democratic Party, which gave $5,000. Mitchell said that money actually came from U.S. Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., and was routed through the party. Campbell on Oct. 5 reported a long list of corporations and business executives, the largest being $60,000 from the Macalloy Corp. of North Charleston, a large defense contractor.
DOC.HEAD: Nelson To Pull Ads; Orr Campaign Criticizes Move
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ben Nelson's withdrawal of broadcast advertising that mentions Gov. Kay Orr's name is hypocritical, a spokesman for Mrs. Orr's campaign said Wednesday. Nelson said he is canceling all television and radio ads that mention Mrs. Orr's name or make negative references to her. Nelson asked Mrs. Orr to do the same by noon Thursday, in keeping with an agreement the candidates for governor reached during their Tuesday debate in Lincoln. ``This is the most hypocritical thing we've seen by Ben Nelson and his media thugs,'' Mrs. Orr's campaign manager, Scott Matter, said from Lincoln. ``Nelson's been swinging a heavy ax for several months. Now he's saying, `Forget all that and have a positive campaign,''' Matter said.

DOC.HEAD: 14-Year-Old Who Set Boy on Fire Convicted of Attempted Murder
DOC.TEXT: A neighborhood bully was convicted of attempted murder for tying up a 12-year-old boy and setting him on fire during a robbery that left his victim scarred for life. The defendant, a 14-year-old who appears much older, was also found guilty Wednesday of kidnapping, robbery and other offenses in the March 7 attack on David Opont. ``There could be no other conclusion than he secreted (David), tied him hand and foot and he set him on fire,'' ruled Family Court Judge Joseph A. Esquirol Jr., who presided over the non-jury trial. The older boy ``intended to and did in fact severely and permanently disfigure David,'' the judge said. Authorities said the teen-ager, whose name was withheld because of his age, was known in his Brooklyn neighborhood as a bully who taunted and stole from smaller children. Under juvenile law, he can be confined to a detention center for three years, but the sentence can be extended each year afterward until he is 21. Esquirol also ordered the boy to undergo psychological tests. The attack shocked the city and evoked an outpouring of sympathy and get-well messages from across the nation. While in the hospital, David was visited by former President Reagan, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and several entertainment and sports figures. In September, David, frail but recovering from his attack, stood and pointed out his attacker in the courtroom. He said the boy stopped him and a companion as they walked to school and searched their pockets for money. The bully then took him into an abandoned building, bound him and set him on fire after he refused to smoke something offered him, David said. David and his parents were not in the courtroom when the verdict was returned Wednesday, but he issued a statement later saying, ``I am looking forward to my life and all the challenge it brings.'' David, who moved with his family from Haiti two years ago, suffered severe burns over much of his body and was initially given less than a 50 percent chance of survival. After several skin grafts, he was released from the hospital in August but is still undergoing extensive rehabilitation.

DOC.HEAD: Special Prosecutor Accuse Attorney General of Abuse
DOC.TEXT:
Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh claims the CIA and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh abused secrecy procedures to frustrate the prosecution of a former CIA agent. ``The attorney general and the CIA not only frustrated the public development'' of evidence against former CIA agent Joseph Fernandez, ``but did so in a manner that exasperated the district court and dragged out the resolution of this issue in unproductive litigation,'' Walsh charged Wednesday in a report on the case. Walsh issued his report nearly two weeks after Thornburgh effectively ended the prosecution by reaffirming his determination to block the release of secrets that the judge had already said Fernandez was entitled to use in his defense. The documents at issue showed the location of CIA facilities in Central America and detailing agency operations in Costa Rica. The Justice Department quoted an administration official as saying release of such information would strike a ``devastating'' blow to national security. Thornburgh's action marked the first time that an attorney general's use of a provision of the Classified Information Procedures Act had blocked a prosecution.
---
DOC.HEAD: Gore Seeks Curbs On Genetic Screening
DOC.TEXT:
Congress should safeguard workers' rights before employers begin widespread screening for genetic diseases, says Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn. Gore released a report Wednesday by the Office of Technology Assessment which showed that few U.S. companies now require genetic testing of their employees and applicants. But he said Congress should move now, before the practice becomes more widespread, to head off discrimination against workers on the basis of genetic characteristics. ``To a large extent there are few clear guidelines on how these tests can be used or how workers can be protected from having their rights violated,'' said Gore, who requested the report. Genetic screening can help save lives by alerting an employer to a worker's susceptibility to a particular occupational exposure, the report noted. But it expressed concern that employers might deny jobs to anyone whose tests show they are at risk of genetic disease and could prove a burden to a company's health insurance program. Genetic tests are available to detect sickle cell anemia, cystic fibrosis, Huntington's disease, hemophilia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy and other diseases. Future tests could screen for such things as hypertension, dyslexia, Alzheimer's disease and cancer, the report said.
---
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Chief Of Staff Nominee Says Fired Predecessor Made Honest
DOC.TEXT: Mistake

The Air Force general named to replace the chief of staff ousted for public comments about U.S. contingency plans against Iraq says his predecessor made an ``honest mistake.'' Gen. Merrill A. McPeak told the Senate Armed Services Committee his colleague erred in discussing issues within the president's bailiwick and speaking on the record with news reporters for 15 consecutive hours. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney fired Gen. Michael Dugan on Sept. 17, one day after Dugan's statements about contingency plans to unleash massive air raids on Iraq and target Saddam Hussein personally appeared in newspapers. Cheney said Dugan had violated Pentagon rules by publicly discussing likely military targets inside Iraq and disclosing classified information about the size of U.S. forces in the gulf area. ``It was an honest mistake on his part, nevertheless a mistake. I'll certainly seek to avoid making the same mistake,'' McPeak told the panel at his confirmation hearing. Lawmakers indicated no opposition to the nominee, a 54-year-old nativeof Santa Rosa, Calif., who is commander-in-chief of forces in the Pacific region. While serving as a fighter pilot in 1961, McPeak said he struck up a friendship with Dugan, a fellow lieutenant. ``Mike Dugan is probably my closest friend in the U.S. Air Force,'' McPeak said. Dugan remains at the Pentagon as a special assistant to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice. He is currently overseeing studies on the future needs for pilots and navigators as well as the officer evaluation system.

DOC.HEAD: Game 6 of Chess Championship Adjourned to Tonight
With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: The sixth game of the world chess championship between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was adjourned until tonight with experts split on whether it would end in a draw or a win for Kasparov. Kasparov, the defending champion, leads 3 points to 2 in the 24-game series. The first player to reach 12{ points wins the championship. Wednesday's game was called for the night after Kasparov wrote down and sealed his 42nd move. The envelope was to be reopened with the resumption of play. During the recess, each player may consult his assistants on how to proceed. National master Shelby Lyman said Kasparov had ``virtually no chance'' of losing based on the board positions at adjournment. Grandmaster Roman Dzindzichashvili agreed: ``I think it's totally lost for Karpov.'' But grandmaster Leonid Shamkovich said he thought the game would end in a draw because Kasparov does not have enough pieces to checkmate. The first 12 games are being played in New York and the rest will be played in Lyon, France. A win is worth a point, a draw a half-point. The winner will get $1.7 million and the loser $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: City's New Brand of Condom is Too Tight, Splits
DOC.TEXT: Health activists say the city's newer, cheaper giveaway condoms are too tight and so flimsy they split apart with the insertion of a couple of fingers. ``If they break on your finger, there's a real risk they could break elsewhere on your body,'' said David Fair, former director of the city AIDS Activities Coordinating Office. Fair and others expressed concern that poor people, drug users and others who use the city's free condoms are getting inadequate protection from AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. Fair said Wednesday that apparently the new brand, Crown, was substituted when the price of the old brand, Prime, went up from 5 to 5{ cents apiece. Gary Henderson, an assistant commissioner at the city Procurement Department, would not say why the switch was made or whether the specifications were changed. The Health Department referred questions to James Hymes, current director of the AIDS Activities Coordinating Office. Hymes said he got no complaints after checking with 10 AIDS counselors who routinely demonstrate the toughness of condoms by putting their fist into them. He said he was checking whether the Crown condoms met specifications issued by the office. Until he hears conclusively, he recommended they not be used. The condoms are made by Okamoto Industries Inc. of Tokyo. Hisayuki Naito, vice president for marketing of its American subsidiary, Okamoto U.S.A., in Stratford, Conn., said he had received no complaints. He said the Crown condom is roughly 1 millimeter smaller in diameter than the average brand and ``a little bit thin, but the same strength'' as thicker brands. He said a Stanford University study rated the condoms as good. As for the fit, he said, ``If you ask 100 people, you can get 100 different opinions.'' ``The only people who would like these condoms are people who like pain,'' Fair said. Fran Stoffa, director of the AIDS Task Force, said his private agency stopped distributing them. ``There's a visible difference in the quality,'' Stoffa said. ``They're real thin. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to see that.'' To demonstrate, he inserted his hand into the Crown condom, which split readily. ``It should be able to withstand me putting a fist into them,'' Stoffa said. However, Stoffa, whose office has been distributing the Crown condoms for about six weeks, said, ``Not a whole lot of people complain about it. It's not the kind of thing where you demand your money back.'' This year's city budget, prepared by Fair, called for the purchase of 1 million condoms, with money set aside for agencies to buy another million. The city controller's office said the city recently bought 625,000 condoms at 5.1 cents apiece.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Goldsmith, AP North African Correspondent, Dead at 68
DOC.TEXT: Michael Goldsmith, an AP foreign correspondent for 45 years who reported on wars and rebellions in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, has died at a hospital in southern France. He was 68. Goldsmith died Wednesday of a massive stomach hemorrhage, said his doctor at the Grasse hospital. He suffered a stroke Oct. 1 and was hospitalized again Sunday after a relapse. Goldsmith's most recent post was North Africa correspondent, based in Paris but traveling frequently. Earlier, he served as a news staffer and bureau chief in Geneva. He reported on numerous conflicts in Africa, Southeast Asia and the Middle East, and covered Olympic Games in Grenoble, France; Montreal; Seoul; and Los Angeles, among others. ``Mike brought the enthusiam of the cub reporter and the honed wisdom of an old foreign service hand to everything he did,'' President and General Manager Lou Boccardi said Wednesday. ``Wherever the big story was - within his territory or outside it - when we sent Mike there, we knew that the story would nestle safely in the hands of a pro. The temptation is to think of Mike as among the last of a breed. Rather, I think of him as someone whose example assures that within the AP the breed will go on,'' Boccardi said. This year, Goldsmith spent five weeks in Liberia covering the civil war in that West African nation. He was detained and briefly beaten by government soldiers on Aug. 12. The soldiers threatened to shoot Goldsmith and two other Western reporters as spies after they had crossed on foot through rebel lines into government-controlled territory in the center of Monrovia, the capital. But they eventually were released. Later in the summer Goldsmith attended the Venice film festival for the premiere of a movie by German director Werner Herzog about the deposed Central African Emperor Bokassa I. Goldsmith served as an adviser on the film and interviewed some of Bokassa's relatives. Goldsmith was on assignment in Bangui covering Bokassa's coronation in 1977 when authorities arrested him and accused him of being a spy. He was beaten unconscious by Bokassa, two of his sons and a group of aides. After being held a month in the infamous Naragba prison, Goldsmith was summoned to Bokassa's palace, where Bokassa ranted at him for hours before announcing he was releasing him for ``humanitarian reasons.'' Despite this incident, Goldsmith keep in touch with the deposed emperor while he lived in exile in France. The Associated Press Managing Editors and the Overseas Press Club cited Goldsmith in connection with the Bokassa story. Goldsmith was born in Vienna, Austria, in 1921 to British parents. He was educated at London University and served as an intelligence officer in the British Army's Royal Ulster Rifles in World War II. He joined AP in 1945 in London and was assigned to British-occupied Germany. Following a roving assignment in Italy, he transferred to Geneva in 1948 and remained there nearly two decades covering U.N. European headquarters and assignments in Africa and the Middle East. He reported on post-independence turmoil in the Congo, now Zaire, Algeria and South Yemen, and the construction of the Berlin Wall. Goldsmith also went to Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia following the 1968 Tet offensive and then returned to cover the Paris peace talks. He covered the 1973 Middle East war and continued reporting on developments in Africa. In 1980, he went to Afghanistan to cover the aftermath of the Soviet invasion, reporting on an anti-Soviet movement in Kabul that virtually paralyzed the government. He is survived by his wife, Roxanne; their son, Andrew, 15; and two sons and a daughter from previous marriages - Martin, Michael and Mary. Roxanne is the daughter of the late Sam Houston Johnson, author of ``My Brother Lyndon.'' His wife said there will be no funeral and that a memorial service will be held in Paris at a later, unspecified date.

DOC.HEAD: Five Americans Arrive In New York From Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores reference to 14 in 2nd graf; inserts reference to nine other Americans in London.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY40, NY41
DOC.TEXT: Five former Persian Gulf hostages came home Wednesday night, with one praising his tough-talking president and all worrying about the fate of captives they left behind Iraq and Kuwait. They were among 14 Americans brought out of Baghdad through the efforts of an American-Iraqi group. Nine of them arrived in London on Wednesday and were to fly home Thursday. The five others flew to New York after a stopover in Amsterdam. ``I'm very elated to be at home,'' said Lloyd Graham, one of five American men who arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport aboard a Royal Jordanian flight at 8:10 p.m. ``The celebration won't start until all our friends and colleagues can come home too,'' the 48-year-old Houston man told an airport news conference. Graham, who suffers from arteriosclerosis and has undergone two quadruple bypass surgeries, appeared in good health, as did the others. ``I'm glad to be home. Morale is great,'' said a man who wouldn't give his name. He was identified by others at the news conference as Mark Ward of Middletown, N.J., a Marine sergeant attached to the U.S. Embassy in Iraq. ``George, keep up the good work,'' he said, apparently having heard of the president's statements about the crisis. ``It's great to be back.'' His family toasted his arrival with champagne in plastic cups. Also on the flight was Jack Frazier, 53, of Santa Ana, Calif., who said he had been in Iraq doing construction work when the country invaded the neighboring Kuwait. Frazier told reporters that leaving the other hostages behind ``was the hardest thing I've ever done in my life.'' After the invasion, the men stayed in private homes in the Baghdad area through U.S. Embassy arrangements. They said the Iraqis knew where they were. Frazier, Graham, Ward, Larry Murray and John Thompson were allowed to leave either because they or their relatives have medical problems, they said. None would specify why they had been released. Murray's wife, Sandy, who lives in the Houston suburb of Kingwood, said she ``talked to him briefly and he seems to be doing very well. He's ready to come home.'' She said in telephone conversations with her husband, ``he would state that he never felt free to talk.'' Mrs. Murray said her husband is ``in chronic pain.'' She didn't know his current medical condition, but ``as far as I know, it's stable.'' Cheryl Graham flew from Texas to New York Wednesday to meet her husband. ``He told me not to spend any money, but money's not important at a time like this,'' Mrs. Graham said. The trip was engineered by seven members of the American-Iraqi Foundation, a Washington, D.C.-based group of U.S. citizens of Iraqi descent. Dr. Ali Hossaini of Richmond, Va., said the hostages were released after the foundation members met with Saddam Hussein for 2{ hours Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill Requiring Colleges to Report Crimes, Graduation Rates
DOC.TEXT: A bill awaiting the president's signature will compel colleges and universities to tell students how many major crimes are committed on campus. ``It is time to take the mask off the idea that a college campus is a completely serene and protected environment,'' said Rep. William Goodling, R-Pa., a former teacher and principal who was the measure's House sponsor. The Senate approved the measure by a voice vote Wednesday, sending it to President Bush for his signature. The bill passed the House Monday night. House and Senate sponsors of the bill say they believe the president will sign it. The``Student Right-To-Know and Campus Security Act'' would require federally-aided colleges and universities to report campus crime statistics each year to students and employees. Covered crimes include murder, rape, robbery and auto theft. Information on violent crimes would have to be provided immediately, and all crime data would be available to prospective students on request. The measure was merged with another bill requiring institutions to release graduation rates of all students and students on sports scholarships. Schools would also have to make data available on athletic department revenues and expenditures, and on racial composition of scholarship athletes. Sponsors included Sens. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., the former Princeton University and New York Knicks basketball star; Edward Kennedy, D-Mass; and Arlen Specter, R-Pa. There is no comprehensive data on campus crime. Out of 3,000 colleges and universities and 5,000 other federally-aided, post-secondary schools, only 352 provide crime statistics to the FBI. Surveys show that 80 percent of campus crimes are committed by one student upon another and that most of the violent crimes are alcohol- or drug-related, according to Congress. Goodling introduced the bill in September 1989 after being contacted by the parents of a 19-year-old Lehigh University student who was raped and murdered in her dormitory room in 1986. The assailant, also a Lehigh student, had entered the dormitory through an emergency exit propped open by students visiting from another dorm. Howard and Connie Clery of Bryn Mawr persuaded Pennsylvania and nearly a dozen other state legislatures to require colleges and universities to release statistics on crimes committed against students. They began pushing for federal legislation last year.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators face several key tax issues as they work on a compromise deficit-reduction bill. Here are some of them, according to a proposed compromise incorporating elements from both parties. Exact figures could change in the final agreement. RATES: The 28 percent top income tax rate on the wealthiest 600,000 Americans likely would be raised to 31 percent; they would get a tax increase. Effective rates could even be higher, depending on exemptions and deductions. About 4 million couples and individuals who now pay a top rate of 33 percent would pay a maximum 31 percent and get a tax cut. DEDUCTIONS: A couple or individual could write off only 97 percent of otherwise allowable itemized deductions on any portion of adjusted gross income exceeding $100,000. Thus, a high-income taxpayer would lose $300 in deductions for each $10,000 of income above $100,000. This has the effect of raising the top marginal tax rate on those people to 32 percent. EXEMPTIONS: Benefits from the $2,050 personal exemption allowed each taxpayer and dependent would be reduced as taxable income exceeds $100,000 for single people and $150,000 for childless couples filing a joint return. The exemption would be fully lost once income tops $225,000 for single individuals or $275,000 for a couple filing jointly. Each exemption lost would raise the effective marginal tax rate by one-half percentage point; the bigger the family, the higher their marginal rate. Thus, a couple with two children would pay a top rate of 34 percent on part of their income: the regular 31 percent rate plus 1 percentage point because of the limit on deductions and 2 points by losing their exemptions. CAPITAL GAINS: The maximum tax rate on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of assets such as investments, would be 28 percent, even though wages and other income would be taxed as high as 31 percent. This would benefit those who pay a top 33 percent rate on income, including capital gains, under present law. GASOLINE: The 9-cent-a-gallon tax would be increased by 5 or 6 cents. ALCOHOL: Negotiators already have settled on higher taxes on alcoholic beverages, tobacco, airplane tickets, furs and jewelry and expensive cars.

DOC.HEAD: Science Writer Says He Lost Job Over Creationism Beliefs
DOC.TEXT: A widely published writer on scientific topics says Scientific American magazine wooed him, then left him at the altar because he believes in the Biblical account of creation. Forrest M. Mims III alleged Wednesday that an editor at the respected publication asked if he'd like to take over its column about amateur experiments and rejected him after learning of his beliefs. Mims, 46, of Seguin, Tex., insisted his own writing is unbiased and said he has never written about creationism. ``I've wanted this opportunity for 20 years,'' he said. ``To have the opportunity and then lose it because of what I do on Sunday is absolutely incredible.'' Scientific American publisher John Moehling refused to address Mims' allegations in detail but said, ``We don't discriminate in our pages among the people who work here or write for us. The people who read us deserve to know that.'' Mims said that he has complained to two professional societies, which ``said if I identified them they would drop the complaints.'' Mims has written in more than 60 publications, including Science Digest, The American Journal of Physics and National Geographic World, a sister publication of National Geographic. He said that in 1989 a Scientific American editor expressed enthusiasm for his work and asked if he'd like to become the magazine's ``Amateur Scientist'' columnist. He said he canceled practically all his writing assignments and was flown to New York, where Scientific American staffers congratulated him for getting the job. But the editor who invited him there suddenly grew cold when Mims mentioned he'd written for Christian magazines on such topics as ``how to organize bicycle trips for church kids,'' the writer said. The editor asked if Mims accepted Darwin's theory of evolution, Mims said. ``I replied that I did not.'' Later, he said, the editor warned him he would be fired or docked in pay if he ``ever wrote anything about creationism for any magazine.'' The editor ended the meeting by telling Mims he had not made up his mind whom to hire, Mims said. The magazine ended up publishing three of his columns this year: about safely observing sunspots; about monitoring ultraviolet radiation, and about taking aerial photographs from helium-filled trash bags. Mims now edits a new amateur science magazine, Science Probe!

DOC.HEAD: Five U.S. Hostages Arrive in New York From Iraq
LaserPhotos NY40, NY41 of Oct. 24.
DOC.TEXT: Five American men freed by Iraq for medical reasons are back in the United States, where one of them, a Marine, raised a toast to President Bush to ``keep up the good work.'' Another hostage was welcomed by his wife, who flew in from Texas despite his urgings to save the air fare. ``He told me not to spend any money, but money's not important at a time like this,'' Cheryl Graham said. Her husband, Lloyd Graham, was among 14 U.S. hostages and 32 British captives freed by Iraq. Five of the Americans arrived at Kennedy Airport aboard a Royal Jordanian Airlines flight Wednesday night. The nine other Americans stayed in London overnight and were expected to fly to the United States today. ``I'm very elated to be at home,'' Graham said. ``The celebration won't start until all our friends and colleagues can come home, too.'' Those released were freed because either they or family members have serious medical conditions. Graham, 48, of Houston, suffers from arteriosclerosis and has undergone two quadruple bypass surgeries. Another freed hostage, Jack Frazier, 53, of Santa Ana, Calif., said he was doing construction work in Iraq when Saddam Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait in August. He said Americans being held in Baghdad could move around ``very discreetly'' and were allowed to go out daily to buy food. The men had been staying in diplomatic ``safe houses'' in Iraq arranged by the U.S. Embassy. Leaving his fellow hostages behind ``was the hardest thing I've ever done in my life,'' Frazier said. The family of one man who wouldn't give his name toasted his safe arrival with champagne in plastic cups. The man, identified by others as Marine Sgt. Mark Ward of Middletown, N.J., a soldier attached to the U.S. Embassy in Iraq, praised the president for his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``George, keep up the good work,'' he said. The hostages' release came after a meeting Sunday between Saddam and members of the Washington-based American-Iraqi Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Deports Mexican TV Crew Over Soviet Report
DOC.TEXT: Cuba has expelled a Mexican television crew in anger over a report by the network on a leading Soviet newspaper's criticism of Cuban President Fidel Castro, the television reported. The action Wednesday against reporters from a country with important links to Cuba appeared to underscore Cuban frustration at worsening ties with Moscow, which has cut aid to Havana and is trying to force Castro to embrace reforms. ``They told us we were expelled from Cuba and we had to leave today,'' said Televisa reporter Jose Eduardo Campos during a live interview on a late-night edition of the private network's Eco news progam. Campos said Cuban officials expressed anger over an Eco report from Moscow quoting a critical report about Castro and his brother in the Soviet daily Pravda. He did not give a date or other details of the Pravda article. ``They explained to us that the work we had done in Havana had been to their liking.'' Campos said. But because of the Moscow report, ``the television Eco was lying ... and that Eco was not going to be received in Havana.'' Anchorman Jacobo Zabludovsky said the report from Moscow ``simply was limited to a textual translation of what was published'' in Pravda, the official Soviet Communist Party newspaper. Castro, a hard-line communist, has criticized Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's endorsemehnt of market-oriented reform. Massive Soviet aid to Cuba has been scaled back. Campos said he and camera crew members Roberto Ruvalcabo and Guillermo Gomez had arrived in Havana on Saturday and worked ``without any problem'' until they were summoned to the Foreign Ministry at midday Wednesday. Ruvalcabo said officials told them ``that we were undesirable persons'' and that they used the word ``deported'' when the crew was loaded on a plane for Mexico.
