The state radio reported government troops had killed 320 rebels and lost 10 soldiers in fighting on Tuesday. Ugandan-based rebels from Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe invaded last month and advanced to within 40 miles northeast of Kigali, the capital. The rebels want to overthrow President Juvenal Habyarimana's government. One Western diplomat doubted a cease-fire would hold between the rebels, who call themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front, and Rwanda's government. ``A cease-fire would mean the rebels would stay where they are,'' the diplomat said by telephone from Kigali. ``That would mean giving the rebels part of the country. I doubt Habyarimana would agree to that.'' Another Western envoy said he saw no evidence of a cease-fire and that the government had not announced it in Rwanda. The diplomats spoke on condition of anonymity. On Wednesday, Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens told journalists in Nairobi that Rwanda's government had accepted an unconditional cease-fire earlier in the day. Eyskens said African nations, possibly through the Organization of African Unity, should provide a neutral force to monitor the cease-fire. He said Belgium, Rwanda's former colonial ruler, would provide logistical and financial support for such a force. Esykens said he had learned of the halt in fighting by telephone from his Rwandan counterpart, Casimir Bizimungu. Uganda's president, Yoweri Museveni, announced on Monday that the rebels had accepted a cease-fire. Belgium, France and Zaire sent troops to Rwanda after the rebel invasion Sept. 30 to protect their citizens. The rebels have insisted foreign troops must leave Rwanda before they would open talks. They also demand Habyarimana's troops stop killing civilians and that his government release thousands of people arested as rebel sympathizers. The rebels, mainly deserters from Uganda's army, are led by Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, former deputy army commander in Uganda. The insurgency sprang from an estimated 250,000 Rwandan refugees in Uganda. The refugees largely belong to the minority Tutsis, who lost power to the majority Hutus in a power struggle in late 1950s and early 1960s. Hundreds of thousands of Tutsis fled to neighboring Uganda, Rwanda, Tanzania, and Zairem, and 10,000 were reported killed in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Coalition Wins, Bhutto Claims Vote Rigged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with more government comment, vote observers may release preliminary findings on Friday. Pickup 10th, `The group's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing coalition scored a landslide victory over former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today, likely setting Pakistan's struggling democracy on a more conservative, Islamic course. Ms. Bhutto, who claims her August dismissal was a ``constiutional coup,'' refused to concede the defeat of her center-left Pakistan People's Party in Wednesday's parliamentary election. She accused the army-backed, caretaker government of large-scale vote rigging, a charge that may be difficult to prove. Opponents called the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto a sore loser and said the more than 2-1 victory margin by the loose-knit, right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance surpassed even their expectations. In the final vote count, almost 24 hours after polls closed, Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party won only 45 of the 216 parliamentary races, to 105 for her opponents. The policy-making assembly, the lower house of Parliament, elects the prime minister. The rest of the seats went to smaller ethnic and religious parties and independents. Voting was postponed in one race because of a candidate's death. ``The people have given their mandate, their verdict. Ms. Bhutto should accept the results and prove to the world that she's a democrat,'' caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi told a news conference today. A 40-member group of international poll-watchers refused immediate comment on Ms. Bhutto's assertions of vote fraud, but said it might discuss its preliminary findings on Friday. The group's assessment could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in vital U.S. aid for the government now headed by Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi. The United States and other Western countries have warned they may cut off aid if the election was rigged and Ms. Bhutto victimized. Poll watchers were suspicious of some constituencies where they witnessed a low voter turnout yet the final vote count showed tens of thousands had marked their ballots. The winning alliance espouses adherence to the principles of Islam, and there is speculation it could tighten controls on the media, and restrict the rights of women and non-Moslems. It also favors a closer relationship with the Islamic world and more distance from the West, particularly the United States. ``I'm angry and shocked at the way election has been rigged. It wasn't even subtle. They have stolen the elections,'' said Ms. Bhutto, who predicted a ``witch hunt'' against her family and supporters would follow. The caretaker government has already charged Ms. Bhutto with abuse of power and had her husband jailed on charges of kidnapping and extortion. She says the charges are baseless and aimed at destroying her politically. ``Since the polling agents were not present and ballot boxes were stolen, I cannot accept these results,'' said Ms. Bhutto, fighting back tears as she talked with reporters Wednesday night in Larkana, her ancestral home in southern Sindh Province. The election was widely seen as a verdict on the Aug. 6 dismissal of Ms. Bhutto's popularly-elected government by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who claimed hers was the most corrupt and inept government in Pakistan's 43 years. Most analysts and opinion polls had predicted a close race between Ms. Bhutto's party and its three smaller allies and the alliance, a coalition spanning the ideological spectrum and united only in contempt for Ms. Bhutto. Yet voter turnout was low, contrasting with the emotionally charged atmosphere that heralded the return to democracy in November 1988 after a decade of military rule. Analysts said Wednesday's numbers reflected the growing cynicism about the country's future and disenchantment with both Ms. Bhutto and her opponents. Despite the presence of nearly 100,000 security forces, at least nine people were killed and 66 others injured in clashes between rival parties during the voting. Alliance leaders who easily won their parliamentary seats included Prime Minister Jatoi and his son Murtaza; Ms. Bhutto's chief rival, Nawaz Sharif; and Ijaz ul-Haq, the eldest son of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's last military dictator. Ms. Bhutto and her mother, Nusrat, were the only winners among the 11 women candidates. The ousted prime minister's controversial and flamboyant husband, Asif Ali Zardari, won the seat to represent Lyari, the sprawling Karachi slum, but lost in his home constituency of Nawabshah in the heart of Sindh. The 38-year-old businessman is in jail, being held without bail. Ms. Bhutto said she had reports of rigging in at least 80 constituencies and accused the caretaker government of suffing and stealing ballot boxes and intimidating and harrassing voters to keep them away from polling booths. ``She's a sore loser,'' Haqqani said. ``After a few days she'll have to accept it.'' The Western-educated Ms. Bhutto became the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation in December 1988 just months after Zia died in a mysterious plane crash that also claimed the life of the U.S. ambassador. She spent 20 troubled months in office. Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was overthrown as prime minister in a 1977 coup and hanged two years later after Zia refused to pardon him.

DOC.HEAD: Koreas to Begin Talks on One Olympic Team
DOC.TEXT: South and North Korea agreed today to begin talks next month on fielding a single team in the 1992 Olympics and other international sporting events. South Korean Sports Minister Chung Dong-sung said the two Koreas agreed to start the talks on Nov. 29 at the truce village of Panmunjom. Chung, reading a joint communique with his North Korean counterpart, Kim Yu Sun, called for joint Korean teams at the Barcelona Olympics, the 1991 world table tennis championships in Japan, and other sports events. Kim said the move is part of ``opening the doors to unification,'' but repeated longstanding demands by the North that border barriers be abolished. The communique capped a five-day trip by North Korean sports officials and soccer players in the first exchange of inter-Korea athletic teams across the heavily fortified border. The group was the first sports delegation from the Communist North to visit South Korea since the division of the peninsula in 1945. Their trip followed a visit to North Korea by South Korean soccer players two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Fall Back America, to Standard Time Again
DOC.TEXT: The American family ritual of changing the clocks comes around again this weekend. Most folks get an extra hour to sleep, or carouse, or whatever it is they like to do in the wee hours of Sunday morning. Of course, that means it's also the weekend some people get stuck working an extra hour - factory workers and convenience store clerks, bartenders, police and even some news reporters. For most people, though, it simply means having to remember to set the clock back - that's right, back - an hour before retiring Saturday night. Technically, the change occurs at 2 a.m. local time, which becomes 1 a.m., and an hour is repeated. Or, in the words of the Uniform Time Act, which set up the system of switching between daylight and standard times, clocks are ``retarded'' an hour at 0200 on the last Sunday in October. The move to standard time means that darkness will come earlier in the evening, with that hour of light shifted back to the morning hours to get the nation off to work on the right foot. Clocks will be ``advanced'' to daylight time the first Sunday of next April 2. While the official switch to standard time covers most of the nation, a few states have taken matters into their own hands and exempted themselves. Since those places didn't spring forward to daylight time last spring, they won't fall back this weekend. Included in the nonconformists are Arizona, Hawaii, part of Indiana, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and American Samoa.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Joins in Another Anti-Israel U.N. Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Perez de Cuellar comments. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Top aides...' Minor editing to CONFORM and TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in two weeks, the United States has joined a unanimous Security Council vote rebuking Israel, this time for not cooperating with a U.N. investigation of the Temple Mount killings. Not even a last-ditch personal appeal from President Bush to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir persuaded Israel to change its mind and officially receive the U.N. investigators. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that he would meet the Israeli ambassador ``to confirm their refusal to my mission.'' ``If that is the case, that they continue to block my mission, I will start preparing my report to the Security Council,'' he told reporters on entering U.N. headquarters. Perez de Cuellar said last week that if Israel doesn't cooperate with the U.N. investigation, he would have no option but to limit his report to ways of protecting Palestinians in the occupied territories seized by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. Top aides to Shamir said today that Israel will ignore the new U.N. resolution and claimed that Washington was coerced into voting for the measure to preserve its alliance with Arab countries opposing Iraq. ``We are sorry because this helps Saddam Hussein to distract attention from what is happening in the gulf ... to what is happening in Jerusalem,'' said Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner. The U.N. resolution, approved 15-0 on Wednesday, is largely symbolic. No sanctions against Israel are expected, said British Ambassador David Hannay, who is president of the council for October. Still, Hannay said Israel's treatment of Palestinians ``is not going to go away from the council agenda ... The principal loser by not receiving the U.N. mission will be Israel.'' Israeli security forces trying to quell a riot opened fire and killed 19 Palestinians on Jerusalem's sacred Temple Mount on Oct. 8. Beforehand Arabs had thrown a volley of stones on Jews praying below at the Western Wall. Israel has since seen a spate of Arab-Israeli revenge attacks. In response, Israeli authorities sealed off the occupied territories Wednesday, preventing Palestinians from getting to jobs in Israel. On Oct. 12, the United States broke with past practice and joined a 15-0 council vote denouncing Israeli security forces for the shootings on the Temple Mount, in which about 140 Palestinians were wounded. That resolution asked Perez de Cuellar to send a delegation to investigate and submit a report on the killings. Israel fears that accepting the U.N. mission would be tantamount to accepting world objections to Israel's annexation of predominantly Arab east Jerusalem, captured with the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the 1967 war. The resolution approved Wednesday ``deplores the refusal of the Israeli government to receive the mission'' and ``insists'' that Israel ``permit the mission ... to proceed in keeping with its purpose.'' The vote was delayed from Tuesday so Bush could contact Shamir, urging him to receive the U.N. mission so the Security Council could resume its series of resolutions condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United States had been under intense pressure from Arab and other states not to veto the resolution and risk eroding the fragile coalition arrayed against Iraq, which depends on moderate Arab states such as Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Morocco. The Israeli government denounced Wednesday's resolution in advance, saying it would not cooperate and calling the council hypocritical. Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein told reporters the Security Council was exercising a double standard in criticizing Israel while Arabs are attacking Jews in Israel in retaliation for the killings on the Temple Mount, which is sacred to both Moslems and Jews. More than 750 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops and civilians in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. The Security Council includes five permanent members with veto power: The United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union; and the non-permanent members: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Announces `Southern Star' Capture of 3,743 Drug Fugitives
DOC.TEXT: An international anti-drug crackdown dubbed ``Southern Star'' has resulted in 3,743 arrests and the seizure of millions of dollars in cash and drugs, authorities said. Fugitives on state, federal and international charges from New Zealand to Bermuda were rounded up during the 10-week effort, along with $12.8 million in cash, property, drugs, guns and other contraband. The operation marked a new level of coordination between the U.S. Marshal's Service and 28 state and local agencies in the war on drugs, said U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh who reported the sweep Wednesday. ``We're making considerable progress in upping the ante for those who are intent upon feeding the appetite that unfortunately still exists in the United States for illegal drugs,'' he said. But he conceded that the federal government was not in a position to say if the operation had actually cut into drug sales in the United States. Authorities said those arrested were tracked through 32 states and several foreign countries. Foreign fugitives have too long been able to ``flee from one country to another, financed by lucrative international criminal activities,'' said K. Michael Moore, director of the U.S. Marshal's Service. ``They assume that the various law enforcement officers don't have the time or resources to track them across international jurisdictions. Operation Southern Star proves them wrong,'' Moore said. Eleven of those arrested were wanted for murder, and one of the fugitives, Charles Bryatt, was wanted in New Zealand on charges of cocaine smuggling and conspiracy to supply LSD. Along with Bryant, federal authorities singled out several other fugitives as principal targets of Southern Star. Gregory Rodgers, wanted on a Kansas cocaine distribution charge, was tracked down in the Central American country of Belize and deported to Miami for arrest. One Florida fugitive, Richard Joseph Lynn, was tracked through Alabama, Georgia, Florida, Louisiana, Mexico and Guatemala before he was arrested at a restaurant in Gulfport, Miss. The most prominent drug cache seized was 150 pounds of cocaine that was found underneath imported seafood on a South American airliner in Miami. Two days later, U.S. Customs Service inspectors at the same airport found 100 pounds of cocaine from Lima, Peru, in a box labeled ``books.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Subcontinent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. reading for the quake. Pickup 3rd pvs, `The city...' Minor editing thereafter to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake centered in Afghanistan's rugged Hindu Kush mountain range sent shock waves throughout the subcontinent early today. Two dozen people were reported injured in this border city. There were conflicting reports on the magnitude of the quake, which was felt as far away as New Delhi, the Indian capital. Russ Needham, a spokesman for the the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said it measured 5.6 on the Richter scale. Pakistan's meteorological center initially reported a 7 reading, and India's meteorology department recorded a 6.5 reading. The city nearest the epicenter is the war-ravaged Afghan capital of Kabul, just 60 miles to the south. The Afghan Embassy in Pakistan had no reports of damage or casulaties in Kabul. An estimated 2 million people live in the Afghan capital, many of them displaced villagers who have taken refuge from the country's civil war. The area of the quake's epicenter, the Laghman province of Afghanistan, is generally considered the turf of anti-government Moslem guerrillas. In Peshawar, south of the epicenter, buildings shook and frightened residents ran into the street, Radio Pakistan reported. It said the quake injured two dozen people in the city. In New Delhi, 590 miles southeast of the epicenter, office workers in high-rise buildings were evacuated as a safety precaustion, but there were no reports of damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. A quake measuring 6 on the scale is capable of severe damage, and a tremor measuring 7 of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Escorts Actress on Tour of White House Grounds
DOC.TEXT: President Bush took a break from the budget battles today to escort actress Bo Derek on a tour of the White House grounds. The actress was in town for the Washington International Horse Show, according to the White House press office. ``She called and wanted to see the White House,'' said spokeswoman Alixe Glen. Bush had delayed a trip to the West Coast, canceling campaign appearances in Arizona and New Mexico, because of the precarious state of negotiations as Congress and the administration sought agreement on a $500-billion deficit-reduction package. The president early this morning averted shutdown of the government by signing a temporary spending measure that will keep operations going until midnight Saturday. There were no scheduled activities on his public agenda for the day. But it became apparent that an Oval Office meeting was in progress when a group of young male White House male aides began to cluster in the hallways. They were soon joined by a gaggle of reporters and photographers. All pressed against the glass doors looking out on the Rose Garden for a glimpse of the blonde actress. The president was seen escorting her and her husband, John Derek, along the driveway near the Oval Office.

DOC.HEAD: Webster Says Saddam's Arsenal Must Be Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration believes the Middle East will never be secure as long as Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein remains in power unless his weapons are destroyed, CIA director William Webster said today. ``Can you put him back in his box?'' Webster asked rhetorically, referring to Saddam. Webster said the administration had ``no real confidence that the area will ever be secure again as long as he is still there unless'' a regional, countervailing force is put in place or ``he is disassociated from his weapons of mass destruction.'' Webster also said U.N.-imposed sanctions against Iraq were beginning to have an effect, forcing Saddam's government ``to take steps to restructure its economic program in order to feed its people and meet the needs of the military.'' Sanctions, imposed after Saddam invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, have cut off 98 percent of Iraq's oil exports and 95 percent of its imports. Although Saddam has long crushed any internal dissent within Iraq, Webster said intelligence analysts have received some ``encouraging reports'' of a little dissatisfaction within the country. Webster, speaking at a breakfast meeting of the National Council of World Affairs Organizations, did not elaborate on the nature of the discontent and said analysts have yet to conclude how significant it is. Drawing a parallel between Saddam and deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega, Webster noted Noriega was able to stay in power despite a coup attempt. Noriega was dislodged by the invasion of U.S. troops last December. Over time, Webster speculated there would be growing discontent against Saddam from his top aides. They are the only ones with enough access to take action against Saddam. The CIA is forbidden under law from taking part in the assassination of a foreign leader. Webster said it was difficult to interpret Saddam's motives because the leader is isolated, frequently taking counsel only from his brother. But he said Saddam's ``willingness to use weapons of mass destruction, his ties to terrorist groups, his appeal to Arab and Muslim solidarity and his playing upon regional economic frustration' represent a real threat. For the time being, Saddam appears to be reinforcing his defense positions inside Kuwait, Webster said, adding that he was skeptical about reports and rumors that Saddam wanted to withdraw from Kuwait with the exception of an oil field and two islands that would give him access to the sea. Saddam's immediate goal apparently is to hold out against sanctions, hoping eventually to see fissures in the blockade against him, Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Administration Plans To Continue Gulf Buildup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-7, Meanwhile, with Webster comments.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today the United States will continue its military buildup in the Persian Gulf, perhaps adding as many as 100,000 more troops. ``We're not at the point yet where we want to stop adding forces,'' Cheney said. He declined to say how many troops might be added to the U.S. deployment, which now totals 220,000 troops in and around Saudi Arabia. But when asked if adding 100,000 troops was possible, Cheney said, ``It's conceivable that we'll end up with that big an increase.'' Pentagon sources said Wednesday the deployment would reach the planned level of 240,000 in three weeks. But Cheney said the administration ``never put an upper ceiling on the deployment.'' His comments came as President Bush faced several decisions about the makeup of the gulf forces and as his top uniformed commander, Gen. Colin Powell, headed home from talks with ground commanders in Saudi Arabia. The talks included discussion of adding more offensive might to the U.S. forces. Meanwhile, CIA Director William Webster said the Bush administration believes the Middle East will never be secure as long as Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein remains in power unless his weapons are destroyed. He said the administration had ``no real confidence that the area will ever be secure again as long as he is still there unless'' a regional, countervailing force is put in place or ``he is disassociated from his weapons of mass destruction.'' The U.S.-led multinational forces now total more than 300,000 but still fall far short of the estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops deployed in heavily fortified positions in occupied Kuwait and southern Iraq. Pentagon planners, noting a recent decline in polls of public support for the desert deployment, have urged Cheney and other senior administration officials to articulate their reasons clearly should they decide to expand the force. Cheney said the administration still hoped for a peaceful solution to the standoff with Iraq's Saddam Hussein but wanted to make sure its force in the region offered Bush the option of ordering an offensive. ``We want to make certain we've got the forces over there to deal with any ontingency,'' Cheney said on ``CBS This Morning.'' On ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' he said: ``We've not yet settled on an upper limit in terms of our total deployment. So for a number of reasons I would expect a continuing flow of forces to the gulf in the period ahead.'' The Pentagon sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that if more troops were sent to the region they likely would be heavy tank divisions, either from the United States or Europe. These sources also said it was possible some non-essential units might be brought home by Christmas, with the 82nd Airborne Division a likely candidate. Cheney said it was ``entirely possible'' that the 82nd would be rotated out and additional heavy units sent in. But he said no decision had been made. Even if the United States subbed a tank division for the 82nd, ``we still wouldn't have an offensive force to be comfortable with,'' a Pentagon source said today. This source said no additional ground units have been ordered to the region. The American buildup hit a symbolic juncture Wednesday with the arrival in Saudi Arabia of the final elements of the 11th Air Defense Brigade from Fort Bliss, Texas. It was the last combat unit scheduled for deployment in the region, Pentagon sources said. The only remaining troops scheduled as of Wednesday to be sent to the area following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait are support units due to arrive over the next three weeks, bringing the deployment to 240,000. There appears to be little domestic or international support for a unilateral U.S. offensive, however. Barring some action by Iraq that would bring consensus for an attack, Pentagon sources and military analysts consider it far more likely that Bush will make small changes to the force. ``We would have to double the force there to make an offensive palatable from a military standpoint,'' said Lawrence J. Korb, a former assistant defense secretary for manpower in the Reagan administration. ``I don't think that is very likely. ... I'd set up a rotation plan but basically keep my troop level about where it is.'' The 82nd Airborne is the first candidate to come home because it was the first to arrive in Saudi Arabia, is lightly armed and not designed for a tank war. Also, many of its troops spent last Christmas in Panama as part of the U.S. invasion force. Withdrawing the paratroopers, one of the Army's premier rapid-deployment offensive units, ``would signal that we are going to hunker down and wait right along with Saddam,'' one source said. In addition, a Pentagon official said, ``We'd look good bringing some people home for Christmas, even if in the big scheme of things it didn't amount to much.'' This official said the 82nd could be sent back to the region after the holdidays. The Pentagon sources said draft rotation plans call for six-month rotations for most units, which would mean the first large-scale substitutions would occur in February. Some units that are harder to replace ``may have to spend more time in the country than we or they would like,'' one source said. The sequence of the rotations is still under discussion, with an announcement expected within two weeks, this source said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Charge Involving AIDS-Prostitution Law
DOC.TEXT: A judge has dismissed a felony charge against a man accused of engaging in prostitution while knowingly carrying the AIDS virus, the first charge of its kind in the county involving a new law. Municipal Judge Rand Schrader ruled Wednesday that Demitri Santangelo, whose infection was found in a court-ordered AIDS test after a prostitution conviction, was not properly warned he could be charged with a felony if he was arrested again for prostitution. Santangelo, 29, could have been sentenced to three years in prison if convicted of the felony charge. Schrader, 45, who describes himself as the only openly homosexual judge on the Los Angeles Municipal Court, was elected chairman of the Los Angeles County AIDS Commission last year. The case was the county's first involving a 1988 law that the Legislature passed after a Los Angeles jury acquitted a man of knowingly selling AIDS-contaminated blood to a plasma center. Deputy District Attorney Vivian Davidson said she would have to research whether there are grounds for appeal. Santangelo's attorney, Deputy Public Defender Patrick Thomason, applauded Schrader's ruling and predicted it would withstand appeal.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO CORRECT WRITETHRU NUMBER
New IRA Tactic of `Human Bombs' Outrages British
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with eight men questioned by authorities, claim of responsibility in latest killing. Pickup 7th, `Brooke, Irish..'
DOC.TEXT: British officials are expressing horror at the IRA's latest tactic - taking a family hostage and forcing one member to drive a bomb-laden vehicle into an army checkpoint in Northern Ireland. The IRA attacks on checkpoints at the border with the Irish Republic on Wednesday killed six British soldiers and a civilian and injured 35 people. The attacks were expected to dominate Irish-British talks in London today. Police in the Republic of Ireland questioned eight men today about a series of attacks including IRA bombings in Northern Ireland. A spokesman for the Irish police, the Garda, said six of them would appear in a special criminal court in Dublin on unspecified charges. But the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the charges were not in connection with Wednesday's bombings. The eight men were arrested near the border with Northern Ireland after Wednesday's attacks. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, the British Cabinet member responsible for the province, said on Wednesday that the Irish Republican Army had ``sunk to new levels of depravity by using people, whose families have been held hostage, as human bombs.'' ``It is hard to imagine anything more evil than tying a man into his car laden with explosives and then forcing him to drive to where the bomb was detonated,'' he told the House of Commons. In new violence today, the outlawed paramilitary organization Ulster Freedom Fighters claimed responsibility for the killing of a man whose body was found by two schoolgirls in a Protestant housing project in south Belfast. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the 28-year-old Protestant man had been questioned by police Wednesday about terrorist acts. He was the 10th person to die in political and sectarian violence in the British-ruled provinc in four days. Brooke, Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins, and police chiefs from both sides of the Irish border were to take part a meeting in London today under the 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement. Meetings are regularly held under the accord, which gives the Irish Republic a formal consultative role in the running of Northern Ireland and provides for cooperation between security forces on both sides of the border. Police in Northern Ireland said that in simultaneous pre-dawn attacks Wednesday, the IRA forced three Roman Catholic civilians it said had collaborated with security forces to drive bomb-laden vehicles to their targets. Five soldiers died in the attack on a army checkpoint near Londonderry, 65 miles northwest of Belfast.The body of Patsy Gillespie, who drove the bomb-laden van while IRA guerrillas held his family hostage, was found Wednesday night at the scene of the blast. Another soldier died in a similar attack on a army checkpoint near Newry, 35 miles south of Belfast. But in that case, the man who drove the bomb-laden van while the IRA held his relatives captive managed to flee the vehicle and shout a warning before the explosion. In a third attack, on an army base at Omagh about 50 miles west of Belfast, guerrillas strapped the driver into his bomb-laden trailer, told him to drive to the target and followed in a car while other guerrillas held his family captive. But the man managed to get free and the bomb failed to go off. Hospitals said a total of 35 people, including two 9-month-old babies, were injured in the Londonderry and Newry attacks. Police in the Irish Republic said today that they were holding a total of eight men arrested Wednesday under anti-terrorist legislation just across the border from the checkpoint near Londonderry. But they refused to say if the men are believed connected with the attack. They can be held without charge for 48 hours. The British domestic news agency Press Association quoted unnamed security sources as saying it was thought the eight were arrested in a process of eliminating possible suspects from investigations in the area. In a message to news organizations, the IRA claimed responsibility for the three attacks. It said the three men forced to drive the bombs were collaborators because they had performed construction work for the security forces. The mainly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Man Aquitted of Killing Detective in Drug Raid
DOC.TEXT: A jury today found a man innocent of killin a Boston police detective in a case that raised questions about whether investigators lied and doctored evidence. Albert Lewin, 34, a Jamaican immigrant, was accused of firing the shots that blasted through a closed apartment door and killed Detective Sherman Griffiths, 36, during a drug raid on Feb. 17, 1988. The Franklin Superior Court jury deliberated for 3 hours and 40 minutes over two days before acquitting Lewin. The case was moved to this western Massachusetts community because of pretrial publicity. Former Detective Carlos Luna, who was a partner of Griffiths, testified that police lied in an attempt to cover up the inadequacies of a search warrant used for the drug raid. Luna is one of two officers indicted for their alleged role in the coverup. Luna testified at Lewin's trial that his superiors and a Boston prosecutor encouraged him to concoct a story that a supposed informant named in the search warrant had either died or left town. In fact, police have admitted, there was no such informant named ``John.'' In his final arguments, defense attorney Max D. Stern maintained the Boston police forfeited their reputation in trying to build a case against Lewin. ``Trust is a precious commodity,'' Stern said Wednesday. ``It is not in endless supply and when officers of the law bend that law, when they twist that law, when they break that law ... they do not deserve that trust any more.'' Assistant Suffolk County District Attorney Thomas J. Mundy acknowledged that the evidence against Lewin, who was in an apartment with several other people, was circumstantial. The only physical evidence linking Lewin with the murder weapon was a fingerprint on the gun. And Stern sharply challenged the authenticity of the print, which surfaced 30 months after the crime. An FBI expert testified he discovered the print and was convinced it was authentic. But two defense witnesses, including a retired fingerprint expert with the state police, testified there were signs the print may have been transferred onto the gun.

DOC.HEAD: Qualified Support for Albania's Quest to Join Europe
DOC.TEXT: Albania's Balkan neighbors today gave only qualified support for its quest to take part in European affairs, and Greece insisted the isolated, hard-line Communist nation make human rights reforms. Albania's attempt to gain international acceptance also was damaged by the defection today of its most famous author to France. The author, Ismail Karare, announced he would seek political asylum because there ``was no possibility of legal opposition'' in his homeland. Word of Karare's defection reached Tirana just after the foreign ministers' meeting closed, and there was no immediate official Albanian reaction. Albania, the host of its first high-level international conference in decades, hopes to be invited to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in time for its summit meeting in Paris next month. But Balkan foreign ministers today did not give Albania a clear endorsement for partipation in the summit. The ministers said only that they ``welcomed the request of Albania for full participation in the CSCE, and expressed their wish to see it realized.'' Albania was the sole European nation not to sign the Helsinki Final Act in 1975, the document that began the European conference process. To be admitted, Albania is likely to have to take human rights reform further than it has to date. Reforms introduced this year have slightly eased the complete ban on religious activities and have allowed a few thousand of the country's 3 million citizens to travel abroad. But the Communist Albanian Labor Party has given no signal it will tolerate other political parties or allow freedom of expression. ``We need some tangible proof that they are indeed walking this path,'' said Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece, the only country to publicly take Albania to task for its human rights record at the two-day meeting. With Kadare's defection, Albania is even less likely to get enough support from the 34 nations in the conference - the United States, the Soviet Union, Canada and all the rest of Europe - to participate fully at the Paris summit. Kadare, the head of the Albanian Writer's Union, had been seen as one of Albania's leading reformers. Albania's quest to take part in Europen affairs places its rulers in a difficult position. They can either accelerate reform, which could provoke violent upheaval, or approach the change gradually and thus fail to make the desired foreign contacts. This summer, about 5,000 Albanians took refuge in embassies in Tirana and eventually were allowed to emigrate.

DOC.HEAD: Five Freed Americans Home; Nine More Due Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Webster comment, today's oil prices, report that gulf allies may forgive $7 billion in Egyptian debt. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7, NY19, NY40, NY41
DOC.TEXT: Five freed Americans enjoyed a homecoming that was overshadowed by fears for colleagues still held captive in Iraq, and nine more former U.S. hostages were flying to the United States today. In Washington, CIA director William Webster said today the Middle East will never be secure as long as Saddam Hussein remains in power - unless the Iraqi president's weapons are destroyed. Regarding the French hostages, Western diplomatic sources in Baghdad said French citizens given permission this week to depart Iraq will begin leaving on Saturday. More than 300 French citizens are among the thousands of foreigners who were trapped in Iraq after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. France has said it would not make any concessions in exchange for the freeing of its nationals, but the Iraqi government-run daily newspaper Al-Jumhouriya said today that France would withdraw some of its forces from the Persian Gulf region. It cited unidentified, official sources in Paris. France has about 5,000 troops in Saudi Arabia, plus an estimated 2,000 sailors aboard 14 ships in the region as part of the predominantly American multinational force. U.S. military strength in the gulf region, now totaling about 220,000 troops, could grow substantially in coming weeks, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today. ``We're not at the point yet where we want to stop adding forces,'' Cheney said on ``CBS This Morning.'' Asked if adding 100,000 troops was possible, he said, ``It's conceivable that we'll end up with that big an increase.'' Congressional sources said Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker III had disclosed an offer by Iraq to free Canadian and German hostages in return for high-level diplomatic visits from those countries. The sources said Cheney and Baker briefed lawmakers in a closed-door meeting on Wednesday. Saddam invited the Canadian and German foreign ministers to visit his country and held out the prospect that some of their nationals could be released if they did so, House members were told. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said the reported entreaties to U.S. allies ``are viewed by our guys as cynical, exploitative of the hostages, and I think Congress agrees with that assessment.'' Webster, meanwhile, told the National Council of World Affairs Organizations that Saddam's ``willingness to use weapons of mass destruction, his ties to terrorist groups, his appeal to Arab and Muslim solidarity and his playing upon regional economic frustration'' make him a continuing threat to long-term peace in the gulf region. The five American men who arrived in the United States on Wednesday were freed by Iraq for medical reasons. They arrived at New York's Kennedy Airport aboard a Royal Jordanian Airlines flight. Freed hostage Jack Frazier, 53, of Santa Ana, Calif., said leaving his fellow hostages behind ``was the hardest thing I've ever done in my life.'' ``I'm very elated to be at home,'' said Lloyd Graham, 48, of Houston. ``The celebration won't start until all our friends and colleagues can come home, too.'' Nine other freed Americans stayed in London overnight and were expected to fly to the United States later today. The hostages' release came after a meeting Sunday between Saddam and members of the Washington-based American-Iraqi Foundation. Saddam, who seized Kuwait in a dispute over money, land and oil, prevented thousands of foreigners from leaving Iraq and the conquered emirate, and has used some as human shields to protect key installations against potential attack. In other gulf developments: -Oil prices jumped more than $2 per barrel in early trading on the futures market today on fears of a confrontation in the Mideast. Light sweet crude oil was up $2.17 to $33.25 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a key market, late this morning. Oil prices were about $21 a barrel before the invasion. -President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt arrived in Oman today on the last leg of a regional tour. ``No one wants war, but at the same time legitimacy must be established and the law of the jungle must not prevail,'' he was quoted as saying in officially distributed statements. -Egypt's official Middle East News Agency said Cairo's allies in the Gulf Cooperation Council have agreed to forgive Egyptian debts totaling $7 billion. Egypt has the largest Arab contingent in the multinational force, with about 15,000 troops deployed in the gulf region. -Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's gulf envoy arrived in Damascas today. The envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, said he was carrying a message from Gorbachev to Syrian President Hafez Assad. Primakov's diplomatic mission has taken him to Baghdad, Washington, Rome, Paris and London.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Reprieve on Israeli Beer Tax
DOC.TEXT: A bureaucratic goof gave beer drinkers a three-day reprieve Thursday before they have to swallow a 20 percent price hike. The Finance Ministry had ordered the hike to take effect Thursday, but ignored a law saying changes in costs of price-controlled commodities - such as beer - need the signature of both the finance and trade ministers. ``Apparently somone forgot to prepare the order for the two ministers to sign,'' Finance Ministry spokesman Eli Yosseph said. He said the order would be signed by both ministers on Sunday, when a sales tax increase from 20 percent to 40 percent will take effect to bring Israel in line with European nations.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Says It May Restore Diplomatic Links With Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania might restore diplomatic relations with Hungary later this year before concluding independence talks with the Soviet Union, the republic's president was quoted as saying Thursday. The official Tass news agency said President Vytautas Landsbergis discussed the possibility during a recent visit to Hungary. It quoted him as saying the Hungarian government accepted his proposal ``to develop relations between the two states on the basis of the 1937 Lithuanian-Hungarian Treaty which remains in force.'' Lithuania was the first of the 15 Soviet republics to declare independence from the Soviet Union. The Baltic republic agreed to suspend its March 11 declaration in exchange for the lifting of an economic embargo and the Kremlin's agreement to negotiate. Officials have held two rounds of talks and agreed to try to start formal negotiations on secession at the end of November. Lithuania was independent for a brief period after World War I, and was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ugandan Vice President Freed
DOC.TEXT: A former Ugandan vice president detained for more than three years on various charges was freed Thursday for lack of evidence. Paul Muwanga's freedom came after prosecutor Mark Kabega told a Kampala magistrate's court the state had no evidence to support charges of kidnapping with intent to murder, but that investigations would continue. He said the charges could be reinstated if sufficient evidence is found. Muwanga, 69, was accused of committing the offense in 1981. He was vice president under former President Milton Obote, who was toppled in a 1985 military coup. Muwanga, who was arrested in October 1986, has remained imprisoned except for period court appearances. He was charged with treason against the present government and with abuse of power while in office under Obote, but was subsequently acquitted. Muwanga was de facto president in 1980 when he chaired a military commission that ruled the East African nation after a combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops ousted dictator Idi Amin in late 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Italy's EC Presidency Under Scrutiny On Eve of Summit
DOC.TEXT: Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis has become a familiar figure in recent months as he travels the world to espouse his vision of a Europe ready to throw its weight on the international stage. De Michelis has used Italy's presidency of the European Community to promote a series of ambitious initiatives and proposals, ranging from a Mediterranean peace conference to an EC military role. Italy's six-month term, which has drawn criticism from some diplomats recently, reaches an important stage this weekend at a summit meeting of the 12 EC leaders in Rome. De Michelis says the officials will discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the EC's relations with the Soviet Union and other East European countries and the process of economic, monetary and political union. As the head of government, Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti will chair the summit. But the real guiding force behind Italy's activist EC presidency has been De Michelis, a rotund, ebullient, rapid-fire talker who relaxes after council meetings by going disco dancing. Among the projects he has promoted: -The Pentagonal Initiative, a grouping of Italy, Austria, Hungary, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia designed to bolster political and economic development in central and Eastern Europe as a counterweight to a unified Germany. -A similar alliance of four West European countries and five Arab states of North Africa to work for political and economic stability in the Mediterranean region. -A joint proposal with Spain to hold a conference on peace and security in the Mediterranean - possibly extending to the entire Middle East - on the lines of the Helsinki conference on European security. -A proposal for the EC to assume a formal military dimension by absorbing the Western European Union, a body which loosely coordinates defense policies of nine EC states. -A proposal for a meeting of EC and Arab foreign ministers to discuss the gulf crisis. Of these, only the Pentagonal Initiative seems to have achieved success. The proposal for a Mediterranean peace conferenee has been stalled by the complexities of the Middle East conflicts. The idea of an EC military arm has been opposed by neutral Ireland, while Britain and other states say NATO should remain the lynchpin of European security. Perhaps most embarrassing for De Michelis was the cancellation of a scheduled meeting in Venice earlier this month of EC and Arab League foreign ministers. Several Arab states refused to come because Iraq was not invited. De Michelis says he still hopes the meeting can be held, perhaps in November. Sniping against Italy's chairmanship has grown in recent weeks. The British magazine, The Economist, said that while De Michelis has generated many ideas, diplomats believe he is unable to ``channel them constructively.'' ``Italy's presidency is proving like a bus trip with the Marx Brothers in the driver's seat,'' The Economist quoted a senior Brussels diplomat as saying. ``A lot of talk but little action,'' is how The Wall Street Journal summed up the view in Brussels. Italy has brushed off the criticism, arguing that Europe needs to be more active in keeping up with the rapid changes in the world. Italy has always considered itself one of the staunchest advocates of European unity and integration. In a referendum last year, more than 80 percent of Italians supported the idea of giving the European Parliament powers to draft a new treaty of European Union. When Italy took over the rotating EC presidency in July, the main priority was to speed up the community's process of political, economic and monetary integration. But since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the EC has been forced to deal with issues of security and Europe's role beyond its immediate borders. While the EC members swiftly agreed on sweeping economic sanctions against Iraq, the consensus frayed over the military response to back them up. Only Britain and France have committed ground troops to the multinational gulf force. This weekend's summit will bring together the 12 EC leaders for the first time since the gulf crisis began, but it was not planned that way. The meeting is listed as an emergency summit, even though it was scheduled before Italy took over the presidency. Rome apparently wanted to keep up with its predecessors, France and Ireland, which called emergency summits to deal with changes in Eastern Europe and German reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Cops Say Bembenek's Resume Lies Tarnish Her Cult Hero Status
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with hearing delayed; lawyer seeks to bar news media. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Ms. Bembenek had...'.
DOC.TEXT: Police vexed at the folk-hero following of Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek say the convicted killer showed her true colors when she created a phony identity after her prison escape. Ms. Bembenek, a 32-year-old former model, Milwaukee police officer and Playboy club waitress, was captured earlier this month in Canada, months after breaking out of a Wisconsin prison. She was serving a life sentence for murder. She had faced a deportation hearing today in Thunder Bay, Ontario, where she was captured Oct. 17. But the hearing was delayed for a week this morning after he lawyers requested more time to prepare their response to illegal immigration charges and also sought to bar news media from the hearing. ``There is a tradition in Canada that we try people in court; we don't try them in the media,'' said David Dubinski, a lawyer for Ms. Bembenek. Adjudicator Carmen DeCarlo delayed a decision on media access until next week and told Ms. Bembenek's lawyers they'll need to present arguments then if they need further delays for the deportation hearing. Ms. Bembenek had claimed she was framed for the killing, and supporters who argued she deserved a new trial cheered her escape in July and took to wearing ``Run, Bambi, Run'' T-shirts. But authorities said Wednesday a bogus resume she used to find work in Canada shows her capacity for deceit. ``It certainly does take a little of the luster off the Bembenek legend,'' said Fond du Lac County sheriff's Lt. Ed Sheppard. The resume identified her as Jennifer Voelkel Gazanna, born Jan. 7, 1961. A child named Jennifer Lee Voelkel - born the same date - died at one month and was buried in a Milwaukee cemetery. Police said Ms. Bembenek may have obtained the dead child's birth certificate and used it to establish a false identity. The resume said she was a prison social worker for nine years and served as a member of the governor's advisory council on AIDS. It also contained a bogus educational background. Ms. Bembenek, 32, was fired from the Milwaukee police force for lying on a report. Prosecutors convinced a jury she killed her husband's ex-wife in 1981 because she disliked the amount of alimony the woman received. After a tip from someone who recognized her from the TV show ``America's Most Wanted,'' she was captured in Thunder Bay, where she was working as a waitress. Her fiance, Dominic Gugliatto, 35, also was arrested. A private detective trying to help Ms. Bembenek get a new trial said authorities were desperately trying to besmirch her claims of innocence. No one who escaped from prison would tell the truth on a resume, Ira Robins said. ``That is absolutely ridiculous.'' The Milwaukee investigator said he has evidence that Ms. Bembenek was framed because she had knowledge of police corruption, but he complained that few are willing to listen. ``There has been no investigation of the corruption I have pointed out,'' he said. ``I am trying to get a woman some justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Ill Feelings Swirl Around Flag Removal Order
DOC.TEXT: Managers of an apartment complex have forced most residents to remove American flags flown in support of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, saying the flags were a safety hazard. Two veterans groups denounced the apartment management as unpatriotic. Most residents of the Plantation Apartments were defiant Wednesday, saying the management was being un-American. But by the end of the day, most complied, removing the small flags that have been flying since mid-September. About 30 residents had displayed the flags, which hung from 30-inch wooden poles outside near the apartment doors. Residents were given notices Monday and Tuesday to remove the flags or maintenance workers would dispose of them. Apartment officials said they will allow flags to be displayed on doors and windows as long as they don't create a hazard. ``We, like the residents who are complaining, are behind our boys in the Mideast all the way,'' said Sylvia Rizk, chairman of Houston International Management Co., which manages the complex. ``Patriotism should never be abused by using it as a reason to disregard safe practices.'' The safety concern, Rizk said, was that the flags jutted into passageways even though they were hung well above eye level. The management company also complained that residents had drilled holes in exterior walls for the flags. Joe Coyle, spokesman for Kor-Vets, the Texas Chapter of the Korean War Veterans Association, said the order to remove the flags was unpatriotic, whatever the reason. He said his organization would back any residents who want to fight the move. The national president of the Brotherhood for Vietnam Veterans, who is a Houston resident, also denounced the management company's actions. ``It causes me to wonder just where the priorities are for these folks living in this country,'' Sibley Cooley said. ``Obviously these people who wanted to fly the flags wanted to fly it because they had a deeper sense of commitment and patriotism.''

DOC.HEAD: Read Their Lips: Americans `Plumb Fed Up' With the District of Contempt
DOC.TEXT: Retired sheet metal worker Ben McAbee knows politics is rarely pretty. But lately, he says, what's been going on in Washington has been downright disgusting. ``I think people are getting plumb fed up with it,'' McAbee said. From California, where 20-year-old Monique Osborne said simply, ``I think it's way bad,'' to Maryland, where Vincent Broco described the U.S. government as a ``circus,'' anti-Washington sentiment is running deeper than the deficit. In Tampa, there's a group called ``Throw the Rascals Out.'' Radio call-in shows across the country hear strong anti-Washington sentiments. The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune set up a phone line for readers who want to complain. Newspaper ads have suggested that all incumbents be tossed overboard. The showdown over a new budget between Congress and President Bush has been about as popular as Roseanne Barr's rendition of the National Anthem. The District of Columbia is now the District of Contempt. ``They would have to clean Washington right out completely and start over,'' said Don Hart, who was running errands Wednesday in downtown Traverse City, Mich. ```Disgusted' isn't the word. `Mad' would be a better one.'' Many everyday Americans interviewed around the country this week said they were following the budget battle closely, and didn't like what they saw. From Bush on down, no one appeared immune to wrath. Politicians' performances seem to have gotten worse over the years, people said, and this year is the worst yet. ``I'm pretty upset about it actually,'' said Neil Tucker, a 34-year-old commercial real estate broker in Baltimore. ``We elect these people to represent us and they're more concerned with their special interests and getting re-elected than voting their convictions.'' ``I blame leadership,'' Tucker added. ``I blame the people in Congress. They're all basically a bunch of jokers.'' ``I'm not going to vote for a single incumbent,'' said Tomas Martinez, a New Mexico state government clerk who lives in Albuquerque. ``I think it's time to give others a chance. ... Maybe they'll think more like a consumer, like a taxpayer, rather than remaining in office feathering their own nest.'' Polls show public confidence in government is at a two-decade low, and Bush's approval ratings at their lowest levels of his presidency. Congress' approval ratings are even lower - a Newsweek poll found 52 percent would be willing to fire the whole Congress. And a recent ABC News/Washington Post poll found a record 79 percent of those surveyed said the country is on the wrong track. ``They've got no respect for us and we've got no respect for them,'' said farmer David Guise, who runs a fruit stand outside Dallas. ``It's a helluva mess. Washington has got too many millionaires in there, and they don't care about the working man.'' ``As far as pointing fingers, I think it's everybody's fault,'' said Art McArdle, who administers a surveyor's apprenticeship program in Oakland, Calif. ``It's an appalling situation. I think the problem is they've known that this was going to happen and they didn't take the bull by the horns soon enough.'' ``Yes, I'm following it,'' construction worker Gary King in Des Moines, Iowa, said of the budget battle. ``I've been following it for 12 years and it seems like it always falls on the working-class man. It doesn't make a whole lot of sense.'' At the Diplomat Mall in Hallandale, Fla., a senior-dominated Broward County city, Laura Goldman said: ``We're all watching it. Look, we're on fixed incomes. They're talking about increasing the cost of Medicare? They should decrease it. ``I don't think it will ever be straightened out. I have grandchildren, and I worry about that budget deficit for them.'' Larry Nusbaum, an artist displaying his acrylics on the Santa Fe, N.M., plaza, blamed the American people more than Congress or Bush for the budget fiasco. The public makes so many conflicting demands on the federal government, he said. Nusbaum said his opinion of Congress ``wasn't very high to begin with, but I can understand their dilemma.'' ``It's not Congress, it's us. They receive the messages from us. We get the government that we deserve. You can blame the government all you want to, and that doesn't cut the cake,'' Nusbaum said. Tax increases expected in the new budget are a particular sore spot. McAbee, the Texas retiree who sells handmade pillows and quilts from a roadside stand, complained that the rich should shoulder a heavier burden. Increasing cigarette, gasoline and beer taxes will hit the working-class hard, he said. ``They didn't tax wine because that's what they drink,'' McAbee said. ``But some poor bastard who has to buy gasoline to drive to work and have a cold beer when he gets home, they're going to tax him to death.'' ``It's politics,'' said Hart in Traverse City, Mich. ``We don't have any statesmen anymore. All we have is politicians.'' ---
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: This story also was reported by Mike Glover in Des Moines, Iowa; Ed Moreno in Santa Fe, N.M.; John Roll in Baltimore; Dan Sewell in Miami; Paige St. John in Traverse City, Mich.; and Kathleen Grubb in Sacramento, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Faces Mass Starvation, U.S. Relief Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Starvation of ``apocalyptic'' proportions is endangering as many as 11 million Sudanese but their government is blocking international food deliveries, U.S. relief officials said Thursday. Administration officials, testifying before the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said Sudan's military government refused to recognize the danger and has derailed a U.S.-led rescue under U.N. auspices that would have saved many Sudanese from hunger. ``The government in Khartoum has been increasingly indifferent if not overtly hostile to the relief efforts,'' said Andrew Natsios, the administration's top relief official. Due to drought and civil war, this year's harvest could fall short by as much as one million metric tons, leaving up to eight million Sudanese to starve, he said. Other relief organizations put the number of those in danger as high as 11 million, said Roger Winter, director of the private U.S. Committee for Refugees. ``If the actual level of need is as high as some people fear, and the donor community is not allowed to respond, we are looking at an apocalyptic situation worse than in Ethiopia in 1984,'' said Natsios, Director of the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. An estimated 250,000 Ethiopians died of hunger in that famine. About 75 percent of the Sudanese at risk live in government-held territory, and the rest in rebel-held lands in southern Sudan. U.S. officials accuse the government, which seized power in a military coup 16 months ago, of preventing food from reaching the south where the Sudan's People Liberation Army has been fighting for autonomy since 1983. The SPLA, too, has used food in its war, shooting down relief planes and attacking trains and truck convoys carrying food from neighboring Kenya. Sudanese planes last month bombed several towns in the south which serve as center of Operation Lifeline Sudan, prompting the United States to temporarily suspend its sales of wheat to the government and to recall Ambassador James Cheek to Washington for consultations. But the government has also prevented food supplies from reaching areas it controls and has spurned U.S. urgings to call for international help. As a result of this attitude and of the harassment of relief workers, Natsios said, European donors have all but stopped helping. The United States, Natsios said, is willing to provide one-third of an emergency 300,000-ton food shipment needed to avert mass starvation. An estimated 50,000 tons of U.S. donated food are already been stored in Sudan, he added. But unless the Sudanese government allows relief workers to distribute the food and turns to the international community for more help, ``we will not be able to respond in time if the call for help goes out after people start dying.'' Winter said he traveled to Sudan last month ``out of concern that famine of biblical dimensions was building.'' He suggested the United States lead a campaign for international economic sanctions against Sudan's government, of the type imposed on Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. But administration officials doubted this would be much help. The United States has stopped everything except emergency aid to Sudan and so ``levers of traditional pressure are not available,'' said Jeffrey Davidow, acting Assistant Secretary of State for Africa. ``And there's not much of an economy left that we can embargo,'' added Natsios. Civil war, years of government incompetence, and isolation by the world community have wreaked havoc on Sudan's economy, he said. Sudan's military suppliers are Iraq, Libya and China - countries with which the United States has little influence, Davidow said. Officials predict the arms flow from Iraq will be limited by the international embargo on President Saddam Hussein. The Sudanese government has also been cut off by other benefactors - Saudi Arabia and Kuwait - as a result of its support for Saddam, the officials said. ``I would like to emphasize that Sudan's position on the Iraq-Kuwait crisis does not affect in any way'' U.S. relief operations, Davidow said. ``We are not using food as a weapon.''

DOC.HEAD: Sales Of Existing Homes At Slowest Pace In Nearly Three Years
DOC.TEXT: Declining consumer confidence and the Persian Gulf crisis pushed September sales of existing homes down 8 percent, a real estate trade group reported Thursday. It was the slowest pace in nearly three years. The National Association of Realtors said resales totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.22 million houses, the slowest pace since a 3.20 million rate in January 1988. All regions posted sales declines except for the Northeast, which was unchanged from an already low level. The August rate had been 3.50 million. Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said declining confidence in the economy has been fueled by uncertainty over the impact of federal budget legislation and the Persian Gulf situation. ``Consumers don't know what to expect,'' Flynn said. ``When people don't know what's coming, they tend to delay big-ticket expenditures. Many of them put their home buying plans on hold.'' The South led the sales decline, falling 10.0 percent to an annual rate of 1.26 million units. In addition to consumer confidence, Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo said the deployment of military troops from Southern bases to the Persian Gulf decreased demand for houses and upset the local economies. ``The military pullout has taken more buyers from the marketplace than the ones sent overseas,'' Tuccillo said. ``Companies in those areas that rely on military business are hurting. The economic fallout has interrupted purchase plans of civilians.'' The Commerce Department next Tuesday will report on September new home sales. Sales of new homes fell 1.4 percent in August to a 550,000 annual rate. Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said higher interest rates, rising unemployment and the uncertainty of Middle East developments will keep the housing market sluggish for months to come. But Holloway said the September existing home sales ``was not as negative as shown on the surface.'' Noting the jump in sales to 3.5 million units in August, he said the average of the two months comes out to 3.3 million houses - ``right in line'' with the level of sales in the previous four months. According to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages averaged between 10.19 percent and 10.22 percent in September. The rates generally were higher than the average during the first half of the year. ``Buyers scaled back their purchases partly because of slightly higher rates,'' Flynn said. ``But economic uncertainty played a much bigger role.'' The median price of an existing home nationally fell 2.9 percent, to $94,300. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. The West posted a resale rate of 520,000 units, down 8.8 percent. The median home price was $134,700, a 3.9 percent decline from August. Sales in the Midwest were off 7.1 percent, to 920,000 units. The median price was $74,000, a 1.7 percent drop. Sales in the Northeast remained unchanged at 520,000 despite a 5.6 percent drop in the median price to $137,100. The median price in the South was $85,900, down 1.2 percent from August.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Sends Quick Message: No Imported Faxes
DOC.TEXT: Brazil has rejected a proposal to remove fax machines from a list of products barred from import - a list that includes personal computers and automatic bank teller machines. The decision Wednesday night by a government commission, over the objections of Brazil's communications secretary, keeps the facsimile mail machines among imported items banned in an effort to encourage local manufacturers. Communications Secretary Joel Rauber said it was unfair to keep Brazilians from acquiring imported machines, which cost less than one-third the price of domestic models. A thriving industry has sprouted up in smuggled faxes. Federal police often make surprise baggage inspections at international airports - not for drugs or machineguns, but for faxes and laptop computers. Federal agents also raid offices demanding to see local receipts for faxes and computers. If proof of Brazilian manufacture is not forthcoming, police seize the machines. Rauber had argued that fax machines had become ``part of everyday office use and personal communications.'' The government's Computer-and-Automation-Policy Council didn't get the message. Science and Technology Secretary Jose Goldemberg, who also is the head of the council, said allowing imports of faxes would wreck Braziliarm bill after the GATT talks end on Dec. 31. The National Grange has said the $13.6 billion cut ordered for USDA programs represented ``unilateral disarmament'' by the United States in the trade talks. The Grange's national master, Robert Barrow, said the costs of trimming the budget deficit should be borne more equitably. Rob Nooter of the American Farm Bureau Federation's Washington office said Wednesday that the farm bill and its tie to the $500 billion budget-reduction package is ``certainly going to have an impact on farm income.'' Some of the income lost from reduced deficiency payments will be made up by other features of the 1990 farm bill, but not all of it, he said. Federation President Dean Kleckner said last week that he wasn't happy with all of the farm bill but urged its adoption. ``Although farm program budget cuts are disproportionate, and we accept them with great reluctance, the bill will continue agricultural market orientation and give farmers greater planting flexibility,'' he said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The 1990 farm law will be a prime topic of discussion as the Agriculture Department unlimbers its annual outlook conference next month. It will be the 67th USDA meeting for economists, farm leaders, commodity experts and others to look at what may be forthcoming in the year ahead. This year's session is Nov. 27-29. The opening day will include talks by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleberger, conference officials said Wednesday. They will be followed by Sidney L. Jones, assistant secretary of the treasury for economic policy, who will present the economic outlook for 1991. USDA officials will discuss prospects for farmers, consumers and agricultural exports. Other first-day events will include a panel discussion on European and Soviet Union affairs. Commodity prospects and the outlook under new farm legislation will be highlights during the remainder of the conference, along with environmental and energy issues. Among the forecasts will be USDA's first for consumer food prices in 1991, and its predictions for exports and farm income. The impact of higher oil prices will be a major factor in the 1991 farm income forecast. Energy also will be important in looking ahead at retail food prices. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Production of farm-raised catfish dropped 9 percent last month from a year earlier to 27.6 million pounds, according to a monthly report by the Agriculture Department. However, the report said the average price paid by processors to growers in September was 78 cents per pound, up 13 cents from a year ago. On a cumulative basis, catfish farmers delivered about 277.8 million pounds of catfish to processors through September, compared with 255.3 million pounds in the same nine months of 1989. Imports of freshwater catfish, mostly from Brazil, are down from a year ago. The report said imports in August, the most recent month calculated, totaled 362,000 pounds, down 14 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Privatization Law
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a law to put into private hands about 100,000 small shops and enterprises that were nationalized during four decades of Communist rule. The privatization process is a key part of reforms aimed at transforming Czechoslovakia's centralized economy into a Western-style one guided by market mechanisms. The law was approved by 202 of the 239 deputies present and voting, the state CTK news agency reported. Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, who presented the draft to the legislature Wednesday, said it was a compromise ``which cannot satisfy all completely.'' The measure will apply to some 100,000 shops and small enterprises with an overall value of about $83 million, equivalent to nearly half the nation's annual budget. Thousands of vendors across the country staged symbolic strikes last month demanding they be given first crack at buying the shops. They wanted to pay up to half the purchase price in installemnts spread over a seven-year period. The vendors were afraid they would be shut out by people with large amounts of capital to invest - foreigners, or onetime Communist functionaries who amassed fortunes under the former government. Although the government draft would have given employees of the enterprises being bought the option of installment payments over five years, the version approved by Parliament scrapped that provision. Auctions will be held in two rounds, with the first round open only to Czechoslovak citizens and those who emigrated after the Communists came to power in 1948. Shops and enterprises which are not sold in the first round will proceed to the second, in which some foreigners will also be allowed to bid. The bidding will begin at prices determined by the government. The minimum price acceptable for any shop sold is 50 percent of the government-proposed amount. If the second-round auction is attended only by Czechoslovak citizens, the minimum purchase price required will be 20 percent of the original amount. The new law is to take effect on Dec. 1, CTK said. Privatization of large industrial plants and the agricultural sector is expected to begin in early 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Terminally Ill Man Wins Right to Die Suit in Israel
DOC.TEXT: A terminaly ill man seeking the right to die won a court ruling Thursday that says doctors must consider his request not to be connected to a life-support machine should the need arise. Tel Aviv District Court Judge Uri Goren ruled that doctors would not face criminal charges if they accepted 50-year-old Binyamin Eyal's request, even if the patient was unconscious at the time. Eyal's lawyer, Shir Adonevitch, said the ruling could set a precedent in Israel. ``For the first time ... a district court recognizes the right of a man over his body,'' Adonevitch said. Eyal's wife, Pnina, told Israel radio she was thankful for the ruling. ``It manifests the last wish of my husband, which is to die with honor, without any needless torture. He has suffered enough,'' she said. The plaintiff sued for the right to order his doctor to avoid prolonging his life by artificial means after he loses consciousness. Eyal suffers from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, better known as Lou Gehrig's disease. It is an incurable illness that causes the breakdown of the muscular system. Dr. Nahman Wilenski, who is treating Eyal, recently told the Jerusalem Post that his patient was having trouble breathing, but he could not say when he would need a respirator. The ruling said the decision whether to connect Eyal to an respirator would be left to the director of the hospital where the plaintiff is being treated.

DOC.HEAD: 9 Years And Many Delays Later, Man Found Guilty Of Rape
DOC.TEXT: A man who claimed he was suffering from post-Vietnam stress was convicted for a second time today of the 1981 rape-kidnap of a woman who went public with her ordeal after years of delays and a retrial. A jury found Robert Percy guilty on all four counts in the 1981 attack on Sue Kremelberg. ``God, yea!'' Kremelberg said, her fists raised in the air, after the jury read its verdict. She and her family then hugged in the courtroom. Percy was accused of raping Kremelberg in 1981 while out on bail after raping an Essex attorney, Susan Sweetser, just weeks earlier. In both cases Percy was convicted of rape by a lower court. In both cases, the Vermont Supreme Court sent the cases back for retrial. The state's highest court recently upheld Percy's second conviction in the Sweetser case. For 10 years the women have been forced repeatedly to return to a Vermont courtroom to recount their ordeals. And outrage over that experience prompted them to go public with their cases earlier this year. ``I want people to know the outrage,'' Kremelberg said recently. Their accounts, in turn, have prompted calls for reforms in the Vermont judiciary that has allowed the cases to drag on through trials, state Supreme Court hearings and retrials. Vermont Attorney General Jeffrey Amestoy, in a note to Sweetser the day the court upheld Percy's conviction in her case, wrote, ``Nine years late. May my daughters have your courage and may they have a fairer and faster criminal justice system.'' Percy does not deny raping Kremelberg, but says he was insane at the time, suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and reliving a Vietnam War flashback. Percy's lawyer, James Dumont, pointed in closing arguments Wednesday to the testimony of psychiatrists, which he said showed Percy was ``wounded in the brain'' by his Vietnam experience. But prosecutor Phillip Cykon said Percy was in control of his actions at the time of the attack. ``The Vietnam War is not on trial here,'' Cykon said. ``Post-tramatic stress disorder alone is not enough to excuse criminal behavior.'' Kremelberg faced Percy for the second time in the courtroom last week. Her voice calm, but at times in tears, she recounted for the jury her nine-hour ordeal on the night of Jan. 16, 1981, when she stopoped at a garage in Stowe where Percy was an attendant. She testified that Percy told her to back her car to the air pump, located in a darker section of the station's lot, because her left tire looked low. She said Percy then jumped into her car, pulled out a gun and forced her to drive away. She was tied up and raped twice before Percy fled.
