DOC.HEAD: Progress Reported Toward Lyme Disease Vaccine
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Yale University efforts with lab mice could lead to a vaccine against Lyme disease in humans, and perhaps against syphilis as well, researchers say. In a study to be published Friday in the journal Science, a Yale team reported that a Lyme disease vaccine for mice was made with a gene-engineering technique that could be applied to other diseases, such as syphilis, that are caused by a type of bacteria called spirochetes. ``It's very likely that we'll be able to get a good vaccine for humans from this technique,'' said Richard A. Flavell, leader of the Yale team. ``If it works on this disease, then it may be used to develop vaccines against other diseases with spirochetes, such as syphilis.'' A Harvard researcher, however, said that the success of a Lyme disease vaccine, even for mice, cannot be proven until the immunity is tested against disease in the way it is naturally spread - through a tick bite. David H. Persing of the Harvard School of Public Health said that the saliva of Lyme disease-infected ticks also contains substances that depress some immune functions. A vaccine would be proven, he said, only when it is shown to give protection against the effects of these substances also. Lyme disease was first identified in 1975 and named for the Connecticut town where a Yale study was conducted. The disease is spread by a small deer tick that passes along the spirochete when it sucks blood from a victim. The disease can cause heart problems, arthritis-like joint pain, skin rash and even brain disorders. Identified early, Lyme disease can be successfully treated with antibiotics. Flavell said that to develop the Lyme disease vaccine, the Yale scientists first had to find a special inbred strain of laboratory mice able to contract the disease. He said Stephen W. Barthold, a Yale veterinary scientist, found that a mouse strain called C3H/He could be infected with the Lyme disease spirochete and develop symptoms within five days. To make the vaccine, the Yale researchers cloned a gene for a protein, called OspA, that is on the surface of the Lyme spirochete. The gene was then spliced into a common laboratory bacteria that then produced the OspA protein. A purified form of OspA was injected into a group of mice and tests showed that the rodents developed antibodies to the protein. Inoculated mice then were injected with the Lyme spirochete. Mice that had been injected with the OspA protein did not get Lyme disease. Antibodies made by the mouse immune system in response to the OspA protein were able to keep the bacteria in check. Other mice that had not received the OspA shots developed the Lyme symptoms. Dr. Erol Fikrig, a member of the Yale team, said the study required injecting the bacteria because the researchers had to know exactly how much spirochete each mouse received. Using a tick to spread the disease, he said, ``would be highly variable and could not be reproduced'' precisely. Fikrig acknowledged that the laboratory test of the vaccine is not a true test of its effectiveness against the tick-born disease. ``In nature, things could be different and further studies on that will have to be done,'' he said. The importance of the study, he said, is that some immune protection was demonstrated against a spirochete bacteria. ``The fact that we can make a vaccine against this organism is certainly encouraging that vaccines against other spirochete illnesses can be developed as well, and that includes syphilis,'' said Fikrig. Flavell said it will take five to eight years of additional laboratory work before the experimental Lyme disease vaccine can be tried on humans. Science, which is publishing the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Historic Books Stolen from University, Sold Abroad
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 3,800 rare books and historic documents have vanished from the Wroclaw University library, apparently sold abroad under the guise of academic exchanges, a newspaper reported Thursday. The thefts were discovered early this year by German researchers working on the collection that came into Polish hands when the German city of Breslau became the Polish city of Wroclaw at the end of World War II. Government auditors and the prosecutor's office have launched an investigation and asked the university rector for disciplinary proceedings against library employees, as well as to start putting the collection in order, according to the Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper. The library houses one of Europe's largest collections of books from the Middle Ages among its 1.5 million volumes, the newspaper said. Auditors said the thefts occurred even after they started their inspection of the library. Investigators concluded that traditional inter-library exchanges of books between universities for academic research were being exploited for commercial purposes, according to Gazeta Wyborcza. Between 1986 and June 1990, 3,793 manuscripts were sent abroad and sold without appropriate permission, the newspaper said. It said it was impossible to determine the prices the documents sold for because the dealings were not recorded by the university accounting office. The customs declarations offer few clues because in 860 cases they state the materials were being exported for free exchange and did not have cultural value, according to the report. Poland has strict laws about exporting pre-1945 antiques, artwork and other items designed to protect the country's cultural heritage. Other investigations have shown, however, that loose controls on museums, the financially beleaguered state of cultural institutions, and abuses by authorities led to the disappearance of many treasures from national art and museum collections during the Communist regime. The government auditing bureau also suggested the collection was not properly cared for because it wasn't Polish. ``The essential reason for this negligence is an inappropriate approach to formerly German collections, by both employees of the library and the scientific staff of the university,'' the auditing bureau said.

DOC.HEAD: Women Get Pregnant After Menopause with Test-Tube Fertilization
DOC.TEXT: The latest medical technology lets women turn back their biological clocks and get pregnant after menopause, but also raises questions about how old is too old for child rearing. Doctors say they can extend women's baby-making years well into their 40s, 50s and perhaps 60s, providing a second chance for those who waited too long to start families. However, some doctors have doubts about the wisdom of childbearing for those who are well past nature's own cutoff. ``Because we can do something technically does not mean we should do it indiscriminately,'' said Dr. Zev Rosenwaks. ``The ability to become pregnant is a physical sign of what nature itself expects of a woman. You cannot push nature past the point where you interfere with safety.'' Rosenwaks is head of the fertility clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, one of several hospitals around the country that has begun using the new technology. The process, described in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, is a variation on the now-routine process of in vitro fertilization, conception in the lab dish. Ordinarily, doctors remove eggs from an infertile woman's ovaries, mix them with sperm and then put the embryos into her womb. However, this is not possible if the woman's ovaries have stopped working, the change of life known as menopause. Until recently, that was the end of the reproductive line for women. But now, doctors are removing eggs from healthy young donors and implanting them in older women after they have been fertilized with sperm. Because the mother does not provide the egg, she is not the genetic parent of her baby, but still undergoes a normal pregnancy and delivery. The major limits to the technique are the health of the mother and the cost - $8,000 for each attempt plus a $1,500 payment to the egg donor. In the journal, Dr. Mark V. Sauer of the University of Southern California described the use of the technique on seven women over 40 whose ``ovaries didn't last as long as their desire to have babies.'' Menopause usually occurs around age 50, but in about 10 percent of women the ovaries stop working by age 40. Sometimes these women have delayed having children, often while they establish their careers. ``Many women are coming in 40 years of age or older. They have an air of desperation. It's their last chance,'' said Dr. Anne Wentz, who has a ``geriatric infertility'' practice at Northwestern University. Pregnancy is riskier for older women than young ones. They are more likely to have high blood pressure, premature labor and bleeding. Wentz and others noted that there is simply no way to know the effects of carrying and delivering a child on a women in her 50s and beyond. ``We don't have any data on that. It opens up a Pandora's box,'' said Dr. Steven Bayer of New England Medical Center. Others noted that older women should carefully think about whether they have the stamina to deal with 2 a.m. feedings and other rigors of bringing up babies. ``There is concern about progressively older individuals trying to provide parenting for an infant and a child as it grows up,'' said Dr. Machelle Seibel of Faulkner Hospital in Boston. ``I have no right to say what is the right age, but at some point there has to be limits to what age is appropriate.'' Dr. Kamren Moghissi of Wayne State University added, ``Some of them won't live to see their kids get married or even graduate from college. The natural lifespan for women is around 80 years, but some women die at age 60 or 65. These women obviously won't see their children grow up.'' While the image of the ticking biological clock became a familiar one for young professional women in the last decade, there is some evidence of a reversal in the popularity of postponement of childbearing for a career. A Time magazine poll of 505 Americans ages 18-24 taken last month by Yankelovich Clancy Shulman found 51 percent put having a long and happy marriage and raising well-adjusted children ahead of career success.

DOC.HEAD: Finishing Touches Being Applied to Deficit-Reduction Package
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 10 grafs new with White House reaction; picks up pvs 4th graf, White House...; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders, in virtual agreement on major tax issues, sought spending compromises today as they neared completion of a deficit-reduction plan that has the tentative support of a majority of lawmakers and President Bush. However, despite the apparent agreement, Republicans today were emphasizing remaining differences among negotiators. ``There's nothing the president has signed off on yet. It's not just one issue. There must be two dozen important issues that haven't been resolved,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said after an afternoon White House meeting. Still, Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., declared ``do not despair; the end is in sight,'' as the House and Senate inched toward final adjournment of the 101st Congress. Bush, who averted a partial shutdown of the government by signing a temporary spending measure to keep operations going until midnight Saturday, said it was time to get the budget crisis ``behind us.'' At a Rose Garden picture-taking session with GOP leaders designed to try to show resurrected GOP unity, Bush said he was now ready to turn his full attention to campaigning for GOP candidates. ``We are totally committed in our determination to send a sound, strong Republican message across this country,'' Bush said. ``We've been bludgeoned by a bunch of demagogic attacks by the Democrats for months,'' Bush said. But even that unity seemed fragile. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., who abandoned Bush on the original budget agreement, was invited to the unity session but still refused to pledge support for the emerging package. ``Since the plan doesn't exist, despite your myopic focus on it, I don't think any of us have an obligation to tell you in advance what we would do'' in terms of voting for the package, Gingrich told reporters. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was satisfied with the overall final package that was emerging, although there were still some details to be worked out. ``There have been compromises on both sides,'' Fitzwater said, noting that the package meets Bush's overall goal of a $500-billion, five-year budget package. A senior administration official, briefing a group of reporters on the condition of anonymity, said Bush expected wide bipartisan support in both chambers for the budget deal. Assuming no unexpected hitch, final votes on the deficit-reduction package could come Friday in the House and Senate. That would close another chapter in a long-running fight between the executive and legislative branches and remove the major obstacle to adjournment - barely a week before the Nov. 6 elections. ``We still have a lot of work to do,'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, told reporters as leaders began another series of closed meetings to work out the budget plan. The plan will mean higher taxes on tobacco, alcoholic beverages, airline tickets, cars, boats, furs and jewelry. A gasoline tax increase of 5 or 6 cents a gallon is likely and retirees probably will have to pay more for Medicare coverage. Several changes whose details were still being negotiated will mean heftier income taxes on those with higher incomes, especially those above the $100,000-a-year range. But a provision that would have raised taxes on lower-and middle-income Americans by forgoing next year's scheduled inflation adjustment in income taxes was dropped. Leaders of both parties embraced broad outlines of the deficit-reduction compromise Wednesday after Democrats dropped demands that it include a special surtax on the rich. Negotiators said sizable problems remained to be worked out on spending for Medicare, Medicaid and farm programs. The talks have produced preliminary agreement on major tax issues ncluding: -Raising the top tax rate on the wealthiest people to 31 percent from the present 28 percent. The 33 percent rate paid by upper-middle-income people on some of their earnings would drop to 31 percent. -Phasing out the $2,050 personal exemptions for single people with taxable incomes over $100,000 and couples above $150,000. -Permitting writing off only 97 percent of otherwise allowable deductions against any portion of adjusted gross income over $100,000 a year. -Setting a maximum tax rate of 28 percent on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments. That would mean a tax cut for those whose gains are now taxed at 33 percent but would fall far short of the general capital-gains tax cut that Bush has demanded. The bill that contains tax increases and restraints on Medicare and other mandatory spending would cut the deficit by about $250 billion over the next five years. Another $250 billion would come principally from scaling back military spending and cutting interest expenses by reducing government borrowing. Even with that package, government spending is expected to total $1.2 trillion during the 12 months that end next Sept. 30 and the deficit still would be a record $250 billion. The bill envisions that today's federal debt of $3 trillion-plus will soar to $5 trillion by the end of the five-year period. The emerging compromise has bipartisan support in the Senate and backing from a clear majority of House Democrats. However, vote-counters ay House Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois will be lucky to get 50 of the 176 GOP members behind the plan, despite Bush's pleas. Most House Republicans adamantly oppose any tax increase.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Police sold Bjorn Borg's villa at a forced auction Thursday after the former tennis star failed to pay more than $3.75 million in debts, Sweden's TT news agency reported. The three-story villa, in the Stockholm suburb of Nacka, fetched $1.9 million from Lars Nilsson, a hotel owner from southern Sweden who said he would use it as a summer house. The villa lies near the Stockholm archipelago and had been valued at between $2.1 million and $2.7 million, the news agency said. Borg, a five-time Wimbledon champion, has had financial troubles since his attempts to build a clothing empire failed two years ago. --- SUPERIOR, Wis. (AP) - Canadian singer Gordon Lightfoot sent a check for $2,500 after a group raising funds for a new ice arena asked for an autographed item for a celebrity auction. Superior made Lightfoot an honorary citizen when he performed last year at nearby Duluth, Minn. Mayor Herb Bergson said it would have taken quite a few items to produce as much money for the Superior Amateur Hockey Association's arena as Lightfoot's check did. Bergson said the city was honoring Lightfoot for his song ``The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald.'' Residents of Superior died in 1975 on the ore carrying ship. The hockey association needs about $60,000 to put the finishing touches on the arena, Bergson said. --- TOWN AND COUNTRY, Mo. (AP) - First lady Barbara Bush and her dog Millie won't attend the opening of a new wing at the Dog Museum of America, but Millie will be represented by a painting. Animal artist Christine Merrill has completed a painting depicting the English springer spaniel in front of the White House, museum president Dorothy Welsh said Wednesday. The painting, done from photographs, will be displayed at the museum. Mrs. Bush got Millie three years ago after the death of the family's longtime dog, C. Fred Bush. Millie's full name is Mildred Kerr Bush. Millie became famous when she appeared on the cover of Life magazine in 1989 after having puppies. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Actress Bo Derek and her producer-director husband, John, stopped at the White House Thursday and got a tour of the grounds from President Bush. The actress was in town for the Washington International Horse Show, according to the White House press office. ``She called and wanted to see the White House,'' said spokeswoman Alixe Glen. Bush had canceled campaign appearances in Arizona and New Mexico because of the precarious state of negotiations as Congress and the administration sought agreement on a $500-billion deficit-reduction package. So the president had no scheduled activities on his public agenda. Several young, male White House aides clustered in the hallways with a gaggle of reporters and photographers to catch a glimpse of the blond actress through the glass doors leading to the Rose Garden. The president was seen escorting the couple along the driveway near the Oval Office. --- SEATTLE (AP) - Nancy and Ann Wilson of the rock group Heart plan a concert to raise money for environmental groups working to preserve Puget Sound, an area they say is threatened by pollution and other environmental hazards. The sisters, who grew up in the Seattle area, say they want the proceeds from ``Puget Sound Live'' to benefit wildlife species threatened by the area's booming population. ``Every day the Sound's marine life is threatened,'' Ann Wilson said at a news conference Wednesday. ``Many wildlife species, from eagles to the smallest creatures in our few remaining wetlands, are forced to retreat or become extinct.'' The concert, scheduled for Dec. 8 at the Seattle Center Coliseum, is to benefit the Seattle Aquarium, the Nature Conservancy, the Washington Environmental Council and the Washington Wildlife and Recreation Coalition. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Jeremy Miller of the television series ``Growing Pains'' teamed up with muppets Bert and Ernie and other characters from ``Sesame Street'' for three new episodes of a children's televison series about Israel. ``Shalom Sesame'' is a joint project of the Children's Television Workshop and Israel Education Television. The shows are released for broadcast on U.S. public television and sold as videotapes. The three new episodes - ``Chanukah,'' ``Sing Around the Seasons,'' and ``Journey to Secret Places'' - will be added to a library of five other ``Shalom Sesame'' programs. ``We wanted to present an everyday image of Israel - of kids, families, customs, traditions and friendship,'' said executive producer Lewis Bernstein. ``If Bert and Ernie can travel to Israel, them maybe American kids will want to.'' The ``Chanukah'' episode also features comedians Joan Rivers and Alan King and actress Nell Carter.

DOC.HEAD: Three Sergeants Fail to Make Weight Limit, Get Demoted
DOC.TEXT: Three recently promoted police sergeants have lost their stripes because they failed to shed their flab, and the Fraternal Order of Police is fighting mad. ``I've got 26 years on the job, and since I got out of the academy nobody's checked my weight to see if I ate too many doughnuts,'' FOP President John Shaw complained. Stephen Guckin, Joseph McGoldrick and John J. Harkins became sergeants in April after passing oral and written tests. But they also signed agreements with the city to meet weight limits. When the deadline came last week, they hadn't made their weight objectives. They were demoted to the rank of officer. City officials said pay varies according to an individual's merit raises and other factors, but that the demotions meant the three men probably went from about $34,380 a year down to around $31,500. The city was sympathetic but firm about standards that had been loosely applied for years. ``Nobody wants to penalize people who are on a promotional list,'' said Ralph J. Teti, the chief deputy city solicitor. ``They've shown they have some qualities of leadership. But you don't want to do anything that's going to endanger them, either.'' Some police who were ordered to get rid of the pounds succeeded. A new lieutenant, two corporals and a detective met their goals. Another detective told to lose 46 pounds got rid of only 35 but kept his promotion because of the progress he had made. Guckin was told to lose 40 pounds and only lost 20; McGoldrick was expected to lose 28 pounds and didn't lose any; and Harkins promised to lose 100 pounds and only dropped two. Guckin said he had lost nearly 50 pounds before his promotion, getting his weight down to 280 pounds. Although it was a struggle to lose 20 more pounds since then, he said he hopes to lose 20 more. McGoldrick, 41, a nine-year veteran of the force, weighed 291 pounds last week. Harkins, 37, a 16-year veteran, weighed 313, according to city officials. The Police Department doesn't require routine physical examinations, but Teti said it eventually hopes to do so once or twice a year. The weight standards have been in effect for at least 15 years, Teti said, although police currently undergo medical tests only when they are hired or promoted or when they return to duty after long leaves. Teti said the city's weight standards are based on tables developed by life insurance companies. Rookies have to be within 20 percent of their ideal weight; veterans must be within 30 percent. For example, the guidelines allow a 6-foot male veteran to weigh up to 244 pounds and a 5-foot-6 female veteran to weigh 207 pounds. Shaw still thought the program was unrealistic. ``You can't walk over to a cop and say, `You're being promoted to sergeant, and by the way, you have to loose 80 pounds.' I know people do it on TV, but that doesn't make it right or good for your health,'' he said Tuesday. Guckin, 31, said he was surprised to learn about the weight requirement last spring. ``These promotions are not handed to you,'' he said. ``Ten years ago they hired me at one weight. Now they expect me to be less than that because I got promoted.'' Teti said the Police Department agreed to put the three policemen back at the top of its list for promotions and they will have a shot at the next openings for sergeant. ``Provided they make the weight minimums,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Scores Landslide Victory, Ms. Bhutto Says She'll Challenge Vote
LaserPhotos ISL1,2
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing coalition scored a landslide victory over ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Thursday and urged her to be a good loser and accept defeat. Ms. Bhutto said she'll go to court. Ms. Bhutto, ejected from office Aug. 6 on corruption and mismanagement charges, refused to concede Wednesday's parliamentary election and accused the army-backed caretaker government of massive vote-rigging. A group of 40 international poll watchers refused to comment on the allegations, but was expected to discuss its preliminary findings Friday in Karachi. The group's assessment could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in U.S. aid to Pakistan. The United States and other Western countries have threatened to cut off aid if the elections were rigged. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States looks forward to working with any Pakistani government ``elected in a free and fair election,'' but it was reserving judgment on the results. Some poll watchers said privately they were suspicious of some constituencies where they witnessed a low voter turnout yet the final count showed tens of thousands had marked their ballot. But they said large-scale vote fraud will be difficult to prove. ``I can assure you the election has not been rigged,'' caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi told a news conference. ``The people have given their mandate, their verdict. She should accept the results and prove to the world that she's a democrat.'' Ms. Bhutto said she would challenge the election results in court rather than call street demonstrations. ``The People's Party candidates who lost because of rigged election will challenge the results in court,'' Ms. Bhutto, 37, said after returning to her hometown of Karachi on Thursday night. Most political analysts, foreign diplomats and opinion polls predicted a close race between Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning Pakistan People's Party and the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance for control of the 217-member National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minister. But the final vote count, completed almost 24 hours after the polls closed, showed Ms. Bhutto's opponents had delivered a stunning upset that surpassed even their expectations. Ms. Bhutto's People's Party and its smaller allies won only 45 seats. The Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 diverse parties united by their contempt for Ms. Bhutto, emerged with 105 seats. Voting was delayed in one constituency because of a candidate's death. The rest of the seats went to smaller ethnic and religious partiies and independents. Most seemed at a loss to explain Ms. Bhutto's dismal showing. Some blamed poor voter turnout, estimated at about 35 percent. ``There's a growing sense of apathy and cynicism about the whole democratic process in Pakistan,'' one Western diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``After watching repeated governments swept aside either by the military or by the constitution, people are beginning to ask why bother to vote.'' Pakistan has been ruled by four military dictators since its creation as a Moslem homeland in the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule of the subcontinent. Ms. Bhutto alleged she lost because of rigging in at least 80 constituencies. She accused the caretaker government of stuffing and stealing ballot boxes and intimidating and harrassing voters to keep them away from polling booths. Jatoi replied: ``The country cannot depend on the whims and fantasies of a young lady, as attractive as she may be, especially with the foreign press. The country has to move forward.'' The winning alliance's first test will come Saturday when voters return to the polls to elect legislative assemblies in Pakistan's four provinces. Ms. Bhutto has said her party will contest the elections. The alliance's victory likely puts Pakistan on a more conservative, Islamic course. The alliance espouses adherence to the tents of Islam, prompting speculation it could tigthen control on the media and restrict the rights of women and non-Moslems. It also favors a closer relationship with the Islamic world and more independence from the West, especially the United States. According to Pakistan's constitution, power must be transferred from the caretaker government to the new government within 30 days. The next prime minister will be elected by secret ballot when the National Assembly is called to session. Party sources say Pakistan's next premier would likely be Nawaz Sharif, the alliance leader and former chief minister of eastern Punjab province, where 60 percent of Pakistan's 110 million people live. Alliance leaders have said the new government will continue the caretaker government's investigation of corruption by Ms. Bhutto's government. The caretaker government has charged Ms. Bhutto with seven counts of abuse of power and had her husband jailed on charges of kidnapping and extortion. She says the charges are baseless.

DOC.HEAD: Man IRA Strapped Into Bomb-Laden Van Lives to Tell the Tale
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic man said Thursday that he thought he was driving to his death when IRA gunmen strapped him into a van loaded with explosives and tailed him to a military base. ``This is it,'' he recalled thinking. But Gerry Kelly was lucky: He wriggled free and the bomb failed to go off. Similar bomb-laden vehicles, which the Irish Republican Army forced two other men to drive, exploded early Wednesday at two army border checkpoints in Londonderry and Newry, killing six soldiers and one of the drivers. It was the deadliest IRA onslaught in the province in two years. The IRA said the drivers were ``collaborators'' who had done construction work for the security forces. Kelly said IRA gunmen came to his house, held his family hostage, took his van and filled it with explosives. They then strapped him in the seat and ordered him to drive to the Sherwood Foresters base at Lisanelly near Omagh 55 miles west of Belfast, where he is a mechanic, Kelly said. He said one of the men told him, ``I'm putting a 40-minute timer on, so you've got plenty of time.''' ``They said, `Don't do anything stupid. We have a rifle trained on you.''' ``It was a terrible ordeal,'' Kelly said. ``I just kept thinking about my family and what would happen to them. The sweat was dribbling down my face. All sorts of things were going through my mind and I thought this was it.'' As he drove through the gates, he said, ``I shouted, `Bombs! I got myself out of the rope.'' ``They told me that the rope was there to make sure I didn't jump out and that when I arrived at the camp the Brits would loosen it and let me out. ``I was tied round my waist. I didn't really know why they did it, but I was absolutely terrified.'' Dozens of local residents, some in tears, laid flowers Thursday in the debris of an army checkpoint outside Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second city 65 miles northwest of Belfast. Five soldiers and driver Patsy Gillespie were killed when his car carrying a 1,000-pound bomb destroyed the Buncara checkpoint. While the residents, some whose houses were damaged in the bomb blast, appealed for an end to violence, the body of another victim of Northern Ireland's political and sectarian violence - 28-year-old Protestant William Skey - was found in Belfast. The Ulster Freedom Fighters, an outlawed Protestant paramilitary group, said they killed William Skey, who had been questioned Wednesday by police about terrorist activities. They accused Skey of passing information about ``prominent loyalists'' to police and Catholic paramilitary groups. ``I just want them to know that we're not all murdering rats,'' said Pat Wylie, 51, who led about 70 local people in laying wreaths at the Buncara checkpoint. ``There are good people here, too. We do live in fear. But somebody has got to make a stand.'' Mrs. Wylie, a grandmother of seven, was crying as she spoke out against the IRA. She demanded to know why Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher didn't call in the army's elite SAS regiment ``and clear them out once and for all.'' Police in the Republic of Ireland said six of eight men arrested just south of the border two hours after Wednesday's IRA bombings would appear in a special criminal court in Dublin Thursday night on unspecified charges. A spokesman for the Garda, or police, said on condition of anonymity the men were questioned about a series of offenses, including the IRA bombings. But the charge was not related to the checkpoint bombings. In the attack on an army checkpoint near Newry 35 miles south of Belfast, one soldier die. The man who drove the bomb-laden van while the IRA held his relatives captive managed to escape from the vehicle after shouting a warning before the explosion. Hospitals reported 35 other people were injured in the attacks near Londonderry and Newry on the border with the Republic of Ireland. The IRA has targeted the security forces in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Airport Security Not Told of Bomb Threat, Inquiry Told
DOC.TEXT: A Heathrow Airport security officer said Thursday he received no warning about a bomb threat to Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988, killing 270 people. There were no instructions to be on the lookout for a Toshiba radio cassette recorder among passengers' baggage, Sulkash Kumar Kamboj told a public inquiry into the terrorist bombing. The bomb that blew up the plane was inside a Toshiba cassette recorder, packed in a suitcase. Kamboj said security staff were told to always check carefully any items of electrical equipment among the luggage. But he said his employers, Alert Security, had given him no specific warning to look out for the Toshiba machine. He said he knew nothing about the so-called ``Helsinki warning'' of a bomb threat to a Pan Am flight. The U.S. Embassy in Helsinki, Finland received a telephone warning that there would be a bombing attack on a Pan Am flight from Frankfurt to New York around Christmas, but the warning was not made public. Pan American World Airways Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt on a Boeing 727, but switched to a larger Boeing 747 at Heathrow for the flight to New York. Kamboj said he was working a 12-hour day on Dec. 21, 1988. He checked passengers' luggage being transferred to Pan Am jets from feeder flights at Heathrow's Terminal 3. All bags transferred from other airlines' flights to Pan Am Flight 103 passed through an X-ray machine, and he paid particular attention to any electrical items. But the outline of a radio-cassette player did not cause special concern among so many electrical items, Kamboj said. The inquiry heard earlier this week that baggage transferred from Pan Am flights, including luggage from Frankfurt, was not screened before being loaded onto the plane. Scottish police have said they believe the bag with the cassette recorder bomb inside was put on the plane in Frankfurt. Kamboj said ``no one can recognize every single thing in the bags. It is impossible to be right 100 percent of the time.'' He said he received one day of training when he joined Alert Security 3{ years ago. The training has been increased to an eight-day course since the disaster, the inquiry was told. There also have been changes to the security system, including the introduction of a color X-ray monitor. The public inquiry is focusing on the deaths of the 259 people aboard the plane and 11 on the ground, and how to prevent a repetition of the disaster, but is not considering criminal responsibility. Scottish authorities have said they are investigating several radical Palestinian groups.

DOC.HEAD: Down to the Wire: Getting Things Done NOW
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For seasoned lawmakers, Congress' final rush to adjournment is a window of opportunity for their legislative priorities. ``There are some members of both the House and Senate who operate best at midnight when they can do their legislative slam-dunks with the public looking the other way,'' said Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont. For Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, it's a chance to win some long-sought incentives for oil exploration. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., quietly won Senate approval of an amendment restricting grants by the National Endowment for the Arts. Others insert provisions into bills for new projects back home. There won't be time enough for opponents to quibble, but enough time to brag just before the election. But not everyone gets to cash in. For some, the end game is a time of pain when the rank-and-file lawmaker gets run over. ``Even as somebody is amputating our legs, they're also pulling out our fingernails,'' said Rep. Jack Buechner, R-Mo. ``The longer we're up here, the more we're going to get rolled.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., described it as a ``natural tendency to negotiate ... up to the point of the absolute running out of time.'' But Congress is running out of time this year lke never before, staying in session with less than two weeks before the election. It happens every Congress: Bills that have been stacking up for two years suddenly must get passed NOW or die. An amazing number - dozens and dozens - rocket through the House and the Senate in the final days. On Thursday, the House approved a $268 billion Pentagon spending compromise in 11 minutes. Congress' closing agenda this year includes everything from fish inspection to clean air, from raising taxes to declaring Statue of Liberty Day. Some, such as clean air, remain individual bills, but others, such as child care, get amalgamated into huge legislative packages. Both are examples of brinksmanship. The child-care bill, a long-argued piece of legislation, was practically given up for dead - until the end game gave it new life. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., its prime Senate sponsor, said he had only intended a bluff when he threatened to offer his version as an amendment to the already huge budget bill that's been crawling through Congress. Suddenly, with the elections around the corner, the White House wanted to negotiate. ``All I know is that Friday evening, for the first time in four years, we had an offer to sit down and talk,'' Dodd said. A deal was reached in three days, and the package is expected to pass along with the budget. The clean air bill, the first major revision of the air pollution law since the 1970s, was one of the goals the Democratic leadership and President Bush listed when the 101st Congress began in January 1989. But the legislation moved from one gridlock to another until finally, with time running out, a compromise was forced. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Thursday he expected final House and Senate action before adjournment. Some members doubt that the final rush produces good legislation. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., is a regular participant in the end game because, as a champion of the big Medicare and Medicaid health programs, he inevitably becomes entwined in last-minute budget-cutting talks. ``We're always dragged in. The politics of the budget is driving health care policy,'' he said. ``It's not a rational way to make decisions.''

DOC.HEAD: Scandinavians Concerned Over Soviet Arctic Nuclear Test
DOC.TEXT: Scandinavians chained themselves to Soviet border posts and Nordic politicians expressed surprise Thursday over a Soviet nuclear test on the arctic islands of Novaya Zemlya. A last-minute appeal to Moscow by Prime Minister Jan P. Syse of Norway failed to halt the test, and Finnish officials ordered an investigation into the effects of the blast, about 370 miles from the Norwegian border. The Soviet nuclear explosion Wednesday afternoon came only days after Soviet officials denied such tests would be carried out. The Soviet Embassy informed Norwegian officials earlier Wednesday about a test ``in the immediate future,'' according to Syse's office in Oslo. The Soviets had invited Norwegian government environmentalists to check the test site earlier in the week. ``We strongly disapprove of what the neighboring state now has done,'' Syse told the national news agency, NTB. Protesters chained themselves to a Norwegian boom at a border post to the Soviet Union and chanted ``Novoya Semlya, Nyet!'' as a Soviet delegation crossed to celebrate the 46th anniversary of the area's liberation from Nazi occupation. A former Norwegian prime minister, Gro Harlem Brundtland, who heads the United Nations Commission on the Environment and Development, condemned the test. ``The Soviet test blast spreads negative reaction and fear - especially in north Norway,'' Brundtland said. However, both Finnish and Norwegian nuclear experts said there was little to fear from the tests. They said no increased radiation had been detected in northern Scandinavia. The Finnish Foreign Ministry said the Nordic countries will jointly demand an end to all global undergound nuclear tests. The Finnish environment minister, Kaj Barlund, said he would discuss the issue with his Soviet counterpart, Nikolai Voronchov, at a meeting of environment ministers in Helsinki next week. ``The test came as a complete surprise to us. I am extremely concerned about it and will demand more information from my Soviet colleague,'' Barlund said in a telephone interview. Barlund said a fact-finding committee had been ordered to study the possible danger of the explosion to Finland and would try to visit the Soviet test site in the Barents Sea. ``We don't know whether this is a one-off test or the beginning of a series. But in any case, such tests are very harmful to the extremely vulnerable arctic environment,'' Barlund said. In a live broadcast on national Finnish radio on Saturday, Soviet officials had denied the Soviet Union planned tests on the islands. ``These days we are not conducting underground explosions on Novaya Zemlya ... And such explosions will not be continued by the USSR,'' Andrei Salatkyov, a Soviet parliamentiarian, said in the broadcast. The Swedish government expressed regret over the resumption of Soviet nuclear testing in the arctic. ``This awakes a deep and justified concern in Sweden and many other countries,'' said Sweden's Foreign Minister, Sten Andersson. He said Soviet embassy officials had been summoned to the Foreign Ministry to be told of his government's concern. Earlier this year, the Nordic countries jointly appealed to the Soviet Union not to resume nuclear testing on Novaya Zemlya after a two-year interruption. The environmental groups Greenpeace and Bellona have warned that the Soviets planned to resume nuclear testing on the islands and sent two ships there earlier this month and in September. Both were intercepted by the Soviet coast guard. The islands were a primary Soviet nuclear test site from 1958-1963.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Student Protests Over University Control
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired tear gas Thursday to break up student demonstrations against plans to bring the University of Zimbabwe under tighter government control. At least a dozen students were arrested. Hundreds of students demonstrated outside the Parliament building in downtown Harare to protest the measure, which would give the higher education minister a say in the university's administration. It would also reduce the protection granted to staff and students facing disciplinary action by the university. ``The government is becoming our headmaster,'' one student demonstrator complained. In the protest downtown, riot police wielding batons and shields dispersed the students and confiscated anti-government placards. Earlier Thursday, riot police fired tear gas at students demonstrating for two hours in the middle of a major road to the capital. Students waved placards and shouted slogans for two hours before being forced back to the campus by police. Once on campus, some students hurled bricks at the university administration building and set fire to overturned garbage bins. Riot police do not have the authority to follow the students back onto campus. Under emergency regulations last October, the government closed down the university for six months following violent protests. More than 480 students in that protest were arrested then. Zimbabwe's 25-year state of emergency was lifted in July.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Disappears from Ship En Route from Cape Town to Wales
DOC.TEXT: A woman passenger has been reported missing from a British ship sailing 500 miles southeast of the remote mid-Atlantic island of St. Helena, a shipping spokesman said Thursday. Ruth Whitehead, 63, a German national who lives in South Africa, was presumed to have fallen overboard from the passenger ship St. Helena Island, according to Michael Howorth of the St. Helena Shipping Co. ``The St. Helena Island is retracing its steps in an effort to find Mrs. Whitehead,'' Howorth said. Another British ship, the Rowanbank, had joined the search, he said. Howorth said the St. Helena Island left Cape Town Oct. 3 carrying 43 passengers. It was due Nov. 3 in Cardiff, Wales. Howorth said Mrs. Whitehead was traveling with her husband, Frederick, 68.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Clashes After Explosion, Fire at Township Building
LaserPhotos CPN1,3
DOC.TEXT: Township residents angry at local officials clashed with police Thursday after an explosion and fire heavily damaged the local government building. At least five people were killed. At least 12 people were injured, including two police officers, in the violence in the Khayelitsha black township, about 25 miles east of Cape Town. Many residents of black townships oppose the local councils and consider council members collaborators with the white-led South African government. Tension has been high in Khayelitsha since last week's slaying of Momsa Mapongwana, the wife of an anti-apartheid leader in the township. According to a police statement, violence broke out shortly before midnight Wednesday in Khayelitsha when an explosion started a fire at the town council building. Police said the blast could have been caused by a limpet mine. Firefighters extinguished the blaze, but police said township residents then began hurling stones at police officers, who fired back with tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot to stop at least 800 people from marching to the council offices. After the crowd was disbanded, one policeman with a shotgun ordered photographers to stop making pictures of a body on the ground. The policemen then taunted the journalists, shouting several times: ``Take my picture if you dare.'' Witnesses said at least two people died in the crash. Police attributed only one of the deaths to the clash early Thursday, police said, saying two others were under investigation. Two more residents were shot to death by police Thursday evening when they attacked the house of a constable, police said. At least 10 residents and two policemen were injured in the unrest Thursday, authorities said. They said police declared the march illegal and gave people a minute to disperse. Some marchers began walking toward police with their hands up, making peace symbols with their fingers, and police began shooting, the witnesses alleged.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak: No Compromise on Iraqi Pullout
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, returning home from a regional tour, said Arab leaders want to avoid war, but do not want to give in to Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The state-run Middle East News Agency quoted Mubarak as saying there was no erosion in determination to confront Saddam, who took over Kuwait on Aug. 2. In official statements distributed in Oman, the last leg of the trip, Mubarak was quoted as saying: ``No one wants war, but at the same time legitimacy must be established and the law of the jungle must not prevail.'' Journalists accompanying the Egyptian leader quoted him as saying that the chances of a war in the Persian Gulf were ``fifty-fifty.'' The Egyptian president visited Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Oman. The state news agency quoted Mubarak as declaring his talks ``showed the desire of their leaders to end the problem of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait by reaching a settlement that spares the region war, but without any compromise on the necessity of an Irll tax. Government employees in Illinois and several other states are now exempt from that levy. ``I want to vote for it, but that's the killer for me,'' he said. For Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., the problem was the limit the plan would put on tax deductions for people earning more than $100,000 annually. ``This is a back-door way of raising taxes on two-income families,'' she said. But House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., was counting on about 50 House Republican votes for the package. That meant for passage, majority Democrats would have to produce about 170 votes out of their 258 members - a figure leaders said they would reach.

DOC.HEAD: EC Grants $34 Million in Heating Fuel, Aid for Romanian Orphans
DOC.TEXT: The EC Commission on Thursday granted $34.4 million in emergency relief aid for 130,000 orphans in Romania. The aid will be used to pay for heating fuel at many orphanages, as well as to provide medicine, infant food and spare parts to fix some orphanages' out-of-order heating systems, the Commission said in a statement. The EC also said it will send an engineer to Romania this week to assess the need for heating equipment that cannot be bought locally. The funds announced Thursday are in addition to $3.6 million the EC granted to non-government agencies recently to help care for the Romanian orphans, many of whom are suffering from AIDS through use of infected needles. Needles have been in chronic short supply in Romania, hence some needles were overused. The plight of orphans in Romania is a legacy of the regime of Nicolae Ceauscescu, the former dictator who was executed last December. The Commission said it planned another grant of almost $9 million ``for additional supplies of infant foods'' at the request of Romania's ministry of health. EC External Relations Commissioner Frans Andriessen, in a letter to Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman, said the aid granted Thursday ``represents the most effective practical solution'' to the immediate heating problem at many orphanages. In Luxembourg last Monday, the EC and Romania signed a five-year trade and economic cooperation agreement. On that occasion, Roman told Andriessen that the Romanian armed forces had been mobilized to help repair heating systems in buildings used as orphanages.

DOC.HEAD: Rift Puts New Pressure on Already-Strained Relationship
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. rift with Israel over Jerusalem tests the Bush administration's skill in shielding its Middle Eastern ally from tougher measures in the United Nations and in keeping flickering hopes for peace talks alive. U.S. officials said Thursday they had no intention of seeking new resolutions in the Security Council attacking Israel. Their hope is the furor over Israel's refusal to cooperate with an investigation into the slaying of 19 Palestinian Arabs will subside in a few days. But Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said unless Israel changed its mind his report would deal with ways of protecting Palestinians. And British Ambassador David Hannay, who is presiding over the Council this month, said Israel's treatment of Palestinians ``is not going to go away from the council agenda. ...'' That portends a U.N. foot in the door that Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir feared and prompted the Israeli Cabinet to refuse to cooperate with the U.N. investigation. The U.S. vote to deplore Israel's decision, along with a U.S. vote two weeks ago to condemn Israel for the shootings, shatters the assumption the United States nearly always stands by its friend in the usually hostile United Nations. This could whet the appetite of Israel's enemies to keep up the pressure while diverting the Bush administration from its goal of refocusing attention on Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. ``The United States and Israel used to agree that the U.N. was a hostile place. That is no longer the case as a result of the end of the Cold War and now the Iraqi aggression,'' said Martin Indyk, director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. ``The United States has increasingly turned to the U.N. as the mechanism for promoting a new world order while for Israel it remains a very hostile place.'' Moreover, Indyk said Thursday that ``the United States ... will constantly have to decide with every new resolution whether it's going to isolate itself or condemn Israel again. This hastens the day when either there will be sanctions against Israel or the United States will have to use its veto. So it's a no-win situation for the United States.'' In fact, Avi Pazner, spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Shamir, said Thursday that the unanimous resolution ``helps Saddam Hussenn to distract attention from what is happening in the Gulf.'' But Richard W. Murphy, a former assistant secretary of state for the Near East, faults Israel for mishandling the dispute ``at a hell of an unfortunate time'' and sees at least one boost for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``He's able to say, ``See, that's exactly what I've been saying all along. Follow me and we'll do something about the Palestinian issue,'' Murphy, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, said Thursday. William B. Quandt, who ran the Middle East desk at the National Security Council for then-President Carter, says it will be difficult for the Bush administration to get the focus back on Iraq at the United Nations. ``There are pressures in the U.N. largely from the Arab group and also the Third World to bargain over U.N. resolutions,'' to try to trade support for U.S. resolutions on the Persian Gulf for U.S. support on Arab-Israeli issues, Quandt said Thursday. And yet, for the foreseeable future, the gulf is so much the dominant issue that ``there is no desire to dwell on this difference - and it's real - with Israel,'' said Quandt, who is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. Conveniently, perhaps, next month is the United States' turn to preside over the Security Council. This could facilitate action on a series of resolutions against Iraq, including a proposal by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain that Saddam Hussein be forced to pay reparations for the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Israeli Cabinet's decision, and Shamir's refusal to reverse it, is the latest in a string of disagreements with the Bush administration. The president has referred to East Jerusalem as occupied territory, thereby suggesting he considers Israel's control over part of its capital illegitimate. Israel's settlement of some Soviet Jewish refugees in East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza is another sore point. The Bush administration considers settlements of Soviet refugees or any other Jews in the territories an obstacle to peace because the Arabs hope to recapture the lands they lost in the 1967 Mideast war. Like its predecessors, the administration also is committed to urging Israel to give up most if not all of the territory in exchange for Arab acceptance of the Jewish state. David Scheffer, an international lawyer who is with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, says Israel could have admitted the U.N. investigators without conceding its claim of sovereignty over east Jerusalem. ``I do not consider it to be giving the U.N. some extraordinary foothold in Jerusalem,'' he said. ``There are U.N. observers in Jerusalem. The U.N. is already there.'' Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III - and others in the administration who would like to see Israel negotiate with Palestinians Arabs - will try to repair the rift before it destroys any chance for getting Israeli-Palestinian talks started. But Israel, which has depended on U.S. support in a world organization largely hostile to the Jewish state, is bound to feel even more anxious about risking negotiations with only the Bush administration for protection. ``Does it leave scars?,'' ex-diplomat Murphy said of the two U.S. votes against Israel. ``Probably yes. Both sides think the other is unreasonable.'' But asked if the rift derails Mideast peace talks, Murphy replied: ``You don't derail something that isn't on the tracks yet. in fact, the tracks aren't there yet.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered U.S.-Israeli affairs for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Grills Industry, Administration Officials On Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Barring the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, gasoline prices will hover between $1.30 and $1.62 per gallon over the next year, an administration energy expert told a Senate panel Thursday. The forecast came in the opening session of a three-day hearing on why oil prices shoot up on the slightest rumor of trouble in the Mideast but don't seem to come down on rumors of peace. U.S. Energy Information Administrator Calvin Kent also predicted that home heating oil would cost between $1.13 and $1.45 per gallon through 1991, roughly equal to the high levels heating oil reached in last winter's cold snap. An improvement in the Mideast situation might lower the price of crude oil. But don't look for an immediate response at the pump, Kent told the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs. ``Prices go up more quickly than they come down,'' Kent said. The price estimates assume that the Persian Gulf crisis does not dissolve into war, that the winter is normal in severity and that market factors such as inventories and daily oil production remain relatively stable. Also assumed in Kent's forecast was that crude oil remains at about $30 per barrel. That assumption seemed open to question even as he testified; in New York's mercantile exchange oil jumped $3.17 per barrel in early trading to $34.25 by mid day. Members of the Senate panel focused on the volatility of the oil market. Committee Chairman John Glenn, D-Ohio, scoffed at how ``some goofy thing,'' like a rumor about Saddam Hussein having a dream can affect oil prices. The reference was to a report in an Iraqi newspaper that Hussein had a dream that his guns were aimed at the wrong enemy. Even the mere suggestion that tensions with the United States might be reduced was enough to cause crude oil prices to drop. In the past few days, though, crude prices have increased as hopes for a compromise to end the Gulf standoff waned. The reason for price volatility, Kent said, is that other Mideast countries like Saudi Arabia are pumping out extra oil to make up for the loss of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. Further trouble in the Mideast could interrupt that flow. ``The vast amount of replacement oil is coming from the Gulf and the vast majority of that is coming from Saudi Arabia,'' Kent said. ``Rumors of war make the market extremely nervous and that's why you see these jumps of $2 and $3 in the price based on fairly trivial rumors.'' American Petroleum Institute President Charles DiBona told the committee that oil industries have shown ``considerable restraint'' in holding back on price increases at the pump. Between Aug. 2 and the end of September, he said, the spot price on crude oil rose 44 cents per gallon while gasoline went up at the pump by only 24 cents. Department of Energy statistics submitted to the committee indicate that heating oil customers have felt the gulf crisis more directly. Oil companies have passed on 90 percent of the crude price increase to consumers of home heating oil.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmits a0662 to include writethru designation
S.C. Representative Convicted of Selling his Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that legislator who pleaded guilty in drug case was among the 10 lawmakers, sted in addition to
DOC.TEXT: A jury Thursday convicted a state lawmaker of selling his vote for pari-mutuel betting for $4,300, ending the first trial stemming from an FBI undercover sting labeled ``Operation Lost Trust.'' The sting so far has resulted in indictments charging 10 legislators with bribery. Four have resigned their seats and pleaded guilty. One of the 10 lawmakers pleaded guilty to drug charges earlier this month, as did a lobbyist. The U.S. District Court jury convicted State Rep. Luther Taylor, a 40-year-old Democrat from Columbia, on all six counts against him of violating the Hobbs Act, a federal anti-bribery law. An indictment accused him of accepting five separate bribes and with conspiring to solicit those bribes in exchange for his support of a pari-mutuel betting bill. Taylor voted for the bill in committee during this past legislative session. The bill never made it to the state House or Senate. The conviction carries a maximum penalty of 120 years in prison and a $1.5 million fine. No sentencing date was set. The jury reached its verdict after about six hours of deliberation that followed a 10-day trial. Videotapes and lobbyist Ron Cobb dominated the prosecution's case. Cobb, a former Democratic House member who had become a lobbyist, testified that he worked undercover for the FBI after getting caught trying to buy cocaine from federal agents. Cobb testified he had bribed Taylor with $2,500 to help recruit other lawmakers to support the pari-mutuel measure, which would have allowed voters to decide whether to allow betting on horse and dog racing in South Carolina. Videotapes showed Cobb giving an appreciative Taylor the cash. Taylor maintained throughout his testimony that Cobb was giving him campaign contributions. But under cross-examination, Taylor admitted that during a January meeting he slipped Cobb a note saying: ``for my undivided attention, $2,500.'' Cobb has been granted immunity. Another lobbyist, James Brown, pleaded guilty to marijuana possession this month in a separate case stemming from Operation Lost Trust. During closing arguments Wednesday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Dale DuTremble reminded jurors of the potential impact of their decision at the Statehouse and around South Carolina. He said a guilty verdict would deter corruption. ``How long can you allow people like Luther Taylor to sell out? How long can you allow South Carolina to be disgraced? You're entitled to better,'' DuTremble said. ``It's time for you to send a message to the Luther Taylors of our General Assembly.'' ``His office of public trust was for sale,'' DuTremble said. Defense attorney Joel Collins attacked the credibility of government witnesses, especially Cobb. ``That ought to bother you that they ought to choose this kind of guy,'' Collins said. Collins argued four separate defenses to the jury: that Taylor had no intent to break the law; that he made a ``good faith'' effort to obey the law; that he did not violate the federal anti-bribery law because he consistently supported the pari-mutuel measure; and that his actions could have no effect on interstate commerce, a required element for a conviction under the law Taylor was accused of violating. Each one of those defenses should cause the jury to have a ``reasonable doubt'' that Taylor committed the crimes, Collins said. He said jurors didn't need to convict Taylor in order to send a message to the Statehouse. If the jury brought back an innocent verdict, ``The message wouldn't be `we tolerate sleazy legislators.' The message would be `Don't bring dope dealers in here and expect us to believe them beyond a reasonable doubt.' '' U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel got the last word in the prosecution's rebuttal. He reminded the jury that Taylor admitted having more ``enthusiasm'' for the pari-mutuel betting bill after he got $2,500 from Cobb. ``Can you imagine a public official testifying on the stand that he could be `more enthusiastic' for $2,500? Or $500? Or $300?,'' Daniel asked.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Jabs Moffett for Moving to District to Run for Congressional Seat
DOC.TEXT: First Lady Barbara Bush on Thursday ridiculed Democrat Toby Moffett for moving into a different district to run for Congress. Campaigning for Republican congressional candidate Gary Franks, Mrs. Bush said that during her marriage, she's lived in 27 homes in 17 cities. ``I thought I knew something about packing fast - that is, until I heard about Gary's opponent,'' Mrs. Bush said. Moffett moved to Newtown to run for the seat being vacated by Republican gubernatorial candidate John G. Rowland.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Agrees To Stay in Washington Party Ballot Issue
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court agreed with an August decision that allows Harold Washington Party candidates for some Cook County offices to be placed on the November ballot. Harold Washington Party official R. Eugene Pincham hailed the order as ``a complete victory for us, a complete victory for the people.'' The Harold Washington Party on Oct. 12 was knocked off the ballot by the Illinois Supreme Court. The Illinois court split 4-3 along partisan lines in upholding a Cook County circuit court's decision that the party had filed insufficient suburban nominating petitions. On Aug. 29, the Cook County Electoral Board voted 2-1 to allow Harold Washington Party candidates for countywide executive offices and for 10 Chicago-only county commissioners seats onto the ballot. Cook County Clerk Stanley Kusper said the order would allow voters to punch a straight ticket for the Washington Party. Democratic officials feared the all-black Harold Washington Party slate would siphon votes from a traditional Democratic voting bloc.
DOC.HEAD: Same Plane Appears in Texas, Michigan Ads
DOC.TEXT: The airplane in a TV commercial used by Republican lieutenant governor candidate Rob Mosbacher to criticize the travels of his Democratic opponent is really flying high. It's also zooming through a campaign commercial in Michigan. Mosbacher uses a film clip of the red-and-white private plane to criticize Bob Bullock's travels as Texas state comptroller. Bullock, the ad contends, even was flown ``north to Alaska.'' In Michigan, the GOP challenger for governor has aired a commercial showing the same film clip of the plane while criticizing incumbent Democratic Gov. James J. Blanchard for flying to Mackinac Island, a Michigan resort. In both ads, the plane bears tail number N62870 and soars over the same terrain. The Michigan ad was shown to news reporters Wednesday by Bullock's campaign staff. ``Our point is just how much Rob Mosbacher is a creation of Mike Murphy media,'' said Bullock spokesman Rafe Greenlee. He was referring to a consultant working on both GOP campaigns.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Stage Mini-Version of Bush Fund-Raiser
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State Sherrod Brown appeared with George Bush - not the president but an auto dealer - at a hot dog and potato chips fund-raiser that cost his supporters $2.50 apiece. The incumbent Democrat said he wanted to point out the difference between working Democrats and wealthy Republicans who shelled out $25,000 each to break bread in Akron earlier this fall with the president. Over a two-day span in Akron and Cleveland, the White House Bush helped Ohio's Republicans raise more than $1.5 million in campaign funds. Brown introduced auto dealer George Bush to the picnic crowd. Brown described him as ``a kinder, gentler and, most importantly, less expensive George Bush ... and most important of all, he wants Sherrod Brown to be the next secretary of state of Ohio.''
Bush, heavier-set than the president and with wavy brown hair mixed with gray, said he was glad to take part in the event ``because I'm a friend and supporter of Sherrod Brown.''
DOC.HEAD: Coats Says Will Quit After Two Elected Terms
DOC.TEXT: If Dan Coats is still a senator in 2004, he says he will not seek another term. Coats, appointed U.S. senator in December 1988, is pledging he will step down after two full elected terms in the Senate. ``I think it is appropriate that someone who believes term limitation is best for the system really ought to practice what he preaches,'' Coats said. A bill Coats introduced as a House member nearly 10 years ago would have limited congressmen to 12 years in the House and 12 in the Senate. That bill failed. Coats' Democratic opponent, Baron Hill, has proposed a two-term limit on service in the Senate that would be in effect until Congress balances the budget.

DOC.HEAD: Aides Say Bush Bruised But Undaunted
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Did President Bush squander a rare 80 percent approval rating in a series of missteps and errors on taxes and the budget? Critics suggest he did. But you wouldn't know it from listening to White House officials. They say the president is bruised but undaunted, and knew all along his ratings in the polls would plunge. Before the ink was even applied to the new budget agreement, the White House was trying Thursday to mend fences and salvage what it could of Bush's sagging popularity. ``Speaking for myself, I want to see this budget matter behind us,'' Bush said at a hastily assembled group photograph in the Rose Garden orchestrated to telegraph a GOP unity that in reality doesn't exist. Tired of fighting with other Republicans, the president is prepared to hit the campaign trail again to beat up on Democrats. That was the strategy the White House was trying to sell Thursday as Bush prepared to leave town for a four-day trip to speak for Republican candidates. Forget about the budget, focus on other areas where Republicans don't agree with Democrats, the message went out. And the charge was led by Bush himself. ``We've been bludgeoned by a bunch of demagogic attacks by the Democrats for months and I've been relatively sanguine in the face of that because we've been trying to get something done,'' Bush said at the Rose Garden event. ``But as soon as we get this done, finished, I will then be free - as will everybody here that's been working on this - to have our say,'' Bush declared. But the picture of GOP unity that the White House carefully sought to paint didn't take long to smear. By the time Rep. Newt Gingrich walked the 100 yards from the Rose Garden to the battery of microphones in the White House driveway, he was again airing his differences with the president on the budget. Gingrich, who opposed the first budget agreement signed off on by the president, grumbled that the deal still had not been made final. ``Since the plan doesn't exist ... I don't think any of us have an obligation to tell you in advance what we would do'' in terms of supporting it, Gingrich said. Bush, who earlier this year had one of the highest approval ratings ever in public opinion polls, saw his acceptance go into a near free-fall over what many critics see as a series of miscalculations and mixed signals on the budget. And, in the end, Bush ended up backing a package that included more than $150 billion in new taxes over five years - a far cry from the ``no new taxes'' pledge of his 1988 campaign. Still, a senior administration official who briefed a group of reporters at the White House on the condition of anonymity, said that Bush ``went into this knowing full well and good he was spending political capital.'' ``None of what has happened is a complete surprise. The details of who did what to whom were not predictable. But the fact that there would be this kind of a rocky road was certainly well anticipated,'' the official said. ``When he started this six months ago, talked to economists about how important it was to get a package like this, we talked at length about how he was going to have to invest his political capital,'' the official continued. ``He knew there would be a big political hit and a big personal hit on him. He could have drawn half of the (political) cartoons himself. There's no naivete in all of that. But that's the thing he felt he had to.'' Furthermore, the official claimed, Bush's approval ratings in the latest polls - hovering around 55 percent - may be way down from 80 percent but ``he is probably in a better position going into a midterm election'' than most previous presidents. ``With all the erosion of support his numbers are still probably fine and he's going to use that to his benefit,'' the official said. One additional sign of White House determination to cut its losses and to move ahead with an increased election-year attack on Democrats: its public denunciation Thursday of Ed Rollins, the director of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Rollins had suggested in a memo to GOP House members that it was OK for them to repudiate Bush's positions if it helped them get elected. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater all but invited Rollins to resign - or be disciplined by the congressional committee.

DOC.HEAD: Militiamen Don't Believe War Is Over Despite Disarmament Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to fix typo in byline.
DOC.TEXT: Mash-Hoor, a bearded Druse Moslem militiaman, greased his AK-47 and wrapped it tightly in a plastic bag to bury it - just in case. Thousands of gunmen like him are doing the same. After countless bloody battles in the course of Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, the three main Moslem and Christian militias agreed Thursday to withdraw from Beirut and its environs. But it is an uneasy peace. ``This rifle is mine,'' Mash-Hoor said. ``I won it in a battle in 1984. Who knows when I or someone dear to me will need it?'' Approval of the withdrawal plan came from Samir Geagea's right-wing Christian Lebanese Forces militia, Nabih Berri's moderate Shiite Amal militia and Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party. But Hezbollah, or Party of God, held off on promising a pullout. The Shiite group is believed be an umbrella for underground extremists holding most of 13 missing Westerners in Lebanon. Hezbollah, with some 3,500 main-force fighters, has long feuded with the more secular Amal for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's biggest sect. The groundwork was laid for the militia withdrawal when President Elias Hrawi's Syrian backers crushed a mutiny by rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun Oct. 13 in fighting that killed up to 750 people in eight hours. The ultimate objective is to be disarm the militias and absorb some of their fighters into government security forces. But hardened gunslingers like Mash-Hoor - a nom de guerre meaning ``Famous'' - don't believe it will happen. ``No one believes they'll be disbanded. It never worked before. It won't work now,'' Mash-Hoor said. There are about 20,000 fighters in the dozen or so militias. Many have their own personal arsenals of automatic weapons, grenade launchers, explosives and hand grenades. During past disarmament bids, fighters handed over some weapons, but hid most of their arms - including tanks, artillery and mortars. Many of the fighters, like Mash-Hoor, have known nothing but violence. They are school dropouts, with no skills. Serving in the militia is a meal ticket - the fighters simply take what they want at restaurants, bars and gas stations. Mash-Hoor has been a member of the Druse Progressive Socialist Party militia since he was seven years old. The civil war is all he's ever known. He was born Marwan Yahya, and grew up in Druse town of Shweifat, in the Chouf foothills. When the war broke out in 1975, he was only a child. But he quit school to join the fighters. His first job in the militia was collecting empty cartridge cases to be refilled. He was dubbed Abu Khartoush - Father of the Bullets. He attended school ``on and off'' during lulls in the fighting, but he found he no longer fit in. ``I was no longer willing to listen to teachers, do homework and be disciplined,'' he said. ``I was Abu Khartoush.'' At 12, he was renamed Abu Tabikh, or Father of Food, because ``I was driving a Land Rover and distributing food to fighters on the front lines.'' In 1983, he proved himself as a fighter, battling Christians in the Chouf Mountains, earning his fighting name. Warfare has been his trade ever since. Unlike Mash-Hoor, Haidar, a 37-year-old Amal militiaman, can now earn a living from his peacetime profession. Before he took up the gun, he was a house painter. ``There'll be lots of painting work to do in greater Beirut,'' he said, in an understated reference to the war-wrecked capital. Haidar echoes Mash-Hoor in his skepticism that the militia will truly lay down arms. He said Amal will withdraw from the south Beirut slum of Shiyah which it controls. But, he said: ``I have no orders from my superiors that the militia will be disbanded.'' Haidar said he'll stay on with his militia as a part-timer. He said on weekends, he would head south to Amal bases, where the fighters would regroup. ``I don't believe that the war's over once and for all,'' he said. ``I won't burn my bridges.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Congressman Hospitalized After Becoming Ill
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Raymond McGrath, R-N.Y., was admitted to the hospital Thursday after he complained of feeling ill at his office, his press secretary said. ``He felt faint. He broke out in a sweat. He said he felt a heaviness in the chest - not pain,'' said Dan Zielinski. ``He was conscious, he was speaking.'' A doctor examined McGrath before he was taken to Walter Reed Army Medical Center about 1:30 p.m., Zielinski said. McGrath, 48, was undergoing tests and was expected to remain hospitalized overnight, Zielinski said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Clash with Police to Protest Leader's Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of radical students hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police in Seoul and three other cities Thursday to protest the arrest of a fugitive student leader. Violent protests flared after Song Gap-suk was arrested along with two bodyguards in a police raid Wednesday on his hideout in Seoul. Song, 24, who heads a nationwide group of student radicals known as Chondaehyup, was wanted by police for more than five months for his role in violent anti-U.S. and anti-government demonstrations. Police said Song jumped from a second-floor apartment window to escape but was stopped by security officials outside. There was a pool of blood in his room indicating a struggle, news reports said. Song's group was responsible for several violent attacks on government offices and U.S. installations. Last week, 11 radical students were arrested for trying to attack the U.S. Embassy in central Seoul, hurling firebombs and wielding steel pipes. There were no reports of arrests in Thursday's protests but about 20 students and police were injured, officials said. The most violent protests broke out in Song's hometown of Kwangju where 1,700 students clashed with riot police after anti-government rallies at Chonnam and Chosun Universities, they said. Kwangju was the scene of a bloody anti-government civil uprising in 1980 in which about 200 people died and more than 1,500 others were injured. The national Yonhap News Agency said police fired barrages of tear gas to block 1,000 Chonnam University students from marching into the streets after a campus rally. Students fought with rocks and firebombs for 90 minutes, it said. Almost simultaneously, about 700 students from Chosun University also clashed with riot police in a different section of Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, Yonhap said. ``Release Chairman Song!'' Yonhap quoted students as shouting. In Seoul, about 500 students, calling for the overthrow of President Roh Tae-woo battled police at Korea University for more than an hour and pledged to step up anti-government rioting. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' students shouted after burning an effigy of the president in front of their school.
