The students also demanded the disbandment of the main government military intelligence organization, the Military Security Command, which has been under fire for spying on civilians. Roh fired the defense minister and the head of the intelligence agency after it was found to have conducted illegal spying on more than 1,300 opposition politicians, dissidents and radical students. In the southeastern city of Taegu, about 20 students and police officers were injured in two different clashes, Yonhap said. A police officer suffered serious burns on his face and body when he was hit by exploding firebombs, it said. In Suwon, about 25 miles south of Seoul, police fired warning shots into the air and arrested six protesters when a dozen students demanding Song's release attacked a police station with firebombs, the agency said. Radical students are a small but vocal minority on Korean campuses. They have little public support because of their extreme views and violent tactics.

DOC.HEAD: `My Friend Flicka' Taken from School Reading List
DOC.TEXT: The 1941 children's literary classic ``My Friend Flicka'' was pulled from fifth- and sixth-grade optional reading lists in this town after parents complained it contained vulgar language. The book contains the word ``bitch,'' in reference to a female dog, and the word ``damn.'' Another children's book, ``Abel's Island,'' was removed from the list because of references to drinking wine. George Bush - not the president, but an insurance agent who is vice chairman of the Clay County School Board - said the decision to remove the books from the lists was made by school administrators. He said he supports the action. The two titles are among several listed by Boston-based publisher Houghton Mifflin in its reading textbooks as suggested additional reading. Bush noted that the school board hasn't banned the books outright. Dawn Wilson, supervisor of elementary curriculum, said both books will still be available in school libraries, but teachers will no longer have the option of assigning them. Alexander Caswell, spokesman for Houghton Mifflin, said he has never heard of any other complaints about the two books. He said the company's reading texts are in use in several hundred school systems. In the wake of the decision, Bush said he would request copies of all reading books and set up a workshop to review them.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: 74 Incumbents With No Challengers Still Raise $10 Million From PACs
DOC.TEXT: Seventy House members who faced no primary challenge and have no major opposition in next month's elections have accepted $10.4 million in political action committee donations, according to a survey released Thursday. The 70 are among 74 representatives with no major party opposition in the Nov. 6 elections. The 74 have raised $19.6 million since their last election, with 53 percent of that total coming from special-interest PACs. The survey by Public Citizen, a Ralph Nader-founded public interest group, said the number of House members running without major party opposition was up 25 percent from 59 in 1988. ``Congress has designed a campaign finance system so favorable to incumbents that challengers have become an endangered species,'' Public Citizen president Joan Claybrook said in a statement. The organization has unsuccessfully lobbied for public financing of congressional elections and sharp restrictions on PAC giving. The special-interest money available to incumbents allows them to build formidable warchests that discourage opposition, Public Citizen said. The survey was based on Federal Election Commission reports filed last week. Of the 74, Public Citizen said 46 received more in PAC contributions than in individual contributions. Indeed, PAC contributions accounted for at least 70 percent of the donations received by a dozen of the lawmakers. Four of the 74 accepted no PAC money. They are Republican Reps. Bill Archer of Texas, Philip Crane of Illinois and Jim Leach of Iowa and Democratic Rep. Edward Markey of Massachusetts. Of the 70 in the group who did accept some PAC donations, Public Citizen said Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois was the leading recipient, accepting $456,595 in PAC money from Jan. 1, 1989 through Sept. 30, the cutoff date for the latest reports.

DOC.HEAD: Levy Rejects Latest U.N. Censure of Israel
With AM-US-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy on Thursday rejected the latest U.N. Security Council censure of Israel and urged the world to focus on enforcing U.N. demands that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. Levy's comments came one day after the Security Council rebuked Israel for not cooperating with a U.N. investigation into the killing Oct. 8 of 19 Palestinians on Jerusalem's Temple Mount. Israeli soldiers, meanwhile, blocked the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza Strip from entering Israel for a second day Thursday in an effort to stem Arab-Jewish violence. Defense Minister Moshe Arens ordered the ban on Palestinians entering after five people were killed and 11 wounded this week in several revenge attacks by Arabs and Jews that date to the Temple Mount deaths. In the West Bank city of Nablus, the local branch of PLO chief Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction distributed a leaflet condemning attacks on Jews and saying that Jewish and Arab blood should not be spilled. ``Blood is blood, with the same color, and there is no difference in religions,'' it said. The leaflet was apparently meant to counter calls from Moslem fundamentalist groups for attacks on Israelis. Levy made his comment in a talk with diplomats, including U.S. Ambassador William Brown. The session was private but a Levy aide later quoted and summarized his statements. According to the aide, Levy told the ambassadors that Israel could not agree to a U.N. mission coming to investigate the killings because the resolution that ordered the inquiry was biased. ``It is prejudging Israel's guilt, ascertaining at the outset that Jerusalem is an occupied area and that ways should be found to protect the Palestinians. We cannot agree to that,'' he was quoted as saying. Levy emphasized the world's main task should be enforcing Security Council resolutions on the Persian Gulf and not trying to link Israel to the Iraqi problem in Kuwait, said the aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Yossi Ben Aharon, director-general of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office, also said Israel would ignore the latest U.N. rebuke. Aharon told Israel army radio he hoped criticism of Israel could be quieted by its own investigation of the Temple Mount deaths. News reports said results of the Israeli inquiry may be issued Friday and will blame senior police officials for the deaths. State-owned television reported ``rumors abound that serious conclusions will be drawn and of heads rolling,'' after the Temple Mount investigation report is published Friday. Police Minister Roni Milo was quoted by the television as promising all recommendations of the commission would be carried out. Avi Pazner, Shamir's spokesman, said the government was disappointed with the Washington vote for the U.N. resolution. ``We are sorry because this helps (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein to distract the attention from what is happening in the gulf ... to what is happening in Jerusalem,'' he told reporters. Faisal Husseini, the leading PLO supporter in Jerusalem, compared Israel's response to Iraq's similar disregard for U.N. resolutions. He said the two U.N. votes against Israel were part of a new direction by the world body. ``If this new system will start dealing in an unbalanced way - dealing with Iraq in one way and Israel in another way - it means the system will be destroyed,'' he told a news conference. Husseini spoke a day after he was released from jail. He had been held on suspicion he incited stone throwing on the Temple Mount, leading to the police charge with live gunfire. Husseini, arrested the day of the killings, was freed on bail while police continue their investigation. On Thursday, Palestinians staged a general strike under orders from the Moslem fundamentalist Hamas movement, which called on Palestinians to defy army orders and go to the week's main prayers at the Mount on Friday. With Arabs blocked from entering Israel, army radio reported that employment agencies received calls from 1,000 businesses looking for 4,500 workers to replace Arabs in such low-paying jobs as construction work and dishwashing. In Tel Aviv, Deputy Police Superintendent Shlomo Turjeman said some employers were hiding their Arab workers so police could not force them back to the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Student Protester Jan Palach Moved to Prague
DOC.TEXT: The remains of Jan Palach, a student who burned himself to death to protest the 1968 Soviet-led invasion, were transferred Thursday to one of the capital's most honored burial places. The ceremony was attended by leading officials of the non-Communist government, including Mayor Jaroslav Koran and President Vaclav Havel, according to official television. Palach's self-immolation has come to symbolize opposition to the 1968 invasion, which the Soviets launched to wipe out fledgling reforms and restore hard-line rule. Havel, himself a former dissident, was arrested by Communist authorities on Jan. 16, 1989, as he tried to place flowers in memory of Palach on Prague's Wenceslas Square. Havel's arrest and 8-month prison sentence touched off street protests and a bloody crackdown. Eleven months later, a peaceful revolution toppled Communist authorities, leading to Havel's selection as president. Palach was originally buried in Prague's Olsany cemetery after he died from burns he suffered when he set himself on fire on Wenceslas Square in January 1969. His original grave became a place of pilgrimage for those who opposed the Soviet-led crackdown and the Communist government. In 1973, at the Communist government's instigation, his remains were cremated, and the urn with his ashes was moved to his native village of Vsetaty, 18 miles north of Prague. They were moved back to Olsany cemetery, one of Prague's most revered burial spots, on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Public Citizen Backtracks Second Time on Insurance Study
DOC.TEXT: The consumer organization Public Citizen backtracked for a second time in a week Thursday from its critical study of the insurance industry, saying it had been wrong in saying that Aetna's property and casualty surpluses had declined. Last Friday, the consumer group admitted a similar mistake in its analysis of the surpluses of the ITT Hartford insurance group. ``We have concluded that neither Hartford nor Aetna should have been highlighted in the report,'' Public Citizen said. It said the two companies failed only three of the standards it used to judge vulnerability to insolvency. The original report, issued Oct. 15, said that five of the nation's top 20 property and casualty insurance companies had failed four of the tests, indicating they might go under in the event of a severe economic downturn. The five were Aetna, American International Group, Hartford, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty. All of the companies disputed the accuracy of the report. ``Public Citizen stands by its report,'' the consumer group said. ``The insurance industry is vulnerable to a pattern of insolvencies and urgently requires stronger federal and state regulation to ensure that consumers are protected. ``Further, the insurance industry's vituperative attack on our report shows that it is painfully aware of its overall accuracy and credibility,'' the organization said. ``Unfortunate as it is, the mathematical error cited above does not affect the validity of the entire report.'' Public Citizen said it employed an independent auditor to go over its figures, and the audit showed that Aetna's surpluses increased by 3 percent between 1972 and 1988, instead of declining, as originally reported.

DOC.HEAD: Citizen Charges Sanitation Foulup
DOC.TEXT: An executive nabbed on a litter violation told a hearing examiner Thursday that he's a samaritan who was wronged by city sanitation enforcement agents. But Jim Hart, spokesman for the Sanitation Department, said that however good their intentions, it's illegal for people to put big stuff in the city's litter baskets. ``It's a tough situation,'' said Hart. ``We're asking people to pick up litter.'' But they risk a summons if they put it in the wrong place. Hart said people sometimes fill up litter baskets with residential and commercial waste, leaving no room for tissues, napkins and hot dog wrappers. He said the litter basket law, which has been on the books 30 or 40 years, is being enforced more frequently as budget constraints are limiting the number of workers available to empty litter baskets. Hart said new litter baskets are now being set out with a version of the international ``No'' sign: a red circle with a slash through it, surrounding a picture of a chair, television, plastic garbage bag and a box. The hearing resulted from a summons given to Warren Mitofsky, executive director of Voter Research and Surveys, which does election exit polls and projections for the major television networks. He says he was walking in Greenwich Village, about a block from a building he owns, last month when he saw two empty, cardboard boxes someone had thrown onto the street. He saw an empty trash can nearby. He stashed the trash. ``I was halfway down the next block when a van pulled up with three sanitation police officers in it,'' said Mitofsky. They gave him a summons with a potential fine of $50 to $100. Mitofsky went to his hearing alone. ``I don't think it's necessary to take a lawyer to garbage court,'' he said. The hearing examiner listened to his story without comment and said a decision would be mailed to him in two to three weeks. ``This is outrageous,'' said Mitofsky. ``We've got a filthy city and they're trying to fine citizens who pick it up.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Plan To Sell Or Close 192 S&Ls
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators approved on Thursday a plan to sell or close about 192 failed savings and loan institutions over the next six months. The proposed action, which involves assets valued at $119 billion, is part of an operating plan for the Resolution Trust Corporation, established to oversee the bailout of the financially devastated thrift industry. Officials of the RTC oversight board approved the new plan. They said its implementation would bring to about 479 the total number of thrifts whose financial problems have been resolved by liquidation or other actions since Aug. 9, 1989. But they noted that the plan is subject to the congressional appropriations process and cannot be completed unless it receives full financing. Under the plan, the trust corporation's oversight board would authorize $62.2 billion in new financing. This would include $23 billion to resolve the financial problems of the 192 savings institutions and $38.9 billion in working capital to be borrowed through the Federal Financing Bank. ``The RTC has proposed an ambitious plan for the first six months of fiscal 1991 (which began on Oct. 1) which will allow it to continue a high level of resolutions,'' said Peter H. Monroe, the president of the oversight board. ``If the RTC meets its target of 192 new resolutions, it will have sold or closed approximately 90 percent of all thrifts seized by the RTC to date,'' Monroe said. The oversight board sets policy, approves the financing and provides general oversight supervision for the Resolution Trust Corp. in its task of liquidating the nation's failed savings and loan associations.

DOC.HEAD: Time Poll: Both Sexes Agree Women Too Burdened
DOC.TEXT: It may be time to write Superwoman's obituary. If the results of a poll released Thursday reflect a new generation, the legions of American women trying to have it all may soon dwindle. The 505 young men and women surveyed in the Time magazine poll agreed there is too much pressure on women to juggle the burdens of work and family. But the biggest surprise in the poll: 48 percent of the men would like to stay home and raise their kids. The poll of people between the ages of 18 and 24 showed four out of five believe it is ``very difficult'' or ``somewhat difficult'' to balance a career, marriage and children. ``These people are smart enough to realize that the whole myth of the superwoman of the 1980s is just that - a myth,'' said Frank McBride, who directed the poll for Yankelovich Clancy Shulman. ``Even though they were raised in an era when women were going to do everything, men and women alike are realizing that you can't have everything without any pain,'' he said. Those polled also appeared to harbor few illusions about hard times ahead for them. When asked the prospects of a having a good marriage today, 56 percent of the women and 55 percent of the men said it was ``difficult.'' The other choices were ``very difficult,'' ``easy'' and ``very easy.'' So much for the idealism of youth. A paltry 3 percent of women and 4 percent of men believe matrimony will be ``very easy.'' Eighty-five percent of both the men and women surveyed said couples in their generation are more likely to get divorced than their parents' generation. In keeping with a shift from the frenzied work ethic of the 1980s to more traditional values, the majority of women listed having a happy marriage as more important than a successful career. By a narrow margin, 32 percent of men listed their careers as their priority and 30 percent chose a successful marriage as most important. Twenty-three percent of the women and 9 percent of the men said that having well-adjusted children was their priority. Eighty-six percent of the men said they were looking for a mate who is ambitious and hardworking. Women cited fidelity and industriousness as their priorities in a spouse. Some attitudes never change. When asked if they think it's easier to be a man or a woman, 65 percent of men and 59 percent of women agreed it's still a man's world. The Time telephone poll taken between Sept. 5 and Sept. 11 consisted of 45 questions pertaining to love, marriage, family and work. The margin of error was plus or minus 4.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Six Alleged Skinheads Indicted for Hate Crimes
DOC.TEXT: The government will not tolerate hate crimes, such as those outlined in the indictment of six alleged members of a skinhead group, Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said Thursday. The 13-count federal indictment filed Wednesday charges the six with assaulting and intimidating minorities and their friends in Tulsa parks, bars and amusement parks from July 1988 to August 1989. ``Their hate crimes are not just a threat to their victims, but a threat to the first civil right of every American,'' Thornburgh said at a news conference. ``We want to send an unmistakable signal that their intimidation is totally unacceptable.'' During the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, the Justice Department obtained convictions against all 46 defendants charged with hate crimes in federal courts nationwide, Deputy Assistant Attorney General James P. Turner told reporters in Washington. About 90 percent of those charged with hate crimes during the previous fiscal year were convicted, Turner said. Indicted Wednesday were Michael Lawrence, Daniel Roush, Forrest Hyde, Tina Christopher, Christopher Jones and Gregory Kennicutt. All were in custody, said U.S. Attorney Tony Graham. Nine others associated with the Tulsa skinhead group, including five juveniles, already have pleaded guilty to hate crime charges, Graham said. Lawrence was among five people convicted in Dallas earlier this year for civil rights conspiracies against minorities. He was sentenced to federal prison. Jones is serving a sentence at an Oklahoma state prison, said Graham. The other four were arrested Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lukens Watches House `Zoo' on TV, Clears Out After Resigning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with special election arrangements, inserting new grafs 4-5
DOC.TEXT: After resigning, Donald Lukens sat back and watched his former House colleagues on TV, ``realized what a zoo it was,'' paid a late-night Capitol visit to pick up his belonging, and left. His office was empty of photographs and personal mementos Thursday when staff members arrived for their first day of work with no congressman for a boss. An aide said Lukens cleared out his things late Wednesday night after resigning his House seat in the face of a sexual-misconduct allegation. The Ohio Republican said in a one-sentence letter to Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste that his decision was ``for the good of the Congress.'' Celeste on Thursday ordered a special election to fill the vacancy. That election will be Nov. 6 - the same day as Ohio's general election - unless candidates other than the two nominated in the May primary file petitions for the post. If others do file petitions of candidacy, which they must do by Saturday, then a primary election would be held Nov. 6 and a special general election Nov. 21. House Clerk Donnald K. Anderson appointed Lukens' chief of staff, William Jarrell, to oversee constituent work and run the office until a new representative is sworn in. The Ohio Republican ``was in good spirits,'' Jarrell said, when he returned to the Cannon House Office Building to pack his things and mark them for delivery to friends, family members and his farm in Ohio. ``He said that he was watching C-Span on TV yesterday and they were arguing about seafood regulation, and for the first time in a long time he realized what a zoo it was.'' Lukens had been a lame duck since May, when he was defeated in the Republican primary. ``We had been in the process of wrapping up and getting things together. All this has done is accelerate the process by a very little bit,'' Jarrell said. Lukens isn't eligible to receive his pension until 1993 and doesn't have a job lined up. ``He has not decided what he's going to do,'' Jarrell said. ``He really wasn't able to concentrate on (job-hunting) while he was here.'' Lukens' resignation followed by two days the House ethics committee's vote to revive its dormant case against him to include a new accusation that he fondled a House elevator operator earlier this month. The committee earlier had been examining whether Lukens had violated House rules by having sex relations with a 16-year-old girl - an episode that led to a misdemeanor conviction in Ohio last year. The 59-year-old congressman, who is divorced, has been free on bond while appealing that conviction to the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup and Investigation of Acid Spill Underway
DOC.TEXT: A valve loosened by a bump in a road is believed to have caused a hydrochloric acid spill that partially melted an asphalt highway and forced the evacuation of about 200 people, officials said Thursday. The Wednesday night spill left a steaming trail of melted asphalt on about a half-mile of U.S. Highway 71, said State Police Sgt. Hamilton Mixon. Five Alexandria police officers were among the 19 people taken to area hospitals and treated for exposure to fumes, said Beverly Herring of the Alexandria Police Department. ``None of them were seriously hurt. The acid fumes kind of burn your skin and make it hard to breathe when you're in it,'' she said. A motorist traveling north on U.S. Highway 71 noticed something leaking from a tanker truck after it hit a bump in the road. The motorist flagged the truck driver down, but not before almost 600 gallons of the acid had spilled onto the highway. James Kemp, assistant manager of a nearby service station, said he called 911 after noticing the tanker was leaving a trail of steam-like vapor. ``The road was smoking from behind the truck,'' Kemp said. ``It looked like steam rising off the ground.'' A partial evacuation of homes near the spill was ordered shortly after the accident and was canceled about 8{ hours later, said State Police Trooper Michael Hataway. Hydrochloric acid is a colorless, corrosive liquid. Inhaling its vapor can irritate the mouth, nose, throat and lungs, causing coughing, shortness of breath, pulmonary edema and even death. Emergency workers spread soda ash powder on the road to neutralize the acid. The company that owned the truck, Alpha-Chem of Reserve, sent a cleanup crew to the scene. Mixon said officials were investigating possible charges against the truck driver.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Shredder, Exercise Bike Cause Congressional Flap
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-two congressman demanded Thursday that prison officials tell them why Manuel Noriega has an exercise bike, paper shredder, copier, computer and two safes in his jail cell. Attorneys for the deposed Panamanian leader said the three-room cell and its furnishings were forced on their client by government security regulations and prosecutor's insistence that classified information be protected. U.S. Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., fired off a letter to the U.S. Bureau of Prisons after reading in The Miami Herald about the facilities at Noriega's cell in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami. The letter was co-signed by 71 other congressmen from both parties. ``It's obviously special treatment, and if the taxpayers are paying for it, it's disgraceful,'' Smith said Thursday. ``Who puts safes in criminal's quarters - I don't understand that at all. What if he had a gun in there?'' The prison agency did not immediately return telephone calls from The Associated Press. Smith said he expected a reply by Friday. Noriega's defense attorney, Jon May, said Smith and the other lawmakers will be disappointed with the answer. And he said the defense attorneys and their client would be happy to relinquish most perks. ``Noriega has a bicycle propped up on a stand because he's in isolation,'' said May. ``He does not have access to the volleyball field or the weight room or any of the other facilities the other prisoners have.'' Prosecutors provided the defense team with the shredder, copying machine, computers and safes to handle reams of classified information, May said. ``The sole reason they were provided at MCC is that I cannot meet with the general in the regular conference area,'' said May. The computer and copying machine are in a room the lawyers use, and Noriega has no access to them, he said. The government insisted on the safes to protect classified information, said May. ``Would Congressman Smith want classified information kept loosely in the general's cell, the way other papers are kept?'' he asked. The special cell was built because MCC is not as secure as federal prisons in Atlanta and Marion, Ill., where the government initially wanted to send Noriega following his surrender to U.S. authorities in Panama. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler decided that moving Noriega would place a burden on his defense team in the complicated drug-trafficking case. ``I would invite the congressman to come to MCC and see the general's situation,'' the attorney said. ``It's not because he's afforded special privileges; it's because he has fewer privileges.'' Noriega has been at the prison since January, when he surrendered two weeks after the U.S. invasion of Panama. He is being held on a February 1988 indictment accusing him of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to protect Colombia's Medellin drug cartel operations in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Made Official Language, But Protesters Demand More
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of the Slovak republic on Thursday made Slovak the official language, but protesters seeking stronger legislation demanded that lawmakers resign. The law was approved by a vote of 82-51 with 10 abstentions after a nearly all-day debate. Thousands of demonstrators had waited outside parliament in Bratislava, the Slovak capital, for lawmakers to decide. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel and top foreign leaders have expressed worries that nationalism will upset this country's stability and damage efforts to shed its Communist past. Some Slovaks, whose republic makes up the more rural, eastern part of the country, say they have been dominated too long by Czechs from the national capital, Prague. The law approved late Thursday declares Slovak the official language, but it allows minorities to use their own language for official communications in regions where they make up at least 10 percent of the population. A tougher version, backed by the separatist Slovak National Party, had called for Slovak to be the official language without exception. Slovakia has sizeable minorities. The largest is an ethnic Hungarian population of at least 570,000, which makes up more than 10 percent of the republic's population. Vitazoslav Moric, chairman of the Slovak National Party, told about 8,000 demonstrators outside parliament that lawmakers were ignoring the will of the Slovak majority. ``The rally considers the parliament as illegitimate and unable to represent the interests of the Slovak nation,'' he said in remarks reported by the CTK news agency. ``For this reason, we demand the resignation of the deputies of parliament and new elections.'' He also promised ``protest actions in the whole territory of the Slovak republic which will include also civil disobedience.'' After the vote was announced, the protesters chanted slogans against the government and parliament, and speakers called for a republic-wide strike to start Friday and last until the government falls. The version of the law approved by parliament was proposed by the coalition of Public Against Violence, the Christian Democratic Movement and the Democratic Party, CTK said. Public Against Violence is the partner of the Czech land's Civic Forum. It is the largest single party in the Slovak parliament, with 48 seats. The Christian Democratic Movement has 31, and the Democratic Party has seven. Among the three groups, they hold a majority of seats. The Slovak National Party has 22 parliamentary seats. CTK also reported that Havel criticized the separatist Slovak party while speaking to a parliamentary committee of the Czech republic. The news agency quoted Havel as saying the Slovak National Party had used the language issue to organize large demonstrations. He said many people who took part did not know what the question was or what the differences were among different proposals. ``The main source for doubts about Czechoslovakia abroad are the problems of the constitutional arrangement of our country,'' he was quoted as saying. ``All potential partners, economic or political, are waiting for Czechoslovakia to be a united and disciplined partner.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow In The Southeast - Already?
DOC.TEXT: Brilliantly colored fall foliage was coated with snow and ice Thursday in the mountains of North Carolina and frost headed as far south as Alabama. Showers and thunderstorms extended during the afternoon over North Carolina, South Carolina, northeastern Georgia, eastern Tennessee and southwestern Virginia. The rain was mixed with snow in the Appalachians and changed completely to snow at higher elevations. ``It was very pretty on these colored leaves,'' said Beulah Calhoun at Calhoun Farm Supply in Newland, N.C. Elsewhere in North Carolina, 8 inches of snow accumulated at Mount Mitchell and Mount Pisgah got a little more than an inch, the National Weather Service reported. The National Park Service closed two sections of the Blue Ridge Parkway in North Carolina because of snow. ``I hear there is enough to scrape up a snowball,'' said Hugh Morton at Grandfather Mountain. In eastern Tennessee, snow closed the Clingman Dome road in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the weather service said. At lower elevations in North Carolina, thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain at Charlotte, including 1.50 inches in the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT, and across much of Mecklenburg County, flooding some streets and roads, the weather service said. Hail about an inch in diameter fell at Locust, N.C. A tornado warning was issued for part of eastern North Carolina after a waterspout was spotted offshore. The waterspout, a tornado that forms over water, did not come ashore. Cold air headed southward across the Ohio and Tennessee valleys with temperatures expected to reach the low 30s by Friday morning in northern Alabama, and the mid to upper 30s across central and southern Alabama. Frost advisories were posted over much of Kentucky and frost warnings were issued over southwestern Ohio. Advisories for frost and freezing temperatures were posted over Indiana and southeastern Lower Michigan. Elsewhere, rain was scattered over western New York state and northeastern Ohio. Rain extended from north-central and western Washington state into northwestern Oregon. Strong, gusty wind blew across the northern Pacific Coast during the morning, with gusts reaching 44 mph at Astoria, Ore., 47 mph at Bellingham, Wash., and 56 mph at Seaside, Ore. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 19 degrees in Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 34 degrees at Chippewa County Airport, Mich., to 96 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Maronite Churchmen Accuse Syrians of Executions
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's Maronite Catholic Church on Thursday accused Syrian forces of summarily executing soldiers loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun when he was defeated in battle this month. The clergymen also demanded the release of rebel officers detained by the Syrian army. They appealed to the Syrian-backed government of Elias Hrawi to arrange the evacuation of Syrian troops from monasteries and Christian hospitals. The buildings in Aoun's stronghold were occupied after Syrian and government troops stormed his rebel army on Oct. 13, forcing the defeated general to flee to the French Embassy. The statement issued by the archbishops of the Maronite community, the largest Christian sect in Lebanon, said ``some of Gen. Aoun's officers had been deliberately killed, and others are being held by non-Lebanese authorities. ``This is a humiliation that cannot be justified by the fall of casualties in the opposite side, for whom we feel sorry.'' The clergymen were alluding to reports of summary executions of supporters of Aoun after they surrendered to the Syrians, who lost 300 soldiers in the battle. About 250 other people were killed. Hrawi's government has denied that Aoun's followers were executed, saying all casualties fell in the fighting. It was not clear from the church statement how many of Aoun's followers have been detained. Hrawi is a Maronite, like Aoun. The million-member community has dominated power in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: White House `Not Happy' With GOP Official's Remarks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf with Vander Jagt comment
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Thursday all but invited the firing of a high-ranking Republican campaign official who told GOP candidates to feel free to break away from President Bush's policies. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater refused to express confidence in the official, Edward J. Rollins. Rollins is co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee and a onetime political director in Ronald Reagan's White House. Despite the White House unhappiness with his remark, Rollins' job apparently is safe - for now. ``There was no suggestion of Ed's leaving before the election,'' said Rep. Guy Vander Jagt, R-Mich., chairman of the committee. He spoke with reporters after Bush met with GOP leaders. Rollins angered the White House with an Oct. 15 memo advising candidates ``on necessary changes in your campaign theme and message.'' Rollins said the mood of the country had shifted dramatically over the past 10 days and that voters were as pessimistic about the direction of the country as at any time in history. Saying that voters were confused about Republican positions on taxes, Rollins wrote, ``Do not hesitate to oppose either the president or (budget) proposals advanced in Congress.'' The GOP committee played down the flap. ``Is he in hot water? Good question,'' said John Roberts, communications director of the congressional committee. ``We don't have any indication that he is. Honestly, if in fact the president wanted him replaced, we haven't heard it.'' Bush, during a Rose Garden appearance, dodged questions about Rollins. Fitzwater said Rollins' remarks ``were not helpful. I think the National Republican Congressional Committee will be able to take charge of this situation.'' Asked if Rollins should be fired, Fitzwater replied, ``That's up to the committee.'' Roberts said Rollins has made a commitment to work for the committee through the 1992 elections. ``I think he probably will honor that commitment.'' Republicans have abandoned Bush in droves on the budget, and some GOP candidates are avoiding the president, shelving political commercials he's made on their behalf. Bush even has been confronted by criticism on the campaign trail by candidates he is supporting. A senior White House official said there was a distinction between opposing the budget plan endorsed by Bush and appearing to attack the president. ``He doesn't mind them beating up on the deal; there's nobody who likes them beating up on him,'' said the official, insisting on anonymity. Trying to squelch talk of GOP disarray, Fitzwater said, ``President Bush is a great asset to any Republican.'' Pressed on whether Rollins should be fired, Fitzwater said, ``This is a matter for the committee. He works for them. We certainly made our views known. ... Obviously we're not happy with his comments the other day.'' The White House hurriedly arranged a ``unity'' picture of Bush and GOP leaders in Congress, including Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who led Republicans in abandoning Bush and his original budget deal with the Democrats. ``I think all of us are totally united in our determination to take a sound, strong Republican message across this country,'' Bush said. ``The point is, we're unified and trying to win these elections,'' the president said. Gingrich said the GOP leaders wanted to meet with Bush ``to lay out the framework for the campaign for the last 10 days of the year.'' The congressmen said Republicans have sharp differences with Democrats on issues such as crime, drugs, government regulations and taxes. Gingrich refused to pledge support for the latest budget deal. While stressing unity, House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said, ``There are those issues, from time to time, on which we can't all be together. And this happens to be one of those.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bishop Defends Meeting With Married Ex-Priests
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. bishop on Thursday defended a meeting he held with married former priests. He spoke after reports the Vatican had frowned on the session because it could encourage opponents of the rule of priestly celibacy. The bishop, Donald Wuerl of Pittsburgh, has been in Rome this month for an international gathering of bishops convened by Pope John Paul II to discuss the formation of priests. Although celibacy wasn't on the synod's official agenda, several bishops have raised questions about the Roman Catholic church's insistence that priests lead celibate lives. Wuerl said his meeting with the ex-priests in June in the United States shouldn't be construed as a criticism of church policy requiring that priests abstain from sex and marriage. ``I listen to what someone has to say, but then I say what I have to say,'' Wuerl said. ``... I think those kind of conversations go on all the time, not just on priestly celibacy ... but on every aspect.'' The New York Times reported Wednesday that Wuerl had received a letter from the Vatican warning that such encounters could erode the church's celibacy rule. Referring to the Vatican's interest in the encounter, Wuerl said, ``A request came for information about what happened ... to which I responded as was my responsibility. ... Any other interpretation of that I'm really not comfortable with because it takes it beyond the fact.'' Wuerl spoke at a news conference with Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, who heads the U.S. bishops' conference. Asked if the synod would further debate celibacy, Pilarczyk said: ``If debate means discussion, nobody can put an end to any discussion. If debate means considering whether a law or discipline should be changed ... in that sense the debate is closed.'' Wuerl, following Pilarczyk's distinction between ``discussion'' and ``debate,'' used the word ``discussion''to describe his meeting with the former priests. ``If you're talking to someone about something very dear to them, that's a discussion,'' Wuerl said. The Vatican's letter was reportedly sent by Cardinal Antonio Innocenti, head of the Vatican office that oversees clergy. Speaking of the sentiments expressed at the synod, now in its fourth week, Pilarczyk said: ``My perception is that bishops on the whole, the vast, vast majority, are saying we want to reaffirm the usefulness and appropriateness of priestly celibacy as strongly as we can.'' A cardinal from Brazil disclosed earlier in the synod that two married men in his country had become priests with papal approval. The Vatican on occasion has also approved married priests who converted to Roman Catholicism from Christian denominations without celibacy rules.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Majority of Catholics Oppose Bishops' Political Involvement
DOC.TEXT: A large majority of Roman Catholics oppose U.S. bishops' involvement in abortion politics, according to a survey released Thursday by a private group of Catholics. The poll commissioned by Catholics for a Free Choice found that 71 percent of Catholics and 74 percent of all respondents said Catholic bishops should not ``use the political arena to advance their moral opinions.'' ``What we find is that Catholics and non-Catholics are opposed to the style and approach the bishops are taking on abortion politics,'' Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice, said at a news conference. Helen Alvare, public information director at the pro-life office of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, disagreed withthe results of the survey. ``It promotes the idea that the bishops shouldn't speak out on the human rights issue of abortion,'' she said. ``It would prefer to gag us as moral leaders in the public square. ``In fact, the bishops won't be silenced on any human rights issue, including thinks like economic justice, civil rights or abortion,'' Alvare said, contending that most of the poll questions involved the church's getting involved in elections, ``which we don't do.'' She also said the survey did not distinguish between regular church-going Catholics and Catholics who don't go to church regularly. Kissling said the U.S. Catholic Conference and a number of bishops were inappropriately participating in the political process by attacking individual candidates and elected officials whose views on abortion differ from theirs. She pointed to several examples, including Cardinal John O'Connor raising the possibility of excommunicating pro-choice Catholics and Guam's bishop threatening Catholic lawmakers with excommunication if they voted against the territory's new abortion bill. ``They have a right to preach against abortion, but they have no right to coerce,'' she said, contending the bishops have been ``using legislators as their own private police force.'' She also cited the bishops' hiring of a public relations company and a polling firm for a nationwide campaign to persuade Catholics and non-Catholics to oppose abortion. Of the 2,002 adults polled nationwide, 523 said they were Catholic. The margin of error for the entire sampling is 2.1 percentage points and the margin of error for the sample of Catholics is 4.2 percentage points. The poll was conducted by KRC Research and Consulting Inc. Surveying was done by telephone Oct. 12-21. Catholics for a Free Choice describes itself as a national education organization that supports the right to legal reproductive health care, especially the right to family planning and abortion.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Calls for Study of Death Appeals
DOC.TEXT: The appeals of Florida prisoners who are condemned to die are badly backed up and the system needs streamlining, the state Supreme Court said in naming a committee to investigate the problem. The high court also cited the problem when it stayed the executions of two death row inmates scheduled for the electric chair Nov. 28. Their execution dates were postponed until March because the state office that represents condemned murderers says it doesn't have the staff or money to take the cases. The state agency working on behalf of the condemned is called the Capital Collateral Representative. Larry Spalding, who heads the agency, said Thursday he welcomes the court's effort. ``Last year for example ... 27 people did the work of 70,'' Spalding said. ``Of that number 10 lawyers did the work of 32 - and we still can't keep up.'' Gov. Bob Martinez signs about 45 execution orders annually, he said. In an administrative order Wednesday, the high court said: ``It appears that the credibility of the entire process is being jeopardized by the untimely way in how these matters are being considered and resolved.'' Peter Dunbar, the governor's general counsel, blamed the delays on those who oppose capital punishment. He said that when private lawyers handled death row cases, they didn't have such delays. ``The truth is these procedural hurdles are used by opponents of the death penalty to frustrate the process,'' Dunbar said. Spalding and Dunbar are on the high court's committee, along with Attorney General Bob Butterworth, Steven Goldstein, a Florida State University law professor, James Fox Miller, president of the Florida bar association, and former bar President James Rinaman. They will study the process of appeals and make their recommendations by March 15. The inmates given reprieves were Samuel Rivera and Jason Dirk Walton. Rivera was condemned to death for killing a police officer at a shopping mall in 1986. Walton was condemned for shooting three people during a home robbery in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Richards, Williams Locked In Dead Heat, Says Poll
DOC.TEXT: Republican Clayton Williams' lead has evaporated and he is deadlocked with Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards, says a new poll released Thursday. Support for both Richards and Williams is running at 38 percent, according to the survey by The Eppstein Group of Fort Worth. Twenty-four percent of voters are undecided, says the poll of 1,209 registered voters, taken Oct. 16-21. The poll has a margin of error of three percentage points. The same poll had shown Williams with a 13-point lead in August and followed by nine days a Gallup poll that had put Williams five percentage points ahead of Richards, at 45-40. Republican candidate Clayton Williams, who on Wednesday had said he was ``nervous,'' remains confident, aides said Thursday. ``It's not (that) the gap is narrowing; this race is even,'' Richards said. ``There's no gap at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Albania's Leading Writer Is Granted Asylum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with asylum accepted, details on Kadare's writing. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Kadare told...'
DOC.TEXT: Albania's leading writer, Ismail Kadare, sought and was granted asylum in France on Thursday. He said Communist hard-liners in his homeland reneged on promises to promote democracy. In southern France, meanwhile, 71 Romanian soccer fans failed to board a chartered plane back to Bucharest, and at least 22 applied for political asylum, authorities said. Kadare, 54, said he decided to seek asylum after becoming convinced that Albania's leaders, despite reformist rhetoric, had no intention of emulating the political changes that swept through Eastern Europe the past year. ``The promises made were not kept, and my disillusion, like that of the immense majority of Albanians, was all the more bitter,'' he said in a statement. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas later said Kadare's request for asylum ha been granted. News of the defection reached Albania as the government played host to a conference of foreign ministers from other Balkan nations, resulting in the unusual presence in Tirana of a large number of foreign journalists. Kadare, former head of the national writer's union, occasionally defended official policy in the past. But he became increasingly critical in recent months, leading a group of intellectuals who denounced the government's Stalinist ideologies and accused the security services of abuses. There was no immediate official reaction to the defection, but his decision caught many Albanians by surprise. Mirlinda Angoni, a journalist for the state news agency ATA, said she thought Kadare's defection would ``provoke resentment toward him.'' Kadare's books are widely available in Albania, and several have been published in France. At least two of his books, ``Doruntine'' and ``Chronicles in Stone,'' have been published in the United States. Kadare's style has been compared to that of the Colombian fabulist writer, Gabriel Garcia Marquez. His stories and novels often deal with the country's Byzantine history and traditional themes of honor and local custom. Kadare told the French newspaper Le Monde that his wife and two daughters had accompanied him to France and would stay with him. He said he left his mother, brother and sister behind. The other asylum case unfolded in the southern city of Montpellier, where about 100 Romanians had come to watch Steaua Bucharest play in a European Cupwinners Cup match Wednesday night. Montpellier won 5-0. Officials said only about 30 Romanians left on the return flight to Bucharest. By evening, 22 members of the group had shown up at government offices to seek political asylum, while the others reportedly headed north by train to Paris or Lyon. Kadare's bid for political asylum was first announced by his French publisher, Claude Durand, who holds the author's international rights. Kadare released the text of a letter sent Tuesday to Albanian President Ramiz Alia explaining his decision. ``Until today, I have tried to help soften the regime, to the extent this is authorized in Albania,'' he wrote. ``In the course of my meetings and an exchange of letters which I had with the president last spring, I expressed very clearly the necessity for a rapid, profound and complete democratization of the country. ``Because there is no possibility of legal opposition in Albania, I have chosen this course which I never wished to take and which I will not recommend to others.'' The author of several novels, essays and poetry collections, Kadare had not been considered an outspoken dissident in past years, although his recent works contained anti-totalitarian themes. He described his decision as ``the logical extension of all that I have argued for until now in my work.'' ``I hope to return to my country one day ... following a true democratization.'' he said. Kadare is fluent in French and has visited France many times.

DOC.HEAD: Kurdish Rebels: Iraq Has Moved Some Equipment from Arms Plants
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has shifted vital equipment from factories making armaments and chemical weapons to secret locations for security reasons, the rebel Kurdish group said Thursday. The decision was made by the Iraqi Defense Ministry early in October, said the statement faxed to The Associated Press in Nicosia from the Kurdistan Democratic Party's office in London. The statement said the group learned that on Oct. 16, the contents of the Al Taji armaments factory in the Al Taji barracks and the chemical plant at Samara, both north of Baghdad, were moved. It added that ``other sensitive military installations have also been vacated, except for the Al Qaim chemical plant, now specializing in producing binary chemical shells in western Iraq. ``The site is the most heavily defended in Iraq by a massive air-defense system and ground troops.'' The fax did not elaborate on how the information has been obtained or why the Iraqis would have moved the equipment. However, Iraqi authorities have moved some Western hostages to strategic sites, fearing a U.S. air attack in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Kurdistan Democratic Party is an outlawed group fighting for autonomy from the central Baghdad government for several decades. In another development, the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, reported that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has toured the Kurdish province of Suleimaniya to inquire about conditions of inhabitants. It did not say when the visit occurred. The trip apparently was designed to boost his popularity among the Kurds, traditionally his main opponents within Iraq. It said thousands of people greeted him and showed support for his stand against anti-Iraqi forces that massed in Saudi Arabia after the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Cancer Drug for Treating Endometriosis
DOC.TEXT: Monthly injections of a newly approved drug for treating endometriosis could help hundreds of thousands of women who have the fertility-threatening condition, doctors said Thursday. The drug, a prostate-cancer medicine called Lupron Depot, is already commonly prescribed for endometriosis. Doctors know it works to reverse the malady and relieve its sometimes debilitating pain, gynecologists said. But the government had not approved its use for treating anything other than prostate cancer and insurance companies refused to cover its costs - $252 for monthly injections, which are typically administered for six months, doctors said. ``It's a drug that's well-tolerated. It's side effects are minimal, and it's an exciting development that we now have approval,'' said Dr. Gary A. Shangold, associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Chicago. He spoke at a press confeence held by the manufacturer, TAP Pharmaceuticals. The Deerfield-based company said it was notified Monday that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had approved Lupron Depot for treating endometriosis. The drug suppresses production of the female hormone estrogen, which controls growth of the tissue that lines the womb, called the endometrium. Endometriosis occurs when that tissue migrates outside the womb, usually into the abdomen and pelvis, where it swells and bleeds during menstruation. If it develops in the ovaries or fallopian tubes, it can cause blockage, scarring and infertility. An estimated 2 million to 5 million women have endometriosis, which may be mild and symptom free. But the condition also may cause severe menstrual cramps, pain during sexual intercourse, painful urination or painful bowel movements. Side effects of Lupron Depot resemble those of menopause, including hot flashes, but are not permanent and may be relieved with other medication. ``In essence, what we're doing is creating a temporary, medically induced menopause, a reversible menopause, that, in turn, stops the stimulation of the endometriosis,'' said Dr. James Miller, medical director at TAP. The company is a joint venture between Japanese pharmaceutical company Takeda Chemical Industries and North Chicago-based Abbott Laboratories. Other doctors said the approval should open the way for using the drug for a variety of gynecological problems, such as premenstrual syndrome, uterine fibroid tumors and even benign breast tumors. ``I think it's very significant,'' Dr. Robert L. Barbieri, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at State University of New York at Stony Brook, said of Thursday's announcement. He estimated it could help up to one-third of women who have endometriosis, including by heading off surgery. Barbieri said the only other drugs approved for treating endometriosis are Synarel, a nasal spray that costs about the same as Lupron Depot, and Danazol, a derivative of the male hormone testosterone that costs about half as much. Synarel requires twice daily doses for six months and is poorly absorbed by the body, Barbieri said. Danazol causes women to develop male traits - a deepening of the voice, facial hair, oilier skin and upper body muscles, he said. As for Lupron Depot, ``the main down side of the drug is it does cause a low estrogen state, and it may cause thinning of vertebral bones,'' Barbieri said. He said further study will be necessary to determine whether the amount of bone thinning is significant.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Peasants Massacred in Northern Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified assailants using guns and machetes on Thursday killed nine peasants, including five children, in a small town in northern Colombia. The peasants were attacked in their homes by the assailants who apparently were carrying out a revenge mission, regional police director Col. Felix Gallardo told reporters. Among the victims were five children aged 5 to 16, he said. Immediately after the massacre, police arrested 18 suspects in the Tierralta area, about 270 miles north of the capital Bogota. The independent U.S.-based human rights group Americas Watch reported on Monday that right-wing paramilitary death squads are responsible for most of the 375 multiple murders committed in the Colombian countryside this year. The squads often kill leftist guerrillas and those they suspect of being left-wing sympathizers.

DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Stone Masons Return Home Safely from Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five Portuguese stone masons returned to their homeland Thursday after Iraqi authorities allowed them to leave Baghdad. The workers finished contracts last week to install marble in a palace for President Saddam Hussein on the banks of the River Tigris in the Iraqi capital. A spokesman for the group, Joao Cacador, said Baghdad authorities granted exit visas to the Portuguese after the Iraqi company supervising work on palace appealed to Saddam's office on their behalf. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva, on working visit to Spain, said he was overjoyed to hear the Portuguese men had left Iraq. Iraq has held thousands of foreigners in their country in the aftermath of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, including Westerners in strategic sites thought to be the targets of a possible U.S. attack.

DOC.HEAD: Government Acknowledges Food Crisis but Won't Call it Famine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf `A government' to ADD dropped word Liberation.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Sudan-Famine, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Cabinet minister acknowledged Thursday that Sudan is facing a food crisis but the government rejected claims by relief workers that millions of its residents are threatened by famine. A top U.S. relief official, meanwhile, told Congress in Washington on Thursday that a famine of ``biblical proportions'' imperiled as many as 11 million Sudanese. Sudan's agriculture minister, Ahmed Ali Genaif, speaking at a news conference in Khartoum, said there was no famine but the country was confronted with ``a food gap that should be handled.'' Seasonal rains were delayed, Genaif said, prompting Western relief organizations to raise the alarm of a food crisis, but the rains had started and the situation was ``under control.'' He acknowledged, however, that while projected figures showed crops this winter should produce 400,000 tons of wheat and 1.8 million tons of sorghum, the country needs more than twice as much wheat and 2.5 million tons of sorghum to feed its people. Foreign Minister Ali Sahlul met Thursday with Harold Norton, the representative of the Food and Agriculture Organization in Khartoum, to thank the U.N. agency for a donation of 25,000 tons of wheat, the official Sudan News Agency reported. A ship loaded with 19,000 tons of wheat was ordered to sail to Sudan immediately to help Sudan cover urgent needs. In Washington, Andrew Natsios, the U.S. administration's top relief official, said the Sudanese government is ``increasingly indifferent if not overtly hostile to the relief efforts'' undertaken by the international community. Most of the Sudanese threatened by famine live in southern Sudan, where a civil war between rebels and government troops has been waged since 1983. The government has barred food shipments to the south, where the countryside is largely controlled by the rebels. A government statement said Thursday that 22 rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army had been killed at Yei in the Equatoria region, 825 miles south of Khartoum. It said a government soldier was also killed in the fighting, but did not say when the battle took place. The report could not be independently verified because reporters are barred from the war zone.

DOC.HEAD: Man Acquitted in Shooting of Boston Police Detective
DOC.TEXT: A Jamaican immigrant burst into tears Thursday after his acquittal on charges of killing a Boston police detective, ending a trial that raised questions about whether police doctored evidence. ``What they tried to do to me. ... I'm a good person,'' Albert Lewin whispered after a jury found him innocent. ``I never knew that the United States was like this,'' he later told reporters. Lewin, 34, had been in Boston a few months when he was accused of firing shots that blasted through a closed apartment door and killed Detective Sherman Griffiths during a 1988 drug raid. ``I think it had to be obvious to the jury that there was no credible evidence,'' said Lewin's attorney, Max Stern. The only physical evidence that linked Lewin with the murder weapon was a fingerprint on the gun. Lewin was arrested after he was found with several other people in an apartment downstairs from where the raid occured Feb. 17, 1988. Lewin still faces deportation to Jamaica as an illegal alien. Two defense witnesses, including a retired fingerprint expert for state police, testified there were signs the print had been transferred onto the gun. The fingerprint was reported by an FBI expert some 30 months after the killing, and then was destroyed. ``I was disappointed,'' Thomas Mundy, assistant Suffolk County district attorney, said of the verdict. ``I can't find fault with the jury. ... I can't believe they didn't believe it was Lewin's fingerprint on the gun.'' Brian Griffiths, a brother of the 36-year-old slain officer, read a statement saying the family was ``very hurt and disappointed'' by the verdict. ``Sherman was a proud and dedicated member of the Boston Police Department's Drug Control Unit and no decision will ever take that away from him,'' he said. ``Sherman died for a cause and his death will never be in vain.'' The verdict was another setback for Boston police, still reeling from the Charles Stuart case last October. In that case, a man claimed his pregnant wife had been shot by a black man as they drove through a Boston neighborhood. Police arrested a black man. When Stuart later was implicated in the slaying and committed suicide, community leaders said police acted too quickly to arrest a black suspect. The Lewin case was moved 90 miles from Boston because of extensive publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies From Turbulent Flight Injuries
DOC.TEXT: An 84-year-old man died of injuries from a turbulent flight aboard a commercial jetliner, authorities said. Philip Romerstein died ``as a result of trauma suffered during the turbulence,'' said Wayne Arbaczawski, chief investigator for the Palm Beach County medical examiner's office. Romerstein, from West Palm Beach, had just left his seat to visit the lavatory Oct. 3 on Eastern Airlines Flight 791 when the turbulence hit, said airlines spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak. It was not clear if falling luggage, being struck by other passengers, or just simply being tossed about caused the trauma. Romerstein had been in intensive care until his death Tuesday. The clear-air turbulence struck at 31,000 feet when the DC-9 was approaching Palm Beach International Airport for a landing. Thirteen people required medical assistance. Four of them were seriously injured. Romersteins's wife, Rose, suffered back injuries. The couple was returning from a visit to Washington for the birth of a great-grandchild. An investigation determined airline employees followed proper procedures during the flight, said Arlene Salac, a Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Pelosi Says She Was Shooed To Back Of Senate Chamber
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic congresswoman trying to win Senate votes for the civil rights bill says a Republican senator proved the need for the bill by shooing her to the back of the chamber. Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said she and other congresswomen were in the Senate on Wednesday encouraging members to override the president's veto of the Civil Rights Act. ``We have a right to be on the floor as members of Congress,'' she said. ``But Sen. (Rudy) Boschwitz kept telling us to `Go to the back ladies.' I don't know if he didn't realize we were members of Congress or what. ``There we were trying to improve conditions for women in the workplace and we were being told 'Go to the back, ladies, go to the back.''' Boschwitz' press secretary Tim Droogsma said Mrs. Pelosi was ``being loud. House members have (Senate) floor privileges. They do not have speaking privileges.'' Droogsma said that Boschwitz and other senators were trying to hear the debate, but were being disturbed by Mrs. Pelosi. He said any effort to equate the incident with sex discrimination trivializes the Civil Rights Act. ``She was simply asked to take her conversation away,'' he said. The Minnesota senator, who is running for re-election, voted against the Civil Rights Act when the Senate took its original action on the bill. He voted, however, to override, becoming the only senator to change his mind. Polls show that Boschwitz, who started with an enormous lead over Democratic challenger Paul Wellstone, is now leading by only a 3 point margin.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Return to United States
Laserphoto WX29
DOC.TEXT: Nine former hostages in Iraq landed to the applause of friends on U.S. soil Thursday night, one of them proclaiming it was ``awesome'' to be home again. The nine were among 14 Americans who left Amman, Jordan for London on Wednesday after flying out of Baghdad. Five flew to New York, arriving Wednesday night. Peter Timko of Lancaster, Pa., was met at Washington's Dulles Airport by his father, Joseph; his mother, Brenda, and a dozen fellow graduate students from Georgetown University in Washington, where he is a graduate student in Arabic studies. The students carried a big sign reading, ``Welcome Home Peter.'' Timko rushed to his mother, hugged her and said, ``Hi, mommy dearest. I've looked forward to this for several months.'' Asked how it felt to be home, Timko replied, ``Pretty awesome.'' Another passenger, John Charlton of Tampa, Fla., said, ``I feel great, but my father's still in Baghdad.'' In London, Timko told reporters members of the group had been asked ``very nicely'' not to describe their treatment by Iraq. He did not say who made the request. Timko had been serving as a summer intern at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Hundreds of men from western countries have been detained in Iraq, often at military installations as a deterrent against attack.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Their U.N. Workers No Longer Must Pay Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Thursday that its employees in the United Nations no longer must pay part of their salaries to Moscow, which for decades reportedly used the hard currency to fund espionage. The announcement by Deputy Foreign Minister Valentin Nikiforov was a concession to reality; Soviet U.N. workers rebelled against the Soviet Mission's control this summer and many refused to turn over their paychecks. A U.N. administrative tribunal ruled that most of their contracts, which gave Moscow the right to require then to return home in two to four years, were invalid. That freed the Soviet employees to seek independent U.N. contracts. Soviet employees indicated the threat of being returned home was used for years to force them to accept Soviet payment terms. The U.N. tribunal also invalidated many short-term contracts of Chinese U.N. employees. It ruled that staffers with five years or more experience could apply directly to the world body to renew their contracts. For years, Chinese, Soviet and other Eastern European workers at the United Nations have had to turn over their paychecks to their countries' U.N. missions. The Soviets lost about 40 percent of the value of their pay this way. Soviet employees said the Soviet Mission paid their rent and gave them monthly allowances of $1,000 to $1,400, keeping the rest. Rossen Vassilev, a former Bulgarian U.N. employee who defected in 1988, said Soviet bloc nations recycled the confiscated cash to fund espionage in the West. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said in 1988 that Moscow would let some Soviets apply for long-term U.N. contracts. The Soviet Mission said only about 10 Soviet professionals have accepted permanent contracts so far. But Nikiforov said all Soviets would be permitted to seek long-term contracts starting Jan. 1. The Soviet Union has about 450 staffers in the Secretariat in New York and overseas. About 500 other Soviets work in U.N.-affiliated agencies in Geneva, Rome, Vienna, Paris, Nairobi, Montreal and Washington. Almost all work on short-term contracts.

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Missing Soviet Six Days After Delegation Departed
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet journalist dropped from sight six days after a peace delegation he was with returned home, but unlike the Cold War days, no one seemed bothered by the disappearance, officials said Thursday. U.S. immigration officials said Maxim A. Kniazkov has not sought asylum and probably has a visa good for six months. His host in Kansas hasn't heard from him. No one knew Thursday where Kniazkov might be. ``I've inquired as many different ways as I could,'' said Rick Plumlee, who opened his Lawrence home to Kniazkov during his weeklong visit to attend the Meeting for Peace. The program is a cultural exchange in which Soviet citizens stayed with Kansas families and toured the state. Kniazkov, who works for the Soviet news agency Tass, was among 250 Soviets at the gathering in Lawrence that ended Oct. 19, the day his delegation flew home without him. Georgi Grechko, who headed the Soviet delegation, said at the time that Kniazkov could stay if he so desired. Grechko said he was surprised Kniazkov's disappearance attracted media interest. ``This is a very old way of thinking - that this is a big deal,'' he said. A Soviet expert at the University of Kansas, Gerald Mikkelson, said Kniazkov's apparent decision to stay behind would have been unheard of 10 years ago. ``I think the prevailing attitude now is, `So what if he wants to stay in the United States, that's his business,''' Mikkelson said. ``I'm not saying they don't care whether their people come back or not, but if this guy is footloose, he just frees up a little space for someone else to occupy.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Minister Heads to Ethiopia to Ease Immigration Plight
DOC.TEXT: A senior Israeli official on Thursday departed for Ethiopia in hopes of easing the plight of thousands of Ethiopian Jews waiting to immigrate to the Jewish state. ``I hope the picture I bring back from there can perhaps help us find ways to help them,'' Deputy Science Minister Geula Cohen said before departure at Ben Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv. She belongs to a special Cabinet committee on immigration. Mrs. Cohen's trip came amid heightened efforts by Israel to bring most of the 22,000 Ethiopian Jews in that country to Israel and unite them with their families. Thousands of Jews left Ethiopia for Israel in the last decade. Most Ethiopian Jews have been stranded in the capital of Addis Ababa after gathering there from outlying villages to await departure. Ethiopian activists in Israel said some of the refugees have died from starvation and disease. On Sunday, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir promised representatives of the 17,000 Ethiopian Jews in Israel that the country was ``doing all it can for their brothers in Ethiopia.'' ``We are in contact with the Ethiopian government to allow greater emigration,'' Shamir added, according to a communique published by his office Monday. He also promised to send doctors to treat the refugees in Addis Ababa. About 8,000 Ethiopians came to Israel during the secret ``Operation Moses'' rescue mission in 1984-85. The effort came to an abrupt halt when news of the air lift was leaked to the press. At the time, Ethiopia lacked diplomatic ties with Israel. But ties were reestablished in October 1989, and Ethiopia's government began permitting about 500 Jews a month to reach Israel. That arrangement broke down in July without explanation.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Suggests 100,000 More U.S. Troops May Head for Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 11: ``Webster said,'' further Bandar comment
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is laying plans to send as many as 100,000 more troops to Saudi Arabia, but the expanded buildup does not signal a U.S. intent to attack Iraq, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday. CIA Director William Webster, meanwhile, suggested a growing U.S. reluctance to let Iraqi President Saddam Hussein survive the current crisis in power, even if he withdraws from Kuwait. Webster said the Persian Gulf region will not be secure unless Saddam is removed from power or he is ``disassociated'' from his chemical weapons and reported efforts to acquire nuclear arms. On Capitol Hill, there was concern over the administration's course and worry that once Congress leaves town, Bush might feel less constrained to follow a peaceful path. ``I am not convinced that this administration will do everything in its power to avoid war,'' said Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., expressing the same sentiments as many of his colleagues who have supported the gulf deployment. Kerrey, a Vietnam veteran and Medal of Honor winner, said ``If ever there was an avoidable war, it is this one.'' The Pentagon's disclosure earlier this week that it was considering adding troops to Operation Desert Shield, beyond the 240,000 already there or en route, raised questions about whether the deployment was being tailored for an offensive. The Saudi ambassador, Pince Bandar Bin Sultan, said after a late afternoon meeting with senior State Department officials, ``The issue of peace or war is in the hands of Saddam Hussein.'' Hussein, he said, ``is playing with the emotions of everybody with this game with the hostages.'' Asked why the United States was sending more troops, the ambassador replied, ``It just means we will not take any chances.'' Prince Bandar met with Robert Kimmitt, under secretary for political affairs, and Morris Busby, head of the department's counter-terrorism office. Asked if Saudi Arabia faced a new terrorist threat, the ambassador declined to answer. Webster said in a breakfast speech the CIA had received ``encouraging reports'' of dissaffection in Iraq. He did not elaborate on where this dissent could be found. Bandar said he had ``great respect'' for Iraq's armed forces and added, ``I can understand why they have great discontent with their leader.'' He declined further comment on intelligence topics. Cheney, speaking in a series of interviews with the television networks ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN, said the Bush administration had not set an upper limit on troop deployments to Saudi Arabia. He said he wanted to have enough forces there ``to deal with any contingency.'' The defense secretary said his orders from Bush were to use American forces to deter Saddam from invading Saudi Arabia, to prepare to defend the Saudi kingdom in the event of an attack and to enforce the U.N. sanctions against Iraq. ``We want to have the capability for the president to make the decision to use other options should that become necessary in response to a provocation, for example,'' Cheney said. He was referring to a possible U.S. offensive action. At another point, he said, ``For a number of reasons I would expect a continuing flow of forces to the gulf in the period ahead.'' Cheney did not provide details of the additional U.S. deployments planned. When asked by an interviewer whether as many as 100,000 more troops might be sent, Cheney said: ``It's conceivable that we'll end up with that big an increase.'' Cheney's spokesman, Pete Williams, later told reporters that Cheney was not suggesting that a decision had been made on how many extra troops to deploy. The need to expand Desert Shield - already the biggest U.S. military operation since Vietnam - is based in part on increases in Iraqi troop strength in occupied Kuwait since the first U.S. deployments began in early August, Williams said. The Pentagon estimates that about 430,000 Iraqi troops are in and around Kuwait now, compared with about 150,000 in August when the American deployment plan was put together. Williams said the request for more troops came from Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander in chief of all U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf area. Schwarzkopf met earlier this week in Saudi Arabia with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to discuss possible additional troop deployments. Williams said that Powell had relayed his advice to Cheney in recent days and that the two likely would discuss the situation in more depth early next week. Williams indicated that Cheney was considering transferring as many as 50,000 troops from Germany to Saudi Arabia, but that plans were incomplete. He did not specify whether the forces from Europe would rotate to Saudi Arabia as replacements for or additions to the troops that have been there for several weeks. The spokesman sought to play down Cheney's comment that 100,000 more troops might be sent. ``I want to steer you away from the notion that there is some piece of paper ... on how many additional forces to send to Saudi Arabia that the secretary is waiting to act on,'' Williams said. The spokesman said no U.S.-based combat troops had been alerted to prepare for deployment to Saudi Arabia beyond those originally committed to Desert Shield. But he said 50,000 U.S. forces in Europe know they will be leaving in coming months. ``Now they understand that they may go through Saudi Arabia on the way home,'' Williams said. U.S. forces now in Saudi Arabia include four Army divisions, three Marine Corps expeditionary brigades, an air defense artillery brigade, a mechanized infantry brigade and an armored cavalry regiment. Also in the gulf area are more than 500 U.S. aircraft and 55 ships. Also on Thursday, Congress made it more likely that combat reserve units would be called to active duty for Desert Shield. House and Senate negotiators added to the 1991 defense spending bill an extension of the reserve duty period to 360 days from 180 days for ``combat arms only.'' The Pentagon had said it wanted the extension before using any combat reserves. The House passed the bill Thursday and the Senate was expected to take it up Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Envoys: No Sign of Cease-Fire in Rwanda
DOC.TEXT: Foreign envoys in Rwanda said Thursday they saw no signs to support reports of a cease-fire in the month-old fighting between the government and rebels. ``I have no evidence of a cease-fire,'' said a Western diplomat. ``I have not heard of it except from foreign news reports.'' Another Western diplomat said he doubted a cease-fire would hold between the rebel Rwandese Patriotic Front and President Juvenal Habyarimana's government. ``A cease-fire would mean the rebels would stay where they are,'' the diplomat said. ``That would mean giving the rebels part of the country.
