I doubt Habyarimana would agree to that.'' The diplomats were interviewed by telephone from Kenya's capital, Nairobi, and requested anonymity. Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens told journalists Wednesday in Nairobi that Rwanda's government had accepted an unconditional cease-fire earlier in the day. State radio reported government troops killed 320 rebels and themselves lost 10 soldiers in fighting Tuesday. The fighting is about 37 miles northeast of the capital of Kigali, which the envoys said remained calm Wednesday. Eyskens proposed African nations provide a neutral force to monitor a cease-fire. He said Belgium, which formerly ruled Rwanda as a colony, would provide logistical and financial support. Esykens said he had learned of the halt in fighting by telephone from Rwanda's foreign minister, Casimir Bizimungu. Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni announced Monday that the rebels had accepted a cease-fire. The Belgians, who have been leading international efforts to settle the conflict peacefully, were concluding a second meeting with the region's leaders. Martens said Belgium would decide Friday whether to withdrew its troops, sent soon after the rebels invaded Sept. 30 from Uganda. In Zaire, neighboring Rwanda, government sources said that at a summit earlier this week the leaders of Zaire, Burundi, and Rwanda had advocated the fromation of an African peacekeeping force to be deployed as soon as a cease-fire took hold.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Agrees to Stay in Washington Party Case
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay Thursday to allow an all-black slate of candidates to appear on the Nov. 6 ballot, a move county officials said will throw election plans into chaos. Harold Washington Party leaders delighted in the win. Cook County officials said the court decision could cost taxpayers up to $2 million. The order, less than two weeks before the general election, is ``a complete victory for us, a complete victory for the people,'' said Eugene Pincham, leader of the party named for the city's first black mayor who died in 1987. County Clerk Stanley Kusper said of the stay: ``We're sitting in here pulling out our collective hair.'' Most ballots already have been printed, without the Washington Party candidates. Kusper said elections officials made last-minute plans to give voters a looseleaf booklet, much like an absentee ballot, including the names of all candidates, including members of the Harold Washington Party. Now, voters will get a separate list of candidates names and will have to match the numbers on the booklet with numbers on a punch card. The Supreme Court order let stand an Aug. 29 Cook County electoral board decision that allowed Harold Washington Party candidates to be listed on city and county ballots. The Illinois Supreme Court ruled Oct. 12 that Washington Party candidates should not be allowed on the ballot because they lacked sufficient nominating petitions. But the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling gives Harold Washington Party attorneys 90 days from Oct. 12 to file formal appeals, well beyond the Nov. 6 election date. The high court will decide later whether to hear the case. Stu Piper, executive director of the Illinois Republican Party, said Republccan candidates could benefit from the ruling if traditionally Democratic black voters opt for Washington Party candidates in local races. ``There's a lot of mad voters out there who were mad about not being able to vote who are now going to vote,'' Piper said.

DOC.HEAD: Defector: Execution of Cuban Officers Hid Anti-Castro Plot
DOC.TEXT: Four top Cuban military and intelligence officers executed on drug charges actually were killed for plotting against Fidel Castro, a newspaper reported Thursday. The conspiracy against the Cuban president included Maj. Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa and many others at the top of the Cuban military and the Interior Ministry, Juan Manuel Rodriguez Camejo, a Cuban major who defected Sunday, told El Nuevo Herald. The newspaper is the Spanish-language companion newspaper to The Miami Herald. Ochoa and three other officials were executed in July 1989 after a televised tribunal in which prosecutors accused them of aiding drug traffickers. ``Inside the (Cuban armed forces) the conspiracy reached very high levels, and Ochoa took the secret to his grave,'' Rodriguez said. Since the discovery of the conspiracy against Castro and the subsequent executions, most intelligence officials have been replaced, he said. ``The situation in the military is very tense,'' Rodriguez said. ``But our lives are controlled 24 hours a day, especially since the trial.'' Rodriguez said he traveled as an official in Cuban commercial enterprises to cover his intelligence activities. He said he was active in infiltrating spy operations run out of the U.S. Interests Section in Havana, which led in 1987 to a series on state-run Cuban television called ``The CIA's War Against Cuba.'' Rodriguez said he decided to defect after becoming disenchanted with Castro's handling of the economy and his failure to adapt to the worldwide political changes of the mid-1980s. He defected in Germany. Rodriguez is living in an undisclosed location in the United States and talked to the newspaper by telephone, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Refuses To Prohibit Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The California Supreme Court refused Thursday to prohibit a death sentence for a former winery worker accused of killing seven people and trying to kill three others. Ramon Salcido, 29, is accused in the slayings, including six family members, during a series of bloody attacks in California's wine country last year. Salcido faces seven counts of murder and three counts of attempted murder. The case went to the jury Wednesday and deliberations continued Thursday. The Supreme Court refused a defense request to intervene in the case and prohibit a death sentence. Jurors could recommend the death penalty if they find Salcido guilty of multiple first-degree murders. Salcido's lawyers had argued their client was removed from Mexico by a subterfuge intended to evade the U.S.-Mexico extradition treaty. That treaty lets Mexico, which has no death penalty for murder, deny extradition if the fugitive could be sentenced to death in the United States. In court papers, public defender Marteen Miller said Mexican officials were deceived into releasing Salcido into U.S. custody without formal extradition after he was arrested in Mexico four days after the killings. ``The law enforcement agents of SonomaCounty sought to evade the effect of these treaty provisions by intentionally misleading the Mexican authorities into falsely believing that (Salcido) was an American citizen and expelling him,'' Miller wrote. Those arguments were rejected earlier by Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell, who is presiding over Salcido's trial in San Mateo County. The proceedings were moved from Sonoma County because of heavy pre-trial publicity. Salcido is accused of shooting his wife, Angela, 24, and cutting the throats of their three young daughters, two of whom died, in April 1989. He also is accused of stabbing to death his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, killing her two daughters and fatally shooting his co-worker Tracey Toovey, 35. He faces three counts of attempted murder for attacks on his surviving daughter, another co-worker, Kenneth Butti, and Butti's wife, Terri.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Two Men of `Illegal Handholding'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, 10th graf and 15th graf to DELETE word arrest. Pick up 16th graf, `Ed Ammann ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: Two men cited for holding hands in a parked car were cleared by a judge, but the American Civil Liberties Union said Thursday it is appalled that the incident even occurred. ``It's entirely offensive. It would be offensive to any civilized person that they're (police) doing this,'' said Jim Rogers, ACLU coordinator for southwestern Ohio. Hamilton County Municipal Judge Joseph Luebbers heard legal argument and testimony Wednesday before dismissing the charges against Commedore C. Canyon, 29, of Cincinnati and John K. Harden, 28, of Ludlow, Ky. ``I see this as a direct violation of freedom of association, for two individuals not to be able to sit and talk,'' Rogers said. ``If these two gentlemen hadn't had the nerve to resist this prosecution, this kind of harassment might have continued to take place.'' ``I'm just glad it's over, because we didn't do anything wrong,'' Canyon said Wednesday. ``I'm pleased that justice was served, because we didn't do anything wrong,'' Harden said Thursday. Defense lawyer Catherine Adams argued that the charge - disorderly conduct for creating a physically offensive condition - was unconstitutional. She said it fails to specify what sort of conduct society considers acceptable or illegal. ``What is a physically offensive condition? Who knows what that means?'' Ms. Adams asked. ``That doesn't put anybody on notice as to what that means. There are all sorts of things that are offensive, from picking your nose to God knows what.'' Police officer Marty Polk found the men holding hands in a parked car Sept. 27 in Eden Park. The men said they had known each other six years and that Canyon was consoling Harden over a death in his family when they were cited. The two are homosexuals, but are not romantically involved, said lawyer Scott Knox, an associate of Ms. Adams. Polk testified that the fact both were men did not make the act offensive - he said the situation would have been as offensive had it involved a man and a woman. Ms. Adams said the two men were cited three days after activists protested at the Hamilton County Courthouse as the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie went on trial on charges of displaying obscene photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe. At issue were seven photos showing sexually graphic acts involving men and two children with their genitals exposed. Barrie and the center were acquitted of all charges. Mapplethorpe, 42, who was a homosexual, died in 1989 of AIDS. The activists who protested Sept. 24 accused police and prosecutors of harassing homosexuals. ``I really believe that this (citations) happened because of the atmosphere generated by the Mapplethorpe case and the Mapplethorpe demonstration,'' Ms. Adams said. Ed Ammann, assistant police chief, denied the allegation Thursday, saying police enforce laws, not harass homosexuals. ``I don't think it was a harassment kind of thing,'' Ammann said. ``The officer believed he had a disorderly conduct case, so he placed the charges. ... There is no attempt to increase enforcement in the area of homosexuals.'' Ms. Adams said the law prohibiting disorderly conduct for creating a physically offensive condition had been in effect since Jan. 1, 1974. But she said her research turned up no published case in Ohio in which the law had been the basis for a prosecution. The maximum penalty for conviction is a $116 fine. Rogers said the ACLU does not plan to file a protest, but will monitor to see if there is evidence of harassment against the gay community. ``It's an enforcement of the statute in a definitely unconstitutional manner,'' Rogers said. ``We all have a right of association ... two people, man and woman, woman and woman, man and man, are allowed to sit and comfort each other,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Angela Lansbury Under Fire for Political Ads
DOC.TEXT: Actress Angela Lansbury has come under fire for appearing in political advertisements opposing term limits for state officials, with supporters of the initiatives calling the ads, ``Distortions, She Wrote.'' The star of CBS-TV's ``Murder, She Wrote'' did not know that the ads were paid for by state legislators, her son said. In addition, she is unfamiliar with other provisions of the two propositions. Commercials featuring the actress aired Tuesday. She did the ads at the request of an unidentified friend, said David Shaw, the actress' son and agent. ``She doesn't really read newspapers,'' Shaw said. Miss Lansbury does feel strongly that politicians' terms should not be limited and has not asked that the ads be pulled, Shaw said. ``She's not backing out of what she said,'' Shaw said. KCBS-TV in Los Angeles pulled the ad Thursday until the dispute over whether to include mention in the ad of state legislators who helped pay for it was resolved, station officials said. Proponents of Proposition 140 said the commercials incorrectly suggest that the measure would require public funding of campaigns.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chicagoan Gives Up U.S. Citizenship
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP)- A former Chicago man who was admitted participating in an infamous World War II death march when he was a Nazi concentration camp guard has renounced his U.S. citizenship, the Justice Department said Thursday. Martin Zultner renounced his American citizenship at the U.S. Consulate in Salsburg, Austria, on Aug. 16 and the State Department accepted the renunciation this week, the Justice Department said. Zultner, who has lived in Austria since 1975, renounced his citizenship two weeks after the Justice Department initiated proceedings in U.S. District Court in Washington to strip him of it. The government has stripped 33 former Nazis of U.S. citizenship and deported 29 from this country since the Justice Department set up its Nazi-hunting unit in 1979, the department said. Zultner confessed under oath during a May 1990 interview with a Justice Department investigator to being a Waffen-SS guard at the Schwechat, Floridsdorf, and Modling subcamps of the Mauthausen concentration camp in Austria, the department said. Zultner also admitted that he had lied about his Nazi past when he immigrated to this country after the war, said Neal Sher, who heads the Office of Special Investigations. ``Zultner confessed to taking part in the infamous death march from Modling to Mauthausen in April 1945, during the course of which hundreds of prisoners were shot to death,'' Sher said in a statement. The department said Zultner denied allegations of former SS comrades that he interrogated camp inmates, was present when they were whipped and that his office issued orders to kill prisoners by lethal heart injections. But Zultner admitted to interviewers that he was an administrative aide to the SS guard supervisor and the commandant at the concentration camps and that he issued rifles to camp guards.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Delivers Guilty Verdict in Decade-Old Rape Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `Percy did ...' to CLARIFY that Percy did not admit to raping either woman. Pick up 17th graf, `Defense attorney....'
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnam veteran who said he was a victim of war stress was convicted Thursday for a second time of the 1981 rape-kidnap of a woman who disclosed her identity in frustration over years of delay. ``God, yea!'' said victim Sue Kremelberg, 35, her fists raised in the air, after the verdicts were read. She and her family then hugged in the courtroom. Robert Percy, 39, was accused of raping Kremelberg in 1981 while out on bail after raping an Essex attorney, Susan Sweetser, just weeks earlier. In both cases Percy was convicted of rape. In his appeals of both cases, the Vermont Supreme Court overturned the convictions on procedural errors and sent them back for retrial. The Sweetser rape led to a second conviction in 1988 and last month the high court upheld the verdict. For years, Kremelberg and Sweetser have had to return again and again to court to recite the stories of their rapes. Outrage over those experiences prompted them to go public with their cases this summer. They shed the anonymity customarily shrouding rape victims hoping to provoke changes in a complex and sluggish judicial system they say favors defendants. Percy, who blamed his crime on his stressful legacy from combat in the Vietnam War, can still appeal this verdict to the Vermont Supreme Court. His lawyer didn't say whether an appeal would be made. Percy's conviction Thursday of sexual assault, kidnapping, armed robbery and committing a felony while carrying a concealed weapon will add to his current sentence of 18 to 20 years for raping Sweetser. He was eligible for parole in 1994. Sentencing in the Kremelberg case is expected within the next few months. Sweetser called Thursday's verdict gratifying. ``I'm both pleased and relieved,'' she said after learning of the verdict. ``I'm happy for all the women of Vermont.'' State Attorney General Jeffrey Amestoy predicted the women's public complaints would yield improvements in the state's justice system. He also intends to propose changes to the Legislature in January. The Kemelberg and Sweetser cases are ``significant beyond the particular cases because they are symbolic of some problems in Vermont's criminal justice system,'' Amestoy said. ``These cases have put a face on the problem.'' ``First and foremost, we need an amendment to Vermont's constitution to clearly establish the authority of Vermont judges to deny bail when the defendant poses a danger to the public,'' he said. He also will push for a way to speed up the Vermont Supreme Court's review of appeals and will propose legislation mandating a minimum 15 years to life in prison for anyone convicted of three violent felonies. Percy did not admit to raping either woman, but his lawyers did not deny the rapes occured, arguing that Percy was insane at the time because he suffered from a post-traumatic stress disorder. Percy's lawyer, James Dumont, said in closing arguments Wednesday that Percy was ``wounded in the brain'' by his Vietnam experience. But prosecutor Phillip Cykon countered that Percy was in control of his actions. ``The defendant was acting in a way that was his continuing anti-social behavior. They were the actions of a defendant who was in control,'' Cykon said. Kremelberg's nine-hour ordeal the night of Jan. 16, 1981, began when she stopped at a gasoline station where Percy was working. Percy told her to back her car to the air pump because her left tire looked low. There Percy jumped into the car and forced Kremelberg at gunpoint to drive away. He tied her up and raped her twice.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Apologizes To Wounded Knee Victims
DOC.TEXT: Descendants of the Indians killed and hurt in the Wounded Knee massacre 100 years ago got their long-awaited apology from the U.S. government Thursday. The House gave final congressional approval to a resolution expressing the government's ``deep regret'' for the event that marked the end of the Indian wars. The Senate approved the measure last week. Depending on the historical account, some 150 to 400 Sioux Indians were killed by the 7th Cavalry on Dec. 29, 1890 on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in southwestern South Dakota. The resolution does not provide any reparations to the descendants or declare the remote site a national monument, as the Wounded Knee Survivors Association had requested. ``No money is spent by this measure,'' said Rep. Tim Johnson, D-S.D., who called the apology a ``long overdue measure.'' The resolution passed by voice vote. The resolution said Congress ``acknowledges the historical significance of this event as the last armed conflict of the Indian wars period ... and hereby expresses its deep regret on behalf of the United States to the descendants of the victims and survivors and their respective tribal communities.'' Te South Dakota congressional delegation hopes to get funds next year for the monument designation and reparations for descendants of the victims. The site was made a national landmark 25 years ago. The descendants want compensation for thousands of dollars in property that was taken from the victims. Indian and government historians have been at odds over the past century on the circumstances surrounding Wounded Knee and the toll of dead and injured. According to the resolution, 350 to 375 Indian men, women and children of Chief Big Foot's band of Minneconjou Sioux were killed at Wounded Knee. The descendants group told a Senate committee last month that 426 Indians were killed when they were attacked while in custody of drunken soldiers. The official position of the Interior Department, parent agency of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, is that fewer than 200 people were killed or wounded. The firing began when an Indian fired his gun as soldiers tried to disarm him, the department says.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Bill Approved
DOC.TEXT: The House approved and sent to the White House on Thursday a bill authorizing a 22 percent increase in spending for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to $13.9 billion. The bill was the result of weeks of negotiation between House and Senate panels. The measure authorizes work in the current fiscal year on the planned permanent space station and development of an advanced space transport system known as the aerospace plane. It would continue studies toward a manned return to the Moon and a mission to Mars. Actual funds must be provided in a separate appropriations bill.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Banished to Back Pew With Guide Dog
DOC.TEXT: The pastor of a rural church may have broken state laws by banishing a blind associate to the back of the church with his guide dog and posting ``beware of the dog'' signs, an official said Thursday. Associate pastor Le Roy Singleton used to sit in the pulpit of Mount Zion AME Church during services. But when Singleton was declared legally blind and got a guide dog last month, the Rev. Ellsworth L. Coleman barred Singleton from the church. Singleton, 62, was allowed to attend services Sunday, but he was forced to sit in a back pew with his dog. ``It appears there may well be a problem,'' said Fred Silverman, Delaware's chief deputy attorney general. ``Our office would be glad to speak with him. The Human Relations Commission would be happy to speak with him.'' The church has large, red ``beware of the dog signs'' on each door, said Earlene A. Hughes, president of the Delaware branch of the National Federation of the Blind. Hughes said state law allows guide dogs in public places with their masters. ``Rev. Coleman told me I was choosing a dog over God,'' Singleton said. ``I told him the dog was my eyes and God wouldn't see it that way.'' Coleman has an unpublished home telephone number and calls to the church, about 20 miles south of Dover, went unanswered Thursday. A member of the congregation said Coleman cited a biblical passage to support his contention that the dog should not be allowed to sit at the front of the church. The passage from Deuteronomy 23:18 says: ``Thou shalt not bring the hire of a whore, or the price of a dog, into the house of the Lord thy God for any vow: for even both these are abominations unto the Lord thy God.'' The guide dog, Digby, sat quietly through Sunday's services, Singleton said. ``There was singing, clapping and praising, and the dog did not interrupt the services,'' he said. ``He was a perfect gentleman.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Prince Arouses Ire Of Cambridge Residents
DOC.TEXT: Two months after a Saudi Arabian prince set up camp near Harvard Square - complete with a satellite dish and an entourage of 65 at a posh hotel - residents say the royals are wearing out their welcome. In the latest of several incidents, North Cambridge residents complained security forces with the Prince Turki bin Abdul Aziz's entourage ejected local children from a park during royal family visits. They also claimed the Saudis drove stretch limousines across newly seeded athletic fields. Prince Turki, a brother of Saudi Arabia's king and the country's former deputy defense minister, arrived at Cambridge's Charles Square Hotel in early August for a visit to Harvard University. But the prince says he has stayed to monitor U.S. response to the crisis in the Middle East. Cambridge City Councilor Edward Cyr said he will ask the council to respond to the incident at the park. ``Once they drove their limousines into the park and almost ran people down, then went up on the athletic field,'' Cyr told The Boston Globe. Cyr said Wednesday he will ask the council to issue a formal reminder to the prince's group that ``nobody will be allowed to essentially usurp a public facility for their exclusive use.'' Mayor Alice K. Wolf said she has fielded complaints from residents that the prince's limousines have made it harder to park in an already congested part of the city. Earlier this month, Harvard University police reduced its participation in the 24-hour guard protecting Prince Turki. ``We don't want to abandon the family, but with the advent of the school semester, we've been trying to phase it out,'' said Harvard Police Chief Paul E. Johnson. ``Hopefully, he's going to be leaving shortly.'' Even Prince Turki's attempts at charity have generated sour publicity. University officials announced last weekend that the prince had endowed a Harvard Medical School professorship in immunology. The prince's father-in-law has been treated in Boston by a Harvard-affiliated physician following a kidney transplant. But the student-run Harvard Crimson newspaper said in an editorial that university president Derek C. Bok was ``selling his soul to the devil for a million-dollar professorship.'' The Crimson referred to allegations from 10 female servants of the prince who claimed 10 years ago they were being held as slaves. The Crimson also cited a 1989 incident in London when two German nursemaids hired to care for the prince's three children dropped notes from a sixth-story hotel window saying they were being held hostage. Two Crimson photographers complained last month of being physically threatened by royal bodyguards. No charges were filed in any of the incidents. But at the Charles Hotel, where the prince has 40 rooms, hotel spokeswoman Martha Sullivan said the Saudis ``have been model guests. I can tell you, honestly, it's been wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Illegitimate Son Campaigns Against Father in Judicial Race
DOC.TEXT: A municipal judge candidate is facing strong opposition, not just from his opponent but also from am angry son born out of wedlock 34 years ago. Leo R. Villa, 62, a part-time court commissioner, is running against trial lawyer David W. Perkins for the judgeship. But Villa's son, Richard, also is opposing his father's candidacy, saying a bad father will make a bad judge. ``Leo R. Villa's son says vote no on Villa,'' read more than 200 campaign signs that Richard Villa has plastered around this Los Angeles suburb. He said he's angry because his father has seen him only twice and barely acknowledges his existence. ``How can someone who lacks such morals and compassion toward me judge others?'' said the younger Villa, a computer book salesman. ``After thinking about it a lot, I decided to go public.'' Richard Villa was born to Valma E. Vose in Orange in 1956. Ms. Vose said Leo Villa, then 27, ended their relationship shortly after he found out she was pregnant. In 1958, a judge declared Villa was Richard Villa's father and ordered him to pay $60 a month child support. In 1975, those payments were dropped to $40 after Leo Villa asked to stop payments altogether. The elder Villa would not comment on Richard Villa's campaign. The elder Villa's wife, Jennie, said he does not plan to stop his son. Leo Villa's brother, Robert, said his brother met his legal obligations by paying child support until Richard Villa turned 21. ``It really has nothing to do with whether he's qualified as a judge or not,'' Robert Villa said. ``If he didn't make the child support payments, then fine. But he paid.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents Arraigned For Allegedly Keeping Daughter Locked In Closet
LaserPhoto SB02
DOC.TEXT: A couple was arraigned Thursday on charges they kept their malnourished 12-year-old daughter captive in a filthy, bug-infested closet. Joseph Sauceda, 33, and his wife, Sandra, 31, each were charged with felony endangerment with great bodily injury. Sauceda also was charged with felony child abuse. Municipal Judge W. Robert Fawk accepted innocent pleas from the two and set a Nov. 6 preliminary hearing. Both remained in jail in lieu of $50,000 bail each. Sauceda faces more than 10 years in state prison if convicted on both counts, prosecutor Patrick Christianson said. His wife faces a maximum of nine years in prison. The Saucedas' daughter was found Monday night in a 4-foot-by-5-foot closet littered with human waste and fast-food wrappers and crawling with cockroaches, police said. Police checked on the girls' condition after receiving a tip from a relative, said police spokeswoman Jenifer Kauffman. Officers said the child, whose name was not released, was lying in her own feces and wore an oversized, urine-stained sweatsuit. She was malnourished and displayed bruises from apparent beatings. The girl and her six brothers and sisters, ages 2 months to 15 years, were placed in foster homes. There was no evidence the others were abused. During a Tuesday jailhouse interview, Sauceda denied abusing the child. San Bernardino police chipped in $500 to start a trust fund to buy the girl clothes and toys.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Tax Drivers Revved Up Over Gas Hikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs `Prices are' to CORRECT gas prices to $2.30 a gallon and to rise to $4 a gallon. Pickup graf 4, `Hundreds of...'
DOC.TEXT: Protesting taxi drivers blocked bridges in this capital city Thursday and others lined up for miles to fill up their tanks after officials announced gasoline price hikes of up to 70 percent. The government said it is increasing the prices, beginning Friday, because of a shortfall in Soviet oil supplies. The higher prices also reflect the loss of imports from Iraq under the U.N.-ordered embargo for its invasion of Kuwait. Prices are to go up by 65 to 70 percent. Currently, the highest grade of gasoline costs about $2.30 a gallon. With the price increase, it will cost about $4 a gallon, a government spokesman said. Hundreds of private taxis joined the protests in Budapest and the eastern city of Debrecen, the state MTI news agency reported. Taxi drivers, angry over the new prices, barricaded bridges that link the Buda and Pest sides of the capital spanning the Danube River, the news agency said. The taxi protest on the bridges halted traffic from one part of town to the other. Many Hungarians live on one side of the Danube, which cuts through the capital, and work on the other. Other drivers lined up for several miles to fill their tanks before the new prices come into effect, snarling traffic in the capital. About 600 private taxi drivers gathered late Thursday in front of Parliament. They demanded that the new prices be revoked, saying the increases threaten their livelihood, MTI said. Transport Minister Csaba Siklos, who came out of a Cabinet session to talk to the protesters, said the government could not revoke the decision because it lacks any reserves to cover the current price of crude oil, MTI reported. Hungary has so far put off an increase in gasoline prices. Czechoslovakia and other East European countries have raised prices the past month because of the shortfalls in Soviet oil. The problem has been compounded by the Persian Gulf crisis. Many East European countries had barter contracts with Iraq, but Baghdad cannot deliver that oil under the embargo for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The last price increase in Hungary was in mid-July, when gasoline prices rose by about 20 percent. Because of the reduced deliveries of Soviet oil, Hungary has had to buy oil on the world market, spending scarce hard currency. Mrs. Katalin Kardos, the spokeswoman for the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, told reporters Thursday that the Soviets are charging Hungary $17 a barrel but shipped only about 700,000 tons in the last quarter. She said Hungary needed to buy another 700,000 or 800,000 tons at world-market prices for the same period. The Soviet Union, for years the main supplier of subsidized oil to Hungary and its East Eropean neighbors, has been unable to fulfill quotas. It will begin demanding convertible currency for the oil starting next year.

DOC.HEAD: Visitors Flock to Yuma House to See Sacred Image
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people flocked this week to see what some say looks like the Virgin Mary, or Jesus Christ or even St. Jude in the boughs of a dead Christmas tree. ``I think it looks like the Virgin Mary all dressed up like she is supposed to be, beautiful,'' visitor Edith Zavala said. Believers claim the image is formed by the wilted boughs of a dead star pine tree. Noah Hefner, who also lives at the house where the tree is displayed, said people have come to see the image since Monday. Debbie Aguilar, who also lives at the house, said visitors have come at all hours of the night, the only time the image can be seen. Roman Catholic Church officials in Yuma would not discuss the image.

DOC.HEAD: Colonel Denies Allegation He Knew of Threats Against Jesuits
DOC.TEXT: A Salvadoran colonel on Thursday denied allegations by a U.S. military adviser that he knew about threats against six Jesuit priests 10 days before they were massacred by an army death squad. Col. Carlos Aviles called U.S. Army Maj. Eric Buckland ``crazy'' for making the accusation. The allegation is contained in an affidavit Buckland gave the FBI in January. U.S. officials waited until this week to turn it over to the Salvadoran judge investigating the massacre. ``This new information that we should have had 10 months ago really complicates our work,'' said one court source. He said it would delay the prosecution of Col. Guillermo Benavides and seven other soldiers charged with the murders. Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., revealed the existence of the affidavit last week. He also said Buckland later recanted this testimony. Moakley, who heads a congressional commission following the Jesuit investigation, blamed U.S. Embassy officials in El Salvador for withholding the affidavit alleging prior knowlege by the high command. ``In withholding this information, the U.S. Embassy has acted in a dirty way. If they hide something, it is for a reason,'' said Father Jose Maria Tojeira, the Jesuit Provincial for Central America. Embassy spokeswoman Pamela Corey-Archer said the State Department has ordered all embassy officials to refuse comment on the affidavit. It was other testimony by Buckland - that Aviles had told him Benavides ordered the killings - that broke the case and led to the arrests of Benavides and the other soldiers. At the time of the slayings, Buckland was stationed in El Salvador as an adviser to a unit headed by Aviles. Court sources said the new affidavit says Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, then chief of staff and now defense minister, sent Aviles to try to calm down Benavides in early November. Buckland's affidavit says Ponce was worried because Benavides, then head of the Military College, had been telling other officers he was going to harm the Jesuits. Buckland said he went to the Military College with Aviles, but was not present when the two officers spoke. ``It is totally false,'' Aviles said in a telephone interview. ``The only explanation for these statements is that Buckland is completely unstable emotionally.'' ``He is crazy,'' Aviles said. He claimed he was not even in the country in early November. He said he was in New Orleans between Oct. 31 and Nov. 14. Ponce's office said the defense minister was not available for comment. The priest-professors wer among Central America's leading intellectuals. They advocated a negotiated settlement to the conflict, and social change in El Salvador, and for this reason many right-wingers hated them. On Nov. 16, army troops roused them from their beds at Central American University before dawn, made them lie face-down in the grass behind their campus residence and shot them to death, according to soldiers' confessions. The troops also murdered the Jesuits' housekeeper and her teenage daughter to eliminate witnesses. The court source said the submission of Buckland's affidavit will delay the case. He said it may not go to trial until next year.

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Chief Arrested for Plotting Against Government
DOC.TEXT: Authorities charged the former chief of the National Police on Thursday with plotting to overthrow the government of President Guillermo Endara. Attorney General Rogelio Cruz, in a letter to the chief of the Technical Judicial Police, Leslie Loaiza, said former Col. Eduardo Herrera was being charged with threatening state security. Herrera led the reorganization of Panama's military in the wake of the Dec. 20, 1989, U.S. invasion that overthrew former strongman Manuel Noriega. But Endara retired him in August, and the government now says Herrera is linked to a group that opposes U.S. intervention in Panama. Herrera was detained Wednesday upon returning from a private visit to Peru. If convicted he could face up to 20 years in prison, although a sentence of such a length would be unlikely. Herrera has denied the allegations. His attorney, Rafael Rodriguez, told reporters that U.S. citizens had offered bribes in exchange for testimony implicating Herrera. The government announced last week that Herrera had ordered members of the National Police to carry out bombings and attempt to seize army barracks. The government said he was also linked to underground 20th of December Movement, which takes its name, in protest, from the date of the U.S. invasion of Panama last year. The government this week said it had uncovered two training camps for the guerrilla group, which it said had about 225 members.

DOC.HEAD: Agents Seize Cocaine on Horses after Exchanging Shots with Smugglers
DOC.TEXT: A train of 30 to 40 horses laden with 4,391 pounds of cocaine were seized by Border Patrol agents after a brief exchange of gunfire with smugglers, authorities said Thursday. The Border Patrol estimated the street-sale value of the cocaine seized Wednesday night at $200 million. The agency said in a statement from Tucson that the seizure was a ``nationwide Border Patrol record.'' The statement did not say what the previous record was. Border Patrol agents in Naco confiscated about 3,200 pounds of cocaine in April. That seizure's street-sale value was estimated at $150 million. Ron Dowdy, chief of the Border Patrol's Tucson sector, said a dozen riders leading the train of horses opened fire on approaching agents about a half-mile west of a border crossing for commercial trucks on the outskirts of Nogales. No agents were wounded in the exchange of gunfire, and the riders dismounted and fled on foot, Dowdy said. The cocaine was in packages of about 2.2 pounds each, which were in burlap bags of 90 to 100 pounds each, two to a horse, Dowdy said. Dowdy said the horses were confiscated and placed in quarantine.

DOC.HEAD: 63 Dead in Indian Riots Over Religious Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire Thursday on protesters in Calcutta during a Hindu-Moslem dispute that has jeopardized the governing coalition and left at least 63 people dead in two days of nationwide riots. The violence flared Wednesday during a nationwide strike called by the Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu fundamentalist group. The party rocked the government Tuesday by withdrawing its support, depriving Prime Minister V.P. Singh of a parliamentary majority and forcing a vote of confidence in two weeks. The Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said Thursday its 195 members in the 522-seat Parliament will vote against Singh. It accused him of mishandling the religious dispute. Congress is the largest opposition group, and its announcement appeared to cripple Singh's hope of winning the confidence vote. The bitter struggle revolves around a plan by Hindu fundamentalists to build a temple on the site of a 16th-century Moslem mosque. The Bharatiya Janata Party supports the plan, and the government has vowed to stop it until the matter is heard in court. Police opened fire in Calcutta on Thursday to quell mobs, killing four people and injuring 10, the United News of India news agency reported. Clashes also were reported for a second day in the western state of Rajasthan, where five people were killed, reports said. Press Trust of India, compiling police reports from four states, said 54 people wer killed Wednesday during the strike. Fighting in the dispute has left at least 140 people dead this month. The defection of the right-wing party, with 86 seats, left Singh's centrist National Front and allied Left Front with just 198 assured votes. The Bharatiya Janata Party and the Congress Party hold a majority of votes between them. Congress Party spokesman Vithal N. Gadgil said his group was willing to support any leader, besides Singh, chosen by the governing National Front coalition. If the coalition can't come up with an alternative, the Congress would stake a claim to form the government, the spokesman said. Most analysts say elections are likely next year, regardless of the immediate outcome. The Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew its support for Singh's minority government after the arrest Tuesday of its leader, Lal Krishna Advani, during a cross-country crusade to replace the mosque with a Hindu temple. Hindus believe the mosque at the site in Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi, stands on the birthplace of the god Rama. They say it is as important to them as Mecca in Saudi Arabia is to Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: California Inmate Claims To Be Ivana's Brother, Sues Donald
DOC.TEXT: A new name briefly emerged in the marital melodrama of Donald and Ivana Trump: prisoner Vladimar Zatko, Ph.D. Zatko filed a complaint Monday in U.S. District Court, claiming he is Mrs. Trump's brother and suing her debt-strapped husband for $275 million. Zatko, an inmate at Pelican Bay State Prison in Crescent City, Calif., claimed he suffered extreme emotional distress after Trump publicly humiliated Mrs. Trump by allegedly having an extra-marital relationship with Marla Maples. U.S. District Court Judge Alfred J. Lechner dismissed the suit as frivolous the same day it was filed. ``Ivana's an only child,'' said John Scanlon, a spokesman for Mrs. Trump. Prison spokesman Al Deines said records do not show that Zatko has a Ph.D. or that he is related to Mrs. Trump. They do show he has a history of threatening public figures and filing lawsuits against them, said Deines. Zatko was moved to Pelican Bay because of his threats against public figures, he said. Zatko has been sentenced to life on two separate occasions - in 1971 for robbery and grand theft and in 1976 for assaulting another inmate.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique Parliament Approves Majority Elections, Freedoms
DOC.TEXT: The Parliament has approved freedom of the press and speech measures as well as majority elections in this East African country shedding the vestiges of Marxist rule, the national news agency reported Thursday. In debate on a new constitution, the Parliament, known as the People's Assembly, previously approved an article to allow opposition parties. The move would end 15 years of one-party rule. All the changes would take effect when Parliament approves the entire new constitution. Article-by-article debate was expected to continue several more days. The Central Committee of the ruling FRELIMO party proposed the new constitution. Support from the FRELIMO-dominated Parliament is expected. President Joachim Chissano said in July he wanted a multiparty system in place for parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for next year. He reviously had opposed such a system, saying it would encourage tribalism and waste the country's scarce resources. Chissano also has promised to end a 13-year-old civil war with the Mozambique National Resistance that has claimed 600,000 lives and left about half the country's 15 million people in need of donated food. Multiparty elections is a key rebel demand for ending the fighting. The Parliament voted unanimously Thursday for a majority-vote election system instead of a proportional system, AIM reported. The agency said the system would be a winner-take-all format instead of a proportional system in which parties receive the same percentage of parliamentary seats as popular votes received. Chissano told the assembly a majority vote system would make ``the process of governing easier, since minority parties were likely to have less weight in parliament,'' AIM reported. In presidential elections, a candidate would be required to gain at least half the votes to win. If no candidate gets half, a runoff would be held between the top two finishers. There have been no presidential elections and FRELIMO has been the sole legal political party since this southeast African nation gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The FRELIMO party was Marxist, but it has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. The Parliament also approved articles guaranteeing all citizens ``the right to freedom of expression and freedom of the press, as well as the right to information,'' AIM reported. The articles give reporters access to sources and protects their independence, and they provide the right to set up newspapers and other publications. However, radio and television will remain government-controlled.

DOC.HEAD: Sadat's Daughter Calls Saddam `Great Satan,' Urges Peace in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of slain Egyptian President Anwar Sadat on Thursday called Saddam Hussein ``the great Satan'' and said world leaders must find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Camelia Sadat, who teaches in the Boston area and is earning a doctorate, was here to address The Women's National Republican Club on peace initiatives in the gulf. ``I have lived wars,'' said Ms. Sadat, recalling Middle East conflicts. ``I was the wife of an officer. I was the daughter of an officer. My cousins were officers. My brother-in-law was an officer. The Sadat family was an army by itself.'' The destruction and suffering of war and the lives of 240,000 troops in the gulf are reason enough to pursue peace there, she said in an interviw before her speech. ``The deployment of military was mainly to deter wars and to help bring peace. So let's keep it this way. Let's keep the idea that we started with. Let's not bar the peaceful solution,'' she said. ``I know very, very well that Saddam Hussein's success in Kuwait would have given him an appetite (for) all of the countries around. ``I think he's Satan. He's the great Satan. Because I tell you, this man had worked on the Iraqi people and has split them. He terrorized them and split them. He terrorized the Arab world and split them by ... keeping Kuwait. He terrorized the Moslem world and split them.'' Sadat was assassinated in 1981 by commandos while he was reviewing a military parade in Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Mutilated Girlfriend, Fed Her to Dogs, Sentenced to 12-17 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A man who killed and mutilated his girlfriend and fed her body parts to his dogs was sentenced Thursday to 12 to 17 years in prison. Jeffrey L. Van Patten, 33, was given the maximum sentence by Judge Harvey W. Moes, who called the case ``suitable for the National Enquirer.'' ``I would have to look far to find something as serious as his conduct,'' Moes said. Van Patten pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter, mutilation of a corpse and felony firearms charges in the July 10 shooting death of his live-in girlfriend, Kimberly A. Knight, 18. In his confession, Van Patten said Knight attacked him with two butcher knives so he shot her and then panicked. He shot her at least twice, burned her body, dismembered it with a chainsaw and fed it to his four dogs. Officials said the self-defense motive and a lack of witnesses and evidence caused them to drop a murder charge in exchange for a manslaughter plea. Prosecutor Michael Smith has said results of a polygraph test indicate Van Patten may have been telling the truth about the knife attack. Defense attorney Thomas O'Brien, saying Knight had a violent past, argued for probation on the manslaughter charge and blamed the mutilation on panic. Smith argued for the maximum sentence, saying Van Patten went far beyond self defense. For six weeks after her disappearance, Van Patten claimed Knight ran away after an argument. ``He has shown no remorse,'' Smith said. ``He led the family and law enforcement officials on a wild goose chase.'' Speaking softly to the judge, Van Patten said he was scared for his life the night he killed Knight. ``I really wish I wouldn't have done it,'' Van Patten said. ``I know now that I did wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Man Guilty of Murder and Conspiracy in Plan to Kill His Wife
DOC.TEXT: A man was found guilty Thursday of murdering two men - including one he videotaped - and of conspiring to kill his wife. Prosecutors charged that Kosta Fotopoulos, a Daytona Beach businessman, enlisted the two men in a failed plot to kill his wife, Lisa, so he could collect insurance. Fotopoulos' one-time lover and employee, Deidre Hunt, 21, was convicted earlier in the same killings and has been sentenced to die in Florida's lectric chair. Jurors will make a sentencing recommendation to Circuit Judge S. James Foxman, who will decide whether Fotopoulos will get life in prison or death. Prosecutors have said they will seek the death penalty. The jury was to begin the sentencing phase of the trial Monday. Fotopoulos, 31, was convicted of the videotaped slaying of Mark Kevin Ramsey, 19, and the shooting of Bryan Chase, 18, both in the fall of 1989. Prosescutors said Fotopoulos forced Ms. Hunt to kill Ramsey to ensure her cooperation in his plan to kill his wife. Fotopoulos then killed Chase when he flubbed his murder-for-hire assignment to kill Fotopoulos' wife and make it look like a burglary. Mrs. Fotopoulos survived the Nov. 4, 1989, shooting and testified that her husband wanted her dead for her money after she threatened to divorce him over his affair with Ms. Hunt. Fotopoulos took the stand in his own defense, claiming prosecutors coerced Ms. Hunt to testify against him. Fotopoulos' attorney, Carmen Corrente, said his client was framed by Ms. Hunt and her friends.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Officials of State-Controlled Greek Companies to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court Thursday ordered 11 former officials of state-controlled companies to stand trial for bribery and accepting proceeds of a crime. The charges revolve around money deposited in the Bank of Crete, which is also at the hub of the legal case against former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou. He was indicted last year. Among those facing the latest charges are Alexandros Akrivakis, former board chairman of Olympic Airways; Theofanis Tombras, ex-director general of the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization; and Panagiotis Vournas, former head of the Greek Post Office. The 11 men were appointed by the former Socialist administration of Papandreou, who governed from 1981-89. The three-member appeals court did not set a trial date for the 11. Akrivakis is a deputy of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, now the major political opposition party. In order to put him on trial, Parliament must decide whether to lift his parliamentary immunity. The charges are related to money deposited by the state-controlled corporations at the Bank of Crete between July and September 1988. Details of the charges were not available. State auditors have accused the bank's president, George Koskotas, of embezzling $200 million in bank funds. Koskotas fled to the United States in November 1988, claiming that ranking Socialist officials, including Papandreou, were behind the multimillion dollar scheme. Koskotas is imprisoned in Massachusetts awaiting the decision of U.S. authorities on a Greek extraditon request. Papandreou and four former Socialist ministers were indicted by a special session of Parliament in July 1989 for their alleged involvement in the Bank of Crete scandal. No date has been set for their trial.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Work Through Final Details, OK Seen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New lede, SUBS grafs 11-12 pvs: ``A chief,'' with 3 gras bgng: ``Bargainers settled,'' to reflect agreements on Medicare beneficiary cuts; FYI meetings continue and we expect updates to the following
DOC.TEXT: Bargainers settled disputes over paring Medicare benefits and wrestled over other cuts and tax breaks Thursday as top lawmakers predicted passage of the broad deficit-reduction bill supported by President Bush. None of the outstanding differences was seen as a deal-killer for the $250-billion collection of tax increases and spending reductions. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush liked the emerging bill, and that seemed to stamp out the possibility of any last-minute setback. ``With the White House optimistic, one would guess it would be hard to shipwreck the thing,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he expected the House to approve the measure Friday. And little trouble was expected in the Senate later. The package would boost the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax by about a nickel and increase levies on alcohol, tobacco and fancy cars as well. It would raise - from 28 percent to 31 percent - the income-tax rate on the richest Americans, but drop the rate paid by the upper-middle class from 33 percent to 31 percent. The measure also would reduce the deductions available to people earning more than $100,000 yearly by 3 percent, and phase out their $2,050 personal exemptions. The plan also aims cuts at veterans, farm aid and other benefit programs. The details were subject to change in late negotiations. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and Richard Darman, Bush's budget chief, met for more than two hours on Capitol Hill with House GOP members, answering questions and seeking support. Sununu said that assuming final details were acceptable to Bush, Republicans should support the package because it contains ``real and credible'' savings. ``I think we picked up votes today,'' said No. 3 House Republican Jerry Lewis of California. ``I think the president will have substantial Republican support for the package.'' Bargainers settled a major difference when they agreed informally to trim the projected growth of benefits for Medicare participants - the elderly and handicapped - by $10 billion over the next five years, officials said. The figure represented the amount of cuts approved by the House earlier this month, $7 billion less than the Senate voted for. Under the agreement, the $75 annual deductible that beneficiaries pay for doctors' bill would increase to $100. The monthly premium - $28.60 this year - would grow gradually to $46.20 by 1995. A chief remaining disagreement over Medicare involved cuts in payments to doctors and hospitals. Those reductions were expected to total more than $30 billion over the next five years. Negotiators worked on other disputes involving: -Medicaid, which helps the poor pay their medical bills. Although the program will be cut, liberals wanted to provide an additional $2.9 billion for low-income elderly people. The Bush administration was trying to reduce that figure. -Tax breaks for the oil and gas industry totaling $3.5 billion over five years. They are championed by Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, but opposed by the House. -Tax advantages for a wide range of business activities, including research, and for individuals, including educational benefits received from employers. These items, sought by the Senate, would cost $5.6 billion. ``We're still working,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Bush, asked how he felt about the package, said as he passed reporters on a morning jog, ``Feel good about it.'' He turned away efforts to get him to be more specific as he appeared with Republican congressional leaders later. Some lawmakers emphasized the remaining differences. ``There's nothing the president has signed off on yet. It's not just one issue. There must be two dozen important issues that haven't been resolved,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said after an afternoon White House meeting. Still, the deal seemed solid. Fatigued after a year of relentless budget combat, most lawmakers seemed to have abandoned their desire to fight much further. Instead, they appeared ready to end Congress' long election-year session and return home for the remaining 12 days of the campaign season. ``The timetable is telling us we won't get as much equity in the package as we'd like,'' said Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich., who like many liberals would have preferred to shift more of the burden to the wealthy. And many lawmakers were displeased with items they believed would hurt their states. For Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., the problem was a provision forcing state and local government workers to begin paying the 1.45 percent Medicare payroll tax. Government employees in Illinois and several other states are now exempt from that levy. ``I want to vote for it, but that's the killer for me,'' he said. For Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., the problem was the limit the plan would put on tax deductions for people earning more than $100,000 annually. ``This is a back-door way of raising taxes on two-income families,'' she said. But House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., was counting on about 50 House Republican votes for the package. That meant for passage, majority Democrats would have to produce about 170 votes out of their 258 members - a figure leaders said they would reach.

The confrontation of multinational forces in Saudi Arabia with Iraq in occupied Kuwait has the makings of the largest tank battle since the classic World War II struggle at Kursk on the Russian Front. Several thousand German and Russian tanks fought in that epic 1943 battle, a Russian victory that marked the German ebb on the Eastern Front. Iraq has about 430,000 troops in Kuwait, bolstered by an estimated 3,500 Soviet-designed tanks, ranging from the aging T-54 to the more advanced T-72. They face more than 300,000 troops in the U.S.-led multinational force with a tank strength expected to reach 1,800 by the end of the month. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush faces several decisions that will affect the size and capabilities of U.S. forces in the Mideast and perhaps signal his intentions in the standoff with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. At the top of the list is whether to enlarge or shrink the Persian Gulf force, now at 220,000, the subject of talks in Saudi Arabia this week between ground commanders and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell. He is due back in Washington tonight. That decision could affect another issue soon to reach Bush's desk - a Pentagon plan that calls for rotating most troops sent to the Middle East on a six-month basis. The American buildup hit a symbolic juncture Wednesday with the arrival in Saudi Arabia of the final elements of the 11th Air Defense Brigade from Fort Bliss, Texas. It was the last combat unit scheduled for deployment in the region, Pentagon sources said. ---= UNITED NATIONS (AP) - For the second time in 10 days, the United States has joined a unanimous Security Council vote rebuking Israel, this time for not cooperating with a U.N. probe into the Temple Mount killings. Not even a last-ditch personal appeal from President Bush to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir persuaded Israel to change its mind and officially receive the U.N. investigators. The U.N. resolution, approved 15-0 on Wednesday, is largely symbolic. No sanctions against Israel are expected, said British Ambassador David Hannay, who is president of the council for October. Still, Hannay said Israel's treatment of Palestinians ``is not going to go away from the council agenda ... The principal loser by not receiving the U.N. mission will be Israel.'' Israeli security forces trying to quell a riot opened fire and killed 19 Palestinians on Jerusalem's sacred Temple Mount on Oct. 8. Arabs had unleashed a volley of stones on Jews praying below at the Western Wall. ---= BOSTON (AP) - Women can now turn back their biological clocks and get pregnant after menopause by way of test-tube fertilization, doctors reported today. The procedure, reported in the New England Journal of Medicine, can extend women's baby-making years well into their 40s, 50s and perhaps even 60s, providing a second chance for those who waited too long to start families. However, some doctors said they had doubts about the wisdom of childbearing for those who are well past nature's cutoff. ``Because we can do something technically does not mean we should do it indiscriminately,'' said Dr. Zev Rosenwaks. ``The ability to become pregnant is a physical sign of what nature itself expects of a woman. You cannot push nature past the point where you interfere with safety.'' Rosenwaks is head of the fertility clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, one of several U.S. hospitals using the new technology, a variation on the now-routine process of in vitro fertilization. ---= ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) - A loose-knit, right-wing coalition headed toward a landslide victory over former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today, likely setting Pakistan's struggling democracy on a more conservative, Islamic course. Ms. Bhutto, who claims her August dismissal was a ``constiutional coup,'' refused to concede defeat of her center-left Pakistan People's Party in Wednesday's parliamentary election. She accused the army-backed caretaker government of large-scale vote rigging, a charge that may be difficult to prove. Opponents called the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto a sore loser, saying the stunning victory margin by the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance surpassed even their expectations. A 40-member group of international poll-watchers refused comment.

DOC.HEAD: Shelves Are Empty and a Cold Winter Lies Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people line up at the TSUM department store to buy scarce, rationed food. At a luxury hotel nearby, Westerners with hard currency enjoy the best of food and wine. Long food lines reflect an economic crisis that is aggravating social tensions and forcing a traditionally agrarian nation to beg for food from the West to get through the winter. The government has proposed a 300-day moratorium on public rallies to keep consumer anger from getting out of hand. Diplomats in Sofia said they did not expect food riots immediately, but an energy shortage means the worst is yet to come. The Soviet Union has reduced oil shipments to Bulgaria and U.N. sanctions have halted supplies from Iraq. At the congress in September of the governing Socialist Party, the new name of the Communist Party, some officials spoke of unrest or civil war. Even without civil unrest, prospects are gloomy. President Zhelyu Zhelev denies reports that Bulgaria faces starvation, but acknowledged recently that ``poverty is a fact.'' Food stores in Sofia and other cities are virtually bare. Sugar, cheese, flour, eggs, cooking oil and detergent are rationed. As in Romania and the Soviet Union, such ordinary items as light bulbs, toilet paper and matches are as scarce as food. About 500 people waited outside TSUM one October morning. A woman in her early 60s had been there all night and was near the head of the line. She has a monthly pension of 102.30 leva, the equivalent of only $15 at the tourist rate of exchange. Hundreds of thousands of elderly and poor people struggle to get by on much less than the average wage, which is only 300 leva a month. Many Bulgarians hunt for food instead of going to work, or spend hours in the quest after their regular shifts. ``Now the whole morning will be wasted,'' said a man in the line, who has two children. ``I was on duty until 1 a.m., but I arrived here at 5.30. If I don't get back home with something, there'll be trouble in the family.'' Another shopper said: ``You don't know what you are lining up for. It may be meat, but you don't know which type or when it will be gone. It's possible only half the people will get something.'' Maria Ivanova, a psychoanalyst, was among the few shoppers willing to reveal their names. ``I have to put up a sign at my consultation room saying it will be closed for several hours so I can go shopping,'' she said. Ms. Ivanova, who studied medicine in East Germany, said it was her birthday but she could not have a party because she had no food. ``I think we won't move ahead without civil war,'' she said. ``If man suffers hunger . . . he is ready for a revolution.'' At the Western chain hotel near TSUM, the special business lunch that day cost $25. Some help is arriving from the West. The United States has shipped 100,000 tons of feed corn and the German Red Cross donated baby food. Japan, Austria, the Netherlands and some other countries have promised food. The European community has pledged $22 million worth of aid for next year. Bulgaria wants it now. Mismanagement and corruption by the rigid Communist regime of Todor Zhivkov, who was ousted last year, are the main reasons for Bulgaria's economic troubles. Zhivkov replaced well-functioning cooperative farms with huge ``agro-industrial complexes'' for greater central control. The food situation got worse when 320,000 ethnic Turks, many of them peasants, emigrated in 1989 to escape growing persecution. Industrial pollution has destroyed large tracts of fertile land. There are chronic shortages of agricultural feed and raw materials for industry. Government officials say stores make shortages worse by holding food back in anticipation of higher prices. Using a new law, police have raided department stores and other food outlets to find hidden supplies. Heavy fines are imposed on storekeepers who break the rules. Shortages or not, the government plans to remove price controls and cut government subsidies under economic reforms proposed by Premier Andrei Lukanov. Western financiers say they will not lend Bulgaria more money for economic recovery unless the Lukanov plan goes through.

DOC.HEAD: OLD RADIO TAPES: Jokes, War, Goat Glands
DOC.TEXT: From live reports on the invasion of Europe to the medical advice of the goat-gland doctor, it's still all there for anyone to hear. And the good thing is, anyone can hear it. The history in sound, dating back to the 1920s, is available through more than 3,800 radio broadcasts on file at Memphis State University. While the collection is not the largest of its kind, it's certainly one of the most accessible. Unlike most radio archives, it isn't just open to broadcasting students and researchers. Any radio fan can drop by to listen to a little Abbott and Costello or perhaps a bit of ``Inner Sanctum.'' ``Not only can you hear it - if you bring an audio cassette with you, they'll high-speed duplicate it for you,'' said Marvin Bensman, founder and chief overseer of the collection. An associate professor of broadcast history, Bensman began putting the collection together in 1969 while working at the University of Vermont. His students, he said, had little access to early radio broadcasts except through such sources as the National Archives in Washington. ``That's sort of ridiculous, to ask a college student to pay his way to Washington to listen to some old radio programs for a course,'' he said. From a variety of sources, including former broadcasters or their families, Bensman has put more than 1,200 radio hours on tape. There's a 1949 pilot of ``Gunsmoke'' starring Mark (that's right, Mark) Dillon and world-saving battles between ``The Shadow'' and various forces of evil. Fibber McGee and Molly build a doghouse or search for lost keys while J. Edgar Hoover warns of creeping communism. The collection includes several hours of live coverage of the Allied invasion of Europe when the outcome of World War II and the fate of the world was very much unsettled. ``Everyone was hanging on their radios to see were we going to make it,'' Bensman said. It also includes a series of shows by Dr. Jospeh R. Brinkley, an almost-governor of Kansas who broadcast medical advice in the 1920s and '30s. Brinkley picked up the nickname ``goat gland doctor'' because of claims he could improve the sex lives of his male patients with animal implants, Bensman said. ``He did a 90-minute program where you would write him and describe your symptoms. He would then diagnose your problem and prescribe to you over the air,'' he said. Raising the ire of the American Medical Association and the Federal Radio Commission, Brinkley lost his broadcasting license in Milford, Kan. He moved to Mexico and set up a hospital straddling the U.S.-Mexican border. ``He was a real pioneer,'' Bensman said. ``His voice is wonderful on the radio. I've listened to the stuff and his advice is not bad.'' A stack of 16-inch recording discs of Brinkley's show were recently found in the attic of his widow, Bensman said. While academic researchers and biographers of radio personalities often use Bensman's radio collection, it can also come in handy for such people as the daughter of the ``Silver-Masked Tenor.'' The tenor, whose real name was Josh White, performed on a radio show sponsored by a tire company in the 1920s. To promote ``silvertone'' tires, program managers staged a yearlong contest featuring an unnamed singer said to be wearing a silver mask. Listeners were urged to guess his identity. White's daughter contacted Bensman looking for a recording of her father's voice and a performance by the ``Silver-Masked Tenor'' was found on one of his tapes. ``We sent a tape and she was overjoyed,'' Bensman said. The older programs in the collection are on 16-inch discs which can hold up to 15 minutes on each side. The broadcasts are put on reel-to-reel tapes and then on the cassettes that are made available to the public. The collection continues to grow as more old programs are located and as modern ones are added to keep up with the evolution of radio. Bensman said he has a list of 60 to 70 programs he still seeks from the early days of radio. ``When we get those, we think we'll have every known program that ever appeared on the networks,'' he said. The sought after shows include such programs as ``Eyes Aloft.'' ``It's a program about air travel or being in the Air Force, I think,'' Bensman said. ``It's hard to say. Nobody has heard these programs in years.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: The ``American Eden'': Inside Wine Country
DOC.TEXT: Author James Conaway calls Napa Valley an ``American Eden,'' which turns out to be an apt description of his book about sex, scandal and sweat among families who built Northern California's famous wineries. ``This is a real place, these are real people in my book,'' Conaway said about his book, ``Napa'' (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95). ``I get as personal as I can because that's the way you write good books. There are many strong characters. And this is the first time their story has been told.'' His book reads like fiction, as the people behind Napa Valley's most famous labels - Inglenook, Krug, Schram, Beaulieu, Martini and Mondavi - come to life. The Mondavis, Robert and Peter, could be the warring Cain and Abel without the fratricide. Following a 1965 fist fight between the two brothers who ran the Charles Krug winery, Peter and the family fired Robert, who went on to start the Robert Mondavi Winery. Robert Mondavi's two sons, Michael and Timothy, now run the successful operation. ``Everybody talked to me, but I've heard that some people are a bit bothered by the book,'' the author said. ``They're not used to being written about in this way. They lead lives that have so far been unexamined.'' Volker Eisele, who has grown grapes in the valley for the past 20 years, said the book is accurate and gives a ``behind-the-scenes glimpse to people who aren't players in Napa.'' ``I've been hearing through the grapevine that a few people are unhappy about how hey came out. Maybe it turned out to be too personal,'' he said. Conaway does get past the doors and cellars of Napa's wineries, spending some time in the bedrooms. But tales of infidelities don't get much ink. ``Occasionally, someone got into bed with someone else's mate, but bridge was the preferred activity,'' he says in the book. Still, Conaway doesn't shy away from telling about Betty Daniel who, despite her Mormon upbringing, was often unfaithful to husband John Daniel, who inherited Inglenook from his father. ``John ... had economic muscle in the valley and twice got rid of Betty's lovers by depriving them of jobs, but there was always a replacement,'' Conaway writes of the Daniels, who eventually divorced. Daniel was among the old families in the lush Napa Valley, which saw the first planting of grapes in the 1830s after George Yount settled the area. Until then, the dust and fog-filled valley some 50 miles north of San Francisco had been inhabited only by Wappo Indians. In 1858, a German named Charles Krug began a Napa Valley wine business, using native Mission grapes. German varieties were soon thriving in the area, along with vintners such as Frederick Beringer and Jacob Schram. The German-born founders were ``Anglo-Saxons with Mediterranean delusions, if truth be told,'' Conaway writes. Interest in wines of the region increased during the 1880s and '90s, when Inglenook was built at the height of a silver mining boom along the Silverado Trail. Prohibition, the Depression and World War II put a cork in the winery business. Some, however, survived. Newcomers such as the Christian Brothers, the Louis Martini family and the Mondavi family even prospered. At that time, the Italian vintners ``didn't care as much for quality in wine as for quantity; their product was sold in jugs,'' Conaway writes. During the early '50s and '60s, interest in Napa Valley was rekindled, with speciality wineries starting up and decrepit properties being renovated. The leaders of the latest renaissance included ``refugees from business, academia and totalitarianism, and some colorful misfits.'' By the mid-'70s, when Northern California wines started beating French wines in taste tests, Napa Valley's boom was on. Every winery had a tasting room and tourists, many on bicycles, began traveling valley road en masse. Enter politics. In the last few chapters of ``Napa,'' Conaway's historical narrative turns into a cautionary tale about the dangers of overdevelopment; about 250 wineries now crowd Napa Valley and nearby Sonoma Valley, compared with just a few dozen 30 years ago. And a touristy railroad - the Wine Train - runs through the area. ``Some would seek to turn the land into tourist attractions,'' with the valley taking on ``a gloss that had more to do with money than with the product for which it became famous,'' Conaway writes. In 1988, Napa County supervisors approved an ordinance that requires wines from Napa Valley to be made with at least 75 percent valley grapes. Now, the county is grappling with how much growth to allow, with grape growers urging preservation as vintners push expansion. ``I think the future is undetermined at this point,'' Conaway said in an interview. ``I see Napa as a kind of agricultural Yosemite that doesn't need too much government protection, but it should be allowed to endure.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
