DOC.TEXT: Factory orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods fell 1.7 percent in September, the government said. Analysts said the report foretells a further production and employment slump in the industrial sector, which already has lost 500,000 jobs since January. The Commerce Department Wednesday said orders for durable goods - items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $124.9 billion last month. --- GENEVA (AP) - The United States offered drastic across-the-board tariff cuts in trade liberalization talks and called on other negotiators to reciprocate. The chief U.S. delegate, Warren Lavorel, told a committee meeting Wednesday that the offer, if fully implemented, would represent a reduction of 43 percent in the average trade-weighted tariff. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The parent of Financial News Network and United Press International announced a management shakeup and disclosed financial problems that could result in the sale of its businesses. Infotechnology Inc. on Wednesday named Alan Hirschfield and Allan Tessler interim co-chief executives. The company also confirmed it is under investigation by the government but declined to say why. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, the first member of President Bush's Cabinet to resign, said she was leaving for new challenges and not because of ``totally erroneous'' reports she lacked influence at the White House. Mrs. Dole, the highest-ranking woman in the Bush administration, said Wednesday that after 25 years of government service, she was looking forward to focusing on humanitarian causes at her new job as president of the American Red Cross. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate failed to override President Bush's veto of a major civil rights bill, sustaining his objection that the measure would lead to hiring quotas. The 66-34 vote Wednesday was one shy of the two-thirds majority needed to enact the bill, and marked the 16th time Bush has made a veto stick without a single reversal. --- DETROIT (AP) - Mid-October sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 11.3 percent over the same period last year, when the sales rate began tumbling, automakers said. The boost announced Wednesday was fueled by an 11.6 percent rise in car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., one of the biggest year-to-year jumps of 1990. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner announced new standards to protect car occupants during side-impact collisions, saying the regulation would prevent 500 deaths a year. The action Wednesday ends more than a decade of haggling over how manufacturers should reinforce cars to help riders withstand side collisions. More people die that way than in any other kind of automobile wreck except frontal collisions. --- DALLAS (AP) - Southland Corp., owner of the 7-Eleven chain that pioneered convenience store shopping, was driven into bankruptcy by a $4.9 billion debt-financed takeover and tough competition. The Chapter 11 federal bankruptcy filing Wednesday ended months of negotiations with creditors. The company could not persuade enough creditors to go along with a refinancing that would have paid them pennies on the dollar for their $1.8 billion in bonds and given them 25 percent of the restructured company. --- NEW YORK (AP) - High jet fuel costs are accelerating the cutbacks and asset sales now reshaping the nation's airlines, and the industry that emerges may disappoint many travelers. ``We probably will see some constriction of the air service available to the American public unless we see fuel prices fall,'' Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association of America, said Wednesday. --- HOUSTON (AP) - Continental Airlines' board of directors briefly considered filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, but decided instead to seek other ways to return to financial health, a spokesman said. Unidentified sources quoted in Wednesday's editions of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal said a team of lawyers worked through the weekend to prepare Chapter 11 papers to be filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court after a board meeting on Monday. Continental responded to the reports by issuing a statement Wednesday saying it had no plans to file for protection from creditors. ---

Stock prices drifted higher Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had slipped 26.73 points Monday and Tuesday, rose 10.15 to 2,504.21. Concern over the U.S. economy and haggling over the federal budget sent the dollar down sharply. Gold prices rose. Corn and and wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade were also up, but soybean futures fell slightly. Crude oil rebounded sharply on the futures market to move back above $30 per barrel as traders placed less faith in speculation that peace was likely in the Persian Gulf. Government bond prices rose slightly.

DOC.HEAD: High Fuel Costs Could Reshape Ailing Airline Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: High jet fuel costs are accelerating the cutbacks and asset sales now reshaping the nation's airlines, and the industry that emerges may disappoint many travelers. ``We probably will see some constriction of the air service available to the American public unless we see fuel prices fall,'' Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association of America, said Wednesday. Sustained jet fuel prices at $1.25 per gallon or more would ``require the total restructuring of an industry,'' Aaronson said at a news briefing. In that scenario, service could be cut back in smaller markets and fewer flights in general could make it harder for business travelers to plan same-day roundtrips to many destinations. Many business people would end up staying out of town overnight for lack of connecting flights. Discount fares also could become scarce. Such gloomy forecasts are circulating as the high price of oil has combined with sluggish demand for travel to deal a double blow to an industry that has announced the elimination of some 10,000 jobs since the invasion. Some carriers are cutting passenger capacity and selling off important routes as they try to shrink to sizes where they can be profitable. In one of the biggest developments so far, struggling Pan Am Corp. agreed Tuesday to sell most of its prized London routes to a healthier competitor, UAL Corp., for $400 million. ``The rising fuel cost is a catalyst for these asset transfers,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. ``There's a whole series of asset transfers taking place from the weak carriers to the strong carriers.'' Future shakeups in the industry could be similarly speeded up, experts said. In addition to United, analysts said the strong airlines that stand to gain from the industry shakeup are American and Delta. Likely losers besides Pan Am include Eastern, Continental, Midway and USAir. In another example of the industry's troubles, Continental Airlines said Wednesday it had considered filing for reorganization in bankruptcy court recently but opted instead to try unspecified alternative strategies for restoring the company's financial health. Aaronson said Continental's troubles ``could just be an example of what other companies are wrestling with. There are a number of carriers that are worried.'' Jet fuel moved from about 60 cents a gallon before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 to more than $1.25 in recent weeks. It has since dipped below $1, but the airlines realize they can't count on lower prices in a market being driven by rumors about the fate of the Persian Gulf standoff. Aaronson predicted more layoffs are inevitable, even if fuel costs fall. Analysts have said the Gulf crisis is pushing the industry toward record losses in 1990, perhaps exceeding $1.5 billion. The crisis also has dimmed the outlook for next year. ``We probably would have seen a moderate loss in 1991,'' Aaronson said. ``It was looking like a week year. Now, it's devastating.''

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Wary of Loans With Environmental Risk After Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Normally, when one of the State Bank of Countryside's better customers wants to borrow money to buy some property, there's a pretty good chance the bank can arrange a loan. But when the suburban Chicago bank was asked recently to lend money to buy 40 acres of railroad property, the answer was: absolutely not. ``We never knew what was coming in on those railroad cars,'' said Thomas P. Boyle, Countryside's senior vice president for lending. ``So we backed away - even though they were a good customer.'' Boyle's anxiety over such a loan can be traced to a federal court ruling made four months ago in Atlanta. There, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in a Georgia case that lenders can be held liable for the costs of cleaning up properties that become contaminated by toxic materials. The decision, said Washington attorney J. Kent Holland Jr., ``turned things upside down.'' With their share of cleaning up hazardous chemical sites potentially costing lenders millions of dollars, bankers say they've quicky developed cold feet about lending money for anything with the slightest hint of environmental trouble. ``It's making everybody a little gun-shy about commercial loans,'' Boyle said. ``We are considering delaying all commercial lending until we get environmental statements,'' said St. Louis banker Walter C. Branneky, who, like Boyle, was among about 50 bankers who attended a discussion on environmental liability this week at the American Bankers Assocaition convention. ``Obviously, it will slow down lending,'' said Branneky, chairman of the St. Johns Bank & Trust Co. Holland, who specializes in environmental law, said the 11th Circuit found that Fleet Factors Corp. was liable as a secured creditor of the contaminated Swainsboro (Ga.) Print Works property, even though it was not involved in the handling of hazardous waste. The court said that Fleet's role in the financial management of the facility put it in a position where it had a ``capacity to influence'' waste management decisions, according to Holland. The 11th Circuit's decision has been appealed to the Supreme Court, Holland said. Holland said that in the wake of the court ruling, the House, the Senate and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency have launched separate efforts to limit secured creditors' liability in such cases. In his opinion, none of the measures would go far enough. Holand said the 11th Circuit acknowledged that its decision could discourage some investment. ``I would assume that's exactly what the reaction would be,'' he said. But the court also said it would encourage lenders to pay closer attention to where money goes. David J. Dybdahl, a Madison, Wis., insurance broker who specializes in environmental matters, said it is difficult for lenders to protect themselves from toxic liability. Most commercial liability policies contain pollution exemptions, he said. Dybdahl, managing director of Environmental Risk Management at Corroon & Black of Wisconsin Inc., said there are some steps lenders can take to prevent becoming entangled in an environmental problem, including a three-phase site audit. But such a process, which includes a review of regulatory files and collecting soil samples, could cost as much as $50,000. Some say bankers are overreacting to the court decision. A Charlotte, N.C., organization, the Southern Finance Project, studied lender liability and found that only seven lenders have actually had to pay the EPA for hazardous material damage since the ``Superfund'' clean-up program began in 1980. The SFP study also said that in most of the cases, the amount paid by lenders was negligible. Holland discounted the significance of that study, telling the bankers, ``You do have enemies out there.'' Dybdahl said an environmental liability claim could be financially disastrous. ``When you get an environmental claim it's not going to be for $500,'' Dybdahl said. ``It's a good idea to have a pre-set plan of what to do if something happens.''

DOC.HEAD: Scant Evidence, Juicy Stories and a Window on Drexel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: As tabloid entertainment, the mini-trial of Michael Milken has been short on bombshells and long on insinuation with a few salacious stories from Wall Street's trenches circa 1985. Paranoid Drexel Burnham Lambert junk-bond workers run water faucets to drown out conversations. Documents burn in a fireplace. Cryptic orders are barked out, possibly instructions to break the law. But the special hearing on unadmitted crimes by the former Drexel junk bond wizard has centered largely on the intricacies of preferred stock, equity kickers and leveraged buyouts. The hearing also has cracked a window on the most celebrated case of Wall Street crime in the 1980s, offering insight into Milken's work and raising questions about the government's heralded prosecution. Testimony finished Tuesday on the second of three alleged illegal transactions presented before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, who will use the information in sentencing Milken on his guilty plea to six felony counts. The government contends the unproven crimes reflect a pattern of lawbreaking by Milken that merits a long prison stay. The defense says Milken's crimes were isolated instances of going too far to help clients. After seven days of testimony by 14 government witnesses, prosecutors haven't overwhelmingly proven Milken guilty of the systematic skulduggery described in court papers. There has been occasional damaging testimony, a charge of violating Drexel policies and descriptions of questionable and possibly illegal behavior by Drexel underlings, but no smoking guns. Whether the signs of shady behavior by Milken constitute what prosecutors have described as ``a pattern of calculated fraud, deceit and corruption of the highest magnitude'' is for Wood to decide. But after four years, a dropped 98-count racketeering indictment and a case that relies on testimony by Milken associates who cut 11th-hour deals to avoid prosecution, Milken's team so far has been crowing. ``See, I told you, no bribery!'' a defense lawyer said after testimony finished on one of the allegations.
DOC.HEAD: Milken Bodyguards, Shopping Cart of Evidence
DOC.TEXT: It's been standing-room-only at Manhattan federal court, site of dozens of past big-name trials - Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, Alger Hiss, Leona Helmsley, Imelda Marcos. Seating is divided, as at a wedding. Milken's wife, Lori, mother, Fern, brother, Lowell, Lowell's wife, Sandy, and Lowell's lawyer, Michael Armstrong, occupy a front row. The opposite side is reserved for the U.S. Attorney's Office. About 100 reporters, lawyers, former Drexel workers and Milken friends strain to hear the proceedings in the ninth-floor courtroom over the air conditioner or howling wind. The witness microphone constantly slips down. Eight or more attorneys plus Milken ring the defense table, passing notes and sometimes smirking during government questioning. Young associates scurry to hand over documents and transcripts. Paralegals and Milken bodyguards stand near the defense prep room. By contrast, there are just four or five government lawyers and no retinue of aides. Lead prosecutor John Carroll himself usually wheels in a shopping cart brimming with materials.
DOC.HEAD: Rumpled Defense Lawyer vs. Textbook Prosecutors
DOC.TEXT: One sure way to gauge the mood of Milken's defense team is to watch Arthur Liman. The Yoda-faced lawyer with the unrelenting New York accent gained national attention for grilling Oliver North during the 1987 Iran-Contra hearings. Disheveled and ungainly, he jams his hands in the pockets of his buttoned jacket during questioning, tie hanging in the breach. While prosecutors Carroll and Jess Fardella elicit prepared testimony by reading a list of questions - sometimes typewritten - Liman works from notes scrawled on slips of yellow paper. When Wood rebuffs his objections - as she does frequently - Liman slumps in his chair and shakes his head. His line of questioning has caused the normally even-tempered judge to lose her patience. On days when Liman believes the defense has done well, he holds court with reporters, schmoozing about old times with newspaper columnist Murray Kempton or answering questions. Other days, Liman and associates leave hastily.
DOC.HEAD: A Trial But Not a Trial
DOC.TEXT: The hearing carries a lower burden of proof than at a trial, which may help the government. Evidence gathering is limited, another defense hurdle. Hearsay by witnesses is allowed. Wood has said she is using the proceeding to gain insight into Milken's professional character. She is unlikely to pronounce guilt or innocence on the three transactions. The hearing has offered a picture of life at Drexel as described by people who until now were faceless names in the government probe. With live evidence after four years of legal maneuvering, it is the first chance to assess what Milken did or didn't do, at least in a few instances. ``I think it's completely riveting,'' said magazine journalist Jesse Kornbluth, who is writing a book on Milken and the 1980s. ``Yes, I nod out from time to time. But for those who know what they're looking at, who know the context and the subtext, it's the best show in town.''
--- EDITOR'S NOTE: Stefan Fatsis has been covering the Milken case for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Software Firm's Call Disables Revlon
DOC.TEXT: A phone call was all it took to cripple Revlon Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of mass-market cosmetics, according to a lawsuit. A small software firm used high-tech guerrilla tactic to ``repossess'' its product from Revlon for non-payment, shutting down two of Revlon's four national distribution centers for three days. Revlon filed suit this week in Santa Clara County Superior Court against the company, Logisticon of Santa Clara. ``We didn't have any remedies left as a small company,'' said Donald Gallagher, president of Logisticon, which has annual sales of less than $20 million. Revlon, with annual sales of $3 billion, hired Logisticon last year to develop inventory control software for warehouses in Phoenix, Ariz., and Edison, N.J. Revlon claimed the software never worked properly, and on Oct. 9 notified Logisticon that it wanted to cancel its $1.2 million contract and would withhold further payments until the software worked. A week later, Logisticon took its own action in the middle of the night, using a phone link and computer access codes to disable all its software in Revlon computers. ``During this period, Revlon could not process inventory or sales orders and was unable to identify and distribute products in the marketplace,'' Revlon said in its lawsuit. Hundreds of Revlon workers were sent home. Gallagher sent Revlon a letter by fax a few hours after the shutdown, saying he was ``forced into using the only leverage available'' because Revlon was refusing to pay for software it had been using for several months. ``When and if an agreement is reached on the outstanding payments, the (software) systems can be restored in a few hours,'' Gallagher said in the letter. Revlon is seeking unspecified damages for the shutdown. ``When it became obvious that the unsuccessful relationship between Revlon and Logisticon had to end, Logisticon and Gallagher used their familiarity with Revlon's computer system to commit . . . extortionate acts,'' the suit says. Revlon wasn't able to resume operations until Logisticon - under some pressure, Gallagher said Tuesday - restored its software on Oct. 19. Gallagher described the termination as a ``repossession'' of Logisticon software and denied allegations that his company destroyed any Revlon data in the process. ``The substance of this dispute is that a giant corporation, Revlon, wrongfully is utilizing software prepared by a very small company, Logisticon, and refusing to pay amounts which are rightfully owed,'' Logisticon said in a memo filed Monday in Superior Court. A spokesman for Revlon at its New York headquarters said the shutdown would not cause any shortage of its products on store shelves. A hearing has been set for Nov. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Price Jump May Be Causing Shift From Trucks to Cars
DOC.TEXT: A 15.4 percent rise in mid-October sales of North American-built autos may indicate the beginning of a shift from light trucks to more fuel-efficient cars, analysts say. The 10 major companies making cars and light trucks in the United States on Wednesday reported a 4.3 percent increase in truck sales, pushing total vehicle sales up 11.3 percent. ``I think car sales may be benefiting from a shift in mix away from trucks and toward cars,'' said auto analyst David Healy of investment banker Barclays de Zoete Wedd of New York City. ``It's the only response I can detect to the higher gasoline prices.'' Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, and the accompanying rocketing of gasoline prices, automakers have said they weren't seeing a shift from large, gas-gulping cars to smaller, more fuel-efficient cars as they saw in the oil crises of the 1970s. In the '80s, the popularity of trucks, including compact pickups, minivans and sport-utility vehicles, soared. But trucks typically aren't as economical as cars and now, analysts say, the lure of trucks may be waning. ``I kind of have a suspicion that the guy who has been buying a truck as his primary personal transportation vehicle is opting out of that vehicle and moving back to a passenger car,'' auto analyst Joseph Pillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers said Wednesday. He said another factor may be that cars bought in the boom years of the mid-1980s are getting old, have been paid for and are prime for replacement. ``They are starting to age out and reach their appointed hour for trade-in time,'' Pillippi said. The 10 major U.S. automakers said their cars and trucks sold at an average daily rate of 31,328 during Oct. 11-20, compared with 28,156 in mid-October 1989. Car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., rose 11.6 percent, one of the biggest year-to-year jumps of 1990. Sales of cars made in Japanese automakers' U.S. plants rose 42.2 percent. The Big Three held 84.8 percent of the domestically produced car market during the period. The mid-October sales rate last year was depressed because consumers who planned to buy cars in the last three months of the year purchased their cars in September to take advantage of incentives that expired Oct. 1. With only a few exceptions, domestic car and truck sales this year have been lower than in 1989. Through Oct. 20, sales fell 4.2 percent from 1989. Car sales for the year fell 4.6 percent and truck sales dropped 3.5 percent. GM's mid-October car sales rose 15.1 percent from 1989, and truck sales rose 7.5 percent, combining for a 12.4 percent increase in vehicle sales. Through Oct. 20, GM's car and truck sales were 4.6 percent lower than in 1989. Ford's 9.3 percent increase in car sales combined with an 11.4 percent rise in truck sales for a 10.1 percent increase in vehicle sales during the period. For the year, Ford's car and truck sales were 8.6 percent behind 1989. Chrysler's mid-October vehicle sales rate was 6.7 percent below 1989 with a 5.6 percent increase in car sales offset by an 18.7 percent decline in truck sales. Since Jan. 1, Chrysler's car and truck sales have fallen 14.3 percent from 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Winnebago Goes to 4-Day Week, More Layoffs Planned
DOC.TEXT: An economic slowdown aggravated by a Persian Gulf oil shock has walloped Winnebago Industries Inc., and the pain felt by the manufacturer of motor homes is being shared by its neighbors. When Winnebago is in trouble, so is its home town of Forest City, says Paul Jefson, mayor of the north central Iowa community. Before layoffs began in late September, the company had a work force of about 2,600 in the community of around 4,300. As problems began surfacing at Winnebago earlier this year the city anticipated its tax revenues would drop off. ``It's important that we live within the means of the city. It will affect us,'' Jefson said Wednesday. That means no new elaborate plans for public works, although a sewer project will proceed as scheduled, he said. The problems will get worse later this week, when Winnebago announces an austerity plan. The company already has laid off hundreds of workers and gone to a four-day work week at its factories. The new retrenchment will mean layoffs for white-collar workers, said Winnebago spokeswoman Sheila Davis. Jefson says a community meeting is set for Monday night to establish a task force to help Winnebago employees. An industry analyst said Winnebago appears to be taking the right steps to return to profitability once the gasoline price outlook and the nation's economic prospects brighten. Analyst Michael Sabbann, who follows the recreational vehicle industry for the Minneapolis investment firm of Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, also said Winnebago is not alone and that other manufacturers are in a bind. A Commerce Department report Wednesday said orders to U.S. factories of durable goods, items such as appliances and vehicles designed to last three years or more, fell 1.7 percent in September. Transportation orders plummeted 6.8 percent. Winnebago, with products that sell for around $27,000 and up, was hurting before Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and sent oil prices soaring. It has been stung by high interest rates and an unsettled economic climate that sapped consumer confidence Winnebago has reported five straight quarterly losses and had a record $17.8 million loss in the fiscal year that ended Aug. 25 as sales fell 23 percent from the previous year. In May, directors suspended semiannual dividends to shareholders. In late September, Winnebago began layoffs and temporary factory shutdowns. Earlier this month, it began offering rebates to new buyers, guaranteeing to reimburse gasoline expenses above $1 a gallon for the first 12 months or 12,000 miles of ownership, whichever came first. Ms. Davis said that the rebates have not led to any noticeable increase in sales. ``It's a little too early to tell'' about the success of the program, she said. She said the company's flagship factory in Forest City and smaller plants at Hampton and Lorimor have been on Monday-to-Thursday schedules since last week, with 1,000 production workers idle each Friday. The four-day week will continue indefinitely, she said. An additional 500 workers were laid off since the end of September with no plans to recall them. Later this week, an austerity program will be announced that will include layoffs among the ranks of some 800 office workers, supervisors and executives, she said. ``Unfortunately, those are the things that have to be done,'' Sabbann said. ``The whole industry cycle has turned against them.'' But Sabbann said Winnebago is in a good position to regain ground once the economy improves. He noted the company's claim to more than 60 percent of the market in sales of micro-mini motor homes, a more fuel-efficient recreational vehicle that has taken a growing share of the RV business. Robert Rollefson, a broker at the Forest City office of the investment firm R.G. Dickinson & Co. and veteran Winnebago watcher, said the company is faced with its most serious challenge since the early 1970s. That's when an Arab oil embargo and the first oil price shock left the company with acres of unsold motor homes. Winnebago is in better financial shape today, but ``the outlook now and the outlook then may be about the same,'' he said. The mood in town ``is certainly not one of joy. There's a certain amount of despair and sadness,'' Rollefson said. But after the initial shock, ``people will tell you - `sure, it will get better.'''

DOC.HEAD: Infotech May Sell Businesses; Confirms SEC Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Infotechnology Inc., the parent of Financial News Network and United Press International, has named two new top executives to look at ways to raise cash, including the possible sale of its businesses. As interim co-chief executives, Alan Hirschfield and Allan Tessler will restructure the company to ``address FNN's and Infotech's financial problems.'' Cash flow at Infotechnology and FNN does not cover operating expenses or some debts, Infotechnology said in a statement. ``We will be considering all available options to provide funding needed to meet obligations and maintain and realize the value of the FNN franchise and of Infotech's other investments,'' Hirschfield and Tessler said in a statement Wednesday. ``We believe that the fundamental franchise value of the FNN service is substantial and should provide a basis for restructuring and-or disposition of businesses that will enable the companies to meet their obligations and move forward,'' they said. Infotechnology said it is renegotiating $20.7 million in loans for itself as well as $49.5 million in loans to FNN. In addition, both are trying to reschedule lease payments for $161 million worth of equipment. Hirschfield and Tessler have been involved in several business restructurings, Infotechnology said. Hirschfield is a former chief executive of both Twentieth Century Fox and Columbia Pictures; Tessler presently is chairman of International Financial Group Inc., Ameriscribe Inc. and International Controls Corp. The two replace Earl Brian, who had been chief executive and who will continue as ``non-executive chairman'' of both the FNN and Infotechnology boards. On Monday, Infotechnology disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the SEC had ``issued a formal order of investigation with respect to the company'' under federal securities laws. Infotechnology spokeswoman Amber Gordon declined to say why the company was under investigation, but said it was cooperating. The SEC, which polices the nation's securities markets, does not comment on any investigations as a matter of policy. Gordon said the investigation was unrelated to FNN's dismissal earlier this month of C. Steven Bolen, its chief financial officer fired for improper financial dealings. FNN's auditors, Deloitte & Touche, also were dismissed. At issue with the accounting firm was how FNN was reporting its $28 million investment in a new service. Deloitte contended the investment should have been deducted from quarterly earnings - which would have put FNN in the red - rather than spread out over a period of years. Because of the dispute, FNN has been unable to file its annual financial reports with the SEC for the fiscal year ended June 30. In addition, Deloitte withdrew its opinions on FNN's and Infotech's 1989 financial statements. Infotechnology and FNN since have hired Coopers & Lybrand. Infotechnology owns 47 percent of FNN, which provides 24-hour stock quotes, business news and sports information on 3,500 cable television systems that reach more than 35 million homes. Infotechnology also owns 97 percent of United Press International, the wire service.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Sets Side-Impact Crash Protection Rule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government is ordering the automobile industry to make cars less deadly in side crashes, which kill 8,000 people and seriously injure 24,000 others each year. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration issued the complex regulation Wednesday, ending a debate among the industry, safety advocates and bureaucrats that dragged on for a dozen years. ``It's been a long time coming,'' Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said. The regulation is designed to prevent 500 deaths annually. The protections it requires would lessen the severity of chest and pelvic injuries. Rules to protect against head injuries are being developed but won't be ready for two or three years, said Jerry R. Curry, head of the traffic safety agency. Also on the drawing board are standards for light trucks and vans. The new regulation drew acceptance from the industry and cautious praise from safety advocates. ``We expect to comply fully with it,'' said Toni Simonetti, spokeswoman for General Motors Corp. The nation's largest automaker fought NHTSA as the rule developed, contending the dummy used in crash tests was faulty. The agency rejected GM's plea to switch to a dummy the company designed. Even so, GM became more supportive after a meeting last January between Curry and Robert Stempel, then-president of the company and its current chairman. Chrysler Corp. considers the regulation ``a positive step in the area of auto safety,'' spokesman John Guiniven said. ``We know from our own figures that safety sells.'' Ford Motor Co. spokesman Robert H. Munson said complying with the rule ``in some cases may necessitate significant re-engineering of our product lines.'' The regulation may increase car weight and make it harder to improve gasoline mileage, Munson said. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and Advocates for Highway Auto Safety said the regulation was ``a long-overdue first step.'' But they said it would be incomplete until head-injury protections were added. The changes will boost the average car's cost by about $50, ``a small price to pay for the prevention of the immense loss of life and suffering as a result of these side impacts,'' Skinner said. Manufacturers can choose between two timetables for phasing in cars that meet the standards. Either way, all new cars must comply by the 1997 model year. Most probably will add padding or structural strength to doors, and some might do both, Curry said. The government will use simulated crash tests to determine which cars meet the standards. The tests will expose cars and passenger dummies to conditions in the typical side collision, in which a car traveling 30 miles per hour at an intersection slams into the side of another car going 15 mph. As many as one-third of today's cars already meet the new standards, said Barry Felrice, the safety administration's associate administrator for rulemaking. He estimated that 75 percent of the remaining cars would need only door padding to comply.

DOC.HEAD: Report That TWA Offers to Buy Eastern Gates in Atlanta, Base in Miami
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. has offered to buy more than 50 Eastern Airlines gates in Atlanta and Eastern's aircraft overhaul base in Miami, TWA Chairman Carl Icahn said in a published report. Icahn would not disclose the value of the offer, which was presented to Eastern's creditors late Wednesday at TWA headquarters in Mount Kisco, N.Y., The Kansas City Star reported today. Icahn told The Star that TWA, which lost $300 million last year and which has been eliminating flights and employees, has about $1 billion in reserves for such a purchase. The offer doesn't involve planes at the Atlanta hub, the primary flight operation of Eastern, which has been in bankruptcy proceedings for 19 months, Icahn told the newspaper in a telephone interview from New York. ``If this goes through, we'd negotiate separately with Eastern creditors for 100 planes,'' Icahn said. ``We might buy planes elsewhere.'' Icahn said Eastern's creditors solicited the offer. He said there is no deadline on the offer. Eastern, based in Miami, has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization since March 1989 after Machinists went on strike. The carrier was still losing $2 million a day in its most recent quarterly report during the summer. Morten Beyer, chairman of aviation consultant Avmark Inc., estimated Eastern's Atlanta operation, including planes, is worth more than $1 billion. He said that even though TWA was ``losing money at the operational level, they have the financial wherewithal to do this, and the credit.'' Icahn said Tuesday that Eastern's north-south routes would provide a ``fair amount of synergy'' with TWA's east-west service based in St. Louis. He said although TWA is cutting back in some areas, the right kind of growth is crucial for the airline. ``If we can't grow, we can't survive,'' he said. On Wednesday, Martin Shugrue, Eastern's bankruptcy trustee, said American Airlines, America West, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and USAir also have expressed interest in buying certain Eastern assets. He said Northwest Airlines, Pan Am and TWA have had discussions with Eastern, and Delta has confirmed interest in buying 19 Eastern gates in Atlanta. Shugrue also said that Eastern's push to get more business travelers could help the carrier break even by February. Dean Breest, a spokesman for Delta Air Lines, said Delta had told Eastern it was interested in acquiring some Eastern gates and ticket counter space in Atlanta, where Delta is the dominant carrier and Eastern is No. 2.

The stock market showed a modest gain today, encouraged by hopes for a resolution of the impasse over the federal budget deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.67 to 2,511.88 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 557 up, 319 down and 460 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.10 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. That would stand to relieve an uncertainty that has been hanging over the markets for the past month. Analysts agree that the Federal Reserve can't be expected to consider any move to relax its credit policy until the budget situation is resolved. DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Mitsubishi to Build New Car at Diamond-Star
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan will build a new series of cars at their jointly owned Diamond-Star Motors Corp. plant in Illinois, the companies said today. The companies said in a joint statement that no decisions have been made on when production of the new cars would begin or whether they would replace current vehicles. The Diamond-Star plant now makes the Mitsubishi Eclipse and Mirage for the Japanese company and the Plymouth Laser, Eagle Talon and Eagle Summit for Chrysler. U.S. companies make about 60 percent of the parts for those cars. The joint venture, ownership of which is split evenly between Mitsubishi and Chrysler, has been making cars since Sept. 1, 1988. Currently, Chrysler gets about 55 percent of Diamond-Star's production and Mitsubishi gets the rest. The companies said distribution of the new vehicles would be split evenly between Chrysler and Mitsubishi. The new generation of cars, the companies said today, would include two- and three-door sporty cars and a four-door sedan. Details of the vehicles were not released. Chrysler spokeswoman Karen Stewart said the new cars would have significantly more U.S.-made parts than the current vehicles.

The stock plunged 8~ Wednesday before Matsushita Electric denied reports that merger talks between the two companCrude's soaring prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August have been rooted in war psychology, as the world has maintained an adequate oil supply despite the global embargo or Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. ``It's not clear whether we are back in a fundamental market or if we need to keep a weather eye out for psychological changes,'' said oil analyst Peter Beutel of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. As oil moved up today, so did futures contracts for refined petroleum products and natural gas. DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs New Food Labeling; Fish Inspection Sidetracked
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf, During debate . . . to CORRECT by removing the word ``not''. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving quickly to assure that consumers learn more from nutrition labels about what they eat, but another food issue - fish inspection - is falling victim to a turf battle. The Senate on Wednesday approved a ill on requiring food manufacturers to list on their labels the amount of nutrients, calories, fat and salt for most packaged foods. Claims like ``low salt'' and ``light'' would be clearly defined, and disease-prevention claims would have to be government-approved. The bill, passed by unanimous consent, now goes back to the House, which passed a similar version in late July and was expected to accept the Senate's changes. ``Labeling will guarantee that advertising claims are supported by the facts, and that consumers have the information they need to make wiser choices about their health and diet,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The Bush administration in mid-July proposed food-labeling regulations that are similar to the provisions in the egislation and therefore opposed the bill. However, it did not threaten a veto. ``The Food and Drug Administration has been saying for years that it will revamp food labels in this country,'' said Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, who lobbied for the bill. ``This legislation will see to it that FDA follows through with its commitment.'' The House, meanwhile, virtually eliminated any chance of federal fish inspection becoming law this year by approving a bill that differs sharply with companion legislation passed by the Senate giving the Agriculture Department the inspection responsibility. By 277-153, the House approved a bill pushed by the Energy and Commerce and Merchant Marine and Fisheries committees assigning the task to the FDA, which already has a limited fish-inspection program. During debate, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, held up a letter from Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and White House chief of staff John Sununu saying they would recommend a veto by President Bush if the Senate plan was adopted. ``We don't have time for a conference'' in the waning days of the 101st Congress to resolve the differences, said Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, who tried unsuccessfully to win House approval of a measure similar to the Senate's. No one questioned the need for inspection. With seafood consumption up and about 60,000 people becoming ill annually from eating fish, even the industry wanted it. ``The issue is not whether we want to inspect seafood,'' said Rep. Billy Tauzin, D-La. ``The issue is whether you want the Agriculture Committee, which may not understand the difference between a chicken and a crawfish, to undertake that effort.'' The Senate legislation, approved last month, gives the Agriculture Department primary responsibility by putting the inspection process under its wing. The department already inspects meat and poultry. The Senate bill requires the FDA to set limits on the level of contamination in fish that would be acceptable for human consumption. It instructs the Commerce Department to monitor the waters in which fish are caught.

DOC.HEAD: Auctions Resume
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with results of short-term auction results.
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department sold $17.2 billion of three-month and six-month bills at an auction today and rescheduled a previously postponed sale of $10.0 billion of 52-week bills for Friday. Both auctions had been postponed because of congressional failure to raise the debt limit, but were rescheduled earlier today shortly after President Bush signed legislation raising the debt limit to $3.195 trillion through Saturday. The department said it had sold $8.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.20 percent, up from 7.18 percent last week. Another $8.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.16 percent, down from 7.22 percent last week. The three-month rate was the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.32 percent on last Sept. 24. The six-month rate was the lowest since six-month bills averaged 7.15 percent on Aug. 1, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.44 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,818.00 and 7.53 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,638.00. The two auctions were put off after the debt ceiling reverted to $3.12 trillion last Saturday. The federal debt already had exceeded that amount. However, to keep within the $3.195 trillion limit, the Treasury said the amount of the rescheduled three-month and six-month bills, usually offered on Mondays, was lowered from $19.2 billion. The 52-week bill offering, which had been scheduled for Oct. 18, was reduced from $10.8 billion. The administration has asked Congress to raise the ceiling. Another postponed auction, a $12 billion 2-year note offering set for Wednesday, has not been rescheduled.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Will Hold Formal Meeting on Dec. 12 in Vienna
DOC.TEXT: OPEC President Sadek Boussena said Thursday the cartel will hold a formal meeting on Dec. 12 in Vienna to discuss the oil markets, which have been thrown into disarray by the Persian Gulf crisis. But Boussena said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was doing as much as it can to pump extra oil into the markets to make up for the loss of some 4 million barrels of embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. He told a news conference that the cartel was producing at its maximum and ``sometimes to the detriment'' of the oilfields. He did not elaborate. Boussena, who is the Algerian mines minister, didn't say how much the cartel was pumping but he said it was under the production level of 22.5 million barrels a day set last July. Analysts have estimated September output at 22.3 million barrels a day. He said OPEC would likely not be able to meet demand for its oil in mid-winter, predicting a gap of 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day between supply and demand. Oil companies would have to draw down their stocks to meet the demand, he said. After Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the cartel suspended its quota system to allow its members to pump as much oil as possible to make up the shortfall in the market. The embargo on Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil was imposed after the invasion. Boussena said the oil producing nations would return to their quota system once the Gulf crisis ended. He made his remarks after attending an energy seminar sponsored by the Belgian government.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Earnings Drop 14.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Thursday reported a 14.8 percent drop in third-quarter earnings partly because of a weak performance by the company's insurance and financial services businesses. For the period ended Sept. 30, profits totaled $132 million, or $1.16 per share, on revenue of $4.5 billion. That compared with earnings of $155 million, or $1.41 per share, on revenue of $4.4 billion in the same 1989 period. Income from continuing operations in Xerox's insurance and other financial services fell 98 percent, to $1 million from 1989's $50 million. Pretax capital gains totaled $4 million in the third quarter, compared with $207 million in the corresponding 1989 quarter. ``Given the adverse forces in our markets, including both the weak pricing environment in the property and casualty insurance industry and the turmoil in financial markets, it is important to note that our results were essentially in line with the second quarter of this year,'' said Stuart B. Ross, Xerox executive vice president and chairman and chief executive of Xerox Financial Services Inc. Income dropped 64.5 percent from Crum and Forster's property and casualty and life insurance operations, falling to $27 million in the third quarter from $76 million last year. Earnings from document processing, Xerox's core business, increased 26 percent to $131 million in the third quarter, compared with $105 million in the third quarter last year. While demand for business equipment was soft in the quarter, revenue increased from rentals, service and the financing of equipment sales, said Paul A. Allaire, Xerox president and chief executive officer. Revenue from document processing increased to $3.3 billion in the third quarter from $3 billion for the same quarter last year. For the first nine months, income from continuing operations fell 22 percent, to $383 million, or $3.38 per share, on revenue of $13.3 billion. That compared with $492 million, or $4.55 per share, on revenue of $13 billion for the same 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Moves Up Sharply Amid New War Jitters
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout to UPDATE prices.
DOC.TEXT: Oil shot up more than $3 per barrel on the futures market today, as speculators bet on war in the Persian Gulf. ``We've got all sorts of little talk in the market of troops being increased in the Middle East on our side and on Iraq's side,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Once again, the market is worried about confrontation.'' Light sweet crude oil jumped $3.02 to $34.10 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange shortly after noon. January and February delivery contracts were up $2 per barrel and later months were all up by more than $1. Today's early trading was a continuation of crude's rise of $1.71 per barrel on Wednesday. That upward surge halted a sharp slide that had knocked oil from above $40 per barrel to less than $30 as traders responded to hints of a peaceful resolution to the Gulf crisis. Traders now think they overestimated the potential for a negotiated settlement. They have begun wondering whether crude will move back into the $40 range or fluctuate in the $30 range. Crude's soaring prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August have been rooted in war psychology, as the world has maintained an adequate oil supply despite the global embargo or Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. ``It's not clear whether we are back in a fundamental market or if we need to keep a weather eye out for psychological changes,'' said oil analyst Peter Beutel of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. As oil moved up today, so did futures contracts for refined petroleum products and natural gas. Unleaded gasoline was up 7.81 cents to 93.20 cents per gallon on November delivery contracts, with all other contract months trading higher. Home heating oil was up 6.88 cents to 92.00 cents per gallon on November contracts, with all later delivery months trading higher. Natural gas was up 3 cents to $2.47 per 1,000 cubic feet on Deember delivery contracts. Most other delivery months were trading higher.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Earnings Up 13.4 Percent for its First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Sara Lee Corp. said Thursday a strong showing from its international operations helped lift its first-quarter profit by 13.4 percent compared with a year earlier. The consumer products and foods company earned $106.3 million, or 42 cents a share, for the quarter ending Sept. 29, up from $93.8 million, or 38 cents per share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter were $3.1 billion, up 11.6 percent over $2.7 billion a year ago this quarter. ``We achieved good sales and earnings growth in our personal products businesses and particularly strong results from our international operations - coffee and grocery and household and personal care,'' Chairman John Bryan said in a news release. ``Profits continue to be somewhat soft in our packaged meats and bakery business,'' Bryan said. Sara Lee is an international food and consumer products company that markets under a variety of brand names, including Hanes, L'eggs, Jimmy Dean and Sara Lee.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Stock Trades Wildly After Report that Takeover Talks Are Going Slowly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 7 new grafs to UPDATE with stock rising sharply today, LA Times report. Picks up 5th graf: It said...
DOC.TEXT: The price of MCA Inc. stock shot higher today on the New York Stock Exchange, one day after gyrating wildly on a report that a big Japanese company was in no rush to acquire the company. Trading in MCA shares on the exchange was halted twice Wednesday after the Nikkei News agency reported Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. wants a ``cool-off period'' in buyout talks. But a top Matsushita official later called that erroneous, as did news reports today. ``If anything, the indications are exactly the opposite. Things have been going very well,'' a person familiar with the deal told the Los Angeles Times. The Wall Street Journal quoted individuals close to the discussions as saying the talks are firmly on track and could lead to an agreement as early as November. By midday today, MCA stock had gained back nearly all its losses of Wednesday, shooting up $6.37{ per share to $56.37{. Today's news reports did not identify anyone by name. But the Journal said people familiar with both companies were particularly eager to dispel any notion that the merger talks were troubled. It said that several sticking points have already been resolved, including a plan to divest MCA's New York-area television station, WWOR, which cannot be foreign-owned. A buyout of MCA, the parent of Universal Studios, could be worth as much as $8.6 billion, according to reports. The Nikkei News report said talks with MCA officials won't resume until mid-November, and quoted a senior Matsushita executive as saying if the two sides can't agree on a price then, ``we are prepared to pull out of the deal.'' The report sent MCA's stock down as low as $48 a share from Tuesday's close of $58.86 before exchange officials stopped trading in the early afternoon. Trading was resumed, only to be halted again after Matsushita's denial of the report prompted an excess of buy orders. MCA finished the day at $50 a share, down $8.87{. ``Discussions with MCA Inc. are proceeding in an orderly fashion and there are no new developments to announce,'' Matsushita Executive Vice President Masihiko Hirata said. An MCA spokeswoman, Chris Hanson, said the company would have no comment. The Nikkei News report, which didn't identify sources by name, said Matsushita wants to let MCA's share price, which climbed above $63 since the deal was reported in late September, ``run out of steam before negotiating a price tag for MCA again.'' ``MCA's asking price is still considerably higher than Matsushita is hoping to pay,'' the Nikkei story reported. ``During the cool-off period, Matsushita is planning to reassess the market value of MCA in an effort to come up with a new price for the American group, company officials say.'' The report also said that Matsushita wants more time to look into how MCA's broadcasting division can be separated from the other operations to comply with federal law that prohibits foreign concerns from owning U.S. television and radio stations. The report closely followed word of another potential problem for the deal: National Park Service Director James Ridenour's suggestion that MCA sell a subsidiary that provides food and lodging at Yosemite National Park because park lovers were concerned about it falling into foreign hands. Another difficulty posed by the proposed takeover is how to structure the deal so that large MCA shareholders such as Chairman Lew Wasserman and Geffen Entertainment chief David Geffen can avoid paying taxes on their gains.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
American Moves To Block UAL's Purchase Of Pan Am's London Operations
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc. moved today to block rival UAL Corp.'s $400 million purchase of Pan Am Corp.'s London routes. In a letter to Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett, American Chairman Robert Crandall said his company wanted to bid on the routes, and suggested government regulators might not approve the UAL-Pan Am deal. ``As I have told you many times in the past, most recently in our telephone conversation of Monday, Oct. 22, we have for some time been interested in acquiring a number of Pan Am's international route authorities, including those to the United Kingdom,'' Crandall said in the letter, released publicly. The agreement with UAL, parent of United Airlines, was announced Tuesday night. Officials at New York-based Pan Am and Chicago-based UAL had no immediate comment. ``We believe that the fiduciary duties owed by you and your fellow directors to maximize value for Pan Am's stockholders and creditors dictate that you afford us an opportunity to make a competing offer for these assets,'' Crandall said. Crandall said American could pursue ``a transaction superior to the proposed United transaction,'' but he offered no specifics. Pan Am has suffered big losses in recent years, and the deal with UAL came after fruitless efforts Pan Am to find a merger partner or buyer for the airline. The deal, which would give United a gateway to Europe through London, is the carrier's second victory over American in recent months. Shortly after reclaiming the No. 1 domestic market share from American, United beat out American for government approval of Chicago-Tokyo routes. Under the agreement, UAL would acquire Pan Am's U.S.-London routes, except for those leaving from Miami and Detroit. UAL's routes into London will leave from New York, Washington, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Seattle. UAL will also get unused Pan Am international routes originating in San Francisco, Washington and London. The deal also provides for UAL to buy gates, hangar and office space at San Francisco and Washington's Dulles International airport, two Boeing 747 jumbo jets and spare parts. The London routes currently bring about $500 million in gross revenues. Earlier today, the Teamsters Airline Division also stated its opposition to the Pan Am-UAL deal, saying Pan Am should have gotten more money for the London routes. The union, which represents 6,500 Pan Am workers, said it planned to file a lawsuit challenging the sale. ``Pan Am should have gotten $750 million to $1 billion in order to pay off its obligations to the workers,'' said William F. Genoese, director of the Teamsters Airline Division. ``The deal announced by Pan Am would hurt our members. No arrangements have been made to protect the workers.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower on London's Stock Exchange Thursday after a late afternoon computer-generated sell program and a setback on Wall Street. However, dealers said trading was light with scant two-way trading because of continued uncertainty over the Middle East, broadly fluctuating oil prices, and negotiations to reduce the U.S. budget deficit. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 21.8 points, or 1 percent, at 2,088.7. Financial Times 30-share index was down 21.4 points at 1,617.5 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 11.83 points to close at 1,114.06. Volume was a light 323 million shares, compared with 467.5 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 225,873 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 206,579, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 219,390 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 147,513 cars this week, compared with 130,305 a week ago and 146,148 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 78,360, compared with last week's 76,274 and last year's 73,242. Canadian automakers were to build 25,950 cars this week, up from 21,134 a week ago and from last year's 23,945. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 18,747, compared with 19,286 a week ago and 19,760 in the same week last year.
