DOC.HEAD: Tenneco Third-Quarter Profit Up a Modest 1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Tenneco Inc. said Thursday its profit rose a modest 1 percent in the third quarter, and predicted lower fourth-quarter earnings than last year. The energy, equipment and chemical company cited uncertainty in the economy and in the industries it serves in reporting earnings of $91 million, or 70 cents per share. That compares with $90 million or 68 cents per share for the year-ago quarter. Revenues in the quarter ended Sept. 30 were $3.4 billion, compared with $3.2 billion for the year-ago period. ``The uncertain business environment overall, and deterioration in some of the industries in which we do business, has begun to impact our financial performance and is likely to continue impacting our businesses during the balance of 1990,'' said James L. Ketelsen, company chairman and chief executive officer. Farm and construction equipment and chemical businesses of Tenneco were hurt most in the third quarter, he said. ``As a result, it now appears that our earnings in the fourth quarter will not match the strong earnings we posted in the fourth quarter of 1989,'' said Ketelsen. The company reported higher operating income at the Newport News Shipbuilding facility. Income totaled $49 million, compared with $37 million in the period last year, as a result of increased activity and higher margins in naval shipbuilding, Tenneco said. In the first nine months, the company said it earned $431 million or $3.34 per common share, compared with $379 million, or $2.88 per share, for the same period last year. Revenues came to $10.6 billion vs. $10.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip on Slack Demand, Harvest Pressure
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed modestly lower Thursday in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand and good harvesting conditions. Speculation that the Soviet Union might soon buy more U.S. corn cooled amid reports from Moscow indicating the Soviets might not make any more such purchases without U.S. credit. The Soviets are required to buy 650,000 metric tons of U.S. corn by the end of the year to fulfill a 1 million ton agreement. But analysts said it now appears the Soviets may not honor the pact. ``I wouldn't bet the rent on it,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Dry weather in the Midwest permitted the corn and soybean harvest to advance, and similar conditions were ideal for winter wheat planting in the central and southern Plains states, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.63} a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents lower with Deceber at $2.30{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.23{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 5} cents lower with November at $6.05 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck's Demise Turns Into A Dramatic Corporate Saga
DOC.TEXT: The rise and fall of Polly Peck International PLC, the conglomerate that owns Del Monte fruit and Sansui stereos, marks one of the most traumatic corporate demises in British history. After five tense weeks, and in a desperate effort to survive, a high-flying company of the 1980s turned to the courts Thursday and obtained help in sorting out debts exceeding 1 billion pounds, or $1.96 billion. Polly Peck's Turkish-Cypriot chairman and chief executive officer, Asil Nadir, insisted to the Financial Times that his company was sound. He told the newspaper he was a victim of a Greek-inspired political conspiracy and of bungling by British investigators. Nadir did not return a phone call from The Associated Press Thursday. The High Court on Thursday afternoon granted Polly Peck's request that it appoint court administrators, and assigned three accountants. Court administration allows for the orderly repayment of debt either through existing operations or through the full or partial liquidation of a company's assets. It is akin to the bankruptcy laws of the United States. The High Court dismissed a rival petition filed earlier in the week by a creditor, the National Bank of Canada, seeking immediate liquidation of Polly Peck. Justice Sir Robert Andrew Morritt said granting the administration order reduced uncertainty and offered the best chance for creditors to be repaid in full and others to benefit. When Polly Peck's directors announced late Wednesday they had decided on this course of action, they said it would ensure the company's survival. The decision followed weeks of wrangling over financing with increasingly nervous creditors, and came after Nadir failed to drum up the money he had promised them. The drama began when Polly Peck suspended trading in its shares on London's Stock Exchange on Sept. 20 after the price tumbled 55 percent in a matter of hours. Creditors pressed for answers because Nadir had given banks Polly Peck shares as collateral for loans. The stock-price dive was prompted by news that the Serious Fraud Office had raided the offices of South Audley Management Ltd., a company linked to a Nadir family trust. Nadir, 47, has been plagued in the British press by allegations of links to a reputed Polly Peck stock fraud scheme. The company and Nadir, who was questioned by the fraud office on the day of the share collapse, have denied wrongdoing. Polly Peck's stock had fallen sharply since August when Nadir, who then owned about 28 percent of the company, said he wanted to take it private, then abandoned the plan after five days. The exchange criticized him for hastiness. Nadir, who since has reduced his stake to about 24 percent, remains the largest shareholder in the conglomerate he built up over more than two decades. The son of a wealthy Cypriot, Nadir came to Britain in the 1960s and set up his own clothing business. Nadir, an ally of Turkish President Turgut Ozal, also developed fruit distribution, electronics, tourism and publishing businesses in Turkey and in the area of Cyprus which Turkey wrested from Greece in 1974. In 1980, Nadir took control of an ailing British textile company called Polly Peck and used it as his stock market vehicle for expansion. It bought the Del Monte fruit operation from RJR Nabisco Inc. for $875 million last year and Sansui Electric Co. for $135 million in December. The company, which employs 17,000 people, was highly profitable over the years, with Polly Peck's after-tax profit rising 16 percent to $268 million on revenue of $2.27 billion in 1989. Profit more than doubled the first six months of this year. Polly Peck's stock was one of the best performers of the 1980s, which helped make Nadir one of Britain's richest individuals with a personal fortune at more than $400 million. But the staid British business world continued to consider Nadir something of a flamboyant outsider. As the saga now stands, much of Nadir's wealth has vanished. Polly Peck's 23,000 shareholders have no idea how much their stock is worth.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Electronics Giant Announces Severe Cost-Cutting, Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Philips, the Dutch electronics manufacturing giant, said Thursday it will cut nearly 16 percent of its worldwide staff and eliminate stock dividends because of heavy losses and stiff competition. The company, which makes items ranging from light bulbs to televisions under a range of brands, said it lost nearly $1.3 billion in the third quarter of the year and has become too fat, bureaucratic and complacent. ``We have to look at our present performance compared to that of our current competition, not compared to our past performance,'' Philips Chairman Jan D. Timmer told a news conference. ``Philips' sales per employee are poor compared to the competition. We just aren't productive enough,'' he said. ``We need more entrepreneurial activity.'' The company will trim up to 45,000 of its 285,700 workers by the end of next year. Timmer said that will help Philips survive against increasingly aggressive rivals, primarily Japanese electronics makers. It was not immediately clear how many of the company's approximately 50,000 U.S. workers would be affected, but most of the job cuts were expected to be in Europe. The reductions are an addition to a cut of 10,000 jobs that is already occurring at the world's sixth largest electronics company. In another sign of austerity that was bound to anger Philips stockholders, Timmer also said the company would not pay8a dividend. ``It's exceptional for a company that has always cherished a stable dividend policy not to pay a dividend. But under the present conditions it is not justified,'' he said. The company paid a dividend of about $3 a share in 1989. The dividend cut caused Philips stock to drop because of selling by international investment funds barred from holding stock that don't pay dividends. Philips' stock closed down 35 cents at $11.95 a share Thursday on the Amsterdam stock exchange. Philips's third-quarter lost compared to a profit of $134 million in the same period last year, Timmer said. North American Philips Corporation, the U.S.-based subsidiary, manufactures lights, appliances, audio and video products and medical equipment under brand names that include Philips, Magnovox, Norelco, Philco and Sylvania. A spokesman for North American Philips, Albert Ruttner, said it was premature to say how many U.S. workers would be affected by the cutback. Timmer did not specify in which of the 45 nations where Philips has employees the job losses would occur, but observers believed most of the cuts would be in Europe. ``Announcements will be made by some of the managers in the countries concerned. We have left it up to them,'' Timmer said. Trouble for the company, formally called N.V. Phiiips Gloeilampenfabrieken, began in the spring when shareholders criticized former chairman C.J. van der Klugt for being too optimistic about first-quarter results. Timmer, who has a reputation for ruthless cost-cutting, took over from Van der Klugt in May after successfully pulling Philips' Consumer Electronics division out of the red. The earlier cut of 10,000 jobs hit hardest at Philip's computer division, where 4,000 jobs were eliminated.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Takes Big Jump on Troop Movements, War Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up more than $3 per barrel in the futures market Thursday on a combination of news and rumors that all pointed to war in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude rose $3.17 to $34.25 a barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was crude's third-biggest one-day jump in the Mideast crisis, after rises of $3.56 per barrel on Aug. 6 and $3.37 per barrel on Oct. 3. Later contract months all rose $2 per barrel, the daily trading limit imposed by the exchange, as oil regained more of the ground it had lost in a recent slide accentuated by a record one-day fall of $5.41 a barrel on Monday. ``Once again, the market is worried about confrontation,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The recent declines had come as traders bet on the possibility of a peaceful resolution to the crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Crude moved up in the morning as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said as many as 100,000 more U.S. troops could be sent to the Gulf and CIA Director William Webster said the Middle East will never be secure while Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is able to threaten neighbors. After oil rose about $2 per barrel Thursday on those comments, as well as a Saudi intelligence report indicating Iraq might have as many as 500,000 troops in Kuwait, crude was propelled even higher by wild rumors that swept the exchange. Traders first responded to a rumor that President Bush had given the Iraqis two weeks to vacate Kuwait. A rally late in the day was sparked by another rumor that U.S. troops had moved into Kuwait. ``That rumor circled on the pit, and we rallied for new highs,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. The rumor was eventually denied by the Pentagon. As oil rose, so did futures for refined petroleum products. Unleaded gasoline rose 8.21 cents to 93.60 cents per gallon on November contracts. Later contract months all rose by their limit of 4 cents a gallon. Home heating oil rose 6.55 cents to 91.67 cents per gallon on November contracts. All later contracts were up by the limit of 4 cents a gallon. Natural gas was up .6 cent to $2.446 per 1,000 cubic feet on December contracts. Most later contracts were trading lower.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rebounds; Gold Also Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded on world currency markets Thursday to recoup the steep losses posted in the previous session. Gold prices also advanced. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.80 a troy ounce, up $2.30 from Wednesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted gold at $376.25, up $3.50 an ounce. U.S. traders were encouraged that the dollar did not lose further ground in overseas trading after the currency fell on Wednesday. As the session unfolded, a flurry of rumors swept the market about U.S. military intentions in the Persian Gulf. Unconfirmed reports that the United States had entered Kuwait and that President Bush had given Iraq an ultimatum encouraged investors to seek a safe haven in the dollar. Traditionally the dollar is viewed as the currency of choice in times of turmoil. ``It was a stop-and-go market,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office here. ``There were constant rumors.'' The dollar was also supported by an agreement on the budget, which is being fine-tuned before being put to Congress for approval. ``The market is saying that it has a little more faith in the whole process, in the validity of the budget,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at Banco di Sicilia. Lawmakers' lengthy inability to agree on a deficit-reduction package has weighed heavily on the financial markets in recent weeks and has diminished investor confidence. A rise in oil prices also helped support the U.S. currency and gave it a particularly strong boost against the Japanese yen. Because Japan imports virtually all of its oil, it is particularly vulnerable when energy prices move higher. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.15 Japanese yen from 128.38 yen at Wednesday's close. But later in London, it rose to 127.35 yen, and in New York, the dollar advanced further to settle at 128.25 yen, from 126.49 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9545 from $1.9550 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9505 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9590. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5185 German marks, up from 1.5067; 1.2845 Swiss francs, up from 1.2695; 5.0820 French francs, up from 5.0435; 1,136.50 Italian lire, up from 1,128.25, and 1.1657 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1683. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5130 German marks, up from 1.5075; 1.2765 Swiss francs, up from 1.2690; 5.0645 French francs, up from 5.0470; 1.7050 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6990; 1,132.75 Italian lire, up from 1,128.75, and 1.1676 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1685. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $376.25 a troy ounce, up from $371.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $374.80 an ounce, up from $371.10 late Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.16 to close at $373.96 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.204 a troy ounce, down from $4.223 on Wednesday. In London, the metal was unchanged for the third consecutive day at $4.24 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: MNC To Sell $1 Billion Credit Card Operation
DOC.TEXT: MNC Financial placed its profitable $1 billion credit card operation on the market Thursday in an attempt to shore up its faltering finances. The move came as MNC, the parent company of Maryland National Bank, reported a third-quarter loss of $173 million, or $2.05 a share, after setting aside $350 million for possible credit losses. The $350 million loan loss provision increases the reserve for credit losses to $791 million or 94 percent coverage of total non-performing loans. MNC reported earnings of $68.8 million, or $1.13 per share, during the 1989 third quarter. The company and its banking subsidiaries also have entered into written agreements with the Federal Reserve Board and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, giving the regulators broad powers in the company's operations. Analysts said the financial conglomerate is preparing for the worst and taking steps to strengthen its capital positions. MNC is selling one of its best divisions ``so the company survives no matter how bad things get,'' said David S. Penn, a bank analyst for Legg Mason Wood Walker. He estimated the bank would be able to get between $1.2 billion and $1.8 billion for the credit card operation. MNC said its total non-performing loans increased 40 percent from $602 million on June 30 to $844 million on Sept. 30. Of that total, $450 million of the non-performing loans are related to commercial real estate. The third-quarter results increased MNC's nine-month loss to $241.9 million, or $2.91 per share, compared with profits of $192.9 million, or $2.24 per share, for the same period a year ago. With assets of $27 billion, MNC is the United States' 25th largest bank in the country. It owns Maryland National Bank and American Security Bank in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Falls
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended Oct. 15, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,323.6 billion from $3,325.2 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,090.4 billion from $4,092.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $819.5 billion from $822.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,307.3 billion, a 3.7 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,087.4 billion, up 1.9 percent, while M1 rose 5.1 percent to an average of $817.9 billion. In other reports: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $345 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $376 million the previous week. - The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.9 billion in the two-week period ended Oct. 3, up from $317.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market pulled back Thursday, faced with revived upward pressure on oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 7 points in the early going, was down 20.05 at 2,484.16 by the close. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 624 up, 851 down and 487 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 141.46 million shares, against 149.29 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 174.26 million shares. The price of crude oil for December delivery climbed more than $3 a barrel, to more than $34 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said that was enough to squelch a tentative early rally that was credited to hopes for a resolution of the budget impasse in Washington. A plan put forward overnight by some members of Congress raised hopes that agreement might soon be reached on a government budget, relieving an uncertainty that has been hanging over the markets for the past month. Analysts agree that the Federal Reserve can't be expected to consider any move to relax its credit policy until the budget situation is resolved. Losers among the blue chips included Exxon, down } at 47}; International Business Machines, down { at 108[; Philip Morris, down } at 47{; Ford Motor, down \ at 31}, and General Electric, down | at 51\. MCA climbed 7 to 57. The stock plunged 8~ points Wednesday before Matsushita Electric denied reports that merger talks between the two companies had run into trouble. Citicorp led the active list, down \ at 11| on volume of nearly 6 million shares. In recent days the bank holding company has had to counter wariness among investors by sharply increasing the dividend rate it pays on a type of preferred stock. Among other prominent bank stocks, Manufacturers Hanover dropped 1{ to 20; Chase Manhattan \ to 11\; J.P. Morgan \ to 36|, and BankAmerica \ to 19~. Quantum Chemical gained 2[ to 11{. The company reported a loss of $1.4 million in the third quarter, compared to a $21.4 million loss in the corresponding period last year. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $17.36 billion, or 0.60 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.09 to 169.51. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.77 to 364.84, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.43 at 310.17. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.24 to 339.74. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 292.78, up .09.

DOC.HEAD: Fell $673.1 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds fell $673.1 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline to $414.44 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $3.76 billion increase in fund assets the previous week when the total hit a record $415.11 billion. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group said that in the latest week, assets of 255 general purpose funds fell $478.3 million to $416.30 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds dropped $205.3 million to $165.20 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose $10.5 million to $102.94 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.45 percent from 7.44 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged from a week earlier at 7.46 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 46 days, up from 45 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.03 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.00 percent from 4.99 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.66 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.67 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.79 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.80 percent; 7.90 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 8.05 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.06 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Hiring Financial Adviser
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to clarify that Chartwell share is of voting stock; SUBS 7th graf to UPDATE stock price; INSERTS one graf after the 7th graf with sale of Avon bloc; picks up 8th graf, On Wednesday ...
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. said Thursday it has hired an investment firm to advise the cosmetics company on ways to increase the value of its stock for shareholders. Avon retained James D. Wolfensohn Inc. to explore a number of options, including special dividends, regular dividend increases and a recapitalization, said James Cox, an Avon spokesman. The company has been under pressure to increase the value of its stock from Chartwell Associates, the limited partnership that has approximately a 20 percent share of Avon's voting stock. Earlier this month, two Chartwell representatives quit a special committee of the Avon board, charging that the panel appeared unwilling to meet its goal of finding ways to increase the company's value. Avon said then the committee would continue its work despite the resignations. The firm's decision to hire Wolfensohn appeared to be part of that plan. Formation of the panel was part of a truce worked out in the spring under which Chartwell agreed not to wage a threatened proxy fight against Avon. Chartwell's members include John P. Rochon, vice chairman of the makeup marketing company Mary Kay; the Fisher brothers of New York; and the Getty Family Trust. Avon stock rose 37{ cents to $25.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday. A 1-million-share bloc of Avon stock was sold Thursday morning. The identity of the seller was not immediately known. On Wednesday, Avon announced its third-quarter earnings rose 29 percent from a year earlier. The company said it earned $44.6 million, or 63 cents a share, compared to $34.6 million, 46 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 5.9 percent to $830.8 million from $785.1 million in the same quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Paint Picture of Dixon as High Roller
DOC.TEXT: Donald Ray Dixon used Vernon Savings Association funds for prostitutes, beach houses, a yacht and other expensive entertainment while watching the institution fail, prosecutors said Thursday in his fraud trial. Dixon's federal trial, one of the most prominent prosecutions in the nationwide cleanup of the savings & loan crisis, began with the government portraying Vernon's former owner as a highflying Texan who had pleasure on his mind more often than supervising his S&L's affairs. ``In these instances, Vernon paid for the toys of Mr. Dixon. The bottom line is Don Dixon didn't pay for these toys,'' said Robert E. Hauberg, a U.S. Justice Department attorney. He said Dixon used the failed thrift's funds to pay for beach houses near San Diego, a yacht anchored in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and two hunting trips to Kansas. But Dixon's attorney, William M. Ravkind, said investigators have pressured witnesses into accusing Dixon of masterminding a conspiracy. ``The government is saying that Don Dixon engaged in a scheme to defraud the federal government. But this conspiracy does not include Mr. Dixon,'' Ravkind said. Ravkind said he will show that Dixon didn't profit from Vernon's failure. Dixon invested $13 million into the thrift, but was left with a $5 million dollar personal debt, Ravkind said. The 38-count indictment also accuses Dixon of conspiring with other Vernon officials to give money to several politicians, including former House Speaker Jim Wright. Hauberg likened Dixon's alleged freewheeling and dealing to a character from Larry McMurtry's Pulitzer-prize winning novel, ``Lonesome Dove.'' ``Like Gus from Lonesome Dove, the hero figure who drove down the cattle from Texas to Montana, when Gus turned and said, `We're gonna do it, but we're going to have to lie, cheat and steal to do it,''' Hauberg said. Hauberg said Dixon used Vernon funds to hire female escorts to attend parties at the Solana Beach house. The women, whom Hauberg called ``professionals,'' usually spent the night. Ravkind said Dixon, who plans to testify, claimed no sexual activity occurred at the Solana Beach house. ``We're not going to solve the S&L problem by locking up Don Dixon and throwing away the key,'' said Ravkind. The witnesses who could be called to testify against Dixon include former Vernon Chairman Woody Lemons, who was sentenced to 30 years in prison earlier this year. His sentence is the stiffest to date for an S&L officer. If convicted on all counts, Dixon could be sentenced to up to 190 years in prison and fined as much as $9.5 million. The Dallas thrift collapsed in 1987 and requires an estimated $1.3 billion government bailout financed by taxpayers. Another scheduled prosecution witness, convicted madam Karen Wilkening, is recovering from a bout of paralysis. Ms. Wilkening, who allegedly supplied Dixon with prostitutes for the parties, was hospitalized Monday suffering from the nerve disorder, Bell's palsy. She is serving a 44-month prison sentence in California and was later released to law enforcement authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Sale Boosts Appliance Maker's Earnings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS plant layoffs in two new grafs after 6th graf, Whirlpool Chairman. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. said Thursday its third-quarter profits advanced nearly 28 percent, but the gain was the result of the sale of a Kentucky plant. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the huge appliance maker said net income totaled $60 million, or 86 cents a share, up from $47 million, or 68 cents a share a year ago. Without the sale of the Danville, Ky., vacuum cleaner plant, profits would have plummeted 21 percent to $37 million, the company said. The plant is now part of a joint venture between Whirlpool and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Revenue during the quarter grew 11 percent to $1.66 billion, from $1.5 billion a year earlier. For the first nine months of the year, Whirlpool reported net income of $126 million, or $1.82 a share, down 12 percent from $138 million, or $1.99 a share in the 1989 period.. Revenue totaled $5 billion, up 15 percent from $4.72 billion. Whirlpool Chairman and Chief Executive David R. Whitwam blamed the decline in profits on the weakening North American economy, which has softened the demand for appliances. He expects industrywide U.S. shipments of appliances to be down about 8 percent for the year. In a separate development Thursday, Whirlpool's dishwasher plant in Mount Sterling, Ky., packed up its last machine shortly past noon and laid off 610 workers, the victims of slow sales in the appliance business. Whirlpool had announced in February it would close the plant and shift its operations to Findlay, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Breakaway Group of Soviet Miners Forms Independent Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with breakaway group founding independent union, details. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A goup of workers from the Soviet Union's richest coal mines defiantly formed an independent union Thursday night, breaking with a larger miners' congress and the wishes of Soviet officials. The more than 130 miners angrily denounced the protracted debates that have occupied the 900 delegates at a congress that claims to represent 2 million workers. ``It's too much to come here for four days and adopt only one resolution,'' said Vyacheslav Golikov, leader of the Kuzbass Council of Workers' Committees, which called the breakaway meeting. Organizers of the formal congress, the second since a series of miners' strikes last year, said they still hoped to form an independent union before concluding Friday. The break came the same day that Soviet Coal Minister Mikhail I. Shchadov warned restive miners that half the nation's shafts could close without state subsidies. Shchadov made a pitch for the workers' loyalties and urged patience while Moscow drafts a new plan to improve their lives. ``When you adopt your decision, remember that it is crucial for us to be together, not divided,'' Shchadov said. Shchadov told the disgruntled miners that they should have a wage increase and a degree of control over their own mines, but pointedly reminded them that the state is helping keep money-losing mines operating. An independent miners' union could become a potent political and economic force in the Soviet Union with enormous influence over the country's energy supply. The breakaway group - made up of representatives of mines in western Siberia, the Kazakh republic, and the Ukraine - marched to a hall across the street from the congress for its meeting. It voted to make their new union a confederation of smaller workers' committees, most of which were formed during the strikes that threatened to leave much of the Soviet Union without fuel in 1989. ``A confederation is for our future!'' one miner shouted, as workers tumbled over each other for a chance to speak at the only microphone. A confederation would allow scores of smaller unions to maintain their own independence within an umbrella organization. The formation of a breakaway confederation comes one day after the government-sponsored National Congress of Trade Unions voted in Moscow to disband after 70 years and reconstitute itself as a voluntary association of unions. A spokesman for the breakaway miners said they had no interest in belonging to a reorganized government trade union. ``The old union called itself new, but it's really the same one because its structure is the same,'' said Golikov, who has been dubbed the Lech Walesa of the Soviet Union for his effort to create an opposition political movement of workers. The Kuzbass miners, among the most radical at the congress, drew up a draft platform for the new confederation that set out a loose structure of grass-roots organizations, legislative bodies and an executive committee. The rich Kuzbass region has 60 mines, most near the town of Kuznetsk in western Siberia. Miners are uncertain about how far they could part from the government in forming an independent confederation of miners' unions. They said they would defer a possible new strike pending resolution of their outstanding complaints by the legislature of the Russian republic, now in session in Moscow. The 1989 miners' strikes began to protest working and living conditions, but quickly escalated to include demands for regional economic autonomy for the main mining regions. The government then persuaded the miners to return to work by promising to meet most of their demands. But most of the promises remain unfulfilled, an issue that hasspurred new strikes. Shchadov said the government hopes to pour up to $10.1 billion into the mining regions next year to build schools, homes and hospitals and plans to convert at least one weapons plant into a factory for making new mining equipment, he said. ``Our technology is backward,'' he said, receiving one of two rounds of applause during his two-hour speech. The 900 delegates in the Donetsk conference hall were generally receptive and good humored during Shchadov's appearance. Shchadov was shouted down by miners in July 1989, when they were engaged in a crippling strike.

DOC.BYLINE: Oil Rally Fuels Gold's Gains; Platinum Plunges ^By DAVID DISHNEAU
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices continued to climb Thursday as the resurgent oil market fanned inflation fears. But platinum prices dropped sharply, reflecting declining Japanese investor interest and worldwide economic jitters. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures retreated, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $2.30 to $2.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery at $375.80 a troy ounce. The increase marked gold's sixth daily advance in the last seven sessions following a plunge to a three-month low of $360 on Oct. 16. Silver futures settled 1.9 cents to 2 cents lower with the spot price at $4.204 a troy ounce in lackluster trading on the Commodity Exchange. Platinum was $6.60 to $8 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the spot price at $415.80 a troy ounce. Analysts said demand for gold has increased as a result of lower prices for the metal and higher prices this week for crude oil, which has bounced back sharply amid escalating Middle East war rhetoric. On Thursday, for example, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the United States conceivably could send another 100,000 troops to Saudi Arabia, which fed rumors of a possible U.S. attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait. ``The war drums were beating today,'' said William O'Neill, a precious metals expert with Merrill Lynch. Higher oil prices could portend higher inflation, which typically spurs investor demand for gold. Higher oil prices also could tip industrialized nations into recession and reduce industrial demand for platinum, which is widely used in automobile pollution-control systems. James Steel, an oil and metals analyst with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc., said platinum also was pressured by lower Japanese stock prices. The Japanese value platinum highly as an investment and jewelry metal. In petroleum trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil settled $2 to $3.17 higher with December at $34.25 a barrel; heating oil was 4 cents to 6.55 cents higher with November at 91.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4 cents to 8.21 cents higher with November at 93.60 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand and harvest pressure. Speculation about possible Soviet purchases of U.S. corn cooled amid reports from Moscow indicating the Soviets might not make any more such purchases without U.S. credit. The Soviets are required to buy 650,000 metric tons of U.S. corn by the end of the year to fulfill a 1 million ton agreement but analysts said it now appears the Soviets may not honor the pact. Wheat settled 1 cent to 2} cents lower with December at $2.63} a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.30{ a bushel; oats were { cent to } cent lower with December at $1.23} a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 5\ cents lower with November at $6.05{ a bushel. Cattle futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the third straight day, while pork futures ended mixed as the bearish impact of lower hog prices was offset by indications of slower hog marketings. Live cattle settled unchanged to .55 cent higher with December at 77.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent to .73 cent higher with November at 87.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .35 cent higher with December at 53.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.15 cents to 2 cents lower with February at 64.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of Boston Posts $255 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston posted a $255 million loss or $3.53 per share in the third quarter, the victim of the deteriorating Northeast economy and a weak real estate market, bank officials said Thursday. For the same quarter last year, Bank of Boston reported a $125 million loss, or $1.82 per share. Bank of Boston last month had predicted a heavy loss of at least $200 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30. ``That's within the range we forecast a month or so ago,'' bank spokesman Wayne J. Taylor said of the loss announced Thursday. ``We telegraphed this more than a month ago. It should not come as a surprise.'' The bank said it set aside $200 million for bad loans during the third quarter, bringing the total loan loss provision for 1990 so far to $450 million. That compares with a $370 million provision for 1989's third quarter and $442 million overall last year. Bank officials said most of the bad loans were for real estate. Bank of Boston, New England's largest bank, had shown signs of recovery earlier this year. After posting huge losses last year, it turned a slight profit in this year's second quarter, and officials said the volume of its bad loans decreased. But last month, the bank cut its dividend from 31 cents per share to 10 cents per share, as have a number of banks. For the nine-month period, Bank of Boston reported a loss of $208 million, or $3.01 per share, compared to earnings of $62 million, or 72 cents per share, for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Consumer Taxes for All, Income Taxes for Wealthiest
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 5: ``The bill,'' to reflect no final agreement on any provision. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumers would pay more for gasoline, cigarettes and beer under the deficit-reduction plan nearing completion in Congress. But the wealthiest Americans would face income-tax increases averaging 6.3 percent as well. As many as 4 million slightly less well-to-do couples and individuals - including most members of Congress - could get a tax cut because the top rate on their earnings, now 33 percent, would drop to 31 percent. They also would get the bill's only tax break for capital gains. It is nothing like President Bush's proposed deep cut in taxes on capital gains, which are profits from investments. But it would prevent anyone from paying a capital-gains rate higher than 28 percent. The 600,000 richest taxpayers would see their top tax rate rise from 28 percent to 31 percent. Even those with incomes just slightly above the $100,000 mark could lose a portion of their itemized deductions and part of the tax saving arising from their personal exemptions. The bill, whose provisions were still being negotiated and subject to change, would raise taxes by about $150 billion over the next five years. But for most people below $50,000 in income, the only increase would be in consumer taxes. Those with incomes under $20,000 would, on average, get a tax cut because of a higher earned-income credit, which helps poor working families with children. Most with incomes between $20,000 and $200,000 would face tax increases in the neighborhood of 2 percent although the bite on those between $50,000 and $75,000 would be slightly less - 1.5 percent. The most striking difference between this bill and those of the last decade is the disproportionately larger burden the new plan would impose on those with higher incomes. The Joint Committee on Taxation estimated the share of federal taxes paid by people with incomes over $200,000 would rise from 15.4 percent to 16.1 percent. The bill would raise the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax and the 15-cent diesel tax by 5 cents each. The tax on cigarettes, now 16 cents a pack, would rise to 20 cents on Jan. 1 and to 24 cents two years later. Taxes on snuff, cigars and other tobacco would go up by 25 percent in each of those years. The levy on a six-pack of beer, now 16 cents, would double. Negotiators are deciding whether to raise the tax on liquor, now $12.50 for a gallon of 100-proof, to $13.70 or $14. Taxes on wines, which vary according to alcohol content, also will go up; the 3-cent levy on a fifth of table wine would rise to 21 or 25 cents. Fliers would pay $6 more on an average 300-mile roundtrip ticket. The 8 percent tax would rise to 10 percent. A new tax would take 10 percent of the price of certain expensive ``luxuries'' - cars, boats, planes, jewels and furs. For example the tax would apply only to that portion of the price of cars exceeding $30,000 and jewelry over $5,000. The 1.45 percent tax that finances basic Medicare coverage would cost higher-income workers and their employers more. It now applies only to the first $51,300 earned each year; the bill would raise it to $125,000 or $130,000. A worker earning $85,000 a year, for example, would pay $1,233, or $489 more than present law. A $50,000 earner would pay no more. The tax is matched by the employer. The bill would limit the total of certain itemized deductions that a person with income over $100,000 or a couple over $150,000 may write off. But the 3 percent limitation would apply only against income above those levels. For each $10,000 of income above the target, the proposal would reduce allowable deductions by $300. Thus, a couple with $175,000 income and itemized deductions of $35,000 would be allowed to write off only $34,250. This has the effect of raising the 31 percent top tax rate for these people to 32 percent. The bill also would gradually take back from the well-to-do the tax saving realized from personal exemptions. This would result in larger high-income families paying a higher marginal tax rate than those with fewer children - a notion under attack as a tax on children. For 1990, a taxpayer is allowed a $2,050 exemption for himself and another for each dependent. At the 31 percent top tax rate set by the bill, that would mean a tax saving of $636 per exemption. Single people would begin losing part of that $636 tax saving once their taxable income - income after subtracting deductions and exemptions - passes $100,000. The benefit would be lost totally when income hits $225,000. For couples who file jointly and have no children, the benefit would be phased out between $150,000 and $275,000 of income. The effect of the phaseout would be to boost the top tax rate on these taxpayers by one-half of a percentage point. Thus, the limit on deductions and the exemption phaseout would raise the top rate to 32.5 percent for a single person and 33 percent for a couple. A couple with two children could have a top rate of 34 percent on part of their earnings; a couple with six children could pay 36 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Options Exchange Cleared To Trade Stocks
DOC.TEXT: CHICAGO (AP) The Chicago Board Options Exchange said Thursday it has been cleared by federal regulators to trade stocks and other securities instruments in addition to options. The approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission effectively makes the Options Exchange the nations' newest stock exchange. But exchange officials said they expect their first new products to be instruments that combine characteristics of stocks with those of debt instruments and certain futures and options contracts. ``There is very strong interest in some of these products,'' said CBOE Chairman Duke Chapman. He said the exchange hoped to begin offering such products in mid-December.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn, GM's Hope of the Future, Goes on Sale
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s new Saturn cars officially went on sale Thursday, but amid all the hoopla at dealerships there was lingering worry about a souring economy. The last time a U.S. automaker introduced a new line of its own cars was 1957, just before the economy slipped into a recession. The car then was the Edsel. As it was 33 years ago with Edsel dealers, Saturn dealers aggressively promoted the cars on their first day of retail sale. On both sides of the country, dealers dueled for bragging rights on who sold the first Saturn. In his own version of time travel, Brad Boeckmann of Saturn of the Valley in Sepulveda, Calif., delivered a four-door Saturn at 9 o'clock PDT Wednesday. He reasoned that back East, Wednesday was turning into Thursday, the official launch date for the new line of GM cars. ``We figured at midnight our time, it would be 3 a.m. East Coast time,'' he said Thursday. `So we delivered ours at 9 o'clock'' during a big party for employees, Saturn officials, bankers and potential customers. The first car went to Andrew and Patricia Gibson of Saugus, Calif. They had no trade-in. Paul Lockey, owner of Saturn of Clearwater in Florida, honored Saturn's official launch according to East Coast time. ``We delivered one at one second after midnight,'' he said. ``The lady who bought it traded in an Oldsmobile.'' She's Betty Terry, 45, of Tampa. That type of trade, however, is what GM is hoping to avoid. Saturn officials have said they want people to buy Saturns instead of import cars, although they concede that a majority of first-year sales are likely to go to people who are GM customers anyway. Terry, a fifth-grade teacher's aide at Anderson Elementary School in Tampa, traded in a 1985 Oldsmobile Delta 88. ``Basically, I wanted a smaller car and I wanted something with better gas mileage,'' she said. Fuel economy has been rising on the list of priorities for new-car buyers recently, especially since gasoline prices began rocketing after the Aug. 2 Iraq invasion of Kuwait. Rising fuel prices are just part of the reason some economists are predicting that the U.S. economy is heading into a recession. Unemployment is up, consumer confidence down and inflation is rising. The economy in the mid-1950s was facing many of the same pressures, and the demise of Ford Motor Co.'s Edsel has been blamed partly on the economic downturn. But the relatively high price of the Edsel and its design, especially the horse-collar looking grille, shared a large part of the responsibility for the death of the car that has come to symbolize failure in America. There was no talk of failure among Saturn dealers Thursday. ``I think we've really got to screw up to make this fail,'' Boeckmann said. Twenty-nine Saturn dealerships were open in 10 states in the South and West for Thursday's kickoff. They received about half of their scheduled allocations because Saturn officials were especially strict in their quality control inspections at the company's Spring Hill, Tenn. assembly plant.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Air Fares to Increase
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines on Thursday joined three other carriers in raising air fares for the third time since the Persian Gulf crisis boosted the price of jet fuel. Delta said domestic fares would rise by 5.8 percent for tickets purchased on or after Oct. 31. It blamed a doubling of jet fuel prices for the increase. Northwest Airlines has also announced a 5.8 percent hike to start Oct. 31, while Continental and Eastern Airlines also said they would raise rates. Delta said its costs for jet fuel have risen 115 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and touched off a steady escalation in the price of crude oil and its byproducts. ``We take this action reluctantly, but previous fare hikes in response to rising fuel prices have fallen well short of levels necessary to offset these increased costs,'' Whit Hawkins, Delta's executive vice president for marketing and stations, said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Chairman Resigns As It Reports Loss, Plans For Job Cuts, Asset Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf to CORRECT to increase, sted decrease; PICKUP fourth graf, The most . . .
DOC.TEXT: Struggling Unisys Corp. said Thursday it may not return to profitability this quarter as originally expected as it announced the resignation of its chairman, plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs and stepped-up asset sales. The nation's third-largest computer company also announced that it lost $356.8 million in the third quarter, or $2.42 a share, compared with a loss of $648 million, or $4.25 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue totaled $2.4 billion, up from $2.35 billion in last year's third quarter. The most recent loss was increased by a charge against earnings of $181 million to pay for consolidations and the elimination of the jobs through attrition, a hiring freeze and possibly ``selected layoffs,'' said spokesman Mike Stugrin. The 1989 quarter included a $231 million restructuring charge. Unisys also said it was ``very possible'' it would report a loss in the current quarter. Unisys until recently predicted it would return to profitability this quarter, a belief shared by several industry analysts. Unisys' statement on the current quarter prompted one of the nation's two leading credit-rating agencies, Standard & Poor's Corp., to lower by one notch its rating of $4 billion in Unisys debt. A lower rating means Unisys may have to pay more to borrow money. W. Michael Blumenthal announced he would resign as chairman and a member of the Unisys board effective Nov. 1. Blumenthal, who engineered the 1986 merger of Burroughs Corp. and Sperry Corp. that formed Unisys, retired from Unisys as chief executive officer April 1, turning over the office to James A. Unruh. Unruh, who also is president, was elected chairman to replace Blumenthal. Blumenthal, the 64-year-old former U.S. Treasury secretary and Burroughs chairman, said he was resigning because of his obligations as limited partner in the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Co. Blumenthal is co-chairman of a new international group of Lazard, which will be based in Paris. Since last October, Unisys has cut more than 8,000 jobs, closed plants and refocused product lines inherited from its predecessor companies. The company, which employs about 78,000, said the new job cuts would be made by mid-1991 and ``will affect most operating units'' but will not result in reductions in the activities by its direct sales force, key research programs and customer support services. Unisys said it was looking into a broad range of asset sales to reduce debt, which mushroomed as Unisys borrowed to pay dividends when profits lagged in the 1980s. Unisys said it hired Lazard Freres and another investment bank, James Wolfensohn Inc., to explore the sales, but it did not disclose what assets might be involved. Unruh said in a statement that it would be ``difficult but not impossible'' for Unisys to achieve its goal of reducing its debt by $600 million to $800 million by year's end. Debt totaled $2.6 billion at the end of the third quarter. Unruh said the quarter's results ``reflect a weakening general business environment and the pronounced softness of demand in the worldwide computer industry.'' ``Order growth in the United States continues to be weak, and orders have slowed significantly in Europe in recent weeks, reflecting customer concern about general economic conditions and about the Middle East situation,'' he said. ``In these circumstances, it is very possible we could post a loss for the fourth quarter, instead of the gain we expected until very recently,'' he said. The restructuring launched in late 1989 wasn't sufficient to cope with the ``changing business environment,'' Unruh added. Despite the slump, Unisys said its Timeplex computer networking business, its defense unit and sales in Asia and the Pacific were doing well. It also said cash flow had increased significantly over last year. ``We remain confident of our course toward restoring the company to profitability and reducing its debt load,'' he said. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Unisys reported a net loss of $348.2 million, or $2.72 a share, compared with a loss of $673.3 million, or $4.75 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue totaled $7.18 billion, up from $7.13 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Accuse Dallas Man of Illegal Diversion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``In Dallas,'' attorney uncreachable, judge's order. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of a failed Dallas savings and loan was accused Thursday of illegally diverting $18 million to pay off delinquent loans as a way of postponing the $1 billion collapse of the once high-flying thrift. Jarrett E. Woods Jr., former owner of the failed Western Savings Association, was accused in a criminal indictment of diverting the funds to help pay off bad loans so that federal regulators wouldn't discover the S&L was insolvent. The 37-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in Dallas charges Woods with bank fraud, misapplication of bank funds, making false ledger entries and conspiracy. The charges, announced in Washington by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, carry a maximum sentence of 185 years in prison and fines totaling at least $8.2 milion or twice the loss proven by prosecutors. ``We have corralled one of the biggest savings and loan bandits in Texas,'' Thornburgh told reporters. ``The free-wheeling lifestyle and fraudulent management practices that led to Western's collapse helped set the trend for our national thrift crisis.'' In Dallas, Woods was expected to surrender to the FBI on Friday and be taken before a federal magistrate. His lawyer did not immediately return telephone calls. Woods' lawyers asked U.S. District Judge Robert B. Maloney for an order barring prosecutors from discussing the case. The judge refused, but ordered the announcement news conference to be held in Washington - something the Justice Department was doing anyway, said spokesman Doug Tillett. Western's failure in 1986 when it was taken over by federal regulators cost the taxpayers $1 billion, the Justice Depatment said. A civil suit filed earlier this week by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. seeks to collect $560 million from Woods. It accuses Woods of spending $7 million of depositors' money in the months before Western failed. The thrift, which Woods purchased in 1982 with $2 million in borrowed money, grew from $70 million in assets to $2 billion four years later, said U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins. Collins said the case ``can be fairly characterized as an example of a real estate developer, Jarrett Woods, buying up a sleepy little S&L, moving it to Dallas, pumping it full of high-cost brokered funds and and then lending the money out on high-risk loans.'' ``The indictment shows the great lengths that people will go to deceive regulators,'' Collins said. The indictment charges that Woods diverted $16 million from a $60 million loan for a Houston real estate deal to businessman James Reagin, a major borrower who was behind on loan payments to Western. Most of the money, plus $2.26 million that was diverted from the sale of Western property, was used to help Reagin pay off loans so that Western would not have to write them off as bad debts. At one point, Reagin was behind on loans worth $64 million, Collins said. ``Just the loans to James Reagin would have likely caused the failure of Western Savings Association,'' Collins said. Reagin, a Houston businessman who faces sentencing in connection with the failure of the Glen Ellyn Savings and Loan in Illinois, is cooperating with prosecutors in their investigation of Woods, officials said. While Woods is not accused of pocketing any of the funds diverted to Reagin, Collins said that as 100 percent owner of Western Woods was motivated by a desire to keep regulators from taking over the S&L. The indictment also charges that Woods arranged for a Western subsidiary to pay a $48,000 commission to a company that had not earned the money. The indictment alleges the money was actually used to pay off a gambling debt Woods owed.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Prices Blamed For Losses, Earnings Drops, in Airlines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT description of transactions; PICKUP 8th graf, For the . . .
DOC.TEXT: Blaming higher jet fuel costs and other factors, Delta Air Lines and USAir Group reported losses Thursday, while UAL said its earnings dropped 4 percent.

For the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30, Atlanta-based Delta reported a loss of $51.6 million, or $1.27 per share, on operating revenue of $2.22 billion. That compared with after-tax profit of $133.1 million, or $2.53 per share, on revenue of $2.17 billion in the same period last year. ``This is the first loss Delta has had in a September quarter since 1982,'' Thomas J. Roeck Jr., senior vice president and chief financial officer, said referring to the busy summer travel months. Roeck attributed the loss to the increase in jet fuel prices since the Iraqi invastion of Kuwait. The increase added $78.1 million to Delta's expenses. He also blamed softening demand and competition from Eastern, saying passenger revenue increased just 2 percent in the quarter. ``If these trends continue, the company expects to report a loss for the full calendar year,'' Roeck said. Delta spokesman Bill Berry said the company set aside $10 million to be tapped if any of its competitors go out of business. When an airline has to book a passenger on another carrier the fare difference goes into a pool that could be jeopardized by a bankruptcy. For the first nine months, Delta's after-tax profits totaled $53.8 million, or 85 cents per share, on operating revenue of $6.6 billion. That compared with earnings of $408.9 million, or $8.12 per share, on revenue of $6.5 billion for the same period last year.

Arlington, Va.-based USAir Group, parent of USAir, reported a third-quarter loss of $120.29 million, or $2.87 per share, on revenue of $1.64 billion. That compared with a loss of $77.68 million, or $1.86 per share, on revenue of $1.53 billion for the same period last year. The results included a one-time depreciation charge of $36 million for 24 Boeing 727-200 aircraft that are being phased out of service. The company also recorded a $14 million accrual in the quarter for merger-related costs. Edwin I. Colodny, USAir Group chairman and president, called the results disappointing and said an increase in jet fuel prices were partly to blame. Airline operations recorded a third-quarter loss of $111.11 million on revenue of $1.52 billion, compared with a 1989 third-quarter loss of $42.97 million on revenue of $1.44 billion. USAir's passenger traffic increased more than 6 percent, Colodny said.

United Airlines parent UAL Corp. said its third-quarter net income slipped 4 percent, reflecting a rise in jet fuel costs and a $30 million expense from the failed employee buyout bid. Those and other expenses were nearly offset by a $93 million gain from the sale of 12 aircraft during the quarter. UAL posted net income of $106.11 million, or $4.87 per share, for the three months ending Sept. 30, compared with $110.86 million, or $5.11 per share, for the same period a year ago. Third-quarter operating revenues rose 15 percent to $2.97 billion from $2.58 billion, UAL said from its headquarters in Elk Grove Village, Ill. The higher revenues were largely a function of United's continuing route-expansion program, which also was reflected in a nearly 12 percent increase in the number of miles flown on United Airlines by paying passengers during the quarter. United's aggressive expansion program accelerated earlier this week with an agreement to purchase trans-Atlantic routes from Pan Am Corp. for $400 million. United's arch-rival American Airlines Inc. moved Thursday to block the deal. For the first nine months of 1990, UAL had net income of $217.99 million, or $10.01 a share, on revenue of $8.23 billion, compared with net income of $317.36 million, or $14.66 a share, on revenue of $7.43 billion for the first nine months of 1989.
